headline: Hooray for Harvey-less Hollywood!
commentone:
We get a lot of reporting on predators and victims. but almost none on the enablers. The publicists and attorneys that cover everything over remain while the money men and their targets come and go. Hollywood's economy is based on rich guys getting suckered out of their cash for the promise of sex with young goddesses, and demi-gods. The agents, and the publicists preside over the game and take their cut.
The press is entirely in on the game, because they are bought for cheap with advertising dollars for their publications and access to celebrities.
It's easy for the press to make bucks outing the perps, but a lot harder to look in the mirror at its own collusion. When will the NY Times investigate its own responsibility for covering up the predatory game that was, and is, in plain sight to its reporters?

headline: Hugs, Smiles And a Pistol At the Ready
commentone: I have worked personally with Cpl. Revels when she took a vested interest in a particularly troubled student with who I had spent a great deal of time with a few years ago. She and I sat in an office on campus where she talked with the student at length about the choices she was making and the consequences that would come with those choices. The young lady (who was NOT a fan of authority, much less the police) was quite responsive to Cpl. Revels because she saw the sincerity in her eyes. The female was a junior and lacked a great deal to graduate. She was allowed to voice some concerns and be heard. Cpl. Revels encouraged her to set goals and made trips to check on her. I believe that conversation was a game changer. She graduated and is doing quite well. I am so grateful to know this lady. She exemplifies what we as parents hope to be in every school to protect our children.

headline: Lower the Voting Age to 16
commentone: Why not 12?
commenttwo:
And what are you going to do if the majority of people 16-21 vote that they want the same rights under the 2nd Amendment that everyone else has and want to buy the same guns 21+ year olds can buy... and the same beer and whiskey... and cigarettes... and...??

We need to have serious discussions about what age we think people should be trusted as adults and be consistent. Is it 16 when we let them drive? Is it 18 when we let them volunteer and potentially die in the military (or potentially require it under selective service and the draft), and when they can vote? Is it 19 when they can buy cigarettes in most states? Is it 21 when they can buy alcohol? Or is it 26 when we expect them to get their own health insurance? Should we give them the adult right to vote and determine our laws and punishments for those laws if we don't intend to charge them as adults under those laws? Because we are very inconsistent about when we say you are a grown up and can do grown up things. And if we don't trust them with most other grown up rights and responsibilities I'm not sure we should be lowering the age at which they get to vote themselves those privileges.

headline: Nakesha’s Demons
commentone: So sad when a vibrant life is destroyed by mental illness and friends are unable to help.Such a tragedy that should not have been.
commenttwo:
When a civil rights (patient rights) revolution came to the involuntary hospitalization process in the early 1970's, it meant that you could no longer be hospitalized against your well unless you had DONE something dangerous to your self or others. Sounds great, but it was actually inspired by money. State legislatures had figured out a way to drastically reduce their patient load in state hospitals. And made it sound upbeat. Libertarian! As an activist lawyer told me at the time (of a deeply psychotic patient about to be released): "he may be eating out of a garbage can tonight but he will be FREE!" [Actually, he was neither. He was in jail on a status offense for disturbing the peace-- which frequently happened as the plight of the chronically mentally ill became incarceration.]
How much freedom do you have when your mind has been hijacked by schizophrenia? Most homeless people are not just "down on their luck": they are substance dependent or chronically ill with a psychosis.
The social workers and mental health personnel know this all too well.

headline: Taxpayers, You’ve Been Scammed
commentone:
For those of you who have busy lives and have to be very selective about how to spend your finite hours in the day I'm going to save you some time. Copy down this comment and print it out and the next time you are going to spend time reading one of Prof. Krugman's columns, read the following instead:

"When the economy is doing bad central governments need to spend more... a lot more, and then raise taxes and inflation to pay for it later.
When the economy is doing good central governments need to tax more and spend more... well because there are people who need stuff and central governments need to give it to them.
Republicans are wrong. Don't listen to them. I am right because I am an Ivy League Economist who won a Nobel. Listen to me."

This is much shorter than his average column but says the same thing all of his do and will save you some much needed time.

I know it doesn't fit his genius theory, but I am a middle class business owner with 9 employees. As a self-employed owner I pay a lot in taxes. A lot. The 20% off the top reduction for sole-proprietorships will be real money for me to offset things like paying income and FICA tax on bank loan principal payments. This tax savings has already allowed me to increase my employees wages at twice the amount I would have without it and double the amount I will be able to put into retirement matching for them in 2018 forward. I'm sorry Prof. Ivy League. That's real money to my family and my workers.

headline: The Tet Offensive Was Not About Americans
commentone:
This is an overly charitable view of ARVN to say the least. He states ARVN suffered from cases of poor leadership and sometimes bested on the battlefield. Cases-how about the majority of ARVN suffered from poor leadership. See David Hackworth, John Vann, Col Corson head of CAPs was especially critical and stated ARVN was poorly trained and organized and its leadership was infected with nepotism, incompetence, and corruption. ARVN officers succeeded through family ties and political allegiances, not merit or competence. ARVN was known for looting in the countryside and it became an epidemic when ARVN invaded Cambodia in 1970. Many of the senior ARVN's wives engaged in corruption and ran bars, brothels and businesses that catered to the American military and civilian war machine including the wife of General Cao Van Vien who was chief of ARVN JCS. Investigators with the MSS, ARVN's counter-intel branch found officers in the border areas "enthusiastically engage in activities or support merchants who sell essential supplies to the communists. They even use manpower and facilities of their units in their personal activities in order to make more money."
In 1974 after 2 defeats Thieu replaced Gen. Dong in III Corp with Gen. Toan who had been fired 2 months earlier from II Corps command for massive corruption. He was given III Corps ( includes Saigon) because Thieu feared coup and needed absolute loyalty and so it went.

headline: U.S. Advances Military Plans for North Korea
commentone: The main reason why the Pentagon does not want war with North Korea is not because of its nuclear weapons (although they play the primary role in this confrontation), it is because of the conventional firepower, i.e. artillery and chemical weapons, they have pre-sighted at Seoul. The Seoul metropolitan population as of 2017 was 25.6 million, or the equivalent of the metropolitan populations of both New York City and Miami that same year. General Tilley is correct in his assessment claiming this conflict would be the most brutal war fought since WW2 due to the sheer size of the noncombatant population that lies less than 40 miles from the DMZ and has thousands of artillery pieces already aimed at them.

headline: When Elder Abuse Is Self-Inflicted
commentone:
there is a difference between self abuse and you own self preservation to live beyond an age limit without conflicts from others who can inflict despair and hardship on someone else because of age or condition. (authority control over)
i see elder abuse as someone called crazy and get pills shoved down their throat and locked up in long confinement to please relatives,doctors, lawyers,neighbors and on out of their hair for good with psych drugs -haldol or something else dangerous where they lose control of their own life and being self sufficient worked out.
commenttwo:
Kudos to the Mr. Kirsch's of the world, trying to salvage their clients despite periodic defeat.
The gentleman in distress is not, however, a victim of "self inflicted elder abuse"-- whatever that is supposed to be. He is a victim of alcoholism and his remarkable (temporary) improvement amply demonstrates how sobriety and abstinence can make a practicing alcoholic look like a million bucks.
There is a real problem mixing these ideas up-- elder abuse does exist and is perfidious-- but the term refers to harm from an outside party. Unfortunately, alcohol dependence is an all too commonly encountered problem in the elderly and we need to recognize it when we see it.

headline: Go Ahead, Millennials, Destroy Us
commentone:
I seem to recall that (a segment of) Baby Boomers also had revolutionary visions of social change to address the ills of society. Look around you to see how perfectly that worked out.

The point is that good intentions are easy to have in youth; achieving real positive social impact over a lifetime is much harder. It's hard to know the full societal impact of any given action or political position, much less where any social or political movement will end up down the road.

So enjoy your time here Mr. Kreider, and don't be in such a hurry to be destroyed. The youth are giving us their dawning social consciousness and not-yet-exhausted desire to right wrongs, as youth has done eternally. That's essential, but doesn't guarantee that their solutions will work out any better than ours. Rather, time has not yet proven them to be the fools the rest of us know ourselves to be.

commenttwo: I loved a man several decades ago who had become distant from family and friends. I spent a year with him, and watched paranoia and deterioration set in. I got psychiatric help for him but he declined, went off to sea to work on a merchant marine ship, and hung himself in the engine room off the coast of Alaska. headline: Wily Trump Aide Nurtures Her Access and Influence
commentone:
There were "alternative facts" to the question of the Inauguration crowd size as Ms. Conway averred. As you consider them bear in mind this question too -- Why on earth was the media even reporting that the Obama crowd size was larger than Trump's?

What's a "larger" crowd size: 4000 dwellers of DC hopping on the Metro for a short ride to the Mall to watch the Obama Inauguration? Or a group of 40 renting a bus together and coming overnight from Harlan County, Kentucky, to see Trump's?

400 lifetime civil servants at the EPA crossing the street to support the person who promised to make the oceans recede and the planet heal? Or a family of four driving from Crowder, Oklahoma, to support the person who has stated as an earlier priority stopping the opioid crisis?

Add them up and which makes a "larger" crowd?

But, first, why was the question even asked? Why did the media even make the comparison?

A presidential inauguration is for the WHOLE country. It's a national celebration, a unifying celebration, a celebration of America and our Constitution. That's as it should be and as it had been heretofore.

Yet the media thought it was news to conjure up the comparison of Trump's crowd size with Obama's. Why?

The purpose was divisive, with deepest intention. It was malicious and mean.

There, friends, are your "alternative facts"!

headline: Xi’s Power Grab in China Rattles Europe and Its Hope for an Ally in the Trump Era
commentone:
I have been doing business in China since 1991 and just returned from a trip there. I took three train rides this visit. None of them traveled at less than 200 mph. In the United States, we can‚Äö√Ñ√¥t even build a train. Instead we spend our money on tax cuts and weapons. We must regard China as an enemy simply because it justifies our choices.
By and large, Chinese people have a far greater confidence and trust in their government than Americans do. Based on their government‚Äö√Ñ√¥s performance in lifting them out of poverty and modernizing the country, that confidence is entirely justified. While democracy is intriguing, most Chinese regard it as a distant goal, and question their population‚Äö√Ñ√¥s readiness for it. Indeed, our present regime in the USA, with its erratic bellicose behavior, tends to fortify that hesitancy.
It‚Äö√Ñ√¥s irrelevant whether China meets our standards for liberal democracy. Xi‚Äö√Ñ√¥s extension of his mandate is far less egregious than the systematic consolidation of right-wing corporate power that has occurred here, where we do pretend to democracy. At least Xi is supported by most of the population.
What matters about China is how they deal with climate change and with the global community. Yes, they are going to steal our secrets, spy on us, and try to get influence with our allies and enemies. They‚Äö√Ñ√¥re looking out for China, not for the USA. None of this means they are our enemy.
Our problems are not a prosperous China, but a decaying United States.

Now I am middle-aged, happily married, and living in Phoenix - located in a traditional purple state. We live in an older, progressive Central Phoenix neighborhood with excellent public schools, a plethora of new restaurants, cafes, and small stores where Bernie stickers outnumbered Trump 20:1. I almost feel guilty life is so painless here...and our mortgage, taxes, and insurance are less than the price of some of these single rooms.

Would I love to live in SF? Absolutely. Is it worth the price? No way...

headline: How the Tet Offensive Broke America
commentone:
I remember that time. Spending the night at my girlfriend's house. Her father was Army in country. My dad had already done his duty. We spent the night waiting for word on whether his position had been attacked. Thank good for the break in the news cycle, or we might have been up for days.

Word came the next day he was OK. Just another Pleasant Valley Sunday.

headline: Hugs, Smiles And a Pistol At the Ready
commentone:
I attended high school in the 80s during the onset of crack and the explosion of gangs. Our district had two police officers at each high school: There were no euphemisms such as Resource Officer. One happened to be my uncle. He requested the assignment. He had a daughter, a couple of nieces and a nephew at the school. When we all graduated he went back to his detective duties. He didn't wear a uniform because he was detective grade; but everyone knew who he was. He was good police. When he died a year ago his funeral was like a high school reunion. Previous students were there to celebrate, honor and thank him for his guidance and care. Many said they wouldn't be where they are today without him.

So I don't agree that it is one of the worst decisions a school can make. But I do believe a school has to be clear about what they are trying to accomplish. I went to school in a large urban district. I am black and so was my uncle. He wanted to make sure the environment was conducive to learning. He said the teachers should teach and let the police handle the policing. Because he was on campus high school was just that - SCHOOL.

headline: In West Virginia, the Politicians Fail, and the Teachers Rise
commentone: I always felt teaching was my calling. I lasted 6 years. Raising a family was my second calling. And when I got serious about that, it was clear that I couldn‚Äö√Ñ√¥t provide for my children in the manner I aspired to on a teacher‚Äö√Ñ√¥s salary. Rather, I would have to live in a marginal neighborhood and send them to marginal schools. My wife was also a teacher. And, as the man, all the income pressure was on me. And so I got a less fulfilling job that paid more. I am hardly alone. And this is the main reason there aren‚Äö√Ñ√¥t many male teahers. I suspect most women teachers have husbands who make more than they do. And summers off allow them to take care of the kids. Some teachers are married to doctors. Some are single. But all across the country they are mostly women. It would be nice if more men could afford to be teachers. Short of that, you could promote equality if you could pay single women more than doctors‚Äö√Ñ√¥ wives. That violates all kinds of rules. What a shame.
commenttwo: As a public employee, I well know that you judge compensation based on benefits as well as salary. A career teacher in West Virginia receives a generous pension upon retirement. Current retirees get about $30,000 per year. Along with Social Security, that's enough for a secure retirement. I know because that‚Äö√Ñ√¥s what I get. The pay is clearly too low. But the pension is the kind of benefit that private sector workers would die for.

headline: Learning to drive at 62
commentone:
This is what happens when you accompany a Syrian refugee woman to the Department of Motor Vehicles in Arizona:

The tester will call you over to the test area and declare that it is impossible for the woman to be tested, because she is unable to understand basic commands. The tester will say, ‚Äö√Ñ√∫I told her to turn on her left blinker, and she just stared at me.‚Äö√Ñ√π

When you explain that the DMV website refers to turn signals as ‚Äö√Ñ√∫turn signals,‚Äö√Ñ√π and that the woman knows all of the commands listed at the DMV website, including ‚Äö√Ñ√∫Turn left at the next traffic light,‚Äö√Ñ√π the tester will say, ‚Äö√Ñ√∫We never say traffic light, we say stop light.‚Äö√Ñ√π

When you tell the tester that you have a dictionary of the English language that is six inches thick, but you‚Äö√Ñ√¥ve concentrated your training efforts on the commands listed at the DMV website, the tester will say, ‚Äö√Ñ√∫Sir, do not cross that line. You must stay on the far side of the line.‚Äö√Ñ√π

And when the woman and the tester return to the DMV at the conclusion of the test, and the woman exits the car with a billboard smile on her face, you will smile, too, and you will do so through tears, which tears are not for the woman, who cannot care for her family or earn a living without a driver license. The tears are for you, lucky enough to live in a country where unsophisticated bureaucrats exist, but where citizens can confront them, challenge them to perform their duties, and help in a very small way to fulfill the promise of liberty and justice for all.

headline: Letting  Teenagers  Live
commentone:
Great article. The shooting that took place last month has stirred the consciousness of many people. It‚Äö√Ñ√¥s like a raging river that come into an eddy and everything slows down and you can now see the beautiful stones beneath the water. I call this hidden reality; things that are moving so fast that few of us take the time to understand what life is all about.

Out of the chaos of Douglas High School, most of us saw the light of possibilities emerge from some of the students who survived this tragedy. At first I thought ‚Äö√Ñ√∫Wow. These kids really get it. They can be the hope of the world‚Äö√Ñ√π. There was this great energy to change gun rules. Was this finally going to be the moment when the Republicans in Congress would finally realize that automatic weapons of death have to be banned? Guess again. That‚Äö√Ñ√¥s not going to happen. Why? Because like everything else that‚Äö√Ñ√¥s happening in the US, the person sitting on the throne in naked. We don‚Äö√Ñ√¥t have a leader. If you‚Äö√Ñ√¥re waiting for ‚Äö√Ñ√∫The Children will Lead Us‚Äö√Ñ√π, you can forget that too. Why? Because although some of them have great ideas of what to do and how to fix it, it‚Äö√Ñ√¥s just not that simple. Change doesn‚Äö√Ñ√¥t come just because of emotion. It takes commitment on the part of everyone. It takes a real leader to have followers. Who is that leader going to be? If not you, then who?
commenttwo: The number one cause of teen deaths is motor vehicle accidents. Number two is gang and other criminal violence. Both kill thousands per year. Over the last 10 years mass shootings have killed 112. But mass shootings get the most publicity by far. That is a decision of the media. I have my own ideas why the emphasis is so counterintuitive. You may have yours. Regardless, this is clearly an instance where the media tells us what is most important, contrary to all common sense.

headline: Make Better Movies Too
commentone:
And who will decide what‚Äö√Ñ√¥s good and bad?
That‚Äö√Ñ√¥s why we have freedom of speech. The author thinks bad is what she doesn‚Äö√Ñ√¥t like, so therefore no one should make or view that art.
Not a good idea at all.
commenttwo: Movies are both an artform and entertainment. Like novels, they range from James Joyce to Jane Austen to Ian Fleming. So when someone says that Get Out is not what they look for in a film for the ages, it doesn't fall neatly into the identity politics  box. Just because a film is about identity, anymore than it is about any important subject like the Holocaust, doesn't make it a great film in a cinematic sense. Now Oscar falls all over itself for "important" films about the Holocaust and Slavery, so perhaps it is right about taking members to task for ignoring Get Out. But as a one who saw Stepford Wives in 1975 at age 14 and it is a film that for a female haunted my thoughts throughout the years, I was still quite able to say Chinatown was a way better film on all levels of film making. I would never have thought Stepford Wives was a great film though it resonated very much with me. Get Out is like Stepford Wives to which it owes a great debt. Its not on the same level of cinematic achievement as Shape of Water or Phantom Thread, though it resonates with many people.  I always ask myself when evaluating a film, is it a social flash in the pan or will I be watching it in 20 years.

headline: Nakesha’s Demons

commenttwo: Whenever there is another mass shooting, we hear, "mental health." In actuality, people with severe mental health problems, such as Nakesha, are rarely guilty of violence, and far more likely to be victims of violence. headline: Romance, Rough Sex or Rape?
commentone: I know Sly used to show that film to the women he was hoping to score with.  Did he wait for that scene to swing in?  She's married to a MUCH nicer man, now.  No need to force anything.  The price of participating in his ring.
commenttwo:
Interesting that most of the comments refer to the movies that Mr. Bruni used to make his point about violence towards women. Having served in a group dedicated to offering battered women safe, anonymous and secure housing, I feel that dealing with the reality--that the demand for services for abused women rises every year--is more relevant.

Organizations dedicated to helping battered women have real difficulties providing everything that is needed by a woman who has the courage to leave her husband. Often they flee their homes without anything--suitcases are just too heavy to lug for miles. So clothing, toiletries, and cash are desperately needed by the women beaten up by a boyfriend or husband--plus shelter, help finding a job, and school for the children they often need to take with them.

Let's look at statistics regarding violence against women, not movies, to motivate us to take action: according to the American Psychologicala Assoc., every year 4,774,000 women experience physical violence by an intmate partner, or, 1 in 4 women will be victims of "severe violence" by an intimate partner according to the Centers for Dissease Control and Prevention.

More shelter space is needed, more volunteers are needed, and more support is needed for battered American women.

headline: The Danger of Waiting for a Wave
commentone: This is an important argument to consider.  It is certainly possible, even likely, that the miserable (and temporary) little tax cuts for most Americans will be enough to keep the Republicans in a majority in both houses of Congress -- the desperate populace as a whole reliably votes for short-term economic dribbles, after all. So we must be prepared for this eventuality, and Charlie Savage is right to remind us of it. What will happen as a result, of course, is anyone's guess.
commenttwo:
There are several weak points in this essay.

First, 1968 was a presidential election year; 2018 is not, so comparisons as to what the relative outcomes would produce are dubious at best. Plus, I'd like to know why Mr. Savage says regarding 1968 that regardless of which way the election went there would be no immediate relief without specifying the relief.

Second, while voters are currently satisfied about the economy over 60% say the country is heading in the wrong direction. This metric portends bad news for Republicans for two reasons: first, they can't rely on the economy to right-track the wrong track poll, that cake is baked. Also, the electorate is not afraid of Democrat's controlling the economy because the economy was not in bad shape in 2016, except to the base voters of Trump and Sanders.

Third, when the media reports on Russian election meddling they are quick to say that while Russia meddled there is no evidence any votes were changed. That is a very, very low threshold to set for evidence of russia's interference.

What about Russian voter suppression which could be done easily by changing a person's name in the data base? It was reported the largest amount of meddling was in Democratic strongholds in toss up states like NC and even in red states like TX.

I would like to see a follow up essay that goes from "What if" to "How?"

commentone:

commenttwo:
"When a country (USA) is losing many billions of dollars on trade with virtually every country it does business with, trade wars are good, and easy to win. "
DJT
The first fallacy in that statement is the word, "losing." The US is not losing dollars on the trade. Dollars are exchanged for goods and services. Credit Inventory: $XXX, Debit Accounts Payable: $XXX.

A capital rich country has the advantage of exchanging dollars for assets with a poorer country that has a cheaper labor force and is rich in ore deposits.

Most Dow 30 companies have large international operations that would be subject to retaliation if the US mandates tariffs based exclusively on the trade deficit. It is likely that the richest country in the world can purchase more goods and services from poorer countries than they can afford to purchase from the US.

headline: The Supreme Court’s Power Play Against Labor

I have never been represented by a union and was a manager in business for many years. I used to think they had outlived their usefulness, until in 2002, a company from the Netherlands bought the company for whom I'd been working for five years. Soon they started closing offices around the country and at mine, 200 people were out of work.

In recent years I read articles about and have heard co-workers talk about loved ones who work at places like Walmart and Home Depot. These people have no set schedule and frequently don't know what hours they work until the day before their work week starts. How can anyone plan their daily life? American businesses see their employees as a "problem" and I no longer believe that unions have outlived their usefulness. This systematic attempt to dismantle them has been a travesty.

headline: Trial of Killer’s Widow:  Scared Victim of Abuse Or Cunning Accomplice?
commentone:
This seems like a straightforward case about Ms. Salman's criminal responsibility. But that is not true, as indicated by this short, but vital, paragraph:

"Under federal antiterrorism laws, prosecutors will have to prove that Ms. Salman knowingly participated in Mr. Mateen‚Äö√Ñ√¥s plans to provide material support to the Islamic State, a foreign terrorist organization."

This is not even remotely a standard accessory to murder case. This is a terrorism case. The government alleges that Ms. Salman was a terrorist, not an accessory to murder. If she is convicted, she can be sentenced to life in prison.

The law governing this case calls for conviction even if:

"there was no link between the material support she gave her husband and violent activity, just that she knew what was given was material support."

The charging statute has been attacked multiple times as unconstitutional, but has been upheld by the courts. People who believe in civil liberties should be concerned whether a wife who merely supports her husband's terrorist cause should be subject to life in prison. If this were a standard criminal case the evidence of aiding and abetting would have to be much stronger. And Ms. Salman's intent would have to be murderous. Here, she can be convicted for terrorist sentiment, apart from the murders. You may approve or disapprove. But you should know that these charges are very aggressive and push the limits of our civil liberties. This is a Guantanamo kind of case.

commentone:
Domestic scene:
DHubby: "What do you want for breakfast, dear?"
MOL: [head down]. "The head of Timothy Polin."

Oookay! First, I did complete the puzzle correctly, but the Reveal and SW corner took me longer than the entire rest of the puzzle, because I had only ever seen KAT spelt this way, and I thought DRIP worked well at 56A (recalling my header into Lake Conway.).

And what is this WORD SQUARE you speak of? Neither DHubby nor I have ever heard of this game! Classic? Really?

Early on I was displeased to see a HOE suggested as an aid to potato harvesting. Use a hoe if you want to starting slicing or mashing right there in the garden. You want to use a garden fork in gingerly fashion to turn up the hills and free the potatoes from the soil. Handle with care.

Just kidding about the breakfast menu, Timothy. Good to see you back.

Regardless of how any individual evaluates the validity, fairness, etc of reparations and intersectional feminism, it's clear to me (as a career marketer) that elections will not be won by this type of mantra.

headline: Fights Worth Having
commentone:
One thing I didn't like about Obama was his refusal to 'fight' for his Supreme Court judge. He knew how important it was. So, why didn't we see him focus bright light on that, talk non-stop about the Constitutionality of his and his appointee's rights, and go to the Congress and lead and stage a dramatic 'fight' for him? No, he's not the fighting kind. And look what we got.

No, being quiet and intellectual and well-reasoned only goes so far in this world. We're seduced by money; just about all of us. How much are Bill and Hillary worth now, compared to before his presidency? And the Obama's? Yes, easily had we all are.

So, we must fight against our baser instincts: selfish greed. We have not; we have embraced it. Our current President is probably the best (worst) example of who the Americans are. Lost, self-centered, angry, vain, self-pitying tools of great destruction. Too harsh? Nah, that is US, today.

What to fight for? Compassion, healing, equality, ecology, community, honor, respect, housing, health care, common good, tax policy, etc. So much to fight for; we're probably intimidated by that, intimidated by the responsibilities of being a citizen in a democracy (we don't have the time or energy).

Trump is so bad, such a liar, cheat, greedy fraud, fake that many are starting to rebel. Slowly, reluctantly, starting to rebel. We've forgotten how. It's over 100 years since workers died in the streets for a 40 hour week. We don't know how to fight.

Now or never.
commenttwo: Social Justice Warriors can be self-righteous, humorless, and often self-defeating. But there is no left-wing Trump, nor anything like him.

headline: Go Ahead, Millennials, Destroy Us
commentone:
I disagree only with the use of the word "race" in this ...

"When a race stops caring for its young, its extinction is not only imminent but well deserved."

American society. The rest of the world knows full well it's a uniquely American problem -- our embarrassingly gutless political class and their pathetic fixation on money, the fear mongering and ignorance.

American society or culture is really what I think you mean. And you're right.
commenttwo:
I don't expect Millennials to save us, I expect us all to save US. And maybe they'll help lead. They certainly are on gun control, right now. We must thank them for that: being braver than their parents and grandparents.

Equality is a value we've lost. We're complicit in creating and promoting billionaires around the world and allowing them to buy everything, including renting our housing to us. We're patsy's. We're dumb and lazy. We're bad, bad citizens.

But, this can end. We can work for a common good. I've seen it small-scale. We just have to vote and elect and be compassionate and community-minded in large-scale. And, we can: whenever we want.

I taught high school US Government and History, regular and ESL. Great, great kids at a low-income, high-minority school. One of the reasons I don't like the term 'white privilege' is because most of my white kids were poor. I think we need to move away from labels of color or sex or sexual orientation. Economics. Money. Distribution. That's a foundational need of equality.

Wealth, income, property, power. Social-Democratic. Much more equal that today. High tax rates for those with over 10 million dollars. Higher still for those with over 100 million. This mad concentration of wealth has happened due to them using the system for their own gain. They've destroyed the nation to get rich. That's what must change.

Destroy greed. Then destroy hate. That'd be a good start.

commentone: "It‚Äö√Ñ√¥s no longer perceived as cool to be a pig." Note to men: Women have never perceived pigs as being cool. Steve McQueen was cool; Harvey Weinstein is a pig, period.

headline: How Liberals Can Reclaim Nationalism
commentone:
Nationalism means taking care of people in the nation, and we don't do that, and, actually few countries do that well.

Immigration is a problem because we can't even take care of our own, or, I should say, we choose not to, and many immigrants arrive with little and we offer them little, so their lives may be better than before, but for many, their lives wouldn't be called 'good'.

We refuse to talk about equality. Refuse. Freedom is easy, because the rich talk of the freedom to make and take as much as possible. But, equality is a non-starter, because the rich don't want near that one.

Our wealth, income, property and power are concentrating; here in the US and in much of the world. The corruption is deep and destructive. Why do you think the anti-immigration mob is so popular now? It's because the people already in these countries are given no hope for a good life. They see the few take more and more, and they're left behind. Struggling. Losing. Falling.

So, we attack the immigrant instead of the rich and powerful. We accept the oligarch and plutocrat but not the immigrant. We're a sad country, too lost and lazy politically to elect people of the left that might try to create a better society, a common good. We're too greedy for democratic-socialism. We want to be rich like Trump. Poor folks vote for the supposed-billionaire. They don't care that he's a bully, they're mad, they relate to the anger.

But, don't call them patriots. They're just selfish, angry and afraid.

headline: How the Left Wins the Culture War
commentone:
I really don't want a label, and I don't have one for Mr.Brooks: part of the reason is that sometimes I disagree with Brooks, but other times I agree. How can we be the 'other' if we agree at times?

I personally want to have access to education, contraception and higher education, all things that help prevent unwanted pregnancies, as the the path to limiting abortions to the fewest possible. I want to limit abortions in that way - by preventing unwanted pregnancies.

I want people who hunt to continue to do so, safely. I'm from Arkansas, we have more deer than people. I've eaten venison and appreciated the hunters than put that meat on the table. But, I also do want semi-automatic weapons sold in America. I think they are not protected by the 2nd Amendment (as tanks are not, or bazookas are not, or B-52s, etc.). As an ex-US Government teacher, I think the word 'militia' was speaking of the minutemen and other citizen-soldiers, which are now the Army, Navy, Air Force, Marines and National Guard: they are our militia.

The 'culture' war should be founded upon the fundamentals: food, housing, jobs, education, health care, community, etc. What is a 'Christian' nation without compassion towards all? Isn't the 'greatest Commandment' love? I think it is. That is culture. Without true, abiding, deeply felt and policy-borne love, I'm not sure who or what we are.
commenttwo: I meant, 'I do not want semi-automatic weapons sold....'. My mistake.

headline: In West Virginia, the Politicians Fail, and the Teachers Rise
commentone:
The average American is America.

Since Reagan's tax cuts for the rich (called trickle-down) we've been used and abused. You can see the concentration of wealth, income, property and power accelerate during those decades. A real problem has been, the average American is complicit in this destruction.

You can believe in the rights of gun owners, you can believe that abortions must be limited (most people believe in both of these), but until you believe in equality, America is for the rich.

We the People means all of us. If we build a land upon the lust for money then we break apart. We fight for our own selfish desires, leaving whatever in our wake. Greed has no honor, no pride, no community.

So, praise West Virginia. Praise the teachers. I've been a high school teacher and saw so many in my school as wonderful, committed, caring, hard-working people. Full of respect for others, honor, love. I'm so proud of my school.

But politically, my fellow teachers were absent. We never talked about anything like our class hours, class sizes, overall number of students, number of preps, underfunded pensions. We avoided that. All the meetings we ever went to were led by administration. We failed to lead politically.

Citizens of a democracy are given a great task: help lead. This is what democracy requires; or it dies. This is why this country is producing more billionaires and children in poverty: we are bad citizens.

So fight. Fight like the teachers in West Virginia. Fight now.

headline: Is ‘Black Panther’ a ‘Defining Moment’ for the United States — and Particularly for Black America?
commentone: 'Black Panther' is absolutely a defining moment for the United States. After I saw it, I began to reflect on the other movies I had seen with all-black casts. I noticed that they all had one element in common: they were all about historical struggles with discrimination. Most were about slavery, like '12 Years a Slave' and others were about just plain mistreatment and racism, like 'Detroit.' While these movies are great and exist for the better, they focus on one part of black history rather than simply celebrating it in a depiction of strength and glory. 'Black Panther' was different. It was a pure, powerful depiction of what the black race truly is: capable and strong. Not only that, women were also portrayed very, very well in the movie. The women were strong and intelligent, with the main character's own sister being a technological genius. All of the women are portrayed as warriors, every bit as strong as their male partners. Some people may write 'Black Panther' off as just another superhero movie, but it is so, so much more than that. I only hope that the Academy's bias against superhero movies doesn't override 'Black Panther's' achievements and that it receives the recognition it deserves at next year's Oscars. Maybe then we will truly see how far we've come in this country.

Every single detail of his meetings with Russians and others, of his efforts to line his pockets and those of daddy-in-law while in the White House, needs to be exposed until all of these rats are cornered.

That was all over too soon, so I am off to print one of BEQ's challenging puzzles. Thank you, Will, Rachel, and Joe--a good time was had by all!

Before getting rid of bad movies, or at least at the same time, let's get rid of economic disparities. Let's face poverty and rid ourselves of it. Let's face concentrated wealth and rid ourselves of it. Then, maybe respect for one another will naturally follow.

You talk of hostility. I wonder when criminal levels of inequality will be seen as the most hostile environment of all.

headline: Mr. Trump and the ‘Very Bad Judge’
commentone:
If democracy means rule by the people, then we elect the President, the leader, of our country. And to me, that means, in a way, 'he is US'.

We have become the liar, the fraud, the greedy-boy-who-continues-to-cry-wolf. We are Trump. And those of us who didn't vote for him, we are guilty of not fighting hard enough for real democracy; including after Gore beats Bush by hundreds of thousands of votes but loses due to the undemocratic Electoral College (so, then, Hillary 'wins' by millions of votes, but 'loses'). Our bad. Very bad.

We are too politically lazy and uncommitted to be a democracy. As they say, the proof is in the pudding. Our pudding is billionaires and lobbyists and lawyers and bought politicians and judges. Our pudding is a grotesque concentration of wealth, income, property and power. Our pudding is poverty and slave wages and hedge fund landlords and much deeper sickness. Criminally incompetent democracy.

So, somehow, recharge, recommit, reconnect and fight for the good, for compassion, for equality: for a healthy democracy : the more perfect Union.
commenttwo:
At times it seems Trump gets his Tweeting points frrom his friends on the TV that direct him toward a theme. But other times it feels like he has an idea but other people help him with the words and concepts.

Trump is President, But just like Obama I don't agree with his actions. I don't think I have liked many of the presidents that were in office during my voting years. (am 54). I even went so far as to announce on my Blog that I was running for the office in 2007, But my ideas are more radical than bernie sanders. Though I did agree with Trump's stated idea of why can't we be friends with Russia. But unlike others, I'd try to be friends with every nation, and fight (pun intended) a war on wars.

Gerald Celente wanted a Peace movement. I have been for peace all my life. But sadly the world is still a violent place and Peace is a hard things to get done in a world that worships Money.

So big wavy hands wall is in the works. When everyone wants to escape to the places south of us, we will lament that wall.

Ban guns and hand everyone a flower and tell that is their new weapon.

headline: Taxpayers, You’ve Been Scammed
commentone:
Humanity, you've been scammed; along with compassion and equality and community, etc. The really bad thing is: we did it to ourselves.

To first see where we are, we must focus on Trump and the Republicans. This tax cut is theirs. They live by cutting taxes for the rich; the people that fund their campaigns and media-promotions. The lower and middle-income groups that vote Republican are complicit (not dumb, not excused). You may not believe in a woman's right to an abortion or any type of gun laws, but you vote for very rich people getting richer and richer (as everyone else struggles).

When you 'want' to believe a lie, is that really 'scammed'? We so badly want to believe in a great and just 'America', even though that doesn't exist today. The billionaires here are very happy and continue to become more and more full with income, wealth, property and power. The billionaires of the world are jumping in, too. We're very bad citizens, bad at democracy.

So, 'scammed'? I like your vision and message. But, for me, we're very lazy and selfish as citizens of a democracy (the type of government that requires good and engaged citizens). Until we change and find compassion and love in our hearts and equality and high tax rates on the wealthy in our policies: it gets worse.

headline: The Macroeconomics of Trade War
commentone:
I'm glad Krugman can explain macro-economics to us, at least those that will listen.

When he speaks of, 'terrible, dumb policy', I think of our entire system which has created this modern-day Gilded Age with oligarchs and plutocrats with hundreds of millions and tens of billions of dollars. I think the top 10 richest people in America are 'worth' about as much as half the country. But, that's not the truth. If you have no home, no stocks, no savings, then you really have nothing, short of paycheck-to-paycheck desperation. Our 'policy' has produced a very diseased democracy.

We need clear, concise answers to this. Straight talk. Sorry, we may be 'losers' electorally, but at least be truthful. Higher tax rates on those with millions and billions. Single-payer health care, just like the military receives (they deserve it, and so do we). Public-financed mass transit, education, housing, infrastructure, clean energy, with all of these of 'affordable' natures.

No, I can't listen to the greedy, self-centered right-wing capitalists, masquerading as patriots and/or Christians any longer. I've seen my country fall, fall into criminal seas of inequality & inequity. I've seen the country I love follow greed into destructive levels of concentrated wealth, income, property and power. I've seen the most fake claim to love this land, then take as much as they possibly can. My God, we elected their leader.

So, we follow the madness of moneychangers, until the reckoning, that I pray comes.

We elected the 'reality tv' showman. That's a real-time sin of America. We are the worst citizens. We have corrupted or allowed corruption to destroy the ideals of a civilized, democratic nation. We the People did it.

Trump is the spoiled, boy-that-cried-wolf. 'I'm great. I'm the only one. I am so good. They're horrible. They're losers. Lock her up. I like soldiers that weren't captured; they can be heroes, like me. I would have run into that school'. What a fake.

Not fake news, fake leader. He's a billionaire wanna-be,with so many bankruptcies and affairs that it must be a sin that evangelicals say he's their man. I can't believe this is my country, now.

So many good people here. Most of us. But, somehow, we let the wild, lost, angry, hateful mob rule. We allow it. We don't vote. We don't get involved. We don't really care enough.

Russia is a madhouse led by a madman. We're headed that way. We can do our best, to be good people everyday, and work and talk and move toward November elections. Democracy can save us, if we're good citizens. If not, then shame on US.

Omarosa said that this guy tweets something controversial and the media goes crazy over it, and the tweets are really just a manipulation of our media: we continually focus on whatever he says; never dealing effectively with the deepest, worst aspects of what he's doing. He's a master at manipulation only because we're so dumb, compliant, easy.

The chaos is not real, what is real is the tax cuts. Republicans gladly, gleefully, cut taxes on the richest Americans. The rest of us kind of shrugged it off. The low-income Republicans acted dumb, but they know, they know what's up. They speak of abortion and guns and Jesus, but they see what's happening. They're led to hate the immigrant, those of a different skin color, those of a different view, but they're complicit in trying to bring down America.

headline: What Motivates Voters More Than Loyalty? Loathing
commentone:
The poster in your photo says, 'Everybody Sucks'. That's the problem, we vote for 'the person', not the party, issues, community. I am a Democrat because I believe in equality first and foremost; and that includes a general economic equality. This is our greatest sin.

We promote oligarchy, we embrace violent competition and grotesque concentrations of wealth, income, property and power. We create this awful place.

We elect a conniving, selfish, vain, bullying, boy-that-cries wolf. He leads people in chanting, 'Lock her up! Lock her up!', much like those that chant, 'Blood and Soil! Blood and Soil!' That's who we are.

We are very bad citizens. We watch two different Presidents get thousands and millions of fewer votes that their opponents, but due to the undemocratic Electoral College, they lead. We just watch and do nothing. We are terrible at democracy; and don't really care. We're too busy focusing on our own job, income, housing and prospects of wealth (or survival).

It's not 'demonization'; that's just a way bullies like Trump or Mussolini, etc. use to create great passion and hatred in their followers, so as to use them as storm-troopers against all opposition.

Trump is President because we're so unequal economically. The poor and struggling are easily manipulated to believe that they're not to blame, that things will get better if they only follow blindly, and that the 'other' is the cause of their sorrow.

They never admit that our greed is the real puppeteer.

headline: 5G Cell Service Is Coming. Critics Fear the Stations Will Look Like ‘a Medusa.’
commentone: is there radiation coming out of these devices and will it affect people??????
commenttwo:
Aesthetics are not the biggest concern we should have with 5G technology.

Electromagnetic Radiation (EMR) has health effects that we should be concerned about. Our bodies (especially our nervous systems) are affected by electricity, radio waves and magnetism. We are just beginning to learn what these effects are, and they are not healthy.

Meanwhile, we have a multi-billion dollar industry wanting to put this technology in front of all of our homes, who have a financial interest in NOT knowing the health effects. I am very worried about the proliferation of this new technology, as we all should be.

headline: A Red Older Than Its Year
commentone:
Good Afternoon: When did Rosso di Montalcino get so expensive? Used to find good ones for less than $10. Nonetheless, the timing for this month's Lesson could not have proved better, because my latest planned dinner had an Italian-American theme. Spaghetti with tomato sauce with mushrooms and ground sausage, roasted broccolini with garlic and red onions, green salad, Tallegio cheese. Music: Italian Renaissance music for viola de gamba by Ekkerhard Weber. On the roof: a steady rain, which somehow seemed right for the occasion. The wine: the 2015 La Torre.

Color: brilliant deep garnet. Nose: blackberry, tobacco, black cherry, spicy, black pepper. Taste: same as the nose, medium bodied, short finish, also earthy, oaky and cedar components. Fairly acidic, but not bitter. Overall, a well made wine. Complemented the spaghetti and Tellegio every bit as well as expected; surprisingly, also went well with the vegetables. Oddly, tasted better with the food than by itself. For $30+, seemed a bit pricy for the quality. Perhaps if I find one of the other recommendations, will give it a try.

headline: A Times Photographer in Italy Must Bring Her Daughter to Work
commentone: When will parents learn that society is not responsible for your child care. People  (men & women) who decide to have children need to think about who & how they will care for that child. You can't have it all, career, parenthood, everything, there are choices to be made, sacrifices to be made - job or child. Who will stay home - again decisions that should be made and agreed upon before to you think about having a child, not an after thought. This idea that society owes me child care is part of the entitlement generation thought process. You owe your first obligation to that child who did not ask to be born but now that it is, it is number one in your life. You and your desires are second place.
commenttwo:
Sorry, but mothers who raise their kids are extremely relevant... Especially to their kids! And they always have been.

Would careerist-feminists please stop and consider that their definition of meaning and relevance re women basically erases the historical contributions of all women who did not work for pay, for the entirely of hunan history?

Raising healthy children is relevant. The way children learn things like emotional self regulation are via attentive, compassionate mothering. There is no daycare provider who is one-on one with a child the way a mother is.

I would say the better lesson of Italy is this: if you go to a nice restaurant at 10 pm, you are very likely to see a baby. If that's your baby, the proprietor will beam at you, and likely to want to hold your baby or engage with him. Italy welcomes children in its midst and this is beautiful.

Zero-three are the mind-building, psyche-building years. Your kids are benefitting from this temporary delay in complete freedom. Enjoy it.

headline: A Tree Is Planted in Brooklyn, And a Homeowner Is Unhappy
commentone: A few cups of salt poured discretely around the roots at nite will make your wish come true...
commenttwo:
In San Francisco, the home owner is responsible for repairing sidewalks, and until recently, for maintaining the trees that the City planted, and still are for watering. That's no small matter given our recent surge in water prices and drought conservation mandates.

So it's not really excess entitlement that has a homeowner interested in being part of the process, in advance of the tree arriving. That doesn't mean anyone can block the process, and random species selections won't have the same end benefit as a cohesive plan. Hopefully species were chosen for their suitability to their location, not just the cheapest or fastest growing

headline: A Trump Fawners Almanac

headline: Big Banks May Weaken Dodd-Frank Oversight
commentone: Republicans (with a few complicit, "moderate" Democrats): "Let's do the Great Recession again. And if we can be truly bold, let's do the Great Depression again!"
commenttwo:
Well, look no further than the title of the article to discern the opinion of the authors.

I spent my entire summer watching congressional testimony and research this exact effect of the impact of asset thresholds upon Main Street Banks. For those unaware, "Main Street" refers to your mom and pop bank where you go and get your loan for your house. Wall street, however, is the complex, derivative trading mess that got us into the financial crisis.

The inherent problem is that your local credit union and JP Morgan have been constrained to the same rules that do not adequately measure for risk. Unnecessary stress tests, living wills, and capital requirements have put undue hardship upon banks with less than 50 billion in assets.

This bill is designed in a bipartisan way to free up credit for rural banks, which will lead to more capital for consumers. In no way does this legislation affect "systemically important" institutions as JP Morgan is defined. Just because we may have distaste for the administration does not mean every piece of legislation is worthless.

headline: Charles Wilson, 88, Lauded For Excising Brain Tumors, Sometimes Several in a Day
commentone: His intensity was unmatched as was his surgical skill. Once in a generation or two someone like Professor Wilson comes along. It was inspirational and at times intimidating to be around him.
commenttwo: In 1994, my 14 year-old niece was diagnosed with a life threatening aneurysm in her brain.  My brother (the patient's father) told me that he would get his family through the situation, but asked me to find the best neurosurgeon in the country for his daughter's condition.  I spent nearly two weeks flying around the country interviewing the best and brightest minds in neurosurgery.  I chose Dr. Wilson.  Although I had no training that would allow me to distinguish gradations of expertise, Dr. Wilson had a uniquely extraordinary demeanor that I had never seen in any other person.  I also felt that if the surgery went in an unexpected or sideways manner, Dr. Wilson would fight to save my niece as if it were his own child.  The operation went eight hours, and Dr. Wilson emerged from the OR with a broad smile.  He explained that the operation required more art than science, and that he had strategically and successfully clipped the aneurysm in five places.  He handed me a torn strip of scratch paper and said, "Here are the serial numbers of the five clips; hold onto this for the rest of your niece's life in case she ever needs it."  He was truly a larger-than-life heroic figure.  I'm sure that thousands of others have similar experiences to share.  My niece is now 38 and has never had a complication from her surgery.

I remember falling for one beautiful picture of a sailboat out at sea.  When I naively inquired about it, I was informed that Jackie Onassis already had dibs on it.  Honestly, I was over the moon that  Ms. Onassis and I both found it lovely. Years later in a used bookstore, I happened to pick up a book " The Pioneers and Patriots of America -- Daniel Boone."  On the third page was HCC's signature as the proud owner of the book as well as the year he bought the book, and of course, his home address 1 W 67th Street.  Perhaps Howard was throwing me a bone, so to speak. Again, another sweet moment.  I still have the book.

headline: How Liberals Can Reclaim Nationalism
commentone:
"Domesticating" nationalism is a sensible and worthy goal, but of little value if we fail to stop denying the myopia, historical ignorance, and political incompetence which are ravaging the United States.

Trump is not a nationalist, he is a kind of pseudo populist. A nationalist would not side with brutal foreign dictators and against American institutions and traditions. Nor does nationalism equal denial. Trump was not elected because he had a huge following, he was elected because Republicans willfully threw away every chance to stop him being nominated, and Democrats threw away every chance to avoid nominating the easiest opponent for him.

Fiscally irresponsible tax cuts for the rich are not patriotic or nationalistic, they are risky gambles on pandering to greed. Multiculturalism can be pro-nationalist, but not if it is based on blind political correctness, tokenism and tepidness.

Nationalism for America would mean reining in any military industrial complexes, and not turning the other cheek for decades towards the murderous imbecility of the NRA. It would include restoring basic factual American history and civics to public education, and combating mass ignorance of the nation's founding principles. It would include an understanding of the Constitution framers' structure of checks and balances, and their stern warnings about the sort of decrepit and dysfunctional two-party system cancer which has been rotting American politics and civil society for too many years.
commenttwo: This piece should be studied by every democratic candidate entering the upcoming elections.  The notion that all of us, despite many different backgrounds, are one ‚Äö√Ñ√∫nation‚Äö√Ñ√π seems so self-evident but our politicians do not embody this ideal; to the contrary, the dems are focused on dissecting each group into distinct political entities. This strategy will not work.  Many people are more in line with the democrat ideals but will not vote for a party that seemingly focuses on tearing down the very idea of one nation.

headline: Mr. Trump and the ‘Very Bad Judge’
commentone:
Having worked in the federal courts in various ways for 30 years now, I have to say that Donald Trump was right to criticize Gonzalo Curiel almost two years ago.

The claims the plaintiffs made in the fraud case against Donald Trump (as opposed to the other defendants) were based on "sales puffery" and were too weak to withstand a motion to dismiss. Donald Trump had the only deep pockets, so if he were dismissed the plaintiffs would have gotten nothing. That's why Gonzalo Curiel would not dismiss the case.

Had the case gone to trial and appeal Donald Trump would have won. The plaintiffs may have been defrauded, but it wasn't by Donald Trump. While his words may have been ill-chosen, Donald Trump was right to criticize Gonzalo Curiel's decision.

The federal courts need more criticism like Donald Trump gave them. Federal judges have become American aristocracy. They are appointed for life. They sit on thrones dressed in robes and demand to be called "your honor". Any one of the hundreds of them can stop even a president from doing his job. And no one can overrule their decisions except another member of the aristocracy.

That's crazy. Who gave them this awesome power? No one. They took it.
commenttwo:
‚Äö√Ñ√∫It‚Äö√Ñ√¥s possible that Mr. Trump simply forgot who Judge Curiel is. More likely, he knows full well and doesn‚Äö√Ñ√¥t care.‚Äö√Ñ√π
No - he is counting on Americans‚Äö√Ñ√¥ notoriously short historical memory, betting that we will not notice yet another instance of his bottomless hypocrisy.

headline: No Pension? You Can ‘Pensionize’ Your Savings
commentone: Good idea. But how do you plan for the abusive employer who makes sure no one over about 60 except management gets to keep their jobs?
commenttwo:
this is terrible advice for most people. Unless Mr. Vernon et al know something the Social Security people do not, postponing the start of benefits provides NO economic benefit.

"lifetime benefits are about the same for the average beneficiary regardless of claiming age. For individuals who retire early, monthly benefits are reduced to take into account the longer period of time they are received."
https://www.ssa.gov/policy/docs/ssb/v74n4/v74n4p21.html

It gets worse. The time to even break even can take decades!

For me if I delay retiring from 62 until my full retirement age I don't receive the same total dollars from Social Security until age 78!! It's a personal decision, but I don't want to accept a lower standard of living for 16 years so that I'm happier at age 78, if I'm even alive then. The payback period is even later if I wait until age 70 to start collecting.

You can go to the chart at https://www.ssa.gov/OACT/ProgData/ar_drc.html and use the info to build a table based on your birth year.

headline: President Trump’s Contradictory, and Sometimes False, Comments About Gun Policy to Lawmakers

commenttwo:
The entire issue of gun rights and gun control is self-contradictory and out of control. Does anyone really believe that the Second Amendment was written by men with God's hand guiding the script? No, it was written because the English wanted to disarm American anti-royalists and hamper muster of militia. And the idea that "the militia" should be "well-regulated"? Did not the authors believe that the Constitution would be subject to periodic updating? Of course they did. But we have a large number of Americans who believe that it is appropriate for individuals to own massive arsenals and chests full of ammo. That kind of collection makes ME less safe.
Was that what the founders meant to create for their people? This interpretation is ridiculous to say the least. And "well-regulated" has always meant that local governments could decide what is appropriate. Sorry Wayne La Pierre, what works in Wyoming does not work in New York City.

headline: Readers React: What Is the Healthiest Way to Feed a Baby?
commentone: Breast is best! Feeding foods other than breast milk for at least the first six months increases the tendency towards obesity in infancy through adulthood. Mothers need to be supported in their efforts to breastfeed, including having enough time off work to establish a nursing routine. They also often need education about why babies cry, and how to cope with the stresses of new parenthood.
commenttwo: When our son was 4 months old he rejected his rice cereal and demanded to have a taste of our risotto dinner. When he was in kindergarten his teachers were amazed by the variety of food in his lunchbox. It wasn‚Äö√Ñ√¥t unusual to see picked herring in his lunch. My husband is a trained chef and my son demands a made to order hot breakfast with protein every day. The only thing our child won‚Äö√Ñ√¥t eat are raw tomatoes. Now as a teenager his only weaknesses are hot sauces and candy. For tutoring snacks he prefers fruit over cookies. He is still learning about what works for best to maintain his focus and energy levels during the day. He is very active and fit for his age, he enjoys CrossFit, mountain biking, swimming, and yoga. As a family we do our best to model healthy diet choices, behaviors and activities.

headline: The Rise of  Dictatorship  Incorporated
commentone:
Apparently it needs to be pointed out that all Stephens is saying is this: if we don't develop a coherent policy with regard to the Mideast real soon, we're going to pay bigly.

He's saying that if we don't stop telling the bad guys--and sorry, kids, but Assad, Putin, the DPRK are as bad as bad guys get--that we're weak and stupid, we'll pay bigly.

He's arguing that whenever Assad employs chemical weapons, he needs to be smacked a hard one. Not some halfwit, haphazard cruise missile strike on an empty airfield, either. And he's arguing that we need to support the Kurds, not cut their weapons off.

Sorry, but it's not an "Invade Syria Now!" routine: it's a serious, committed version of what Obama did, which at its best was to act calmly, in accord woth a coherent strategy, and bop the bad guys a hard one.

Sorry: let 'em all hang is stupid, and invade 'em all is stupid. You do what you can, and you do NOT flail around and show these guys that you're stupid, lazy and a coward.

As for those screaming about the End of America or whatever, I'd like to suggest tapering off on the florid adjectives. Seriously, guys, studies show that it's bad fer yer liver an' yer lights.
commenttwo: Syria, like Afghanistan before it, would have been a perfect place to give Putin a bloody nose (remember Russia's withdrawal from Afghanistan?).  As in Afghanistan, we could have supplied arms (including Stinger shoulder-fired missiles to bring down Russian aircraft) to the rebels.  Unfortunately, the U.S. has fumbled badly, and missed a valuable opportunity in Syria.

headline: What Motivates Voters More Than Loyalty? Loathing
commentone:
I'm a lifelong Democrat, and I freely admit loathing Republicans. To self-identify as a Republican after 1968 is to identify yourself with a party that has committed treason to win elections twice, pardoned those who participated to hold the presidency a third time, and twice stolen presidential elections. The party practices voter-suppression and has shamelessly put its hacks on the Supreme Court with the aim of destroying the power of regular people to participate meaningfully in their supposed democracy. And now it is headed by a racist, misogynist, xenophobic cowardly lackwit.

However, it's easy for me to see why the other side hates the Democratic Party. Since the administration of Bill Clinton it has been hijacked by those who would use it for their own enrichment. The administrations of Clinton and Obama also turned their backs on working people, organized labor, and "the little guy" in general. I agree with the sign shown at the start of this column that says "Everybody Sucks".

That said, I think the Democratic Party can be saved. The GOP can't be.
commenttwo:
Several years ago, Rush Limbaugh proclaimed to his broadcast audience, "We have nothing in common with Democrats!"

I am a liberal, and it greatly saddens me that millions of my fellow Americans are easily drawn into a Twilight Zone of -
- conspiracy theories
- scapegoating people who are "different from me"
- blindness to duplicity, dishonesty, and moral failings (as long as it's "our guy) - belief in statements which have little or no supporting evidence
- willingness to classify likable ideas as "Real" and unlikable ideas as "Fake"
- lack of curiosity regarding the broader context of many of the problems and challenges of our country and the world

I know that my world view differs in many ways from that of many other Americans, however, I DO NOT BELIEVE that "I have nothing in common with you."

Good grief. We are all citizens of the planet Earth. We all are born into more or less favorable circumstances. We all have the same needs for safety, food, shelter, and for love, emotional support, and being valued as unique individuals. We go through struggles as we grow up and try to get an education.

Then, we venture out and search for a good, meaningful job, a congenial life partner, and a network of friends.

Ultimately, we and those we love, all come face-to-face with our own mortality, and we may wonder about what mystery (and unifying essence?) may lie beyond death.

In truth, we Earthling-Americans all have a whole fabric of human life in common.

commenttwo: As I said before, the answer to why it's so hard to invest in good conscience is easy-- the commercial profit motive is in essence violence against other humans.  If you invest, you are complicit with a system that rewards only competition, greed, dishonesty, and one-upsmanship. Companies that aren't ruthless don't survive.  The ones that tart up their marketing successfully do.  You can analyze and nitpick details of how to invest within the system all you want, but to find a way to come out with a clean conscience can't be done.  Anybody who can follow a chain of causal analysis should be able to come to the greater conclusion.  And that is, Marx was right.  In a strange sense it doesn't matter anymore whether we value the higher good in our society (which we don't, except for a few outliers everyone disdains) because the consequences of our stupidity and selfishness will play out.  Though that is a damn shame, and it's a damn shame that we can't value something other than our own prevailing.

headline: Your Kid’s Phone Is Not Like a Cigarette
commentone:
Digital technology is indeed an inevitability to be accepted (not to do so would be to make the same mistake movie studio moguls did seven decades ago when they tried to dismiss television as a fad that wouldn't last), but it may be a bit early yet to pronounce it a completely benign, completely necessary influence on human lives. After all, smoking had been around for centuries before its health hazards became known.

Is it merely coincidence that there's an "obesity/diabetes epidemic" at a time when people spend most if not all their waking hours staring passively as a screen rather than exercising their bodies? Can all that prolonged artificial light in the eyes be good for them? How about the increased suicide statistics among children and teenagers because technology has simplified cruelty? Or the rising number of accidents among both drivers and pedestrians because people are paying less attention to there they're going (and what's coming their way).

It'll take another generation at least to determine conclusively how much "digital" is actually synonymous with "improved." Any addiction is a cause for concern. However unrealistic it may be to deny technology, those who manage to opt out and still live productive lives could well be the ones to be envied.

commentone:
I stopped watching award shows a while ago, when they started to become political events. Just because a person is a good actor, actress, or director, and make a great sum of money, doe snot mean they can use an awards show, as a platform, to push their own political agenda. If they want to engage in politics, they can do so, but do it on cable news, and not during a n awards show. Why? Because we, as Americans, need to have an escape from the political reality and divisions of this country, once in a while. This si why we go to movies, plays, watch TV or listen to music. We already have a 24/7 news cycle as it is, so there needs to be a respite. And, unfortunately we cannot escape this any more in movies, plays, music or TV shows, let alone award shows.

I emphasize with the discriminated, the harassed, the lack of diversity, et. al.; but, it has gotten to the point that everything is now political, divisive and painful. All this is doing is further fragmenting an already fragmented country. And this anger, negativity, continues to feed on anger and negativity. It is at the point that "cooperation", "unity", "hope", "love", "positive", have completely fallen out of the lexicon.

So, it is appropriate, for a negative, divided country, that Trump is president. He is an embodiment of this nation's problems, all tied up in a neat package: greed, selfishness, ignorance, hared, brashness, egotism, elitism and prejudice.

From many we are one ("E Pluribus Unum") is long forgotten.

headline: A Times Photographer in Italy Must Bring Her Daughter to Work
commentone: With so much ancient beauty in plain sight, Italy is rightly described as an outdoor museum. Thanks to the warmth of its people and the elite status children enjoy as princes and princesses, it‚Äö√Ñ√¥s also a living nursery, with the general public willingly on call as accidental caretakers. So it‚Äö√Ñ√¥s no surprise Olivia was looked after while her mom worked. This doesn‚Äö√Ñ√¥t mean child care programs are adequately funded. I suspect politicians turn a blind eye to helping mothers more because they know how much everyone already pitches in.

headline: A Trump Fawners Almanac
commentone:
‚Äö√Ñ√∫Consider the White House. Stuffed with people who got picked for their jobs because they appeared to worship the ground Donald Trump walked on.‚Äö√Ñ√π

These days mark a contemptible time that will be relegated to the dustbin of American history.

‚Äö√Ñ√∫Hmm, what do all those offices have in common?‚Äö√Ñ√π Aside from posing threats to Trump, none of these people were appointed by him. Trump won‚Äö√Ñ√¥t fire anyone he appoints because it will eat away at his innate narcissism ‚Äö√Ñ√¨ that he could have made a bad choice, that he is a bad judge of people.

These op-ed columns are important. As Dr. Seuss said: ‚Äö√Ñ√∫Nonsense wakes up the brain cells. And it helps develop a sense of humor, which is awfully important in this day and age. Humor has a tremendous place in this sordid world. It‚Äö√Ñ√¥s more than just a matter of laughing. If you can see things out of whack, then you can see how things can be in whack.‚Äö√Ñ√π

Keep on whacking, Gail Collins. Trumpworld is a vast collection of overstuffed pi‚àö¬±atas, at your disposal.
commenttwo:
People, pay attention! This is just another iteration of the most astoundingly inept administration in our nation's history. Your children will someday tell their own grandchildren that they were alive during the Trump years and watched as he flailed and floundered, raged and roared ineffectually. They won't believe the stories but by then you'll be able to point to a thousand learned books from incredulous historian's documenting the carnage.

And you were there! It will be almost religious-like hearing a World Wat Two vet tell of distant battles and battlefields.

headline: At Heart of Tight Race, Folks Who Picked Trump But Wish They Hadn’t
commentone:
Ah ha. Now I understand Trump's hasty announcement about placing tariffs on imported steel. This appears to me to be less about rejecting his own advisers recommendations, along with those of our allies and numerous reputable economists, and more to do with winning this special election in Pennsylvania, a State longing to regain its former steel manufacturing glory days.

After the special election, we may well see Trump change his mind again and back off of these tariffs. As Trump often likes to say, "let's see what happens."
commenttwo: I would hope that this special election and the mid terms are more than a referendum on only Trump. The GOP, including those already in office and the candidates running are culpable for enabling Trump by their support and/or silence.  A courageous, moral and thinking republican is a rare item today.
