headline: Go Ahead, Millennials, Destroy Us
commentone:
I'm a millenial. I own an AR-15 and a total of 10 guns. I carry a pistol around with me all the time.

So yeah, the suburban wealthy kids who never shot a gun in their lives are making their voices heard. Meanwhile, the millions of gun owning millenials are silent.

I am not an NRA member and I don't carry a weapon I can kill someone with because I'm fulfilling role-playing fantasies.

I carry a pistol with me because I am a transgender woman living in a rural community, away from the safety of LGBT-loving cities and in a land where people may believe that I am a child molester. I've been assaulted before, and after that I decided that I needed to protect myself. I don't have any cops nearby and tweeting out #metoo isn't going to save my butt if I'm about to be raped where I live. All I got is myself. As such, a pistol in my pocket and an assault rifle at home are what I needed to feel safe.

As for gun control, I'm all about it. Universal background checks, raising the age to 21, everything except.the assault weapons ban. Sorry, but even if that happens I won't give up my AR.
commenttwo:
My son was a junior in HS at a school close to Columbine during that massacre. We both knew it could have been his school. I thought something would happen after Newton because the children were oh, so young. It breaks my heart that our elected officials ( e.g. NRA fearing members of congress) have failed to protect our rights as Americans to safely go to schools, concerts, movies, churches, etc. We used to live in a country worth emulating but now we are a corrupt nation, run by gun manufacturers and other corporations.

I believe the blood of every child killed in a school shooting is on the hands of these NRA-supporting politicians who refuse to incorporate common sense measures to protect Americans‚Äö√Ñ√¥ rights to life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness. All in the name of a false interpretation of the second amendment. Sad beyond words...

headline: God, Don’t Save the King
commentone:
Speaking of "do-nothing viscounts and earls," and having just read Paul Krugman's column ("Taxpayers, You've Been Scammed"), may I remind you that we're already headed towards permanently-entrenched royalty due to the utterly insane inheritance-tax rollback in the GOP tax bill.

Hypocrisy is synonymous with GOP politics. They who love to impugn lower-income "takers" are, meanwhile, fine with idle, spendthrift rich heirs. We're closer to reinstating Medieval Feudal Europe than you think.
commenttwo:
Nice piece of allegory here, but a small quibble:
Benjamin Franklin's pre Revolution mission to the British Parliament and the King was to try to convince them that the Colonies should be considered full citizens and partners not colonies. There were at least ten years of that track tried getting only opposition from most of Parliament and the King and his minister. Then, when our Founders knew there was no other recourse did they write the Declaration of Independence and begin the Revolution.
There was one great theme then that we should try now: "No taxation without representation" and we should realize that maxim pertains to health insurance premiums, large fines for traffic and parking violations, and all the other "on the cheap" ploys republicans have taken to funding this vast enterprise of a Nation.
Another thing we would do well to remember from that time: It takes an educated electorate and a vigorous free Press to maintain a democracy. Right now we may have neither, but we just might be waking up to that fact again.
Writers, reporters, anchors and pundits need to remember that in fascist states reporters are generally out of work and in prison.

headline: Goodbye, Pay-as-You-Wish
commentone: I have absolutely no problem with this. When it was voluntary, we paid even more than the suggested donation. We love visiting Paris and you pay to go into all of their galleries and museums. What's the big deal?
commenttwo:
Just came back from a week in London. Walked into the Tate modern and Victoria and Albert museums, both free. Charging to enter a museum is like charging people to take out books from the library. If you want a cultured, knowledgeable society, you can't expect people to pay such a steep fee.

Here in Denver, we have days when all of the museums and public facilities are free of charge...zoo, museums, gardens. And the places are packed, with families, seniors, tourists, school kids, and all walks of life. That's how we insure our future, not by charging a preposterous fee.

headline: How Liberals Can Reclaim Nationalism
commentone:
There is a fascist idea that has taken a pretty deep hold in America and the oligarchs who have foisted this upon US are not going to go away quietly. We might very well end up a real two tiered Nation with our feudal lords living in extreme wealth on islands of plenty surrounded by oceans of desperate and heavily armed people.
The republican party has worked very hard to create a divided Nation of us against them; they are coming for our guns, they won't let us be Christians, they want to turn us all into moochers and takers, they are trying to install Sharia law, they believe illegal Mexicans are better than "real" Americans.
These tactics have worked better than imagined because they have concentrated their wrath on issues like abortion and gay rights; which really do deeply offend some of us.
I don't know if We the People will be able to negate the influence of the koch bother's money and F(alse)ox not news but we had better.
When our government is once again under the guidance of public servants who believe in serving their Nation and everyone in it we can then begin to educate and welcome back those who believe us to be the enemy.
If we don't put our government back into capable hands we have lost.
commenttwo:
"Patriotism, some philosophers argue, should be understood as an innocent love of country that is inclusive at home and cooperative abroad. Nationalism, by contrast, excludes other ethnicities and stands in competition with the interests of other countries."

Succinct explanation of an important distinction. Not just "ethnicities," though. Deeply troubling to me, at least, is the schism in this country between Trump-backing so-called "Evangelical" Christians and everyone else--progressive, liberal Christians and just about everything else including Jews, Muslims, Buddhists, etc. So, besides ethnicities, let's add tribalism; in this example it's tribalism cloaked in religious vestments.

The Constitutional separation of church and state wasn't just a novel, noble goal at the time of our country's founding. These people understood that the only way to create a cohesive public body was to eliminate religious tribalism--in fact, that was obviously more important at the time than racism (slavery) or gender (women couldn't vote or even own property).

The hard-right fundamentalist, nationalist "Christian" movement in this country is every bit as dangerous as the Catholic Church's crusades all over Europe in Medieval times when they wiped out people of their own ethnicity (along with others, no doubt) who didn't toe the official Church's dogmatic line.

Vote in November, and get out the vote among women, minorities, and all who appreciate how important this is right now.

headline: How the Left Wins the Culture War
commentone: I would agree progressives increasingly act like fascists and attempt to silence dissent. However, if by "polite society," you refer to the progressive mandarin class, you are correct there are not nearly enough to you to win elections and pass legislation in most states.
commenttwo:
It's a lot like equality for GLBTQ folks, MADD, or civil rights, or whatever. At some point when people are getting seriously hurt one has to discard political calculation and simply say "this is wrong, period. It must be changed."

We stigmatize people smoking indoors around kids, cooking with lard, beating dogs for misbehavior, or letting kids ride without seatbelts. We don't consider wife beating and drunk driving normal. And now we are beginning to place social disfavor on gun absolutists and assault rifle owners. We probably won't ban assault rifles or end open carry, but like smoking, we can limit crazy gun stuff by common sense gun safety rules: universal background checks, storage laws, restraining orders, and the like.

headline: Intrigue in the House of Trump
commentone:
While I applaud the sentiment of this piece, the more important issue is that we never allow another person like this man into the Oval Office again. Yes, let's do put some safe guards in place for staffing that don't rely upon good judgment and ethics, but let's start with the Presidency itself.

We need to safe guard our highest office from fools and buffoons and craven usurpers. And we need to begin to think about this now. It's a probability the world may never see us in the same light again. We made fade into irreverence on the world stage because of this moment in time, but let us look to protect ourselves from the likes of another Trump. The next one might not be so inept and intellectually challenged and then where will we be?
commenttwo: Like so many things, the idea that the things that Trump does has precedents is thin at best.  The Trump family has a long history of close business relationships with shady characters.  They have continued those relationships in the campaign and in the White House.  They are using the White House as an office for their businesses and profiting mightily from selling their hospitality services to the Secret Service.  This is completely unprecedented. I remember the scorn that Hillary received right from the start in the health care debate.  The Republicans have treated Ivanka and Jared as the crown prince and princess.  Just because they look bright and shiny and not old and vulgar doesn't make them any more honest than the Con Artist in Chief.

headline: Learning to drive at 62
commentone:
"Thanks, Eddie; thanks to the kindness of strangers in America."

Don't overthink it: passing you was also the easiest way for Eddie not to have to deal with you anymore.

Aside from many other pieces of obvious advice, wear your seat belt and come to a full stop at stop signs. Sooner or later, cops will get you for those things.

You're not going to drive in NYC. Take a road trip across the country. That will be a good first test of your driving mettle. Make sure you check the weather and road conditions/construction. Maybe you'll discover a little Charles Kuralt in you? Might be worth a try.
commenttwo:
A splendid story, particularly Mr. Cohen's affection for Pigpen, who passed away 8 March 1973, nearly 45 years ago. The Grateful Dead were never the same without his rave-up talents and greasy blues.

When the gentleman who oversaw my driving test told me I'd passed, I was all smiles. Success! He put the kabosh on that: "Don't kill anyone," he said with a flat intonation, indicating that he thought it likely.

headline: Letting  Teenagers  Live
commentone:
The day I turned 16 I skipped my morning classes at school and was in the door at the DMV the moment it opened. But.... that was a half century ago; there were a lot less cars on the road and they went slower. There were a lot few distractions and NO cell phones. My buddy's dad wouldn't let him listen to the radio while driving. We did, but .......
Twelve years ago my daughter got her supervised permit and we spent the next two years trying to convince her to learn to drive, which she didn't seem that intent on doing. At 18 she finally got her license and we haven't seen her since. Kidding......
We have a system like that in Colorado and kids seem OK with it and teen traffic deaths are declining. In rural areas kids will drive like they always did, when they need to.
commenttwo:
For those who feel that this saps the gun safety issue I have this thought. Just why, exactly, is it not possible to deal with both issues under the umbrella of teen safety?

Is there some reason that both cannot be addressed? We really can do more than one thing at a time. I understand that keeping the pressure on about guns is important yet that need not keep us from examining teen driving laws. My grand daughter has not been allowed to get her license yet. Her parents do not feel she is responsible enough yet and her decision making is not quite where it needs to be.

I spent 30 years with HS age teens. Slowing down the process certainly is not going to harm them. I've seen the tears and the black border in the year book and the memorials. Enough is enough.

Oh - and make the access to our schools at least as secure as any large business as well.

headline: Lower the Voting Age to 16
commentone:
I was a anarchist when I was 16. I was an idiot when I was 16.

If anything, the voting age should be raised to 21. 18 year olds are not adults any more, they are still children. Millenials didn't become adults until they were like 25 years old and some of them still live in their parents basement.

Besides, letting 16 year olds vote will just mean a huge group of uneducated people without high school degrees voting, which is a recipe for stupid choices that further dilute the voice of educated informed people in this nation.

Remember, most 16 year olds in this nation can barely do math, read, or write. Most 16 year olds in this nation aren't going to go to college. Most 16 year olds in this nation spent absolutely no time thinking about anything besides themselves. I don't believe they should vote.
commenttwo: 16 year olds are heavily influenced by their parents. Giving them the vote would essentially be giving millions of middle aged conservatives an extra vote. I say conservatives because parents of teenagers tend to strongly oppose under aged drinking, drug use and unrestrained sex. They may favor doing well at school and respect for authority. If Democrats want to win more elections, they should work out a scheme to double the votes of people in public housing projects and college professors.

headline: Make Better Movies Too
commentone: Women and men belong to the same species. They typically have the same motivates and goals (e.g., power, rewards, status, etc.), but sometimes employee different strategies. What we now have is a power differential, not a sex difference.
commenttwo:
Hum. I am a woman over 40. I work in a STEM field. I recognize misogyny when I see it and make no mistake, I see it every day.

I love the hopefulness of this article but the fact is we aren't living it. We have a horrid dreadful example in the Oval Office, his VP on many levels is even worse. We work in places when women are still very much second class citizens. And I just finished watching Altered Carbon on Netflix where I can't tell if women are victims, powerful or crazy.

And I have to be brutally honest, the entire Al Franken thing still bothers the heck out of me. We cannot become those we hope to retrain.

There is a fascinating article in the current NY Magazine about Boys. I would encourage everyone to pick it up and have a read. It might give you hope. Or it might not.

headline: Mr. Trump’s Problem With Democracy
commentone: Two and a quarter centuries from ‚Äö√Ñ√∫America‚Äö√Ñ√¥s Cincinnatus‚Äö√Ñ√π (Washington) to ‚Äö√Ñ√∫America‚Äö√Ñ√¥s Caligula‚Äö√Ñ√π (guess who)
commenttwo:
DJT is a man who has never shared anything with anybody. Actually he has made a ton of money on the backs of other people and investors sharing his losses. People like him like democracy just because they can milk a democratic society. headline: Putin Says He Has ‘Invincible’ Nuclear Missile
commentone:
O please what vulnerabilities? The Russians cannot even build a car or refrigerator that works. And about 7/8 of the rural areas of the country has no paved roads and uses outhouses.

I am very scared. A paper tiger. Putin is the biggest fool on the world stage. He is Andropov without half the brains. You think the billionaires would allow any type of war. There is too much money to be made.
commenttwo:
I'm American and my significant other is Russian, so we frequently discuss what embarrassing thing our respective leaders are doing, which is pretty much every day these days. We also discuss lots of other topics, like culture, history, and philosophy. And therefore, I kind of wanted to throw in my two cents of perspective...

(1) We think that Putin is building up the Russian military because he seems to be unable to build up a functional economy. And this same type of focus on military power over economic power appears to be what led to the collapse of the Soviet Union.

(2) I'm guessing that most people don't realize just how centralized modern Russia is. For example, the people there seem to either stay in their home city/town, or move to Moscow or St. Petersburg for work. With my point being that if a serious war ever breaks out, I believe that targeting only Moscow and St. Petersburg would be sufficient to collapse the entire country. Whereas in contrast, the United States has a diverse economy spread across a large number of large cities. So, even if Putin has "super weapons" that perhaps we do not, it would be completely idiotic to actually use them against us.

(3) Putin implying that our missile defense systems are "useless" is a hollow threat, since those systems weren't designed to stop a large-scale nuclear attack in the first place. His goal is to make Russians feel proud and powerful, because he can't promise them any better quality of life.

headline: Silicon Valley Disruption In an Australian School
commentone:
This exemplifies everything I despise in the rah rah start up culture. Not everyone should be an entrepreneur. In fact, I would argue, that very few people should. With very few exceptions, people that have groundbreaking ideas, and who build organically sustainable business, have domain expertise that allows them to identify inefficiencies, and to build differentiated businesses to take advantage of those inefficiencies. Very rarely does someone magically come up with a new transformative idea just because they want to have a startup.

You know what department on University campuses typically creates the most startups? Engineering. You know why? Because engineers have deep expertise and training that typically focuses on applied technology development.

Evangelists like Wu, fail to remember or even recognize that starting a legitimate company - not some cult of t-shirt wearing millennials whose company will be dead long before the logo on their t shirt fades - is incredibly difficult and requires fortitude and the ability to deal with immense challenges. These attributes often come from difficult fields of study, advanced degrees, or working in very high-pressure, high-standard environments.

There are too many people (CU Boulder for example) who will throw bean bag chairs in a room with some 3D printers to show how serious they are about the innovation age. It's meaningless, a waste of time, and absurd.

headline: To Borrow Trauma Surgeons’ Eyes
commentone: I call on reporters and media outlets to acquire and publish the crime scene photos from mass shootings and the autopsy photos of the victims. Don't try to tell me it's too graphic. We need to see it. We need to see what a bullet from an AR-15 does to the body of a high school freshman. We need to have that seared onto our retinas and into our brains so that we can never unsee it, we can never forget it. We need to see it so we can finally defeat the NRA.
commenttwo:
It was a miserably cold and misty December day in 1965 at Lackland Air Force Base, near San Antonio, Texas, when I, and about 50 others in basic training were introduced to a new rifle for small arms training. The rifle range was wet and muddy but that didn't stop us from trying our best to win a medal for marksmanship. But here was the thing: the range officer gave us a demonstration of the firepower of this new rifle: the M-16. Described as the best killing machine a man could carry into war, we watched this rifle in action ‚Äö√Ñ√Æ in semi-automatic, and fully automatic fire.

The range officer was right. The M-16 was truly a killing machine and we were being trained to use it on other people in the event we were caught in a firefight.

Despite what you may hear from sport shooters at gun club competitions, or about the hunt in the woods, the AR-15 is the nearly same killing machine as the original M-16. The now infamous "bump stock" used in the Las Vegas massacre made the semi-automatic AR-15 fire like the killing machine I learned to use in Air Force basic training.

The Second Amendment was written when George Washington no longer had a standing army and most homes had a single-shot, flintlock musket available in the event the British decided to take America back. Armed militias could be formed to keep us free. A military musket was the same as the civilian musket. Not anymore.

The Second Amendment should not include the right to own military killing machines.

headline: What Motivates Voters More Than Loyalty? Loathing
commentone:
As others have already commented (echoing Paul Krugman), we need to reject "false equivalency" when evaluating the evolution of hyper-partisanship in American politics.

Only one party (the GOP) has waged an open hate campaign for the last four decades to define "Real Americans" as limited to "white, Christian conservatives" - while demonizing all other "out-groups" as "socialists", "radicals", "unpatriotic", "subversives", "moochers", "traitors", "Godless", "deviants", "perverts" and racially impure.

I've heard all these specific pejoratives hurled repeatedly by right-wing radio and TV shows for years at anyone who doesn't reflect the deep cultural tribalism of the modern GOP. This continuously virulent level of non-stop invective employed by the Right against "The Other" (i.e. the majority of diverse Americans) has no parallel in any other post-WWII "First World" nation.

This culminated in the epithet "Muslim, Kenyan socialist".

In short, "the Right started it". THEY were the ones to categorically demonize any and all Americans who failed the tribal "purity test" of homogeneous ethnicity, fundamentalist Christianity and knee-jerk conservatism.

IMHO, this unprecedented level of tribal hostility towards "The Other" is rooted in the Right's fear of losing the culture war. First it was the blacks, then the hippies, women, gays, non-Christians and then all The Others who demanded their share of the American pie.

And the Right is fighting to the death to hoard "their" pie.
commenttwo: This article is a collection of banalities. The basic reason for the growing polarization is the decline and marginalization of religion. Faith promotes two attitudes: that anyone who puts one's hopes in politics will be disappointed, and that this world is far less important than the next. Politics becomes not much more than an amusing game. If this world is all there is, though, the stakes become (ironically, in view of the left's dismissal of the notion) transcendent. Equally ironically, the more important politics becomes, the less it accomplishes.

headline: Why It’s So Hard to Invest With a Social Conscience
commentone:
How about if people with money to invest and want to do it in a socially conscientious way, first invest some of their disposable income into things like solar panels and insulation for their home?

I live in Colorado - with 300 days of sunshine a year. There is a lot of money here too. And yet there might be one solar array of panels per 40 houses. That's crazy. I also recently moved into a Denver house built in the early 1960s. There was no insulation in the walls and very little in the attic. For almost 60 years, people continued to live in this house and instead of insulating it, over-consumed a limited resource and over-paid the oil and gas industries. Totally insane. I've insulated the house. And put on solar panels. Both actions employed local people and helped the local economy. I've also planted many fruit trees and edible shrubs in areas where they can grow using directed rain water.... There are many ways to invest with a social conscience that don't include Wall Street.
commenttwo:

In CO, the state tax office won't direct deposit your tax refund to your bank. Instead, it sends you a paper check, and informs you that only Wells Fargo will cash it without a charge. You then get multiple emails from Wells Fargo about your account with them.

YAARGH

headline: A Whole Lot Is Riding On This New ‘Wrinkle’
commentone:
As someone who is neither black nor a woman, yet still loved A Wrinkle In Time when I read it around fifth grade, I can't help but feeling a little left out while reading this article.

I don't object in the slightest to the multiracial casting or the expansion of Hollywood norms, in fact I support them enthusiastically, but to hear of this story being "black woman-ified" makes me somewhat concerned.

We're already at risk of the very people who perpetuate injustice tuning out because they fear being displaced, and stories like this only enhance that false narrative.

Shouldn't there a way to support a multiracial, inclusive cast with people like me still actually feeling included?

headline: Can There Be Good Porn?
commentone: No. Porn in any form is disgusting, and harms marriages, hurts souls, and ruins lives.
commenttwo:
Personally, I think that "power porn" -- i.e., the lust for money, guns, political office, physical domination (another nuke, anyone?), and the various and sundry tribal enhancing status symbols like McMansions, Beemers and the gilded faucets and crystal chandeliers so beloved by our beloved leader -- are far, far more dangerous to the future of our society than sex porn.

Perhaps it's time to learn a lesson from the 'sex-is-good-for-all-sorts-of-problems' bonobos and wean ourselves from the blood-thirsty, alpha-male, killer-take-all chimpanzees.

Unfortunately, ever since Freud -- in fact, probably as far back as Augustine -- not only has "sex porn" been bad but we've been coached to "sublimate" (see, Freud) those sex porn desires for the more "productive" power porn desires.

It's time to reset the balance before we destroy ourselves and our planet with our never-ending lust to lord it over others and the world we inhabit.

Chaos is the antithesis of organized effort--little can get done, at least nothing good.

Our culture has gone nuts in its overemphasis on individualism, and individual competition such that ‚Äö√Ñ√∫proof‚Äö√Ñ√π of maturity means living alone, even if that results in isolation and the unhappiness that brought so many young professionals to my office. headline: Go Ahead, Millennials, Destroy Us
commentone:
You are putting us on, right? You are a puppy. It has nothing to do with age. It is essential sanity. Have you heard of the reality principle?

What you here call the facts of life are in reality the facts of death. Death for the human species, or at least a large majority of it. The occasional slaughter of a few American kids is nothing compared to what our government does to foreign kids, and that is nothing compared to what our economy is doing to the ecosphere, and at the bottom of it is the profit system, aka capitalism. If this continues it is clear that most of us are going to die pretty soon, along with wives and kids and friends and enemies. Let's get real. The name of the game is change or die and a sane person doesn't need outliers like this to tell them that. But hardly anyone is sane. Humans are herd animals and they prefer to remain in denial. Sooner or later a large number of them will panic and stampede, and I doubt if that will help much either. Our disease is called civilization. It makes us crazy. How do you deal with that? That is the question.
commenttwo: Now then, decades ago when I searched for my first professional job, the want ads were divided into men's and women's jobs. My husband had to cosign when I applied for a credit card, even though we both had jobs with decent incomes. If you ate out or flew on a plane, you smoked your neighbor's cigarette smoke, like it or not. Drunk driving? It could give you bragging rights.  The little woman could work, as long as she could keep up with the housework. Racial slurs might barely elicit a frown. Automobile safety standards were still eyed with suspicion.  And acid rain fell and waterways sometimes spontaneously combusted. So yes, some boomers have sadly turned into old cranks who still smoke like chimneys and brandish their weapons like trophies, but many others really did make the world a better place, just like the next bunch will do.

headline: How Did Europe Freeze As North Pole Warmed Up?
commentone:
The author of this article writes:

‚Äö√Ñ√∫It is fair to say that it is not as definitive as, say, the evidence for human-caused climate change, which is agreed upon by 97 percent of climate scientists.‚Äö√Ñ√π

headline: How Liberals Can Reclaim Nationalism
commentone:
At this point in the chaos we are forced to live in, I don't' give a rip what you call yourself. The truth be told, very few of us are a pure breed of the label we choose.

We, all of "us" have got to reclaim the 2 seats of power that continue to hold us hostage. In November, when we win back the majority of these 2 houses, the transition will not be easy nor very pretty. It is all too apparent that we have a lot of work to do to bring our democracy back the middle.

A historical midterm voter turnout is our only hope. Vote, yell it from the hood of your car, the roof of your dwelling, make phone calls, cast your vote.
commenttwo:
All due respect, to construe this as a way to "reclaim nationalism" is wrongheaded (or perhaps, just poorly put). I'm not sure that political parties can get past the current civil war between them. But as citizens we should not be thinking about "claiming" anything for our group. We should be thinking about how to find common ground that bridge the political divide, and to rebuild a common civic identity all Americans can share. As citizens we should be thinking about our shared values and how we can govern ourseives. This means not only best practices locally. It means we need to work out how together we can take our country back from economic elites and corporate interests, their toadies in Congress and the clown prince in the White House.

For a delightful PBS segment on how the co-founder of Tea Party Patriots and the co-founder of MoveOn.org became friends and realized how much they had in common), see http://bit.ly/2I0PqUC . This is from the new PBS documentary, "American Creed." And this is just the beginning.

again, thanks.

" We make art, and it simultaneously makes us."

I have recently been confined to my bed due to a battle with this flu. I subscribe to cable and have access to a drove of things to watch. All I was searching for was a film to watch that took we away from the headlines I read every day. A film that spoke to my hope in the human drama of life, a film that reminded me that our species contiunes to evolve bringing resolution to all this chaos we live in. Yes, and not a splash of human blood should fill my screen, and if evil should raise its head to make a point, it's life was but a Nano second. A film that awakens my hope for all peoples that inhabit our planet.

My clicking finger grew weary for the majority of stories showed me;
heinous bloody violence, shear hatred, quest for power, the pretty people are the ones that win, males species rules the roost, the quest for money is the road to successful life, the stuff we drape our selves in with speaks to our worth, the ordinary person may win a battle, but go back to losing the war.

So I watched the science channels, Documentaries that shared another perspective, Ted Talks, cooking, and gardening shows.

Ms. West , for a brief time I lived among a piece of the Hollywood scene. Box office profits lead the parade. Some films, true art will squeak through, but like everything else in the world we live in, the profit of money is king.

headline: Romance, Rough Sex or Rape?
commentone:
Jeffery Belton's, and his grandfather's, comment is dead on - it's the thinking and conversation that matters. People raise us, not screens.

It's the conversation between the two people interested in each other, and it's also the conversation between the children and their parents or grandparents or otherwise involved adults.

For me, it was also my grandfather who shared his wisdom over bowls of cornflakes late at night. He told me to see myself in qualities I admired - not necessarily in the gender on screen or in real life. And my adult neighbor, Nell, taught me that we could be irreverent about boys and men - she explained that many were immature, just acting like he-men. So I could see myself rescuing people like Stephen Segal, lifting myself up like Rocky, and probably above all, acting as a forceful change agent who could move mountains like my mom - no one person defined me.

I don't encourage censorship, like Lindy West's column, but I do encourage intelligent analysis and discussion like Mr. Bruni's column. Understanding that we are responsible for using our brains, and teaching children how to use theirs, is in short supply in these days of Trumpian ignorance and boycott-ready indignation.

When we raise thinkers - we won't have to censor - thinkers will vote with their wallets to see better quality films. Hidden Figures, Lady Bird and Black Panther are proof we have many thinkers among us - let's spread the word.
commenttwo:

As for "The Graduate" I'm sure the fact that Dustin Hoffman has recently been accused of harassment also gives one a new perspective on the movie. I've had to reassess so many movies I loved after learning that the lead actor is a jerk. Rain Man TWICE now.

headline: Saying a Prayer I Don’t Believe In
commentone: I read that a child's Kaddish prayer is a way of saying to G-d that the parent did the good work of raising an observant Jew.
commenttwo: When I explain the Kaddish to people, I find it helpful to reorient them to a more palatable understanding of God for progressive, skeptical and post Holocaust ears, based on Kabbalistic and eastern philosophical concepts.  I begin by explaining that all human beings are created in God's image (not just Jews), so when a person dies, the cosmos itself is diminished and.  Repeating this prayer over and over is a means of restoring balance and wholeness to the shattered Universe, of repairing God, Godself, even as we begin to fill that gaping hole in our own lives.  By praying for the restoration of order in a chaotic cosmos we are also slowly restoring order and balance within our own individual lives. That healing comes from prayer, but even more from the support of community and family implicit in the need for ten adults (a minyan) minimally to recite the Kaddish in public.

Months later the same symptoms flared up again, only this time I recognized their cause: I‚Äö√Ñ√¥d pulled a small muscle in my back using a StairMaster. My doctor still insists on her original diagnosis. A real confidence builder, don‚Äö√Ñ√¥t you think?
commenttwo: The medical world is rife with stories of patients who knew something was wrong and their doctors did not believe them, only to be disapproved by the patients when the patients otherwise discovered their own diagnosis. headline: The Macroeconomics of Trade War
commentone: Trump and his supporters often "go with their gut" rather than thinking things through. We should not disparage such instinctive actions, as this may be the best option for those with limited analytic skills. Hopefully, as Trumpian trade and tax failures play out, the "gut voters" will start to become a little queasy with the results, and will turn to more stable, if less exciting, policies.
commenttwo:
I agree the tariffs are a terrible thing, but the low unemployment rate is a specious argument. The reason the number is so low is that the gov't doesn't count anyone who hasn't looked for a job in a given period of time. If you look at the labor force participation rate, it's below 63%. Granted not all those millions of people are able and willing to work, but a number much, much larger than 0 is labor-in-waiting. The slack in the labor force is never talked about, but IMHO it's the mostly likely reason we don't have wage inflation, or more inflation in general.

Sure, you can make any number look better by excluding results that you don't want to count. We can declare that anyone who hasn't killed anyone in 90 days isn't a murderer either, and then cheer that the number of murderers has gone way down! But it doesn't mean we're any safer. So why do we not count the millions of unemployed simply because they're discouraged?

That said, I don't think tariffs boost employment.

headline: The Supreme Court’s Power Play Against Labor
commentone:
Unions and Collective Bargaining power.
This is a difficult subject. In Hamden and the State of CT, we have a too much power in the public employee unions, or, for complex reasons, they negotiated for overly generous, and unsustainable pension and work benefits, that now endanger the economies of the state and local governments. Meanwhile, we have workers at places like Walmart, Subway, and home nursing aides, who are so poorly paid, that they remain in poverty after working full time. How will this extreme haircut affect these two problems? On the one hand, we have unionized public service labor that is overpowerful, and needs a haircut, and poorly paid service workers in the private sector, who desperately need more collective bargaining power, and better wages and benefits. The benefit of this right wing hair cut it that it might bring some support to Hamden and Connecticut against the unsustainable benefits agreed to in the last 40 years or so. Will this haircut throw out many babies with the bathwater? Or will it curb the the excesses of big labor, while allowing for a new growth in unionization in the private sector where collective bargaining is so desperately needed. The answer probably lies in the practices of counties like Germany, and the Scandinavian countries, where the social net is stronger, which allows for more risk taking.
David Lindsay Jr. is the author of "The Tay Son Rebellion," and blogs at TheTaySonRebellion.com and InconvenientNews.wordpress.com
commenttwo: Along with Trump's obscene tax "reform", this decision - if it goes as expected - could be the final, killing blow against the individual.  Just as Citizens United pronounced that corporations are people, this will declare that individual human workers are not. Making the world safe for capitalism, not for democracy. Our only possible, unlikely hope is that the Chief Justice will awaken to this & be the fairness umpire he evoked in his testimony when he was appointed. Help us, Obi-wan , you're our only hope.

headline: When Elder Abuse Is Self-Inflicted
commentone: My mother-in-law went from a bad situation living in an apartment to a beautiful assisted living facility and is now in skilled nursing. We moved her out of her apartment for all the reasons stated in the article. She was not taking good care of herself, and her neighbors were forced to intervene many times to take care of her animals and her. She called the ambulance when she didn‚Äö√Ñ√¥t feel well and had repeated hospitalizations since she wasn‚Äö√Ñ√¥t eating well or moving around much. She regarded to move into the assisted living facility as imprisonment and punishment, especially as she had to give up her animals (which were not being well cared for). Once there, she continued to isolate herself, refused to go to meals, and would not partake of any of the many activities offered. Eventually her health became precarious enough so that she moved into skilled nursing, where she now mainly lies in bed, reading, watching tv, and sporadically eating the pretty awful food. I often wonder whether we did the right thing to move her out of her apartment. Of course we had to, because she was neglecting herself. But even though we got her into care, it didn‚Äö√Ñ√¥t stop the self-neglect. And by the way, she has consistently had psychiatric care throughout. It‚Äö√Ñ√¥s just a tragedy, for her and her son, who has to watch this unfold. I think the person who wrote about self-loathing because of aging may have the real answer. Her most repeated comment has been, ‚Äö√Ñ√∫I never thought I would get old.‚Äö√Ñ√π
commenttwo: As we age, we fall apart, piece by piece.  We make trade-offs and enter into lifestyles not considered socially acceptable.  My father valued freedom over all else and stopped seeing doctors because he did not want to be prevented from driving, even though he stopped driving by his own choice.  His dementia caused him to become lost if he drove further than the end of the street.  Urinating in bottles simply means a man has mobility/frequency problems (the horror, the horror).   My mother used a chamber pot in the middle of the living room.  Neither of my parents wanted to die in a hospital, neither wanted their lives prolonged once their quality of life deteriorated.  Neither wanted to live with dementia.  Both were in their 90's and knew their conditions were irreversible.  Mom, who became deaf and lost her sense of taste, ate chocolate daily and watched old movies; dad drank vodka, quietly.  Later, we found many cases stashed around the house.  We could have taken either one and put them in assisted living, placed in front of a window or TV, visiting occasionally until they passed, but they had that and more, at their home.  I moved home and did the cooking and the errands.  Once my mother wanted to see our first house, so we took a road trip.  Every afternoon we took out the albums and discussed family history for an hour.  Eventually, they spent more and more time sleeping.

headline: Where Land Meets Sea? On Your Tongue
commentone:
This sounds like a nice dish, a marriage of the American South and Northern Italy. As others noted, grits are different from polenta in texture and flavor. Both can be delicious. I take some issue with Mr. Tanis' method of cooking polenta. First of all, there is no reason to start with boiling water and fighting the lumps with a wire wisk. I start with cold water and stir with the tapered end of a cut off end piece of a broom handle over medium/medium low heat. Mr. Tanis cooks his polenta more than 45 minutes, because he uses very low heat and doesn't stir the polenta continuously. The stirring prevents the splashing of the increasingly viscous mass and assures aeration and even cooking. The bitter flavor might be caused by uncooked kernels and/or old polenta meal. After 35 to 40 minutes the polenta should be done. I usually
buy coarse cornmeal at supermarkets with a large Hispanic clientele in order to get the freshest product. Don't buy any fancy polenta meal in gourmet stores! They usually don't have a high enough turnover, and the end product will taste stale and bitter after all that strenous stirring. I speak out of experience!
And to the stirring: Consider it a combination of meditation and arm strengthening exercise!
I don't own a pressure cooker, but I am curious about the method and the results.

commentone:
Good article. It ends, "Now Mr. Xi‚Äö√Ñ√¥s open-ended tenure could give China a chance to plan long-term and carry out its policies systematically with ‚Äö√Ñ√∫a steady hand on the helm of a great power,‚Äö√Ñ√π Mr. Schell said. ‚Äö√Ñ√∫But it is rooted in Leninism, autocracy and control, which will make it a tremendous challenge for liberal democracies rooted in a different value system, especially in a world reeling with no leadership.‚Äö√Ñ√π "

It is suprising to think the Europeans are so dependant on the US for leadership. It would be useful, if we in the US could rally around an alternative leader, who could challenge our current president, with the leadership that is called for in the article here. Former Secretary State John Kerry is the name that pops up in my mind. Who else should be on the short list?

David Lindsay Jr. is the author of "The Tay Son Rebellion, Historical Fiction of Eighteenth-century Vietnam," and blogs at TheTaySonRebellion.com and InconvenientNewsWorldwide.wordpress.com
commenttwo: China is bent on slowly but surely having the whole of humanity and their local governments remade to tow the Chinese line, with the Beiling metropolis as Capital of the Earth.  As long as nations are more intent on wanting Chinese money and trade than standing up for their identities and values, the Chinese government and Mr. Xi will get what they want.  China is a totalitarian state, pure and simple.  The window of opportunity during which the rest of the planet can stand up and contain the expansion of this historically unparalleled autocratic overreach is not infinite.

headline: ‘Don’t I Know You?’
commentone:
Here are my thoughts, Jeffery: I'm guessing that their paths never crossed again after their unexpected meeting when they both decided to "take the A train." Nevertheless, they both remembered the meeting, and they thought about it often.

But here's a further thought: You didn't say if this happened recently or if it happened a year or two ago. Let's assume that it happened two years ago. And let's also assume that the man and the woman are both avid readers of the Metropolitan Diary and that we're going to see comments from both of them later today or tomorrow. As it turns out, they met again at her sister's birthday party in London the following spring. (This is starting to sound like a story from the Weddings Section of the NYT.) He is now back in London, and she moved to London to be close to her sister. They are dating, but they're not sure if they will make a permanent commitment. Only time will tell.

headline: Is It Harder to Grow Up in the 21st Century Than It Was in the Past?
commentone: As I‚Äö√Ñ√¥ve been growing up the 21st century, I can only speak on my experiences regarding my life- I can‚Äö√Ñ√¥t truly compare with what it was like in the past. What I can go on, is accounts from people that I know- and trust me- I get a lot. ‚Äö√Ñ√∫When I was your age I had to do _______, nowadays we have ______:‚Äö√Ñ√π now this is something I‚Äö√Ñ√¥ve probably heard a million times. And what I can gather from this, is that teenagers had a lot more responsibilities in the past, they had to take initiative of their lives at a far younger age and that was definitely harder. And that parents didn‚Äö√Ñ√¥t really have to worry about their kids as much as they do these day. I‚Äö√Ñ√¥m often told that schools are far more competitive today than they used to be, that the workload has gotten worse, and college fees have gone up. So I think this generation of teens has had significantly more academic stress than previous generations. What I have come to believe is that being a teenager a few decades ago is, without a doubt, different. But I don‚Äö√Ñ√¥t think it‚Äö√Ñ√¥s harder. Society will change, and with that change we will see evolutions in how we grow up- things will get easier and things will get harder- but parallels will always exists among the generations.

headline: Is ‘Black Panther’ a ‘Defining Moment’ for the United States — and Particularly for Black America?
commentone:
This movie is easily one of the greatest cinematic masterpieces Marvel has created. From the creative ancient history of Wakanda, to how the civilization has grown over time with technologies the which we can only hope to achieve, this movie tells a great story through a great perspective. It is action packed, driven by an interesting and intriguing narrative of the role of the Black Panther, the king and protector of Wakanda and their relations with not only the tribes of their nation, but with the world around them as well. This movie is proud to possess a majorly black cast, from the protagonist, King T'Challa, played by Chadwick Boseman, to the main antagonist Erik Killmonger, played by Michael B. Jordan, along with many other characters making up the majority of the cast.

Although this movie has a cast composed many famous black actors, I don't think this movie is going to change anything. Sure, it boasts a cast comprised of a majority of America, but besides those actors who portrayed a comic book story, I don't understand how this leads to something different happening in our country. I think its a great thing that Marvel made this movie, but that's all it is, a movie. There are many other cinematic stories of struggles the black community has faced in America, and you don't hear about those movies being hailed as cinematic masterpieces, not so much so as Black Panther, from what I've seen. Why is that?

headline: Can Venezuela Be Saved?
commentone:
The author simultaneously suggests that Chavez "destroy[ed] democracy with democratic support" and that his brief replacement Pedro Carmona's severe undermining of democratic institutions was what brought protesters into the streets against his rule. In other words, Venezuelans supported a massive undermining of democracy under Chavez, but opposed a massive undermining of democracy under Carmona. We're left thinking that Venezuelans opposed "democracy" under Chavez but came out in the streets to support "democracy" under Carmona.

The author's analysis here sheds more light on his own notion of democracy than any Venezuelan one. To answer the question "can Venezuela be saved?" we ought to know more about the latter than the former.

Perhaps Venezuelans had particular, substantive support for Chavez and equally substantive opposition Carmona. It may even be the case that Chavez's systematic empowerment of working people was more democratic than a system which grants individuals the right to vote for a leader in a de facto power sharing arrangement every 4 years.
commenttwo: Beautiful, well-written article.

Members of his own party routinely dismiss his ideas and joke about his ineptness. The White House staff consistently leaks unflattering portraits of him. Virtually everyone believes he needs to be extensively managed... Now, Trump impulsively & single-handedly erased untold millions in stock market-value... because he was feeling a bit tetchy?

headline: Dorm Living for Professionals
commentone: Great story and one of the reasons I stayed in the dorms for all of my college life. This developer should consider Murphy Beds for his rooms. Makes the space infinitely more useful.
commenttwo:
Good Lord, it sounds like at least most of these people are working full-time at jobs that would put them solidly into middle-income housing (e.g., a 1-bedroom apartment) elsewhere and all they can get for their salary is a single dorm-sized room, toilet seats being sat on and shower tiles being walked on by 10 other people? Obviously people who are homeless are much worse off, but we see in this situation how the resources of everyone below the 1% are being compressed downwards.

On a personal note, the 'who needs to watch TV, eat food and drink wine alone' line? Me. A lot of people, in fact--at least some of the time.

I suppose these places will only draw the types of people who WANT to talk to people every time they go into the kitchen; who WANT to chat over wine with housemates and the strangers they bring with them.

I know San Francisco is an extreme case in terms of housing prices, but I guess I just resent that this--this single room, not even a studio apartment--is in any way being normalized as being all that individuals who earn a middle class income should expect to afford.

headline: Fights Worth Having
commentone: I consider myself ideologically liberal but more of a moderate when it comes to the actual practice of politics. So a small piece of me wants to agree with Mr. Stephens' criticism of Democratic activists in this piece. But anytime I hear someone making this argument (no one has the sole claim to "Truth"), I would encourage them to carry their same argument back to the '60s (either 19th or 20th century) and see if it holds up.
commenttwo: Only sheer illiteracy about what the Enlightenment was could allow someone to write that it "champion[ed] social solidarity for the sake of empowering the individual." In fact the Enlightenment was radically individualistic‚Äö√Ñ√Æ'sapere aude‚Äö√Ñ√Æchampioned its notion of Truth, yes with a capital T, and resented having to ever compromise with what it saw as the forces of irrational conservatism, which were made relevant only by their residual inherited power. Which, ironically, is what Bret Stephens and NeverTrumpers (who, just be the numbers are poltically irrelevant, and no, facing angry comments in reply to your column in the national paper of record is not the same as Stalinism) are: relevant only because some residual locus of power hasn't been swept away by the changing tides of history.

headline: Goodbye, Pay-as-You-Wish
commentone: How about charging based on income instead of residency? for every $100K you make, you pay $25. If you make under $100K, admission is free. Just show tax returns at the door. It's beyond time to take away the many "free lunches" for the wealthy. If you get to take (often steal) money from the economy, it's time to put some back!
commenttwo:
Ignored here is the responsibility to the public for the non-profit status of institutions like the Met.

The Met has not been taxed, as it could/should have, except for the public service purpose of the Met. The theory is no taxes in exchange for providing the opportunity to see art by all. Now, despite its federal and state tax-free status, the museum levees these fees. This tax-free status is a gift of all the citizens of the United States, yet all such citizens except New Yorkers are being targeted. Many donors of art to the Met also received massive deductions from federal taxes, effectively paid for by these out of town visitors now being double-charged.

We have seen numerous cases of failure of responsibility by Boards of Directors, like the Met‚Äö√Ñ√¥s, to handle the funding. This is a period of unequaled concentration of wealth. It is a period of intense financial pressure on middle and lower-income people. Yet rather than develop innovative strategies to get the money where it is, the Met chooses to target the citizens it had pledged to serve when it received its non-profit status.

headline: How the Tet Offensive Broke America
commentone:
I was in Vietnam in a 105 howitzer battery right after Tet. The accuracy of Mr. Kirk's reporting doesn't impress me. Morale was high in my battery in the sense that we were confident that we could defend ourselves. As for the "Big War", we had no sense of it at all. Contrary to the many "Stab in the Back" comments, what destroyed support for the war was the accurate reports that Gen. Westmoreland was going to ask President Johnson for another major troop increase, which would have necessitated the mobilizing of the National Guard, depriving the privileged like George W. Bush with their escape hatch. Reaction against that idea was overwhelming in Congress and the poor general disappeared from the scene.

If Mr. Kirk thought that "FTA" only appeared after Tet, I don't think he knows what it's like to be a GI. As for fragging, a soldier with the 82nd Airborne who was in Vietnam in 1966 told of something a little less subtle than a grenade pin. The men thought their lieutenant was a total incompetent. So in the next fire fight they shot him in the back and killed him. If Mr. Kirk had fought the war, instead of writing about it, he might have a better story.
commenttwo:
>> Tensions among the troops was like nothing
Tensions were, not tensions was. Also ‚Äö√Ñ√∫barrack walls‚Äö√Ñ√π should be barracks walls.

headline: I Saw a Genocide in Slow Motion
commentone:
"Sometimes Myanmar uses guns and machetes for ethnic cleansing, and that‚Äö√Ñ√¥s how Sono Wara earlier lost her mother and sister. But it also kills more subtly and secretly by regularly denying medical care and blocking humanitarian aid to Rohingya, and that‚Äö√Ñ√¥s why her twins are gone."

This sounds exactly like what the Trump administration is doing to Puerto Rico.
commenttwo:
I appreciate Mr. Kristof's compassion for all people. What's happening to the Rohingya is horrible and is incredibly sad. Ensuring these atrocities stop will not be achieved by "naming and shaming," if that was the case, their would be progress at this point. Instead you have misguided individuals like Bill Richardson who go in, cause a commotion and completely take the US away from where we need to be - at the table. Asian countries do not respond well to being called out. This is especially true in Myanmar where the concept of "ana" - not wanting to embarrass another or make them feel bad - is a very important part of the society. You can say that Daw Aung San Suu Kyi and the military don't deserve us to respect their culture, but that means a conversation never starts and that we are no closer to solving the crisis than we were before. It's easy to look at this situation and give in to the emotional response, but it won't solve the problem and it will prolong the suffering of the Rohingya. What matters is finding a solution. Myanmar is a country that was isolated for decades, they don't follow international law, they will not be taken to the international court. We have to live in a realistic world where we recognize that the bad guys often win and innocent people die. We need to look for "second best" solutions that will solve the problem.

"...outside protests about the Rohingya have been largely ineffective, sometimes counterproductive..."

This is completely true.

headline: In West Virginia, the Politicians Fail, and the Teachers Rise
commentone:
I'm a native West Virginian now living in NJ, 3 miles from NY City. In the 1920s and 30s, my grandfather taught in a one-room schoolhouse in Mason County, West Virginia, and his young family lived in a cold, drafty log cabin, subsisting on potatoes and whatever they could grow and can in summers. My mother and her two brothers wore patched clothes, some made from feed sacks. My grandfather's surviving students are in their 80s and 90s now, and some still recall the wonderful education my grandfather gave them. But he had to give up teaching, the profession he loved more than anything, because he couldn't support his family on the state's meager salary. It was a devastating loss not only to him but also to the generations that followed who could have had such a fine teacher, had he been paid enough to survive.

Supporting teachers should be the priority of every state. I am proud of these good, strong West Virginia teachers, and I hope they win the raise they so sorely deserve.
commenttwo: Could someone be kind enough to post where donations to the Teachers Union, or food banks helping them out are?

This includes congressmen and congresswomen; any executive department employee; the judiciary; state, local, community, and NGO elected officials, leaders and officials; industry leaders; and foreign officials and dignitaries.

Anyone doing any business with this particular White House should - indeed, must - be constantly wary of changing, blow with the wind agreements in principle, and protective of their backsides when making any decisions of consequence that involve the Trump administration.

Putting aside domestic policies, God help our respected military forces, and this world, in the days, months, and years ahead. With this President, acting upon advice from such a handful of unread, uneducated and inexperienced senior advisors, directing those who upon orders from the President must trigger our nuclear launch codes, we are all in harm's way and in for a very, very rough ride ahead.

headline: Is It Harder to Grow Up in the 21st Century Than It Was in the Past?
commentone:
It's more difficult to grow up in the 21st century than the past, because even though things are easier to do than long ago, and people are much more informed, there are still new trends and bullying and drugs and pressure of coming out on top of an increasingly competitive school system. Humans keep wanting to explore, to reach higher destinations, to become smarter, to be influential. More and more expectations are being placed on our generations shoulders. ‚Äö√Ñ√∫It‚Äö√Ñ√¥s up to you all to save the world from global warming!‚Äö√Ñ√π ‚Äö√Ñ√∫Looks like your generation will have to solve that problem!‚Äö√Ñ√π ‚Äö√Ñ√∫You better become successful and make an impact on the world!‚Äö√Ñ√π Everyone wants to be someone, and I think it‚Äö√Ñ√¥s harder to grow up nowadays in the midst of all of the shootings and problems which place us in a certain position and sometimes even prevent us from reaching higher.
In the past it was easier to be creative and out of the box. It was easier to excel in the industries that had been just recently born. It was easier to make friendships, without the technology that we have today that makes us continually retreat into our shells more and more. Sure, there was still racism and poverty and wars and bad people, but not so much expectation. So it is probably harder to grow up in the 21st century than the past.

headline: Mr. Trump and the ‘Very Bad Judge’
commentone: Kudos for a well-written editorial.  As a retired civil servant residing in ‚Äö√Ñ√∫real DC,‚Äö√Ñ√π as opposed to ‚Äö√Ñ√∫political DC,‚Äö√Ñ√π we are long-confronted by mostly Republican attacks now led by a president who has no concept of leadership or of quality performance. Those jobs have been outsourced, at high profit margins.  Most of the remainder require skill, training and higher education. headline: Mr. Trump’s Destructive Trade War
commentone: Trade Wars are destructive to the interests of the US and Chinese elites, not the US working/middle classes. The data from the last 40 years indicates that most international trade has reduced US economic growth, labor participation, and wages. Median income has been stagnant since at least 1989. See: http://economics.mit.edu/files/6613/ Q4 economic growth would have been over 3%, but for a rise in imports. Male Labor participation has gone from 78.8% in 1980 to 69.2% now. See: https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/LNS11300001 We are running $600B-$800B+ Trade Deficits annually. See: https://www.census.gov/foreign-trade/balance/c0004.html This stagnation is also clearly seen in the lack of growth in the incomes of the Middle Class in developed nations since 1988. See: http://voxeu.org/article/greatest-reshuffle-individual-incomes-industria... Production processes were exported and the working/middle classes in the developed world were gutted. As noted in this thread, during this period US Total Factor Productivity declined from around 1.5%/year to -.2% as the newer production processes moved off of US soil.

headline: Romance, Rough Sex or Rape?
commentone: I first saw GWTW at a neighborhood theatre when the movie was re-released in the late 60's. My date and I both thought that the scene where Rhett carries Scarlett upstairs was hokey and unrealistic, that it was a standard trope of a certain kind of movie making or romance story, and not really relatable to our contemporary adolescent sensibilities at the time. I still think it was a hokey stunt and Scarlett's morning reaction was silly and stupid, and not believable even by  1960's movie standards. And I always thought that Rocky's capturing Adrian in the corner and making her kiss and surrender to him was equally hokey-- a standard Hollywood device-- since we never did that sort of thing (maybe I was lucky in that young women  I dated actually wanted to kiss me without my having to "capture" them?). So how did this behavior become a standard and acceptable thing for Hollywood stories generally? I was the culture at the time, and I hope we are finally moving past that, but I am  not reassured.

headline: Saying a Prayer I Don’t Believe In
commentone:
Your writing brought tears to my eyes. I understand the concept of Jewish tribalism. I was only able to explore the world of international development after my parents died. Concurrently I would seek out synagogues and Jewish cemeteries in the exotic and obscure places I would pass through just to confirm a feeling of, "My people". I'm not religious but I like the comfort of tracing the tribe.

My father held the conflicting views that the synagogue (of which he was a charter member but never entered) was the center of Jewish life and as he told the rabbi at a party, that religion was a monkey on his back. Apparently the rabbi just smiled. My father was a generous donor to the rabbi's discretionary fund no matter how he felt. The rabbi came out of retirement to preside at my father's funeral many years later.

headline: The Challenge of Doctor-Patient Relations in the Internet Age
commentone: I recently saw a doctor who wanted to spend our whole appointment discussing an area outside of his area of expertise instead of addressing what I came in about.  Then he recommended a treatment, and when I stated that it was contraindicated for people with a condition I had, he dismissed my concerns. As I try to respect the expertise of others, I let him go ahead with the procedure, which caused quite a bit of harm.  I should have listened to the knowledge I came in armed with, but instead, knowing that doctors feel we patients should be more acquiescent, I did as he recommended, and now am paying the price.
commenttwo: As a trauma and addiction therapist, I wrestle with this same issue all the time. I always applaud clients for taking the time to empower themselves through education. Once I've done that, I find they're more open to hearing my reasons for or against a treatment decision and then spend more time getting theirs. When possible, I like to dedicate one session to just educating clients on how to digest online information and how to discern reputable sources from not. Having a background in research pays off when working with patients on this topic.

headline: The Danger of Waiting for a Wave
commentone:
It was obvious to me before the election, as it was to millions of others, and it is doubly obvious to me now that Donald Trump is one of the most unqualified people that America could have elected to be its president. But I don't chalk up his win as a result of Russian meddling; I doubt the Russians had much of an effect on the 2016 election. Rather Trump won because of the gross stupidity of many Americans.

The stupidity took two forms: Democrats who favored a candidate who was smart but despised by half of America and all those who were willing to vote for a person who was obviously a clown and did not belong in politics at any level. Had virtually any other Democrat been the nominee of the party in 2016, Trump would not be in the White House now. Yet it is hard to understand how so many Americans could be so gullible and stupid that they would vote for a man who was so vastly under qualified to be president compared to his opponent.

If this country cannot bring itself to turn control of Congress over to Democrats in November after all we have witnessed over the last year, then this country is truly a sad country and deserves whatever incompetent leadership will bring it. Midterm elections are notorious for producing low turnout. This year should be a dramatic exception, and an overwhelming wave of voters should vote to throw Republicans out of office. If that doesn't happen, then it is America we need to point to, not Russia.
commenttwo: I think it is a guarantee that the Republicans will keep control of both houses in November.  Their propaganda machine and blind loyalty of their base will combine with Democratic incompetence to keep the current tyranny in place for at least 2 more years, but more likely all the way through 2024.

headline: The Escalation of Love
commentone: I have personally experienced end of life dementia in my immediate family, and while it's a terrible thing to say, accelerating nature's course could sometimes be the best way out for all concerned, the patient, who really "died" when mental faculties faded beyond a point, and the family who provide care or funding for it.  But, as always, an industry has grown up which profits from the extended physical survival of a "dead" patient and emotionally blackmails society to ensure it.
commenttwo: Beautifully written. I feel her pain and her forgiveness. Time, and love, can heal old wounds.

Putin, for a trivial investment of a few millions of dollars, has created a storyline he undoubtedly knew would be irresistible to American media, and every article and breathless report about the intricacies of Russia-gate and Putin's nefarious influence on our politics and democracy yields wildly inflated return to that man who rules a second rate country that is in fact simply incapable of posing any real threat to America.

He is dangerous. This is beyond a choice at the ballot box.

headline: Trump’s Call to Arm Teachers Resonates at Schools That Do
commentone:
I am a reluctant Vietnam combat Infantry veteran whose preferred survival aid was an M-16 with the selector switch turned to burst fire...3 rounds with one trigger pull.

And I will unequivocally say that no civilian armed with a handgun is going to be anything but a warm corpse and a blood smear facing down a weapon firing a .223 round, even if the rifle is in semi-automatic mode.

Arming teachers is fundamentally a stupid idea. You will never harden schools enough until you reduce the number of weapons available to would be shooters.

Any competent epidemiologist will tell you that controlling a lethal bug epidemic doesn't involve just treating the symptoms of individuals after onset...it depends on choking off the source of the infection at a point in the bug's life cycle that it is vulnerable to control.

Big clue: that isn't when the rifle is already inside the school building.

Control access and make the owner maintain eligibility to possess a combat weapon (rate of fire x magazine capacity) with bi-annual re-qualification. This isn't rocket science unless you failed to grasp 3rd grade arithmetic.

I don't mind an easy puzzle once in a while, though. Like Paul said, it's a nice ego boost. ;)

Thanks for another great puzzle, EC and HR!

headline: What Motivates Voters More Than Loyalty? Loathing
commentone:
A lot of new insights, but overall Thomas Edsall reflects my perceptions, and why I chose to become an independent after considering myself a Democrat all of the life. I found it interesting that some of my conservative friends whose opinions I have always valued did the same. For me the turning point was the amount of unvarnished hatred expressed by so many Democrats in these pages for anyone living in 'flyover country'. My own observation is that even in the 'pure Red' state of Oklahoma, where all of the counties have been Red in something like the last three elections, about a third of people still voted Democrat in the last election. The same attitude towards 'flyover country' resulted in the collapse of the 'Democratic firewall' and subsequently the loss of the election for Democrats.

A book I read awhile back was trying to express the attitude of some people. When asked what could be done to help someone that was struggling to make ends meet, the gentleman answered that a neighbor who was doing better had more cows than he had; could they kill some of the neighbors cows.
commenttwo:
I used to consider myself a liberal Dem, but then along came identity politics pitting every imaginable group against every other group, especially women against men. I only see it getting worse with the inevitable result that men will increasingly vote Republican and women increasingly Democratic.

Most of this is being shaped by political correctness, of course. Anytime a man tries to engage in a discussion about #MeToo or any of the complex gender issues we face, he is instantly undercut as a mansplainer whose opinions are illegitimate.

Americans like to think that Europeans value U.S. leadership, but that's just wrong. Europeans resent American banks for creating the economic crisis in 2008 that devastated the eurozone countries, and Europeans resent the U.S. military for its adventurism in the Middle East that created the migrant crisis, which has destabilized Southern Europe and fueled Brexit, as well as extreme politics in countries like Poland, Hungary, and Italy. commenttwo:
I lived in Central PA for more than 55 years. During those years I watched in dismay how jobs and industries headed overseas. I've seen empty factory buildings, once formerly vibrant downtown business areas turn into ghost towns and steel mills becomes museums. Our family business was compelled to close after almost 100 years and I had to return to graduate school at age 49 to start over from scratch. In my view both Democrats and Republicans are responsible for dismantling of almost everything in PA. The state legislature can never reach agreement. Schools across the Commonwealth are terribly strapped for cash and teachers have seen benefits reduced and salaries don't keep pace with the cost of living.
There are no politicians who are not guilty. Ideology, demagogues, and political loyalists who support their party line at any price are the cause of the destruction. Mr. Lamb says we don't need anymore gun laws but he supports more fracking. Fracking causes water pollution. Guns kill students. Is he really a Democrat? Then he says he wants to "work with the people on the other side." What is talking about? He just espoused the other side's mantra.
PA doesn't need pseudo Democrats that support Republican policy. We need a moderate Democrat who will fight for the middle class. Mr. Lamb is not going to be the man to do it. Democrats still aren't getting the message. The middle class wants real change and improvement not empty promises to just get along. How about jobs?

headline: Letting  Teenagers  Live
commentone: I note a common theme here, a claim that when people (young or old) shoot other people the intent is to kill.  No.  That's why our legal system distinguishes so many different kinds of homicide.  The intent of young people is more likely to be to show how they feel: afraid, angry, confused, disrespected, annoyed, lost.  I taught philosophy to young people for fifty years with happy results, because philosophy is the effort to "know thyself," to master your feelings rather than simply to display them.
commenttwo:
Dave, I have railed about the slaughter on our highways forever. No one listens. We are, as you write, totally inured and oblivious to the many teenage deaths on our highways, most of which are avoidable. The carnage on our highways is far greater than the slaughter by guns.
When I was a high school senior my first prom date was a very good and wonderful young lady, Judy Layer of Susquehanna Twp. Judy was cute as a button and I had a huge crush on her. We knew each from band from 8th grade. I fell in love with her. He warm smile and beautiful red hair separated her from the crowd. She was a beautiful, sweet young girl.
In the spring of 1966 I came home from college to learn that Judy had been killed in an automobile accident. A tragically unnecessary accident that could easily have been avoided.
I am 70 years old now and I'm still heartbroken. Last night, before this article was published I was looking through old photos and I came across the photo of Judy and me going to the prom. I couldn't hold back the tears.
You're 100% right David. We need to find a way to let our teenagers live. We need to protect and defend them and treasure their lives. And we must make a far greater effort to end the slaughter of our teens on the highways.
Judy I always miss you. I loved you then and now. I wish I could have come home to ask you out again.
Maybe David, maybe your column may influence some change and save the lives of our precious children. I pray that you're successful.

headline: Nakesha’s Demons
commentone: Tears are flowing.  Mental illness stole the promise of a life, Rest In Peace Nakesha.
commenttwo:
This story could have been written about my sister. She has suffered frm mental illness all of her life. I raised her son from the time he was twelve. Besides the person, the families suffer as well. It is hard to finally say that you've had enough. The angry phone calls, the accusations, the stealing. While the article only briefly mentioned it, often the mentally ill "self-medicate" with street drugs. Families also suffer from the "jedgment" of others who have no idea what is going on. They think that you are being cold and heartless because you aren't "takin care" of your family member. It wss difficult to finally tell my sster, no more. I was no longer going o continue to enable her to continue her self-destructive lifestyle. Eventually you have to protect yourself and your family. I felt guilty, but I just couldn't do it anymore. It seems like there must be something someone can do. When I ask for help from authorities, I am told that it isn't a crime to be crazy. Ever since Ronald Reagan emptied the mental hospitals, the mentally ill homeless have become the "invisible" people. My state, Florida, has very few resources to deal with mental illness and NO resources to deal with involuntary committment.
I don't have any answers, I just know that I finally felt that my first obligation was to my sister's son and keeping him safe. You can't protect everyone from themselves.
