headline: Romance, Rough Sex or Rape?
commentone:
"NO" doesn't mean "maybe", period. Consent is never negotiable -
notwithstanding Rhett and Scarlett's unseen frolicking in her bedroom, but
her eyes "atwinkle" the next a.m. in Gone With the Wiond (1938). Frankly...

Cute, your alluding to Sly Stallone's "Rocky", which won the Oscar instead of "Taxi Driver" and "All the President's Men" - Just another routine miscarriage of Academy Awards justice in Hollywoodland in 1977. Guy in wife-beater, girl friend unwilling, but overcome.

Carry us further back to the glorious Academy Awards of 1954, when "From Here to Eternity" was nominated for 13 awards and won 8 Oscars. Now that was worth staying up to watch, even though FHtoE was still "censored" under the Motion Pictures Production Code eschewing obscenity in movies from 1934 to 1966.

Movies aren't real life, and imagining whether romance, rough sex or rape occured in the sex scenes we never saw in the movies because of the "code" was a lot more exciting and memorable than watching Tom Cruise and his then wife, Nicole Kidman, in Stanley Kubrick's oh, so awful movie "Eyes Wide Shut" in 1999, when they let it all hang out, so to speak. Whatever - happy Oscar-watching to millions tomorrow night!
commenttwo:
Good grief Frank. Rocky was a masterpiece. Cliched plotline of a underdog in sports? Sure, but there are only something like 7 basic plots in literature, and therefore film. Amazing soundtrack, terrific directing, great acting, superb screenwriting. The worst part of the movie was the exaggerated title fight. "Network," "All the President's Men," "Taxi Driver," and a few others snagged their statuettes.
Adrian was uncomfortable not because Rocky was some disreputable groper. She was sheltered by her unlikable brother Paulie, we're never given the backstory on why she's codependent on the drunkard. Rocky courts her, and never treats her with anything but respect. She's further uncomfortable because he lives in a dump that needs both money and a woman's touch, his hovel of a room matching his character as a down on his luck boxer who lacks the brains to hold a real job. She does, remember, marry him and they live happily ever without any hint of adultery, domestic violence, or rape. Romance? Presumably. Rough sex? Ask Adrian.
The sequels were mostly awful, but that's Hollywood and the quest for numbers at the box office. The original was the opposite of a money grab. Stallone wrote the script and the studios refused to make the film with him as the lead actor. He insisted the film would only be made if he played Rocky, and took a big financial hit for his stubborn belief in himself. He more than made up for it afterwards. De Niro should have won best actor.

headline: Saying a Prayer I Don’t Believe In
commentone: "I am 'turning somersaults' (3x) each day." Now, THAT would impress me...and God too, I bet...
commenttwo: On a recent Shabbat, i stood to say Kaddish on the anniversary of my father's death.  I share Mr. Lefkowitz's struggle with the prayer to a God I don't believe in.  But at lunch after services, a man I knew only from our synagogue said to me, "I saw that you were saying Kaddish for your father. (the names and relatives of the deceased are printed in the program each Shabbat morning.)  Tell me, what kind of man was your father."  His question gave me an opportunity that I had never had - to talk at length about my father and his life.  It felt wonderful and would never have happened if I hadn't decided to observe his Yahrzeit.  (Anniversary of a death.)

headline: The Macroeconomics of Trade War
commentone: This is a great, fast read to highlight the silliness of Trump's idea.   We are getting what we deserve as Americans - a president with absolutely no understanding of economics, but even worse, one with absolutely no interest in trying to understand economics.
commenttwo: For an interesting take on the subject, see the Chicken Tax established during the Kennedy-Johnson administration and how it evolved during the years and the unintended consequences of such wars.  To this day, both Ford Motor Company and what remains of Chrysler, as well as Mercedes-Benz (and its Freightliner subsidiary) have to go through contortions to bring their light "commercial" vans and trucks to the U.S. to avoid paying a tax of up to 25.0% placed by the U.S. in retaliation to Germany and France for their enactment of a tariff on chicken shipments from the U.S.  This results in waste and higher prices to consumers on both sides of the war.  These trade wars never end well, never produce the intended results and history is witness to this.

headline: Trump Embraces a Trade War, Which Could Undermine Growth
commentone: Interesting that not a single Trump-hater has argued that other countries are not dumping their goods on us and requiring tariffs on our goods that they import.
commenttwo:
‚Äö√Ñ√∫‚Äö√Ñ¬∂the trade war ‚Äö√Ñ¬∂ could backfire, sending America and the world into recession‚Äö√Ñ¬∂‚Äö√Ñ√π

Actually, the more likely result would be a full-blown depression.

A so-called ‚Äö√Ñ√∫negative‚Äö√Ñ√π or ‚Äö√Ñ√∫unfavorable‚Äö√Ñ√π trade balance is the result of our buying more goods and services from other countries than the value of the goods and services other countries buy from us.

That means that jobs are created in other countries for workers who can now buy US goods and services which they could not buy before because they did not have jobs.

It also means that foreign governments accumulate dollars which they need to invest in order to protect the value of those dollars from inflation. There have been no better, safer instruments to invest them in than US treasuries, helping finance our federal budget deficit, keeping down our interest rates and stimulating investment in housing and other industries in our country.

The real reason trade has harmed the US is that companies that sell goods and services in the US have been able to avoid paying US taxes by keeping their earnings abroad.

If those companies had been paying their taxes the federal government would have been able to increase spending on infrastructure and other services, for example, creating direct and indirect jobs that would have offset some of the job losses from trade.

headline: What Motivates Voters More Than Loyalty? Loathing
commentone:
There is some irony here. Every Democrat I know thinks Republicans are evil because they see GOP politicians trying to take away people's health insurance while showering benefits on the rich. They see GOP leaders supporting the NRA even when that means a 19 year old can buy an assault rifle and shoot 17 children to death in a matter of minutes.

If Edsall is correct, however, the allegiance of GOP voters to their party has little to do with such policies and is more a matter of sheer tribalism. So the low opinion of GOP voters is in a sense misguided - they don't necessarily approve of what their leaders are doing. Is it reason enough to hate them because they support the man, if not the policy?
commenttwo:
Both political parties are broken. Neither could or would offer a real, viable candidate that we could all warm to. Instead millions of us simply loathed one, the other or both. Hillary in my view was the most reprehensible and unfit candidates ever offered. And I am a fiercely devoted Democrat. As for trump, loathing him was too easy. I also loathed his supporters. His psycho misguided troops all to easily pledged their fealty to him, while gobbling up the nonsensical foul-mouthed utterances that spewed forth from his mouth and his terrible tweets. What was not to loathe?
Today I am still a registered Democrat but there is not one that I support save perhaps Mr. Booker and one or two others like him. The rest are far left-leaning ideologues without an ounce of common sense or understanding of the plight of ordinary, once middle-class citizens.
Our jobs and industry have been gutted by both Republican and Democrats. Our schools have been all but bankrupted by both parties. The national debt is now, finally starting to become too large to casually dismiss.
Now too America's role and image on the world stage is greatly diminished by Turmp. It is also diminished by the Democrats gutting of defense spending and a former president's fear of military involvement to protect and defend America.
So, I ask, what is not to loathe? All of these politicians are complicit.
If we're smart we'll clean house in the fall. Until then loathing will have to do.

headline: What We Will Lose When the Union Carbide Building Falls
commentone:
What rises falls. In Manhattan - where space is at a premium (as it is in Hong Kong Singapore Tokyo, L.A.), it's only a question of time before Post World War II corporate modernist skyscrapers will be demolished like rotten teeth in favour of new implants. The vagaries of global finance today will be reflected in horrific monoliths bigger and better than the buildings (like Union Carbide) that will be "tear-downs" in New York City.

American architects hired by Big Business are bent on destroying the city with their megaliths darkening the canyons of Manhattan's shadowed streets.
Steel and concrete and glass buildings aren't plants or flowers bending toward the sun. Entropy exists everywhere on our planet. The hanging gardens of Babylon rose, flourished, fell, and are only remembered as one of the ancient seven wonders of the world. We Americans are living in Babyon Redux.
commenttwo:
Disappointing to just learn that the Union Carbide Building is going to be demolished? A good argument these days for keeping a building rather than demolishing it was noted in a speech giving by Richard Moe past President of the National Trust for Historic Preservation years ago in Berkeley, CA on ‚Äö√Ñ√πSustainable Stewardship and Historic Preservation's Essential Role fighting climate change‚Äö√Ñ√π

He said ‚Äö√Ñ√∫Up to now, our approach to life on this planet has been based on the assumption that ‚Äö√Ñ√∫there‚Äö√Ñ√¥s plenty more where that came from.‚Äö√Ñ√π With our environment in crisis, we have to face the fact that there may not be ‚Äö√Ñ√∫plenty more‚Äö√Ñ√π of anything‚Äö√Ñ√Æexcept trouble. Today we‚Äö√Ñ√¥re challenged to find a way of living that will ensure the longevity and health of our environmental, economic, and social resources.‚Äö√Ñ√π

http://berkeleyheritage.com/speeches/richard_moe.html

headline: When Elder Abuse Is Self-Inflicted
commentone: I'm a financial advisor in Florida, and I had a client who was sending her money to crooks in Jamaica in a lottery scam.  I called every authority: Adult Protective Services, The Dept. of Children and Families, the police, and the FBI.  They all sent out inspectors, but nobody did anything.  I finally went to court to sue my client for an incapacity judgment, which I got.  The court appointed a guardian to manager her affairs.  The legal fees were as bad as the money lost to crooks.  Our society is just not set up to handle elder self-abuse, but this has got to change.  I did have one success story with another elder client who developed paranoia.  He had three phones because he thought they were being monitored depending on who he called.  I reported it to Adult Protective Services, and they met with him immediately.  They couldn't tell me about their actions because of privacy rules, but I know I got a great inspector who was busting her butt to help my client.  These stories need to be told, and we all need to plan for our own aging and that of our loved ones.
commenttwo: My mother who was a hoarder all her life passed away over a year ago. It took the family many months to get through the stuff in order to sell the house. She would not share information for many years, but fortunately she trusted one child with her financial needs. Hoarding starts well before the senior years and may be a symptom of anxiety, depression, and other issues. Some have said even historical periods like the great Depression can make the seniors who suffer from hoarding in what they believe is a reason to keep everything - paper, plastic, string, whatever, because they were taught to keep these items during earlier years of deprivation and rationing. Is it the early years of abuse and neglect that pushes such seniors over the edge along with borderline depression and other ailments?

headline: A Whole Lot Is Riding On This New ‘Wrinkle’
commentone:
I'm a bit confused by all the race-related talk on "Wrinkle in Time". The book was quite ahead of its time, talking about broken families, working women, "Stepford"-style conformity. However, there are no African-Americans in the novel. It was written in the pre-Civil-Rights 1960s The main ethnic group mentioned is a poor Irish family. Other oppressed groups mentioned are "nerds" ( as we would say now) and the disabled. (Meg and her brother are geniuses, but she wears thick glasses and her brother seems to be autistic, which subject both to ridicule.) The moviemakers not only changed their race for the movie but seems to have made it a central theme, judging by this article.

I think it's a good idea: rewriting old heroic novels to give minority groups good role models like Meg. But I thought the moviemakers should mention that this is what they are doing.

headline: At Heart of Tight Race, Folks Who Picked Trump But Wish They Hadn’t
commentone: To sum it up:  You can't trust GOP nuts.  Other places should be warned also.  There are more nuts out there than Trump although they are being attracted to him.
commenttwo:
It's amazing IMO when people are so condescending to the people who admit voting for Trump and now regret it - yet they never, ever point fingers at the Sanders/Stein progressives who also contribute to this mess, in 2016 and now.

Some of those progressives stayed home in 2016 or voted for Stein/Trump. Yet in the midst of Trump's reign of terror, all they focus on is opposing "Republican-Lite" candidates - all across this vast country - for midterms. A Democrat has to pass their purity test as a candidate. What's dangerous now is that if a moderate Democrat wins, they call it "a win but not a victory".

Who are these people and why are they not called out publicly as deplorables - as they should be?

There are a number of angry Republicans all over this country who are getting their acts together and willing to vote for a moderate Democrat for the good of the country. Kansas is one place where you see them; perhaps Pennsylvania will be another. And you know what? These people have been Republicans their entire lives; they aren't going to just jump up and down and say "I'm a Democrat now!"

But what they are willing to do - unlike the deplorables of the left - is compromise to get the nation back on track with a moderate government. Then they'll go back to being Republicans - just moderate ones who hopefully keep better watch on the extremists.

Deplorable, defined: https://www.npr.org/2017/08/24/545812242/1-in-10-sanders-primary-voters-...

headline: Can There Be Good Porn?
commentone:
I think Stoya underestimates the potential for porn to "teach empathy" and "discuss sexual boundaries". Non-pornographic movies and TV shows have been discussing personal and social issues like race, gender roles, and mental health with significant success for years, and society has changed as a result. This demonstrates that the video/movie medium in itself can be quite powerful in educating the masses and changing attitudes. Porn that is done in a well-researched and thoughtful way surely could do the same with sexual behavior - it's all about what you show and what you don't show.

Of course porn can also be mindless entertainment, but so are many non-porn movies too.
commenttwo: It is an unavoidable fact that while pornography is not supposed to be a replacement for sex education, no amount of birds and bees explanations captures exactly what happens physically during sex, or why sex should even be considered desirable. Any young person who has listened to any intellectual explanation of sex will, upon viewing pornography for the first time, think, "Oh ho, so that's what this is about!" While it may not convey a feeling of caring or anything about real chemistry between people, the graphic   value of pornography goes way beyond the embarrassing explanations from parents or teachers in literally showing what physical sex is, which I don't think is a bad thing.

headline: Dorm Living for Professionals
commentone:
Different strokes for different folks, but:

1. I did my time hauling my bath caddy down the hall each day to the shared bathroom. I believe that's known as college. Once you graduate from college it's desirable not to do that anymore, especially when paying $1,400-2,400 a month to do so. How we've gotten to the place where people think that looks fun, well...that's politely called severely diminished expectations.

2. Do these people know the words "saving for down payment" or is that just a nonstarter now?

3. It's understandable that not everyone wants to own a home with metro real estate prices now. But why not rent a studio or share a 1-bedroom - with one other person - which has all the amenities of this place? Plenty of apartments across the country offer tons of social amenities now to attract residents. And those big group kitchens at apartment complexes? Those are offered to reserve for throwing parties, not actual regular resident use because they don't have their own kitchens in their $2400 a month apartment. (Seriously? Didn't tiny old apartments in the movies at least have a hot plate and a tub in the kitchen?)

4. It's all fun "Friends" right now but watch when a resident confesses his/her crush and it's unrequited. Or somebody starts dating one resident, but then hooks up with another one. I don't think the go-kart outings with all the "best friends" and hanging out in the communal kitchen after the inevitable messy relationships implode will be all that fun.
commenttwo: I'm baffled as to how an article about what appears to be a new take on SROs in the Tenderloin more or less fails to mention . . . the history and prevalence of SROs in the Tenderloin. (Beyond "formerly a residential hotel that served homeless and low-income people in the Tenderloin neighborhood," that is.) It's been a few years since I left SF, but they're not all gone at this point, right? And if they are gone, that seems relevant.

headline: God, Don’t Save the King
commentone: I am in agreement with the premise of this essay, but I think that Mr. Egan is being unfair by painting all monarchs as entitled buffoons. Kaiser Wilhelm and Tsarina Alexandra (via her feeble minded husband) certainly bear a big part of the blame for WWI. But King George V deserves recognition for his steadfast support of his country's democratic institutions, as well as those of the great French Republic, that ensured the defeat of Prussian militarism. And his son George VI (Egan's "Bertie") was a courageous and inspirational head of state who played his part admirably when Britain was all that stood between civilization and barbarity. Without losing sight of the fact that the key players in these historic events were all democratically elected leaders - Churchill, Roosevelt, Lloyd George, Clemenceau - credit where credit is due.

commenttwo:
Typical Friday for me, but only because Fridays always take me a very long time. Tried to think of Winter Olympics locations at 3d. The only two I could immediately recall were Lake Placid and St. Moritz, so I went ahead and typed in the latter, figuring I'd take it out later. Very FORTUNAte for me. Remembered IPCRESSFILE with the PC in place. Just chipped away in other areas. Had a couple of failed checks.

Never heard of a COUGHBUTTON. Was a programmer for over 30 years but never heard the term SLOTTING. Not only didn't know FOIAREQUEST, I couldn't even parse it after I had it filled in. There were some other unknowns as clued also. Did somehow remember SVETLANA with a cross or two. No idea why I knew that.

Thought the clues for CLOSET, ROCKFANS and DOZENS were outstanding. Good puzzle overall.

Wandering brain department: I wondered if anything like ALGORERHYTHM had ever appeared in a crossword. Yep - in the plural in a 1997 puzzle.

headline: Learning to drive at 62
commentone: Congratulations!  Here's to the adventures in driving in your future!

headline: Letting  Teenagers  Live
commentone: Americans risk their lives every day, when they drink a little too much wine, eat too many French fries or don‚Äö√Ñ√¥t exercise.  The risk of dying a car crash as a teenager is ~7 in 10,000 (2900 deaths per year over 4.1 million births).  Nothing will cut that risk to zero, heavily restricting teenage driving in urban and suburban areas might cut it to 4 or 5 in 10,000.  I would think twice before further restricting the most highly regulated and protected generation in American history.
commenttwo:
Apples and oranges, David.
1) Many more people drive cars than own guns.
2) Cars have a purpose in our culture that guns do not. Cars get you to work, to school, to the supermarket. Gun just emit bullets.
3) Reasonable controls on how people use cars-- testing, licensing, laws regarding seat belts and driving while impaired-- cut the death toll from traffic accidents.
Your suggestions are good, but comparing teen driving to gun violence is just a harmful distraction at a time when we should be focusing on controlling the use of guns to kill each other.

headline: Lower the Voting Age to 16
commentone: Bad idea. Sixteen year old brains have not matured enough, sixteen year olds have not had to support themselves and a family, and sixteen year olds are not generally concerned with long term goals. If anything, maybe the voting age should be raised to 25, the same age one has to be to serve in Congress.
commenttwo: Teenagers need to learn first-hand the difficulties that Republican lawmakers have legislated into the voting process. It ain't easy, young people. Begin with the ancient, mindless Tuesday voting (one thing the GOP didn't cause), and check out the documents requirements. Prepare yourself for an inquisition before you get a ballot. After you successfully vote, go home wondering if someone in Moscow tampered with your ballot. Perhaps you and your friends will feel the outrage that eludes your elders and force sane voting, kinda like you file and pay your income taxes: by mail or online. Caveat: Republicans, cloaked in the flag, will fight you with a vengeance.

headline: Mr. Trump’s Destructive Trade War
commentone: God help us when the threat of war isn't just about trade.
commenttwo:
What world are you living in NYT? Just look around! How many TVs, washing machines, cars, etc. etc. etc. do you see made in the US? This is the result, at lease in part, of the trade negotiations you tout! As the same time how many US cars or motorcycles do you see in China Japan or Korea? Etc. Etc. Etc.

We have been traded out of our shorts and the NYT still can't see that we are naked!

Of course organizations who benefit from current lower costs will object. Of course, US consumers will pay more. Of course anyone who exports may see some countries restrict their product or increase their tariff.

If I buy twice as much from you as you do from me, who is more impacted when we both stop buying? The answer is obvious. If your export sales are a much higher portion of your total production than mine, who is more impacted when we stop trading? Again the answer is obvious.

Common sense tells you that Trump will win while China, Japan, Korea and anyone else who practices unfair trade will loose. Yes, some US individuals and companies will be negatively impacted. So what. Thay have had the benefit of an unfair trade policy for years.

All of that said, US companies will still have to globalize to compete in the world market but they will be able to do so much more fairly.

commenttwo:
I can't shake the feeling that this is the thing historians will judge him on aside from whatever his role in his campaign's probable collusion with Russia. This has the potential to alter the economy. Let's face some facts, not everyone can, should, nor wants to get on the higher education merry go round. It may be popular to say that this will fail, because of the price increases it will cause, but the world of college for all has gone on long enough to show us that there are far too many left behind, including many underemployed MAs and PhDs.

I'm not a a Trump fan, but I'm hopeful here. I'm not an idiot. I know unions are weak, and that that was the key, but this is a start.

headline: Putin Says He Has ‘Invincible’ Nuclear Missile
commentone:
"Putin Shows Off New Weapons, and Warns U.S. and Europe, Too"

Putin can show off all the weapons he wants, but that is a meaningless posturing for consumption within Russia.

We in the U.S, as well as Russia, Britain and France all have enough nuclear weapons to blow up our entire planet several times. It's is called: M.A.D. which stands for: Mutually Assured Destruction.
commenttwo: We don't have a no nuclear first strike policy, and our nuclear arsenal is being revamped to include smaller "tactical" nukes, likelier to be used, some of which are being deployed on Russia's any number of the NATO installations located around borders. We have probably spent a trillion dollars (nobody really knows these numbers) on missile defense, and in spite of their doubtful efficacy, have lulled many in the security and foreign policy establishment into believing that the nuclear stalemate has broken in our favor, and that we can now win a nuclear war. On any given day, there must be 10 hysterical anti-Russia articles even in the most respectable of papers, a pattern one recognizes from our road to past conflict, except this is not some weak state. Liberals? they are as lost as the neocons these days. Putin is reminding the west that any fantasy about fighting Russia and returning home to normalcy during off-rotation should be replaced with a very healthy dose of reality. The fire will burn everyone everywhere. We are back in a new arms race, and it was our mismanagement of the aftermath of the last through hubris greed and bullying that caused it.

headline: Saying a Prayer I Don’t Believe In
commentone:

the faith.

I never heard of the Kaddish until I read it this morning, but it reminds me that even in our most challenging times, our Heavenly Father is still Great. My condolences regarding the loss of your Dad. May you continue to find peace and comfort as you recite the Kaddish.Job 1:21 KJV
[21] And said, Naked came I out of my mother's womb, and naked shall I return thither: the Lord gave, and the Lord hath taken away; blessed be the name of the Lord .

( Fred's wife sohy posting here )

headline: Silicon Valley Disruption In an Australian School
commentone: All this is fine and well.  But some advice: keep the screens out of the classroom.  Reading, writing, engagement with nature.  Get outside and hike, breathe in the cosmos.  Experiential education.  There are so many ways to learn.  But the mind must be engaged in an active way, in a challenging way, not in the passive construct of staring at digital images.  It's Soma for the brain.  This does not make kids smarter, more creative, or more empathetic.  It makes them sheep.  I taught flocks of them for twenty years, right out of high school, English and writing, and the pattern of decline was alarming.  It all started with the tyranny of screens.  Good luck.

headline: The Macroeconomics of Trade War
commentone: This issue goes away on March 13th once the special house election in Western PA is over.
commenttwo:
This might sound like a dumb question, but what if Trump gives an order for a trade war and no one in the government obeys it - I mean, not just at the cabinet level, but at the sub-cabinet and lower levels of the Federal bureaucracy?

It would be like a WWI battle where the crazy general yells "Charge!" and his soldiers just look at him and say "Bot bloody likely!". Generals can't fight a battle if their troops won't fight.

I remember reading that Kissinger gave orders during Watergate's endgame that specifically instructed the military not to pay any attention to orders given by Nixon if the tricky one decided to dust off the Soviet Union while drunk. Can't something like that happen again? After all, the rich creeps that are in Trump's cabinet stand to loose a fortune if our unbalanced and profoundly ignorant president decides to destroy an economic order that has given the world its greatest level of material wealth in recorded human history. That latter point probably won't matter to Trump's cabinet, given the character of its members; but the whole loosing a fortune part should definitely register. So why can't these people let Trump know that he just won't be obeyed if he tries to do anything as incredibly dumb as instigating a trade war? Especially so if doing so saves them all, including Trump, a fortune in personal wealth?

headline: The Rise of  Dictatorship  Incorporated
commentone: The Kurds are fighting the Turks in Syria, but that's not may primary disagreement with Stephens. He mentions Iran's interest in maintaining the "Shiite crescent" by helping Assad stay in power (Iran is a majority Shiite Muslim country and Assad is Shiite, although Syria is a majority Sunni Muslim country). The "Shiite crescent"? Shiite Muslims make up less than 15% of Muslims worldwide, Sunni Muslims more than 85%. I'd be a little insecure too if I were a Shiite Muslim in a world (and region) dominated by Sunni Muslims, Sunni Muslims who believe I am a heretic and should be either "reformed" or eliminated. Assad is a brutal dictator, but he isn't America's most dangerous enemy in the region, nor are the Shiite Muslims. That distinction belongs to Sunni Muslim extremists, funded by our Sunni Muslim friends in Saudi Arabia, who attacked America on 9/11, killed and maimed thousands of American soldiers in Iraq, and have been committing unspeakable acts of terror and violence against Shiite Muslims and Christians in Syria and Iraq. I'm no fan of Assad, but make no mistake: if the Sunni Muslim insurgents in Syria defeat Assad, Assad and the rest of the Shiite Muslims in Syria will face certain death. That's why Assad resorts to such brutal tactics: survival.
commenttwo: You neglect to mention a few other rising dictatorships such as Turkey, Egypt and Saudi Arabia.  Each of these countries have seen recent power grabs by aggressive autocrats but China is the greatest threat to western democracy.  Putin, Erdogan and their ilk aren't builders of any sustainable economic power but China has the ability and will to out grow the west.  The US and it's allies will be sorely tested by Xi and his disciplined vision for world domination.  We must avoid the urge to spend to much of our capital fighting the evil destroyers or we will be to weak to resist the evil builders rising in Asia.

headline: The Supreme Court’s Power Play Against Labor
commentone:
The nine men and women who sit on this court are supposed to be judges. Judges are supposed to exercise judgement after hearing and reading the arguments. They are not supposed to exercise pre-judgement based on their personal opinions. Pre-judgement, of course, is prejudice. Shame on them.

This is what we get from the highly politicized process we use to appoint and confirm (i.e. stack the court with) justices. And it's what we get from lifetime terms.
commenttwo: Assuming Gorsuch read the transcript of the previous argument that deadlocked, he almost certainly had no need to ask questions on the rehash.  The argument about not embarrassing a former partner or taking a cue from Thomas seems weak.

headline: Trump: King of Chaos
commentone:
King? You flatter him. Friend of mine knows somebody who's golfed with Trump. Trump apparently cheated during a game and my friend's buddy called him on it. Trump's response: "I cheat on my wives, I cheat on my business; why shouldn't I cheat on this game?"

This guy is king of nothing; he's not even that good at being bad. He's just a loser, in every sense of that word that means anything.
commenttwo:
Well said Mr. Blow. That's as good a description of the male in the oval office as I've ever read. It leaves little to be added in my opinion.

Now that we have a good description of the cancer that has metastasized from sea to shining sea, how do we get rid of it and make sure it doesn't come back in some other form? We have to acknowledge that Trump is a relentless and brilliant con man. He has hired a marketing genius to lead his next campaign for president. I think there's a good chance Mueller will nail him in some form or fashion but I also thought Trump was done for when he admitted to grabbing women's genitals. Not only was I wrong, Trump won the female vote while running against a female. Figure that one out.

One favor Trump has done the country is he has forced us to look at our weaknesses. He has revealed we are polarized and not striving together as a nation toward a common goal. I see pockets of resistance and leadership springing up here and there. But honestly what I see most is the fall of Rome. We need to wake up as a country and produce some leaders or else it won't be four countries trying to figure out how to manipulate Jared Kushner, it will be every country with a vision trying to figure out how they can continue to play puppet Trump. It would seem our country can no longer always distinguish between a reality show and fantasy. Somehow the cancer that is gaslighting our country must be removed before there is no more immune system to fight it off.

commenttwo:

The last thing that Black children need are overwhelmingly white armed teachers. Can you imagine the narrative that will swirl when a ‚Äö√Ñ√∫beloved‚Äö√Ñ√π white teacher decides to unload on an unarmed Black student? ‚Äö√Ñ√∫Oh, but he was rowdy and disruptive!‚Äö√Ñ√π ‚Äö√Ñ√∫Oh, but she was always disrespectful and getting suspended!‚Äö√Ñ√π ‚Äö√Ñ√∫Oh, but she stole a candy bar from the cafeteria!‚Äö√Ñ√π

Where I live in Kennesaw, GA, all three of my little cousins have reported taking classes with a racist North Cobb high school math teacher who routinely makes inappropriate comments about Black students and Black culture. When I ask them why they don‚Äö√Ñ√¥t report her or get my aunts involved, they all tell me that they are fearful of retaliation (they were all juniors when they took her class and would be applying to college in the following fall). This is the reality for too many Black kids across this country. Our lives are in danger every day we leave our homes. School is the one place where we shouldn‚Äö√Ñ√¥t have to worry about getting gunned down for the simple sin of being born Black.

-A Black Millennial

headline: Why It’s So Hard to Invest With a Social Conscience
commentone:
This article does not include IRA's which are almost double the value of investments in 401k's. 401k's represent 19% of invested retirement funds.

I mention this because in an IRA, unlike 401k's, one can invest in individual companies. This makes it much easier to isolate those companies you "don't" want to invest in, i.e. Smith & Wesson. In effect you can build your own mutual fund made up of companies you value. Whether it be 3 or 20 or more.

headline: Why Sessions Is Right to Stand Up to Trump
commentone: In the land of the blind, the one-eyed is king.
commenttwo:
I was born and raised in Alabama and recognize Jeff Sessions' genteel brand of racism for what it is, so I will not go overboard with overbroad praise for his honor and integrity.

On the other hand, he has repeatedly demonstrated his respect for both the rule of law and legal ethics (both of which unquestionably demanded his recusal from the investigation of the Trump campaign) and even more importantly, for the proposition that the Justice Department not be used as the president's personal sword and shield. And deep down in his racist soul I believe he is a true patriot.

I also suspect that even though he is recused from managing the Mueller investigation, he has reviewed enough of the evidence to know it is critical to our democracy's future that it be allowed to proceed. And he knows his boss well enough to know that if he resigns it will not, that our president will find a way to replace him with someone far less scrupulous of the integrity of the Department of Justice.

So God bless, Mr. Sessions, and hang in there. You may be the most important shield of the Mueller investigation we have--as I expect you know, given your oh-so-public dinner with Rod Rosenstein. Perhaps your willingness to endure the president's schoolyard taunts will, at the end of the day, redeem your considerable flaws.

headline: ‘The Assassination of Gianni Versace’ Episode 6: A Nothing Man
commentone:
To me, the operative word in the title has always been "assassination." Why not "The Murder of Gianni Versace?" "Assassination" has a meaning distinct from "murder." The series is not so much about Versace as it is about what led to his death and why he died.

I don't think Murphy's intention was to focus on Versace any more than Shakespeare intended to focus on the character of Julius Caesar in "The Tragedy of Julius Caesar." Brutus is the central character, not Caesar, who dies less than halfway through the play. Cunanan does not exhibit the ennobling characteristics of the tragic hero because he has no self-knowledge. The reverse chronology intentionally makes it dramatically impossible to show such self-knowledge developing.

To add to Toni's point, Andrew sees life as a series of transactions for commodities. Only knowing Versace's public personae, he wrongly sees Versace as the embodiment of that world view. His mother's pride at being able to brag about Andrew, as well as Andrew's revelations and lies about his childhood, may suggest where this idea came from.

Having hit bottom, Andrew cannot control his psychocultural mania. Unable to own Jeff and David, he kills them. He kills Miglin for the money and payback to Blanchard, etc. He kills the gardener for the truck. His transaction with the older man and the hustler in Miami are of a piece. In his mind, killing Versace is an assassination because it is almost a "political" act, killing the lies of his worldview.
commenttwo: This isn't a review, it's a synopsis.

This quote from the article; ‚Äö√Ñ√∫We look at places that have dormant or growing Democratic DNA, and this one has neither,‚Äö√Ñ√π said Meredith Kelly, a spokeswoman for the committee. ‚Äö√Ñ√∫I think people underestimate that this is a tough district.‚Äö√Ñ√π, is the reason that Trump won.

Tough district! Really? No kidding. But THAT is what you are paid for. Go into those districts and argue your case/policy. Earn the votes! In order for DEMs to have popular policy that can be made into meaningful laws, they must engage with all aspects of our country. The process of debating about policy at the grass roots level is good for both sides of the debate. It is the natural education process that is meant to go along with democracy. Both sides learn from it.

‚Äö√Ñ√∫People say they‚Äö√Ñ√¥re conservative, and then it turns out things aren‚Äö√Ñ√¥t what they say once they get into office,‚Äö√Ñ√π

commentone: Having spent years overseas in a country with an advanced mass transit system (clean, economical, on time and technologically cutting edge) I knew I would have to "get with the program" - aka drive. - when I returned to the US. Unfortunately my state has terrible infrastructure, awful traffic, scarce parking, etc so I decided why not live in the city? And I did. No commutes, no maintenance, no high gas bills, (too few electric car stations), no nothing. Plus with Lyft and Uber I'm set. Compared to my friends who complain of long commutes into town that start as early as 4:30 am I walk to or take a short bus everywhere in town. Albeit my retired life allows this but I have maintained my driver's license. It serves as ID.

headline: Nakesha’s Demons
commentone:
Like many other readers, I was profoundly touched by this story, especially so, because my daughter is a Williams grad. I was touched because, knowing Williams, I realized how high Nakesha had soared before her tragic descent.

What many people may not realize about Williams is that for decades, US News has consistently rated it the top Liberal Arts college in the nation...the "Harvard" of small colleges, if you like. It is extremely competitive (taking only a tiny percentage of highly qualified applicants) and expensive: a year (with tuition, room and board), now costs $66,240. The school takes only the "best and the brightest" and--one would ascertain from this story--the most caring.

The article raises the important question: "Should mentally-ill people be forced to receive treatment?'

After reading this sensitive and beautifully-written piece, I would say "Yes!"
commenttwo:
This is a tragic story and many of the earlier comments capture my thoughts and feelings about this lovely woman and her heartbreaking mental illness.
I think we are wrong not to intervene. Recently, I have read some very interesting articles coming out of Scandinavian countries which present new approaches for helping people manage their mental illness. A key approach is
for the psychiatrist to enter a partnership with the individual and help he/she learn the patterns of their illness, when they are losing clarity and the delusional thinking is coming into action. Along with this approach, options of medications are considered. I think this approach could be helpful because the individual is able to manage the illness and, potentially, can uphold dignity and responsibility.
If people can learn skills to manage their illness, the concerns about housing, hygiene and general well-being can be addressed. Unfortunately, so often, new concepts take a longish time for acceptance and utilization into the mainstream of a profession.

Supposedly, we can't afford to have Trump with his finger on the nuclear button because he's too impulsive, a refrain which  Kim Jung Un is only too happy to echo. Brilliant. Has Trump pressed the button? The threats he has been making may not endear him to his critics, but his intended audience is not them but Kim Jung. So far it has worked. Now Kim is proposing talks with the US. Trump might very well jump at the chance if his goal was to placate his domestic critics, but Kim would only interpret that as a sign of weakness. The Democrats try to portray him as impulsive. They should be so impulsive. They then might have won the election. Now they can only play their fake narratives which endlessly drone in the background.

headline: Tariffs Are Small Economically, but Big Symbolically
commentone: Market-makers are a fickle lot. They have many reasons for their various transactions ranging all the way from panic-selling to calculated risk-taking and avoidance. Millions of them are not even human but computerized buyers and sellers that trade in nano-seconds. The problem is they have not adequately factored in the mercurial Trump into their calculations. These are the losers, of course. There are just as many who hedged their bets in various ways and turned others' misery --if bots have feelings--, in to their own fortune. But there is a silver lining for the rest if us. Today's dip can become tomorrow's upswing. Then the Times will be running articles on how little effect the market has on the vast numbers of Trump's base who like most of us do not make money from markets but merely live their lives and get along as best they can.

headline: When Elder Abuse Is Self-Inflicted
commentone: I plan for the future. My parents were an elderly couple that lived in a dump that could have used a housekeeper. After my mother passed away at 80 I literally besieged my father (with a network of friends, as it does take a village) to move into a retirement community. I was concerned about his mental well being living alone, creating daily routines and a change of pace. It worked. Left to his own devices he would have become one of those old decrepit men living among boxes of junk and eating unhealthy options. Yes he resisted and he swore by the overrated American principle of independence but as his daughter I saw the writing on the wall. There is no dignity in aging badly in place and it is not an independence issue. There were many times he remarked at how lucky he was to have moved to the community and often thanked me.  He spent 7 years in comfort and among friends who appreciated him. I plan to do the same for myself - plan ahead and not wait till old age creeps up on me. Another old veteran acquaintance is literally living in squalor despite having the financial means for assistance; his children who live in another state have given up trying to help him. He is not doing well medically but refuses all external assistance. When he goes he will likely die a solitary death - very sad, very unfortunate. I considered that his children did not try hard enough as I had. Perhaps that is an unfair judgment but I believe we are the caretakers of our aging parents.

headline: Why It’s So Hard to Invest With a Social Conscience
commentone:
There are cheap, socially-conscious index funds that might appeal to New York Times investors. While they don't nix every iffy company, they're worth researching. (VFTSX and TRSCX come to mind.) But I'm incredibly wary that people who want completely divest themselves of every trace of evil in the corporate world‚Äö√Ñ√Æfirearms, fossil fuel, nuclear energy, palm oil, labor disputes, privacy concerns, the list goes on and on‚Äö√Ñ√Æare liable to get ripped off by inevitably embracing active management.

I used to own an actively-managed, socially-conscious fund with an expense ratio approaching 0.9%. It was regarded as one of the best in its peer group, and it got trounced by the S&P 500 for three years before I decided I had enough. I moved my money into Vanguard's Total Stock Market Index, where I currently pay an expense ratio of 0.04%. If you hold such a fund for thirty years, those 80+ basis points add up to hundreds of thousands of dollars. Where does that money go if you don't keep it? Straight into the pocket of some of the wealthiest people on the planet. Not very progressive, right?

Index funds are a game-changer and deserve a place in most Americans' portfolios, because they remove Wall Street middlemen from the equation entirely. Yes, 0.02% of your money gets invested in gun manufacturers. But that's a small price to pay when your investment serves you and only you, not your fund manager. There are better ways to fight the gun lobby than making the rich richer at your expense.

headline: Fights Worth Having
commentone:
Stephens seems to be chiding Democrats to accept a more centrist position than Bernie Sanders or Elizabeth Warren want. The problem with the centrist Democratic position we got under Bill Clinton and Obama, and more of same promised by Hillary, is that it failed completely for the poor, the working and middle classes.

That centrist position has given us worsening climate change, never ending wars, bailing out banks while abandoning debt ridden (former) home owners, unaffordable higher education and unaffordable and chaotic healthcare.

As a campaigner, Trump won by promising to help the working and middle classes. He promised to wreck establishment politics to help those classes. (Whether he leaves those promises unfulfilled is beside the point. He knew where people were hurting.) Hillary Clinton lost because she was establishment politics promising more of same.

The necessity of Democrats moving to a populist Sanders-Warren left isn't a matter of choice. It's the only viable position left after the complete failure of "centrist," big corporation, big money Democrats -- the Clintons, Obama, Biden, Pelosi, Schumer -- to help the poor, the working and middle classes. You can't compromise with complete failure, and that's what centrist Democrats have given us.

headline: How the Left Wins the Culture War

commenttwo:
Mr Brooks,
Your efforts at promoting compromises between the left and right are well intended, but doomed. Republicans doomed compromising in 2009 when they vowed to support absolutely nothing that Obama and the Democratic Congress might propose, even when those Democratic proposals -- the ACA, Obama's Grand Bargain on entitlements -- were essentially conservative ones.

The blind Republican opposition to anything from Obama and Democrats made subsequent compromise impossible and taught the left that any progress on the nation's problems meant vanquishing the right. That's where we are now, for better or worse. Sorry to say, Mr. Brooks, the left compromising with the right is no longer an option.

The only hope the left has in making improvements is to do what FDR and LBJ did: Implement improvements over the objections of the right, and when the masses saw that such programs like Social Security, Medicare, Equal Rights benefited everybody, the programs were accepted by all reasonable people.

That kind of production of the obvious good is what an uncompromising left needs to do with clean energy, Medicare for All, tuition free higher education, minimum wages, fairer taxes. The right can then howl in protest all it wants to, but nobody's listening.

After the Euorpean Campaign was over in May of 1945,
the Army planned to send soldiers to fight in the Pacific.
A large majority of those soldiers informed the Army that they
would not go, and the Army fearing that they would go AWOL
once they returned to America and were re-united with their
families informed Truman. That is one reason why Truman dropped

headline: Why It’s So Hard to Invest With a Social Conscience
commentone: My question is, what's the point of not owning stocks in unethical companies? Unless you're buying an IPO, you're not providing funds to the company itself--you're just paying another investor. In fact, the term "investor" itself is a misnomer--the vast majority of stock owners aren't investors, they're speculators, people hoping to sell the stock later after the price has gone up. When you buy a stock, you're bumping up the price a teeny bit, but otherwise, what difference does it make who owns it? In fact, an argument could be made for intentionally buying unethical companies in order to have some leverage to change their behavior.

headline: Can There Be Good Porn?
commentone: If the author, Stoya, were so proud of her vocation, then why not use your real name? Yes, porn will always exist, but don't blame piracy for porn's raw impact on social attitudes, especially toward women. The issue here is that most viewers - especially young males and females - generally do not engage in conversations with their parents or SOs about what they take away from porn. They aren't going to bother watching the "tutorials" and "counseling sessions" padding these productions. They do not necessarily distinguish or even have the sexual experience to understand between scripted and real-life sexual situations. The typically secretive nature of viewing porn means it is a fantasy land with no defined borders and scant post-analysis or discussion. It dehumanizes the emotional aspects of sex and normalizes using surgery-enhanced women as brainless props, further devaluing females. There is very little "real" about porn, except that viewers too often don't even recognize that real-life aspect.

headline: Goodbye, Pay-as-You-Wish
commentone:
So, there was plenty of money, but, it was horribly mismanaged. Now, everyone who didn't mismanage the money has to pay for that mismanagement. Why does this sound familiar? It almost sounds like a bad tax bill. Or a war of choice. Or the better judgement of the majority being subjugated to the runaway criminal negligence of the minority.

"You're going to pay for my mistakes!", is about as American as you can get these days.
commenttwo:
Can we all agree that, considering how messed up the United State's value system is right now, it's pretty amazing that we have any museums at all?

After all, the objective and main benefit of public museums isn't profit. It's knowledge. Joy. The love of the arts. An illumination of the past. An embrace of the common goals, trials, desires and aspirations of human history. A celebration of what makes us human. What moves us and touches us. An homage to the artistic giants of the past, as a recognition of their contributions to our shared humanity. The magic of deep communication through, mostly, inanimate objects. The experience of awe. Joy.

Like public libraries, museums are a reminder of the better angels of our nature. Of the human desire to be and live in a truly civilized society.

In short, all the things that really matter. That really matter. All the things that seem so increasingly irrelevant, trite and meaningless to those who are currently running the country. To the current mood of the nation.

Museums are a bulwark for the idea that life is precious. That life has meaning. Life is important. Life is fragile. And, most importantly, that life can be beautiful.

Museums are one of the greatist gifts one age can give to another. A repository of humanity.

So, whatever you may feel about the money aspect, at least we still have them. And I thank God for that. Long live the arts!

headline: How Did Europe Freeze As North Pole Warmed Up?
commentone: This is further evidence that global warming does not necessarily mean balmier temperatures in the temperate zones, but rather destabilization of the jet stream bringing arctic air to lower latitudes and warmer air to the higher latitudes. Melting of sea ice in the polar regions and blizzards, hurricanes and flooding below. Climate change will certain change the climate for all. How climate will change and who will benefit and who will suffer still remains to be seen. We have done and we will all feel the consequences. The only question is how will the climate change affect the entire planet.
commenttwo: Temperatures in Norway were much more moderate than reported: 5 F or -15 Celsius rather than -42 Celsius (see https://www.timeanddate.com/weather/norway/oslo/historic?month=2&yea.... The reported numbers might have been the "real feel" temperature. This is not to say that it hasn't been unusually cold in Europe the past few weeks but please be careful with the numbers.

headline: How Liberals Can Reclaim Nationalism

‚Äö√Ñ√∫It is a state in which all members have the same rights and opportunities.‚Äö√Ñ√π This is a utopian fantasy. How can people truly have equal rights, with the stark difference in wealth that exists? Answer: They can‚Äö√Ñ√¥t.

Nationalism and patriotism are forever tainted terms. What Mounk is proposing would require a collective reprograming of how we perceive society.

It would be wonderful if humans could embrace a single tribe ‚Äö√Ñ√¨ humanity ‚Äö√Ñ√¨ that would recognize common goals and challenges. But racism, religion, sexism, power-lust, and capitalism have all colluded to fractionalize the human species rather than unify it. Realizing ‚Äö√Ñ√∫a common future fair to all‚Äö√Ñ√π would necessitate stripping humans of contrived tribal identities they misguidedly cling to for comfort and sense of purpose.

The only way toward a common collective identity is to force capitalism to recognize the social contract - that there is another kind of profit other than financial profit i.e. social profit. But capitalism is a rapacious shark that runs on greed, the myth of the free market, and socially toxic financial regulations that give corporations license to seek profits only for their shareholders.

Capitalism is the ‚Äö√Ñ√∫half-wild‚Äö√Ñ√π beast that needs to be domesticated. To do that we also need to re-imagine our democracy and recognize that, from day one, it was never meant to be egalitarian, but a process ‚Äö√Ñ√¨ contrary to national myth ‚Äö√Ñ√¨ intentionally designed to keep power and wealth in the hands of a few.

headline: How the Left Wins the Culture War
commentone:
David, I'm with you in the repeated undercurrent to your columns that identitarian politics can be deeply flawed. Identity informs perspective but is not itself a monopoly on perspective, and plenty of educated people can speak truth to power despite the terrible affliction of majority status.

But, come on man: Leftists are not tribalists just because the Democrats big tent includes more tribes.

Primitive tribalism is trying to deport or ban the brown-skinned. It is curtailing programs and agendas that disproportionately benefit women, poor people, and minorities (be it consumer protections or defense of civil rights, etc.) because your base is hostile to diversity and expansion of opportunity.

Insistence on recognizing people's basic humanity as a barrier to entry in public discussion is hardly the tragic career-ending boundary shift you make it out to be; it's what should have been happening all along. All progressives are telegraphing is: Go ahead and be against gay marriage and cater to the like-minded should you choose, just don't expect others to view you as a tolerant person when you do.
commenttwo: Oh yay. Today's mental pretzel is massive projection. Wouldn't it be easier to give up the ghost on Republicans, David? I don't think you mean to advocate bad or hateful policies (even if you're willing to tolerate those outcomes), so whatever you believe or once believed, surely today's party does not represent you.

headline: How the Tet Offensive Broke America
commentone: Those who believe the war was won because of Viet Cong and NVA losses after Tet are living a pipe dream. Without the support of the population, there is no way we could have "won". On my first patrol through a village near Da Nang in July, 1968, the two reactions I got from the villagers were "Please don't hurt me Mr. Marine" and "If I had a gun, you'd be dead" - hardly the support for the cause we had been told existed among the South Vietnamese. It's easy to blame the media for the outcome, but actual research shows that the US populace lead, rather than followed the media. After Tet, it was abundantly clear that the war could not be "won". As other commentators have noted, it was obvious from history that we couldn't "win" even before the first advisors landed there.

commentone: I was fortunately never in an accident as a teenager (or since), but with thirty years of retrospect I can say with certainty that it was a bad idea for me to get my license at the age of 16: too many close calls, too much needlessly risky behavior. 18 or 20 is more like it.
commenttwo:
Using smart phones while driving also needs more attention. With cars now having Wi-Fi (a nutty idea, in my opinion) the issue goes far beyond texting and voice calls. Many teens and far too many adults seem to think both that they are different, i.e., that they can be "good" drivers, but dial that phone or send that text without a problem, and that there is little price to pay. Stand on a CTA platform in the middle of Chicago's expressways and watch how many cars have drivers, whether traffic is stop & go or fast moving, are holding smart phones and looking from phone to road and back again. It is 'against the law' in Illinois.

The wired generation, which thinks it can text safely anywhere including driving or crossing a busy street without consequences must be confronted with good laws and intensive enforcement or many more lives will be lost.

headline: Nakesha’s Demons
commentone: Thank you for this haunting story.  The profound sense of loss over the course of her tragic and gifted life is staggering.  It is such a tragedy that mental illness remains such a stigma in this country.  If children come to school coughing or showing signs of a contagious disease, we are prepared to intervene and seek heip.  How do we identify children who are being molested to intervene? How do we identify people who are coming undone before our very eyes and get them help before they are too far gone?  So much of her life was interrupted; molestation, separated from her mother, her mother's illness and eventual death, so much pain!  If we regarded mental illness and the mentally ill with the care and treatment needed, perhaps then we will be able to save the Nakisha's, help them prosper in their gifts and live full lives.  My heart aches!
commenttwo:
This story illustrates one of the saddest sides of working with the homeless. There are simply some folks who cannot be helped to shelter and treatment short of physical restraint (which works for shelter, but is never a solution). I ran a church-based social service center in Chicago about 20 years ago. There were always the folks who, if gotten into a room by an agency, would in short order be back on the street. Many of them, like Nakesha, were paranoid. They simply felt safer on the streets because in housing they felt trapped and sure that sinister voices were coming out of the radiator or microwave etc.

There are many good hearted people in this story who did what they can. The question for society is, "How do we respond as a society so that the care of these folks is more consistent and offers them the best life they can have, given their illness?"

The only other answer is involuntary commitment to mental institutions, but that is never a good answer. Such places have often been worse for human beings than life on the streets. AND often once the patient is stabilized on medications they are released. Because the meds have nasty side-effects, they stop taking them, and again descend into psychosis and homelessness.

headline: Oil Was Central in Decision to Shrink Protected Utah Site, Emails Show
commentone:
On so many levels this decision makes no sense. Tthe world is awash in oil. Dozens of countries around the world never suspecting they had viable fossil fuel fields copied American companies and are fracking at growing pace. Saudi Arabia continues to pump at record levels as do other Mid-East nations, Brazil and Venezuela are awash in oil and gasoline is cheap at the pumps.

Trashing national treasures should never occur, but if it does take place, it should be done as a last desperate measure when a lack of available oil impacts national security. The U.S. is awash in gas and petroleum.
commenttwo:
OK, I get the part about the school trust lands. That's income that Utah depends on to fund its schools, just like the property taxes do elsewhere. That needs to be preserved. That involves about 110,000 acres.

Then you see that Bears Ears wiil be reduced by 85%. It is about 1,351,000 acres, so that means a reduction of about 1,241,000 acres or about 1,131,000 acres more than would be needed to simply let the schools keep getting their funding unimpeded by federal ineptness (Obama) or rank hypocrisy (Trump).

The return to the taxpayer on the extraction of resources from federal lands is minuscule, an outrage, and nothing more than more socialism for the rich. How about spreading such largess around?

They should pay market value. Why isn't Congress doing something about this by adjusting mineral pricing to modern times, instead of the gimmee to the well-heeled it has long been.

Remember nearly a 100 years ago? Most of us don't, but the Teapot Dome scandal rested on making federal resources available as sweetheart deals to serve private interests at scandalous rates.

Now under Trump and Zinke, Big Coal and Oil don't even need bribery, they can save that cash and take it straight to the bottom line.

Teapot Dome resulted in actual criminal convictions. Has the Trump crowd looked into contracting for a luxury rent-a-prison yet? They may need one, or should need one, for their criminal contempt of the public's financial interests.

headline: Saying a Prayer I Don’t Believe In
commentone:
Community is a good thing, and anthropologically speaking, that has been the traditional benefit and purpose of religion. For those who actually believe it is more than that, like belief in a supreme being ‚Äö√Ñ√¨ I don‚Äö√Ñ√¥t know what to say.
But surely there is a better way to promote community than with religion. After all, religion is merely one tribal marker. Perhaps we could coalesce around a more universal trait: that we are all human with common challenges, and share empathy for each other.
‚Äö√Ñ√∫It defines me as a member of the tribe. My tribe.‚Äö√Ñ√π There is the problem. Tribes can be insular and divisive. Most of the problems in the world are caused by tribal differences and rivalries. Tribes promote the ‚Äö√Ñ√∫other‚Äö√Ñ√π - us versus them. Fundamentalist Evangelical Christians are not likely to buddy up with a Christian denomination that embraces gay marriage. Sunnis vs. Shiites.
And, can a tribe that is thousands of years old address modern challenges? Saying Kaddish or not eating pork does nothing for the global community. And what of tribal hypocrisy e.g. Catholics remaining in their tribe in the face of long-standing pedophilia by their priests?
If you don‚Äö√Ñ√¥t believe the prayers of your tribe, doesn‚Äö√Ñ√¥t that make a mockery of the tribal beliefs, and therefore of the tribe that would believe in such nonsense? It undercuts the credibility of the tribe.
If one doesn‚Äö√Ñ√¥t believe in their tribe‚Äö√Ñ√¥s doctrines, prayers, and metaphysics ‚Äö√Ñ√¨ maybe they should find another tribe that they can believe in.
commenttwo: We don't have the intellectual ability to understand God. He is way above us. He also says in the Bible that " My ways are not your ways." Personally I don't like rote prayers such as, The Lord's Prayer that we Christians recite. Jesus gave that prayer to His followers as an example of how to pray, not what to pray.

headline: The Challenge of Doctor-Patient Relations in the Internet Age
commentone: Can I put in a plug for librarians here? As we all know, the internet can be a disaster or a godsend. And librarians have been at the forefront of understanding, evaluating and organizing content since it began.  We know the red flags, recognize the scams, are familiar with the reputable sources, and are trained and experienced in some level of critical appraisal of content and evidence.  We know, for example, that the PDR is nothing more than a compendium of the package inserts, written by the drug companies, that come in your drug envelope, and that they might include every symptom ever reported by someone on that drug whether or not it had anything to do with the drug. We encourage people to look stuff up for themselves, and help to filter out the garbage and sales pitches and focus on the important, current, most reliable stuff.  And our services are free at public libraries.  Try us.
commenttwo: While reading this article, I was reminded of a comment in Dr. Steven Z. Kussin's 2011 book Doctor, Your Patient Will See You Now: "If all you know is what your doctor and WebMD tell you, your interests are not being maximized."

Tear down Trump‚Äö√Ñ√¥s wall. Take down Big Pharma and demand a fair and equitable healthcare system. Challenge the NRA. Take back democracy. headline: The Tet Offensive Was Not About Americans
commentone: Another interesting article in this series, thank you. One comment, though - the author starts to use the term "Communists" to refer to, I think, both the North Vietnamese soldiers and the Viet Cong. I think that's mistaken, because he does not refer to the South Vietnamese and the Americans as "Capitalists", which I think would be the appropriate term, compared to Communist. Using that term clouds the nature of the long war in Vietnam, and makes it look like part of the Soviet Union's quest for expansion and domination, so that Vietnam was just another domino set to fall. I think no matter what economic philosophy the North Vietnamese were following, there would still have been a push to evict the French colonials and later to combat we Americans, in an effort to unify the country and gain independence. In other words, whether or not the North was a Communist country, the war would've happened nonetheless.

headline: Why It’s So Hard to Invest With a Social Conscience
commentone: I don't get it. If we want to change the ways of these terrible companies, shouldn't we be BUYING stock? We can then vote as activist shareholders and better hold the leadership and board of directors accountable. If we sell all our shares in the companies, they have a lot less reason to listen to us.
commenttwo:
Ron, thank you for a very interesting article which adds to previous articles on how difficult it is to avoid owning stocks in gun manufacturers or other industries you do not favor.
Some years ago I thought of this and looked closely at the prospectus of mutual funds I owned. I owned a consumer staples mutual fund and the 3rd and 5th largest stocks it held were Phillip Morris and Altria and down the list other tobacco or liquor companies.
Additionally, breaking down it's holding by sub-industry diversification the leading holdings at 25% were soft drinks companies. Tobacco products were 4th at almost 14 %. Distillers were lower at about 3 %. That left about 58% for what you might think of "staples" such as paper and health products and more in this line of thinking.
I sold that mutual fund and don't miss it.

You can search for funds that invest in alternative energy verses fossil fuel exploration or drilling or mining.

This takes time but looking at the holdings within your funds or indexes can help you understand what you hold yourself and shape your own portfolio.

headline: Your Kid’s Phone Is Not Like a Cigarette
commentone: It may or may not turn out to be a factor like nicotine, but readers should become aware that the kind of RF signaling emitted by cell phones has been found in several studies to stimulate the opioid receptors in the brain. See this 2007 review of evidence (to date) in the paper by de la Puente and Balmori, "Addiction to cell phones: Are there neurophysiological mechanisms involved?" (full paper follows the abstract) https://www.researchgate.net/publication/238032691_Addiction_to_cell_pho...
commenttwo:
Would that the telecom industry were interested in helping to limit overuse, but they are not. Quite the opposite. While the auto industry is pretty happy once you've purchased their car, whatever you do with it, telecoms need you to buy minutes and plans and new gizmos after you obtain your phone, and they'd like you to find your phone out-of-date and ready to be replaced as soon as possible. Online, companies want you to use your phone as much as possible, to keep you there as a source of marketing info and as a resource for constant consumption. I've been on committees with industry people when we were asking for tools or guidelines to help people limit use, and they were not interested. I know this from first-hand experience.
And if the author knew the history of the health research on both tobacco and cell phones, and their industries' response to it as things looked worse and worse, she would not hesitate to make the parallel between cell phones and tobacco.

headline: ‘President for Life’? Trump’s Remarks About Xi Find Fans in China
commentone: If Obama had even joked about this I think Hannity‚Äö√Ñ√¥s head would have exploded.
commenttwo:
‚Äö√Ñ√∫The failure of Western leaders to speak out against Mr. Xi‚Äö√Ñ√¥s plans for limitless power was in step with a growing acceptance among democracies of one-man rule in many countries, said Fran‚àö√üois Godement, director of the Asia and China program at the European Council on Foreign Relations.‚Äö√Ñ√π

My life has been lived in the shadow of the men and women who survived WWII and paid the price for the indifference to xenophobic nationalism and affection for ‚Äö√Ñ√≤strongmen‚Äö√Ñ√¥ that the larger portion of the population of the Western democracies ignored in the 1920‚Äö√Ñ√¥s and 30‚Äö√Ñ√¥s. For the most part they didn‚Äö√Ñ√¥t speak of it much, but mention the names Mussolini, Stalin, Tojo, or Hitler and their response was uniform revulsion. The cost of the lesson they learned came at a great price that haunted the darker nights of their lives.

They are mostly dead now and I fear that for many of us the lesson they learned has been buried with them. They didn‚Äö√Ñ√¥t necessarily admire democracy as it played out in their lifetimes, but they knew that democracies ugly cousin, authoritarianism, was an infinitely worse solution to the continuing problem of governance. I fear that our failure to learn that lesson will bequeath, at unimaginable cost, the re-learning of that lesson to our children‚Äö√Ñ√¥s children.

headline: Can There Be Good Porn?
commentone: Porn should never be a substitute for an open realistic sex-education program. However, the GOP would prefer to pretend that sex doesn't exist and will only fund abstinence as a sex education plan. Teens are bound to go elsewhere for their education and porn has become an imperfect substitute. We have a very puritanical approach to sex in general in this country. Things that are taboo hold great fascination for the young. Stop pretending that sex doesn't exist and that we are not a sexually motivated animal. Consensual sex is normal and healthy. Bring it out of the closet and remove the stigma.
commenttwo:
Of course there can be "good" porn, if by "good" you mean porn that's effectively arousing and liberatingly amoral while depicting sex you wouldn't be humiliated or terrified to have. Yeah, it should be the opposite of sex education; is there anything that makes you want sex less than the stern disease- and pregnancy-prevention sex ed most of us received? Porn should be fun.

But as a heterosexual woman, I guess I've never managed to wade through enough of the horrifying stuff to find a porn genre I'd like, or even be able to stomach on a regular basis. The aesthetics and the attitudes toward women are just too dismal. The players are uninteresting. No sense of simple fun or the comedy of sex; but at the same time, nothing intriguing or complex.

And hey, that's an admission that I've looked.

I don't think it's practical to censor porn, but most heterosexual porn I've seen does more harm than good, if the goal is to promote better sex. I mean, I have to ask: why does so much of it show women being abused, humiliated, and put in situations that would cause serious pain or even injury? That is not a harmless aid to sexual pleasure.

headline: Goodbye, Pay-as-You-Wish
commentone: I was born and raised in New York. I was a native for 30+ years. I've lived the last 35+ years in the Midwest so I believe I see this from a better "overall" perspective. To go from whatever one can afford to a mandatory $25 fee overnight is much more than a huge increase. It's a seal on the notice to a large segment of the population that you're not welcome. Face it, folks class warfare has been going on for some time and this is but one small aspect. Before anyone dismisses what I'm saying let me point out that if it was only an increase in revenue needed to raise $6 Million why the jump from $0 to $25? It states the number of goers paying the suggested amount has declined from 63% to 17% with an attendance of 7 Million. If they added just a $5 fee on those that couldn't donate the full amount, which is an amount most everyone could afford, it would generate more than $29 Million or 5x what they claim to want to raise with a $25 fee. Do you see the dishonesty yet? If you are like me and can not afford the new admission fees you now have a clue to the truth or at least you know what they are telling you is not actually true.

headline: How Did Europe Freeze As North Pole Warmed Up?
commentone: Thank you for including the Rohde diagram and the refrigerator example.  I'm trying hard to understand and this was a help.  You gave me something for both parts of my brain.
commenttwo:
When it‚Äö√Ñ√¥s too warm, it because of global warming. And when it‚Äö√Ñ√¥s too cold it‚Äö√Ñ√¥s because of global warming.

97% of climate scientists believe there is global warming, and that human activity is the dominant cause. That‚Äö√Ñ√¥s strong evidence. But it‚Äö√Ñ√¥s not conclusive proof. If a scientist is in the 3% he/she will be branded a ‚Äö√Ñ√∫denier‚Äö√Ñ√π by the media, the same word as in the phrase ‚Äö√Ñ√∫Holocaust denier,‚Äö√Ñ√π and he/she will have a very hard time getting published. Far easier to join the crowd. This is the psychology of ‚Äö√Ñ√∫pack science,‚Äö√Ñ√π which is similar to ‚Äö√Ñ√∫pack journalism.‚Äö√Ñ√π

Where I live, the dominant geological feature is the Great Lakes, which formed about 14,000 years ago, due to global warming, and the end of the last ice age. There was not much human activity 14,000 years ago. Today, we again have global warming, and it seems to be occurring much faster than it did 14,000 years ago, and the explanation seems to be greenhouse gases from human activity. But let‚Äö√Ñ√¥s also remember, we‚Äö√Ñ√¥ve only had accurate global temperature monitoring for 50 or 60 years, with satellites and accurate, worldwide, thermometers.

At this point, I‚Äö√Ñ√¥m a believer, and I think we need to act accordingly. A root cause of human activity is population growth, perhaps it‚Äö√Ñ√¥s finally time to address this. It‚Äö√Ñ√¥s certainly time to moderate our carbon footprint.

But, at the same time, let‚Äö√Ñ√¥s keep an open mind. There have been many times when 97% of scientists got it wrong. Who thinks the sun revolves around the earth?

headline: How Liberals Can Reclaim Nationalism
commentone: Yes,  believe we can redefine the word nationalism if we must. I find it too close to Nazi in my brain. However, I understand the need for pride to exist. It CAN exist on a broad plain to include all of us.
commenttwo:
A person with liberal sentiments (tolerant, generous) can hardly espouse nationalism (the idea that states should represent groups formed on the basis of the characteristics of common birth -- physical ethnicity, language, and religion): it's not tolerant.

On the other hand, the political sentiment that historically is associated with parties called "Liberal" (replacement of the ancien regime -- monarchical, military, clerical -- with republican forms of government) has in many cases drawn on nationalism as an alternative to multi-national imperial territorial aggrandizement.

The U.S. was exceptional, however, in that it inherited political liberalism from post-Glorious Revolution England and was republican from birth. Its unity was based on a geographic territory that it wanted to wrest from London's control, so no appeal to national distinction from England was needed (or possible). Instead, the U.S. was a contractual association via a written Constitution.

U.S. white nationalism rejects this tradition. As a minority movement, its best chance for success might be through a personality cult. The best response for people of tolerant, generous sentiments might be to exalt the U.S. political tradition of Constitutionalism and the rule of law.

headline: How the Left Wins the Culture War
