Brooks claims that a number of "formerly popular beliefs" can now end your career. Let's add some obvious additional ones: racial bigotry and virulent anti-semitism and the belief that any sufficiently powerful man can grab the genitals of unwilling women whenever he feels like it. Admittedly these are still not just acceptable, but valued in some circles. Representative Scalise has advanced well in the Republican party, and Trump is now President.
It should be noted that belief in the three milder matters chosen by Brooks will not end your careers. Even going public with your belief hasn't ended any careers that I know of. The few careers that I have heard of being disadvantaged were not harmed by the belief, or by public expression of the belief, but by use of the belief in an effort to harm somebody else. People didn't just believe that men and women have inherent psychological differences, (an opinion which I hold is true on average), they tried to keep women out of computer programming and other STEM education and jobs. .

headline: The Supreme Court’s Power Play Against Labor
commentone:
I was a union member for most of my working life, and I, too, think that this decision is preordained by ideology, not the law. But I hope that the labor movement can see this as an opportunity to return to our roots as a social movement. Over the course of my career, we have given hundreds of millions of dollars to the Democratic Party, an activity that is the crux of this case. IMO, it usually boils down to paying media corporations who hate us to support candidates who don't much care about us.
Many unionists think that different strategies are needed. Imagine if the AFL-CIO devoted the money once given to the will-o-the-wisp of political campaigns to a national network of storefront legal and political offices that would help any worker who comes in the door; run union candidates for office, every single election cycle; recruit people into an associate member organization with a nominal fee, like NGOs do; run free seminars about the workplace rights that we still have.
This approach resembles much of the community organizing that unions did from the 1870s through the Depression, back when similar Supreme Courts branded the labor movement as a criminal conspiracy. The courts and reactionary Republicans will strip us of our power every time they have the power, just like they always have. We have to adjust and find the newer ways to counterbalance this corporate supremacy, ways that even the Supreme Court can't declare illegal.
commenttwo: Grouch should recuse himself, as his former law partner is arguing before him. Probably not required, but certainly there is the taint of possible bias.

headline: The Tet Offensive Was Not About Americans
commentone:
Tet, like many other actions by the Communists in Vietnam, was designed more to destroy the ARVN than to attack American forces, That much seems obvious. I disagree with Wiest concerning just how well the Communists succeeded. The NLF and NVA took staggering losses that would have spelled defeat to the US military had it taken a fraction of that percentage of casualties. However, it sure looked to me like in 1968, and 1971, and 1975 when I was there briefly for the evacuations, the ARVN was progressively destroyed.
Furthermore, any significant demonstration of the insufficiency of the ARVN - for example the battle of Hue in 1968, after we had been so strongly told that South Vietnam had stood up and won its war, affected American opinion. A LOT!

commenttwo:
Chaos is his strategy to hide his incompetence. He is like the chess player who insists on making every move a bold move: He trades powerful rooks for knights, blabbering all the time about how strong his position, is when the situation is quite the opposite; He boldly places the opponents King in check with his Queen - then promptly loses that most valuable piece on the next series of plays.

People who don't know the game are impressed by his bluster. "Wow, that was an aggressive, disruptive move!" And he says, "Boy, am I being disruptive! It's because I am so brilliant!"

Meanwhile, he is being crushed by his opponents, some of them ridiculous to the world in their own right (Putin, Erdogan), but better at this game because he is so bad.

And the pieces he is losing are our national treasures - the rule of law; the environment and clean energy initiatives; our role as a refuge for those who dream; our well-regulated financial markets; our reserve currency; our constitution and its brilliant constructs, the bill of rights and the separation of powers, and the emoluments clause; the civil service; the apolitical Justice Department and National Security infrastructure; the progressive tax system; and Congressional rules designed for comity.

This charlatan who manages to lose money on a casino (Hillary: "I ask you, how do you lose money running a casino?") is managing to lose America's stature, and her other national treasures.

A Blue Wave cannot come soon enough.

headline: How the Left Wins the Culture War
commentone: I can usually read Mr Brooks without feeling enraged. However, the arrogant, condescending right-wing elite righteousness that pervades this piece is infuriating. Your party has given this country the most corrupt administration we have encountered in over a hundred plus years, Your religious leaders reek of hypocrisy. Your senior administrators offer little white lies, others likely sell influence to our enemies! And you have the utter audacity to imply you are commenting from some arena  of moral righteousness. Let me provide some feedback. You are not. Look in the mirror. See the depravity your representatives have been inflicting on others through the dark money buying of votes and supreme court justices and decisions. Your hypocrisy is legend and your vision is so distorted through the money used to buy congress that you cannnot perceive the corrupt underpinning of your value system.
commenttwo: This is even more myopic than usual for Mr. Brooks. He seems to want to warn us against defeating a political movement that has devolved into a tyranny of minority rule at the expense of logic, justice, public safety, religious freedom, and human rights. Somehow, we are to believe this will be a bad thing. We are issued a threat that if this tyrannical minority is overthrown, then, with respect to Trump, we ain't seen nothin' yet. The truth is, if the conservative movement (whatever that even means anymore) is ever to be "defeated" it will only be because an overwhelming majority of Americans realize the logical and moral rot at its foundations. (Which may not be far away.) The people left to hunker down and get angry at liberals while plotting to install a king even dumber and more immoral than Trump will not represent 40% of the population, because most will have left the party already. The rest of us will re-organize and re-stratify, liberal and conservative alike, and hopefully into a fuller spectrum of political thought, represented by a healthier number of political parties (i.e. any number greater than two.) As for the warning that liberals should be careful in how we win our victories, perhaps conservatives should heed Mr. Brooks' advice. If he thinks his party is imploding, it's only because of how they've won over the last two decades. By his own theory, our next president will make Obama look like Reagan.

headline: Plan for Tariffs Creates Divide In Trump Base
commentone: There are always winners and losers across industries in trade policy. With free trade, market forces determine the winners and losers. With restrictive trade policy, politicians choose the winners and losers. Your choice.
commenttwo: There's also the real danger of retaliatory tariffs against other US industries and exports. Coming from a farming State, the first thing I worry about is China putting tariffs on soybeans, maize, and meat. That would be the most effective retaliation that China could take because it would threaten the incomes of a swath of Republican agricultural States and threaten Trump's rural base. China could also find other non-US sources for agricultural imports. The Chinese market is vitally important to US agriculture.

headline: Tariffs Are Small Economically, but Big Symbolically
commentone:
The most effective retaliatory tariffs would be on U.S. agricultural exports particularly maize, soybeans and meat products. That would hit key Trump supporting Republican States, like mine, very hard and would put immediate pressure on Trump and farm state Republicans in Congress. China also has the threat of importing from other agricultural countries.

Terry Branstad, US ambassador to China, is a former Iowa governor who has to understand the importance of the Chinese market for US agricultural exports.

headline: Taxpayers, You’ve Been Scammed
commentone: W gave everyone a $600.00 check and then Obama had to clean up the mess so we didn't have a depression.  We have seen this play before.  Vote them out!
commenttwo:
Is it just me or is this column getting repetitive and redundant?

I think I get it. The Republicans are following donors' orders to change our national and state government policies. The changes are not intended to benefit people in lower income brackets.

This was a fun read when it revealed and explained the opaque malevolent machinations and motivations underlying various economic maneuvers by politicians and government officials.

Now, however, the deplorable positions of our ruling class, the objectives and the consequences are nearly obvious. What's the point in repeatedly pointing them out?

What messaging should we now expect? Maybe the specific identification of people and groups in which we should trust and invest? Perhaps explanations of how they plan to and can gain and exercise influence and power on our behalf?

What would you request?

headline: The Challenge of Doctor-Patient Relations in the Internet Age
commentone: Trusting doctors without doing your own research is foolish.  Drugs cause side effects in me that are not often encountered by others.  My current doctor knows this and was fine with my response that I'd think about when he recommended I get a shot of the widely advertised Prevnar 13.  At my next visit I told my doctor I wanted the Prevnar 13 as I'd been impressed with the results of the study done in The Netherlands and thought I'd have minimal side effects.  My doctor told me he was unaware of this study.  I was dumbstruck. The results of this study had been published in The New England Journal of Medicine.  Why was my doctor recommending something that he had not studied?

headline: The Danger of Waiting for a Wave

Vote.

headline: The Supreme Court’s Power Play Against Labor
commentone: Selective obligation does not build a nation. Some recognize the need to band together and the benefits to be gained and the price to be paid for these benefits. Rugged individuals don`t need to band together, they don`t need police until they have been beaten, they don`t need health insurance until they get sick, they don`t need firemen until their house is on fire, they won`t need clean water until it costs too much to buy in a store. Rugged individuals don`t need a country, they can just put on that rugged individual hat and head out to, where do rugged individuals go now to divorce themselves of societal obligations, maybe Russia? Just don`t dis Vlad.
commenttwo: Justice Kennedy's question is not a simple yes/no question. Is the diminishing of a union's political influence if the case is decided against it proof that its political activities are supported by these "conscientious objectors"? No. It's proof that the presence of freeloaders, who will now pay nothing for union representation in collective bargaining, will cause others, who do in fact support the union's political activities, to withhold their dues b/c they resent their colleagues getting something for nothing. It is proof that the undermining of a reasonable compromise (reduced fees to pay for apolitical services rendered) is in fact politically motivated.

headline: The Trump-Russia Story Gets Even Weirder
commentone:
This tawdry article is simply unproved speculation heaped upon unproved speculation. I can scarcely believe the Times printed it. There has yet to be drawn a direct, nefarious line between Trump and Putin or the Russian government. There may very well be one, it just has yet to be proved.

Most opinion about the Trump/Putin/Russia melodrama seems to be based almost entirely on how its audience feels personally about the main characters and also how they want to see the series play out.

Meanwhile, massive real damage is being done daily by Trump and his Republican - and sometimes, Democratic - enablers with no end in sight. This is in no small part because such a lopsided chunk of regard is being given to the interference/collusion showpiece that's holding its fans in such rapt attention to the exclusion of other critical issues.

Of course, the Democrats are perfectly fine with this and actually facilitate it as it deflects focus away from their own political and legislative impotence and onto the Bad Guys everyone can hate and blame. Sad...

headline: Trade War, What Is It Good For? Absolutely Nothing
commentone:
Let's see, so far Trump has heroically fought to restore the coal mining and steel manufacturing industries to their former glory. What could be the next high-tech and rapidly growing industry which has been treated very badly and unfairly in the past and needs only his brilliant deal-making talent to be restored?

My guess would be the clothing and textile industry, which previous administrations have been stupid enough not to protect with tariffs. A huge tariff on all clothing and textile imports should be enough to bring back the sweatshops and textile mills with their well-paying jobs and pleasant working conditions without increasing clothing prices or causing inflation. USA! USA! Make 19th century America great again!

headline: A Times Photographer in Italy Must Bring Her Daughter to Work

I lived on the other coast from my family and my mother inlaw never took care of my son. I hired a woman we named "Aunt Elaine" to care for him when I worked. He grew up thinking her entire name was "Auntelaine".

headline: An ‘Annie Hall’ Reboot for the Ages
commentone:
A delightful read to wake up to.

The secret to happiness is purpose in life.
Having something rewarding and fun to do.
And, something to look forward to.

Add in proper eating, physical activity, mental stimulation, rest, friends‚Äö√Ñ¬∂ human connection.

And fun, fun, fun.
Be silly at least a half hour a day.
It will balance the dreadful and dreary.

These two were lucky to get into this project.
A great thing to replicate in senior facilities all over - in-house productions.

And‚Äö√Ñ¬∂ let's go there‚Äö√Ñ¬∂As for Woody Allen‚Äö√Ñ¬∂ is his transgression, if he even committed it, say as bad as the Holocaust?

No.

So we shun him but not bookstores that sell material about the Nazis. Offensive to keep that stuff in our face, no? Why do they keep doing that to us!

We don't shun Steven Spielberg.
He made a film that brutally threw the atrocities of the Nazis in our face with Schindler's List. How dare he offend us!
I'm done with him!

Woody.
Is the verdict in?
Does the concept of reasonable doubt still hold? That's the American way, right?
What's our prescribed punishment for any crime, and once the debt to society is paid is the perpetrator welcomed back? Do we ever let go of our animus or does it feel too good to hate another person?

And God forbid we should ever forgive anyone!! How would we survive and enjoy ourselves if we were deprived of the myriad daily hatreds that shape us?

- son of a Holocaust survivor who learned that lightness of heart and love set you free at last.

headline: Fights Worth Having
commentone: Our political rift is not to be decried, but embraced.  The socioeconomic rift been increasingly widening under a bipartisan consensus that promulgates the lie that laissez-faire capitalism, now branded as "free" markets, is the means toward a democratic and just society.   Most of America in the 80's and 90's bought into this illusion, blind while the American Dream was being pulled out from under its feet.  Thank God America is waking up and the political rift is widening along with the economic one. Again, most Americans turn on at their screens and see the one percent glory in riches while they wear themselves out treading water.  Most Americans see the 10 percent smiling and prospering while they with furrowed brow fear the final hardship that will plunge them into poverty and misery.  No, the middle path, Republican nor Democrat, is not the answer, nor is Ms. Charen, no matter how nobly she speaks to the worst elements of her party.   We need a third party now, a party that advances political and social democracy and  offers more than the tired, old status quo.  This is what Mr. Stephens fears.  Frankly, whether the survivor of our corrupt two party system is Republican or Democrat is irrelevant.  What matters is whether the challenge to the corrupt status quo will be from the dark forces of corporate and racist neo-fascism, embodied in Mr. Trump, or from the social justice warriors that Stephens fears and decries.  If if is the former then all hope will be lost.

headline: How Liberals Can Reclaim Nationalism
commentone: Throw out the "culinary metaphors." Our country is a mosaic. Each piece is unique and no two shapes are identical. Yet even as we remain identifiable in our uniqueness, together we make the picture. That's what we have to remember.
commenttwo:
My father, born poor, went to the Air Force on graduating high school in 1948. He served through the Korean War, then went to college with the aid of the G.I. Bill. He became a school superintendent, my mother a teacher.

Though in the service along with most young men his age because of the ‚Äö√Ñ√∫draft‚Äö√Ñ√π, my father and his contemporaries came to realize there was something bigger than themselves and see the value in the sacrifice they were involuntarily compelled to make‚Äö√Ñ√Æand they respected one another for it. One of the first questions men of my father‚Äö√Ñ√¥s generation would ask was ‚Äö√Ñ√∫where did you do your service?‚Äö√Ñ√π It didn‚Äö√Ñ√¥t matter whether you were a bus driver or a C.E.O., it was assumed you had served. And because of that universal experience they respected each other regardless of their politics. My dad, who sported a crew cut, would pick up hitchhiking, long-haired Vietnam vets in fatigue coats and dirty jeans (when mom wasn‚Äö√Ñ√¥t along).

I am the oldest of four boys and missed the Vietnam War by a few years. The ‚Äö√Ñ√∫draft‚Äö√Ñ√π was over when I graduated high school in 1974. I gave no thought to military service. I was never made to sacrifice. My wife and I are both attorneys and have done well. I paid my taxes, but as far as my ‚Äö√Ñ√∫country‚Äö√Ñ√π is concerned I have done the bare minimum. My attitude has been, look, I was just born here, what do you want?

Until we require universal, involuntary, uncomfortable, multi-year service we will be fractured alienated from one another.

headline: In a New York Minute, Hire for Schools Opts Out
commentone: As dad used to say, whoopsie!
commenttwo:
Obviously a difficult and emotional decision for him.

But he had planned to 'leave on top' when things were going smoothly for him and there was just a terrible school shooting in the area. While not directly in his district, it must have unsettled many people and students.

Suddenly there are a million people who need stability and calm thoughtful leadership at home. I kind of admire his loyalty to his current students, by refusing to leave in those circumstances.

Maybe the shooting affected him emotionally too? It doesn't really matter why. For whatever reason, he changed his mind.

I understand the frustration of New Yorkers, but by turning on him immediately you hurt yourselves and your prospects for hiring another candidate more than you hurt him. (any potential candidate will surely call the guy who ran away for an off the record chat)

The classiest thing to do would be to accept his decision with the same respect you had when you hired him.

The mayor should ask him, candidly and off the record, for feedback on any aspects of the search process, or his perceptions about the new job or new york that might have put him off. Salvage something from all the effort.

You didn't get a new chancellor, but you did get a high level independent management review from an expert in the field. Ask for a report of his findings and his help with the ongoing search. He owes you that much.

headline: The Challenge of Doctor-Patient Relations in the Internet Age
commentone: I have a PhD in a social science and know how to evaluate most scientific sources. So my research of health conditions on the web runs very little risk of relying on anecdotal or other unscientific sources. What I find most often when researching meds is that they have been tested on very small groups of people or for very short periods of time but my doctors want me to take them forever. I have also spent many years on meds prescribed to me by my pulmonologists that I have since discovered cause me more harm than help. Same with psych meds. Also had a GI MD offer to prescribe a med for me that I knew from past experience would cause me cognitive impairment. Drs. specialize today in one area and learn very little of how their meds may affect other areas. Thus, when offered medical treatment, I prefer to research the alternatives, where there are such, myself.
commenttwo: The average American with motivation to do so can access real information - not just anecdotes, opinions, and sales pitches - online through Medscape, pubmed, etc.  Some of us pay to subscribe to journals in order to stay informed, but plenty is also available free to all.  College/University students can frequently gain access to articles for which they would otherwise need to pay by logging in through their schools‚Äö√Ñ√¥ libraries.  Those of us without medical degrees can gain incomparable benefit from the counsel of our doctors, but we are also capable of reading, assimilating, and interpreting information ourselves and of bringing what we cannot make sense of ourselves to our doctors for discussion.  Patients should be treated with respect and responsibility.  We deserve thorough individual examination and evaluation before diagnoses and judgements are made.  This applies to our research and self-advocacy skills as well as to our physical selves.  Judging all of us to be unable to discern real information from the litter strewn across the internet is not helpful.

headline: The Supreme Court’s Power Play Against Labor
commentone: It's hilarious to read that SCOTUS is a right wing lobbyist, when in reality its half right, half left, and one swing vote in the middle.
commenttwo:
One would think this an easy case.

Those who don't formally join the union, which is their right, are asked to pay a fee that goes into a pot of funds to cover collective bargaining on behalf of them and all other workers. The benefits of that bargaining affect everyone.

So, pay your fair share for that benefit.

I might have pushed back on the grossly partisan judges like this:

"Your honor, since you are so concerned with politics instead of settled law, and can't see how to separate collective bargaining from political stance of a union, I'd ask you this: If the union's mission is to represent its members and others in the worker pool to the best of its ability and to get them the best deal in the best compromise, which political party historically is on the side of the average working person and why wouldn't the union want that party in power?

Your honor, the court has found that money cannot be limited in our election finance, so why shouldn't the union, as part of its mission to favor the interests of workers, not favor the interests of the party that favors workers?

Should the non-union workers in the pool suffer from bad labor deals? Should they not benefit from the union's political choices?

Why, your honor, should they and all workers have their hands tied while management gets your overt approval instead?

Why??"

To all conservatives out there- enjoy the weekend. The union movement 90 years ago won the 40 hour week with their blood.

Say thank you.

headline: What We Will Lose When the Union Carbide Building Falls
commentone:
Architecture is under attack everywhere, and where is your ‚Äö√Ñ√∫architecture critic‚Äö√Ñ√π? Still chasing climate change conference cash? Anyway, the bank could easily add space by other means ‚Äö√Ñ√Æ their justification to tear down a modernist jewel is a disaster (of experience, energy, history). This SOM rhetoric of ‚Äö√Ñ√∫corporation was de facto the architect‚Äö√Ñ√π is typical client whispering, it doesn‚Äö√Ñ√¥t make it true. I‚Äö√Ñ√¥d call this building Classical Modernism, the earlier style related closely to classical proportions, as opposed to the hodge podge McUrbanism you find at Hudson Yards. Look at the extreme spectrum of types within modernism, a movement that we are still living in.

Speaking of Hudson Yards, you can see how the New York Times architecture negligence has led to a travesty of mediocrity. While the NYT has been looking away, we lost a superior Steven Holl masterplan and got a banal glass, opaque crapfest ‚Äö√Ñ√Æ the style that will likely replace this building. Its no wonder Classic Modern architecture is under attack in media and cities ‚Äö√Ñ√Æ its tied to a human idea of technology that the big urbanists, technocrats and corrupt arch critics would rather you forget so they can focus on top-down, generic masterplanning.
commenttwo:

headline: What to Expect (And Not) at the Oscars

In the same vein this film is less a fit for #MeToo than #StopArguing.

Filipovic: Hope Hicks is quiet, hardworking, stereotypically beautiful, and polite. Hicks is a loyal employee who has rejected opportunities to boost her own career and focus the spotlight on herself.

Isn't that what journalists used to do?

This comment is not politically motivated. I am not a Trump supporter, I am not a Republican, and I don't know HH. I do know fairness and logic.

headline: A Big Hollywood Night in a #MeToo Moment
commentone: Let's call Oscar "Frankenstein." Like Frankenstein, Oscar is dead but he continues to walk. 90 years ago, if you wanted to see a moving picture, you had to go to a movie theater. The movies were modern and relevant. Not anymore. I went to see several of the nominee films but found myself in a space empty of people. You can see great acting and great stories now on your computer and your flat screen television. Why go out when I can stay in and watch something far better on TV?  And there's so much to see: Homeland, the Walking Dead (although that story is slipping these days), Counterpart,  Stranger Things, The Crown, and Black Mirror. The list goes on and on. headline: When Elder Abuse Is Self-Inflicted
commentone: In my work as a clinical ethicist, the issue of safe discharges is increasingly becoming a major multipronged, complicated ethical dilemma in our society.  The poorly funded paradigm shift from hospital to intensive home care is at the heart of this issue. Hospitals rely on untrained family members to provide complex care at a time when they need to work to support themselves.  Elderly spouses or frazzled parents of children with complex needs can't provide the care that our healthcare system demands of them.  Addiction and mental illness create huge problems for families and healthcare providers without much medical, legal, or ethical guidance.  Healthcare reform decisions to save money included sending patients home faster without funding a safety net or providing trained doctors and nurses.  Every complex care patient, young or old, should have a homecare referral prior to discharge from the hospital without placing the burden on stressed families to provide the care.  More families are refusing to sign discharge papers and take their loved ones home due to the physical and financial stress.  And I don't blame them. Time to design a healthcare system that provides medical and nursing supports in the home in collaboration with family members.  Additionally, standardized ethical/legal guidelines describing when a patient is no longer capable caring for themselves would help professional caregivers and family members.  Thank you for highlighting this major healthcare issue.

headline: How Liberals Can Reclaim Nationalism
commentone:
What's a liberal to base their nationalism on? Certainly not the Constitution. According to them it was written by white men, slave owners who wrote the Bill of Rights to keep the black man on the plantations. No! America is not a nation worth getting national about. America's history is one of racism and genocide. Even the Declaration of Independence was penned by a white supremacist who owned slaves and used the slave women for his sex toys.
Why are liberals even thinking about nationalism in America? Call it a squatter's rights ism. They have attempted to repudiate the very foundations of this country. Not even the elections are valid. The Electoral system is flawed. It was written to protect the plantations and keep the slaves down. The second amendment was included to suppress slave rebellions. American territory was stolen from the native tribes through genocide.
commenttwo: Mr. Mounk makes a compelling argument for liberals to work within the reality of how nation states define themselves within their respective borders and across the community of nations.  His proposal is sound.  However, in addition to liberals recognizing the indelible nature of national identity as a step toward a better patriotism, enough of us across political spectrums must acknowledge other realities.  In the United States, for example, the fact is that we have always been a racially interdependent society.  The problem has been with our national identify's failure to acknowledge it.  The United States could not have conceivably emerged with its global influence in less than a century had it not been for the contribution of its diverse populations, fundamentally its slaves whose labor was totally capitalized to their owners and to the world markets that consumed our exported commodities at costs discounted of wages.  Even the physical appearance of our population is evidence of our shared history long before any legal ruling sanctioning "mixed-marriages."  We have been integrated throughout our history, but we have yet to acknowledge the unjust terms of that integration let alone account for its essential role within our national identity.   Before the world can realize Mr. Mounk's vision, even Europe's identity, which ascended on the backs of other continents, must embrace its historic dependence on the very parts of the world whose populations they now reject.

headline: Nakesha’s Demons
commentone:
I can think of a number of ‚Äö√Ñ√∫caring‚Äö√Ñ√π religious institutions in New York City and abroad that appeal for donations to assist the needs of the poor, after the religious charitable groups or foundations have taken their administrative overhead cut of the donations. Hence the worst cases of homeless mentally ill persons, who have ‚Äö√Ñ√∫lost the ability‚Äö√Ñ√π to take care of themselves, go unrecognized as treatable by the very institutions begging for public support to serve them. One guesses from the report that she was suffering from something akin to extreme emotional trauma or PTSD from rape or some other brutality, or a mental breakdown of unknown origin.
Nakesha like others afflicted with mental dysfunction was doomed in the urban jungles of America, because our country got rid of the mental hospitals that could have provided compulsory shelter and professional care for them. Charitable advocacy groups clearly would lose their clients if they pushed for a return of institutional care for the chronically homeless, thus dooming them to an early grave.
commenttwo:
This is a beautiful written and (obviously) extremely well researched article. It is also very tragic.

I lived in NYC almost 30 years. In that amount of time, it is hard not to become oblivious to thousands of people. Please know I in no way mean to take anything away from this woman's story. That noted, there are so many people and each of them have their own story. Usually, drugs and/or alcohol are involved, which is maybe the most difficult part for people to understand about Ms. Williams.

I have known people who stay in the same spot (or have several spots) for years. who were schizophrenic, go off their meds and end up in a circuitous route between the hospital and the street. Many are/were highly functioning; they either were either in denial or in the throes of their disease.

I mentioned addicts; specifically opiate addicts, which I have been in recovery from for over 30 years (with a few mistakes) who are now the fastest growing and highest cause of death for people under 50 years old.

So many people have one thing in common: One way or another, falling through the cracks in the "system" (a word I hesitate to use); a truly broken system, at that.

I assume the reason this article which most find hard to accept is "how can a young woman who is so beautiful, so talented, highly intelligent and motivated refuse any real help?" I posit the answer is a tragic, but simple one: it is the nature of the disease; also, the nature of several other diseases.

headline: Trump’s Call to Arm Teachers Resonates at Schools That Do
commentone: This is a local issue, not federal.  Of all the gun proposals being discussed, only changes to the NICS, the instant check system is national.   Whether to limit ‚Äö√Ñ√∫assault‚Äö√Ñ√π rifles, allowed age of purchase, and magazine size are also within the police power of the state and its right under the second amendment to regulate it‚Äö√Ñ√¥s ‚Äö√Ñ√∫militia‚Äö√Ñ√π.
commenttwo:
If a gun is locked up, it is useless for immediate defense. Locking weapons and having vests nearby are useless protective measures.

When I taught in 1997-2005 in New Orleans, everyone in middle- and high-schools, including faculty, walked through metal detectors. If we caused a beep, we stood to the side and were wanded until the offensive object was identified. The metal object could be confiscated at the door if necessary.

Students were neither allowed to go to their cars nor leave campus and return during the day. If so, they had to pass through the metal detector. Any faculty member who was seen going to his/her car was wanded upon re-entry. I'm certain we had at least six security guards in each high school of 500-600 students. And only one door could be opened from the outside--no exterior handles on the other three doors.

I always felt 100% safe in the public schools of New Orleans.

headline: Whole Foods Gets Primed With the Amazon Treatment
commentone: amazon in its insane and unquenchable blind ambition enters an industry it knows nothing about and really has mo business being in.
commenttwo:
I was born and raised in NW Louisiana, which is right in the middle of the "Bible Belt". In the fall of 1987, I visited NYC with my (then) girlfriend and her family.

I loved the City, and made up mind on the spot: I was going to move to there, and set a goal of 6 months to prepare.

Since my family did not have a lot of money, I leaving, I sold my car, saved as much money as I could and I flew there in April, 1988 with $5000 in my pocket, I knew 1 person.

Long story short, I got a job almost immediately, and found a truly incredible deal on a rent stabilized apartment in SoHo shortly thereafter. 3 years later (Jan., 1991), a friend of mine and I took a leap and bootstrapped a niche, small business, which we nurtured and grew to 20+ employees, a better than decent living, etc. Over 25 years later, I was forced to it sell it due to multiple events (primarily derived from the great recession in 2008/9). My point is this: Our business was located just below Houston St., across from a former dirt floored parking lot for trucks. The large lot stood empty for over a decade. Lo and behold, the first Whole Foods in NYC opened there. It was a huge hit, considering the neighborhood had only prostitutes and junkies on our block when we had moved in.

At first, it was great; then it became good, then it was simply "okay". I had no choice but to move back to Louisiana.

headline: Go Ahead, Millennials, Destroy Us
commentone:
Gen X here (age 52 as of last week), and I resent the author labeling me and others in my generation as believing climate change is a hoax or that transgenderism is a fad.

We latchkey kids are particularly noted for our keen sense of injustice. As such, most of us are enraged at what is happening with the climate, and feel both welcoming of our transgendered brothers and sisters and outraged at how they are treated by the right wing.

The invitation for a takedown of Gen X is just plain silly if not outright narcissistic and useless.

As for today‚Äö√Ñ√¥s kids, teens are showing us that they are paying attention, hard, and it‚Äö√Ñ√¥s about time we gave them credit for it by listening to what they are telling us.

See you in DC with my walking shoes and signs of support.

headline: Learning to drive at 62
commentone: I grew up on Staten Island.  The first time I took my road test there, I was in a 1964 Renault Dauphine with a push button automatic transmission.  I could not proceed on the test because either my headlights didn't work or my back up lights didn't work.  Little did I know that the Renault's headlights or backup lights (can't remember which) did not work unless the car was running or something else odd about the Renault.  Too long ago to remember the exact oddity of that car.  So I sadly went home without even being able to take the test, finding out later that my car was totally operable.  The next time I took the test was in our big boat of a family car:  a 1967 Pontiac Bonneville Brougham.  It was plum with a black vinyl roof.  Burled wood interior.  I passed.  I might note that the road test in those days was in a very hilly part of Staten Island.  So God help you if you had a standard transmission.  I taught my 3 kids to drive a standard and they all aced their test the first time. Note:  Do not take anyone out to teach them to drive a standard on a full stomach.  You'll be sorry.  Congratulations Mr. Cohen on your new found freedom.

headline: Letting  Teenagers  Live
commentone: The US no longer does policy based on evidence, rigorous testing, data analysis, etc.  Nope. We make our decisions based on greed; "FREEDOM" for the individual with the biggest voice and the most cash; bigotry and bias. Dead kids are other people's dead kids ... until they aren't.
commenttwo:
I think one problem is the cars teenagers tend to drive; particularly for lower-income families without the resources to put a priority on vehicle safety. Typically, at least around here in rural Maine, teenagers drive older vehicles, often cheap junkers, with worn tires. Remember: tires are the only thing between the driver and the road. If a car's tires lose grip, it will be more difficult for an inexperienced driver to maintain control of the vehicle. Throw in texting and other driver-distractions, and it's an accident waiting to happen.

I know a mechanic who said he's always dismayed when parents come in looking for used tires for their children's cars.

Tire safety deserves more scrutiny, particularly for inexperienced drivers.

headline: Mr. Trump’s Destructive Trade War
commentone:
Anyone notice how Trump jumps in with enthusiastic tweet policies beginning with "It's easy!" Says everything about our president: ignorance, narcissism and going after the easy stuff...until it becomes un-easy work.

Soon we will be left with Ivanka, Conway and Sanders as the only people willing to say they work...in the WH.
commenttwo:
Unfortunately we have a president who knows almost nothing of both history and economics. On top of his ignorance lies a layer of overconfidence, so what little he knows about US history and trade is skewed by his over simplified intuitive interpretation of how world trade works.

After World War II, the US took the mantle of the protector of world trade from Great Britain. Since then we have vigorously defended free and open trade for two reasons; first, the US emerged as the world's greatest industrial power after the war, so it was in our economic interest to promote open trade. Second, open trade tends to prevent another catastrophic world war. This is why the Marshall Plan demanded that Western Europe build closer economic ties.

Although the US has receded somewhat from its position as the world's leader in manufacturing, trade us not the zero-sum-game Trump makes it out to be. But more importantly, free trade promotes world peace and American democratic values. Our abdication from leading the world on this issue, abandoning the TPP to now imposing tariffs to protect our industry, opens the door to authoritarian countries like China and Russia to further exert their growing economic power in the space left by the US. But it also raises world tensions at a time when they are already on the rise.

If you think think this growing desire for fascism is frightening, you should be, not only from a growing portion of ordinary citizens who believe in this, but from those on the front line who are sworn to uphold and protect our constitution - our police and military - who also are ironically among Donald Trump‚Äö√Ñ√¥s biggest supporters.

This is the real challenge we face, not a bogeyman in the White House, but finding some way to reverse the malaise of a citizenry that has clearly lost its faith in our democratic government.

headline: Romance, Rough Sex or Rape?
commentone:
When I was a girl, Zorba the Greek (1964) taught me how to expect society to treat me.

Zorba's male friend Basil seduces a widow. A boy whose annoying attentions the widow has long rejected is aware of this, and kills himself.

The villagers hold the widow responsible for the boy's suicide--his father slits her throat in a scene I'll never forget.

Zorba pulls Basil from the scene. A mere woman's death is not to be taken deeply! Basil must not feel bad for his role in it, though he knew that she--not he--would suffer any social punishment the village might demand. They are men! This is a time for philosophy, not mourning!

Near the end, as Zorba and Basil danced together to the film's signature Greek music, I saw them as affirming their masculine above-it-all position, while I was still reeling from witnessing the murder of a woman for the "crime" of having sex with a man other than the boy who'd stalked her.

headline: Saying a Prayer I Don’t Believe In
commentone: "I am not confident that God even listens to our prayers"...... that's because there isn't one and prayers are a total waste of time.
commenttwo:
The major spiritual insight of my life occurred within the context of my gentle brother's horrible suicide. Something tore loose in me. I turned my face full on to Him as I would turn to the murderer of all people beloved to me. I spent the following years grappling with my bitterness, my despair, until I had this epiphany, a thing far more of feeling than of thought: that He Who is this world and all in it is an incomprehensible and implacable machine. I cannot "know" why I am crushed sometimes in His actions that seem indifferent and cruel. I can't understand any more easily why I and those I love or protected at times in this World. The insight brought me to my knees. The German language has a word for this feeling: ehrfurcht. It means a feeling of both awe and terror.
Finally I have come to believe that I, my brother and all humanity are His outgrowth and embodiment, His heart. Whatever He is, my journey began with the turning of my face in rage to Him. My first real words to Him were curses. It's how I finally unexpectedly located Him within myself. I still don't comprehend. All I have left is a kind of tremulous submission, of peace. And that's everything to me.

headline: The Challenge of Doctor-Patient Relations in the Internet Age
commentone:
A dear friend in her early 80s was prescribed several medications for Parkinson's. She told her neurologist many times about a horrible sensation in her head that made life unbearable. He shrugged off her complaints.

I did extensive Internet-based research about possible side effects of her medications and finally determined that the most likely culprit was bromocriptine. It can cause painful sensations in the sinuses. Alternatives exist.

Before I could get this information to her, she needed surgery for an unrelated condition. She told her daughter that she intended to die during surgery to avoid awakening with that horrible sensation still in her head.

Unfortunately, she succeeded.
commenttwo: I finally got a mug that I put in my exam rooms: Please do not confuse your google search with my medical degree.  It is not just young people.....

Countries do not last forever. Trump supporters have almost all of the guns, but moderates and liberals have the brains and most of the money (especially if the Gates, Buffets Zuckerbers and Bloombergs wake up and decide that they need to challenge the Kochs, Mercers and De Vos's to preserve democracy).

headline: The Escalation of Love
commentone: My mother in law, soon to be 99, lives in the same world as this woman. I dont think she will ever die. Not that I care either as she is invincible. She tells me I need a shave when I visit (I'm a woman).. Tells my brother in law, her son, he's fat  (he's not).. she panics if we wheel down the hall. This nebulous world she lives in, where ensure ensures she lives, she spends 12K a month to live in this place, good thing she was so cheap when she was younger, I mean that sincerely because otherwise my husband and his 5 siblings would be paying.  All my mother in law looks forward to is when we say good bye. This a woman who taught 1st grade for 20 years, who was such a good Catholic. A good mom, a great wife, a loving grandma.  It's all so sad really. She has been this way for 7 years and before that we could see she was going, we all thought she would die once as she got sick. nope! she recovered.  I miss my old mother in law. This shell, this super aged woman isn't my kids grandma (granted my kiis are 31 and 29).. It also makes me face my own mortality, going on 70... do I want her life? NO NEVER.. but my husband may have to, my family has the good sense to not live past 78..intact. It's a very sad end to a life full of love.  My mother died 18 years ago of lung cancer.. I said good bye the night before and she said good bye to me.... if my mom lived like my mother in law she would have hated it. Life is for the living, glad my mom had good sense. miss her.

headline: The Rise of  Dictatorship  Incorporated
commentone:
At this point we are the world's aggressors every bit as much as Russia et al. We export killing and expertise in the name of helping countries whose governments we see as merely "better than the alternative." We are hollowing out our own country or maybe we are merely supporting one of the few remaining industries we still excel at --war. Regardless, our country is becoming a nation of a wealthy few who support global commercialism and the hungry hordes who lack living-wage jobs, education, health care and even the infrastructure to get to work. (Obesity is a symptom of our food policies that promote cheap calories over nutrition. Ever wonder why corn has price supports but not organic vegetables? Corn is the junk food of the entire domestic animal kingdom.)

We have lost any moral authority in choosing sides. Our own government has been bought. (Have we ever before had legislation in which a significant number of Congressmen publicly stated that they voted to pay back their donors?) We are governing with the ethics of a banana republic and our Congress now cravenly asks Trump: "what legislation will you sign, so we can write it your way?" So much for checks and balances, so much for separate and equal branches of government. Money rules all.

The honest truth is that we will help Syria only on the basis of "What's in it for us?" Nation-building? We seem to be better these days at destroying our own.

headline: What Motivates Voters More Than Loyalty? Loathing
commentone: How does one point out that the country is failing to deal with vital issues because of poisonous partisanship in the face of all this 'Republicans are evil, Republicans are evil, we're the only good ones' stuff? Is it necessary to point out Democratic failures, and either be ignored by emotionally self-serving ideologues, or just increase the mud-slinging? What about just one or two questions? Like when and by who were the seeds planted for the 2008 financial crisis? How and by whom have US policies on trying to encourage democratic values and serious consideration of human rights in China by helping it become a more powerful player in international trade formulated? Maybe things are actually more complicated than hostile partisanship would suggest? In the midst of a very difficult few days, Trump just took a position on guns Democrats might be able to work with. There used to be, in Congress, and perhaps still is, just a bit, a tradition of treating members of the other party with human respect, and thus being able to engage HONESTLY in civil discourse. If the nation is ever going to craft compromises that protect people from the oncoming problems this country is facing, we all are going to have to relearn the underlying moral strength involved in treating other people - everyone, without exception, as a human being. Dehumanizing other people is the sort of moral failure that damages your own capacity to think.
commenttwo:
To argue that both sides are comparably culpable in this bifurcation of the American spirit, you must start by castigating Murrow and Sevareid and Cronkite, some of the godfathers of television journalism, or as it's known on the right, pinko propaganda.

Through the 1950's, right-wing arguments began and ended with "we have to fight the Commies there so we don't have to fight them here." If only social progress had halted then we could discuss something else today.

However, American society evolved. The ground shifted against those who had presumed a God-given ethnic or gender hierarchy; things then got ugly. In 1962, Barry Goldwater's GOP team proposed a Union ticket with Orval Faubus to offer America an unambiguously racist Presidential choice.

Now, such a ticket might not have won, but it would have been competitive. However, merely the possibility signaled that enough was enough: Those who were being steamrolled by history decided, like that lone person in Tienanmen Square, to stand strong before the tanks rolling toward racial and gender equality.

White backlash and the resentment of the Silent Majority reignited during Vietnam and again after Roe v. Wade. Each time, moreover, well-heeled Americans who saw the government as an impediment to their fortunes invested in the resentment against change, and from a few voices like Irving Kristol crying in the wilderness was born a new media dedicated to presenting as truth whatever does the job.

Let's not kid ourselves.

commenttwo:
Unfortunately many people give up years before this man. I look around the small city I live in and I see thirty year olds who are morbidly obese and out in their pjs.
I am nearly 70 and though I still work part time and go to exercise, a book club etc. ,I still often feel invisible and lonely. Life can seem meaningless. I think these feelings are not uncommon. Another thing I dislike about getting older is that people assume that they can tell you what to do. Don‚Äö√Ñ√¥t eat this, don‚Äö√Ñ√¥t do this, and they think all you care about is your next doctor appointment.
I have worked in the social service field all my adult life. I have mixed feelings about telling an 86 year old what he can or can‚Äö√Ñ√¥t do. If he wants to drink leave him alone. Threatening people with nursing homes is horrible. They are a form of hell. I have met some great people who really care in the social services field but I have met my share of misanthropes who bring great harm to vulnerable people.
I don‚Äö√Ñ√¥t have answers to any of this but I do know we lack a sense of community and caring in our culture which leave many feeling isolated more and more each year as we age.

It's ironic to listen to Brett Stephens complain about people who have sacrificed principle for power. The Republican Party made that deal in the mid-sixties when they decided to follow a "southern strategy." After Goldwater's historic defeat in 1964, the Republican powers that be realized that they could play on the racial and moral conservatism of the south as a road back to power. After decades of failing to deliver on the racial and moralistic promises that the business and Buckleyite types made, the "populists" of the south and rural areas of the country got sick of being played for fools and decided to take the party away from them. headline: God, Don’t Save the King
commentone: Most of the true believing sycophants in this administration would have been Torries in 1783, expatriated to places like Toronto, Halifax, Nassau and Kingston to avoid tar and feathers. Same goes for the "Freedom Caucua" Republicans in Congress.
commenttwo: I agree with the spirit of this column. And the republican (small R!) and democratic aspirations of the American Constitution are too obvious to need mention. But as U.S. historians will undoubtedly note, the column (and legions of U.S. history books) are misleading when it comes to analyzing the history of the U.S. Revolution. After the Glorious Revolution, the British monarchy was hardly all powerful. It was Parliament that reigned supreme in 1776! George III was favoring oppressive policies, but it was only because the British Parliament was persuaded to enact those policies that they were put into effect in the colonies. The Americans were essentially revolting against British Parliament and colonialism during the Revolutionary War, not King George. Yes, King George was a great figurehead to demonize and oppose for the colonists. And legally and technically it was to the British monarch that the colonists were required to swear allegiance. But it was Parliament that had the power.

headline: How Liberals Can Reclaim Nationalism
commentone:
Ken Galbraith (a 1960s liberal political economist) coined the expression "word-fact." When society does not approve of some aspect of itself, but saw it as too difficult to improve, Galbraith said, it just gave it a more favorable name. This tendency, noted from Orwell through Trump, seems too useful to die and appears, among many other places, in this column.

By any moderately accurate definition, "nationalism" is exclusive. Let's not ruin the word just because it's non-P.C. It is what it is, and for better or worse it's strongly reflective of, and strengthened by, our inherited tendency to divide the world into groups of some kind of "us vs. them." Even on the original Star Trek, the United Federation of Planets was at never-ending war with the Klingons and the Romulans. We real people have been expanding the "us" for a century or so, and I hope and expect we will continue, in spite of the current bump. The forces behind this expansion are mighty, but so is our genome, which will never be comfortable with the meme of expansion. Compromises will continue to be made. But the pure idea of "liberals" is not, never were, and never will partake of the pure idea of "nationalism."

Let's at least be honest and accurate virtues to be prized now more than ever...

headline: How the Tet Offensive Broke America
commentone: Excellent article.  For me one of the principal tragedies of the Vietnam War was the role played by public opinion in the United States.  The widespread support for the war got us into the conflict.  No American politician could be seen or heard to advocate steering clear of Vietnam in the late 1950s or early 1960s.  But it was public opinion, reflected by the common soldiers in this article, that eventually soured America on the conflict.  LBJ lied about the war because he did not want to be seen as the first US president to preside over a defeat, but for quite a while most Americans agreed with him.

headline: Is It Harder to Grow Up in the 21st Century Than It Was in the Past?
commentone: Growing up in the 21st century isn‚Äö√Ñ√¥t necessarily harder, just different. For a middle-class kid in a developed country like the US, the fundamentals, physical needs of life are easily met. I don‚Äö√Ñ√¥t have to worry about famine like my Chinese grandparents did. I don‚Äö√Ñ√¥t even need to cook my own meals, like my mother did. We have vaccines and medicines for sickness. However, one can argue that the generations before lived in a simpler time. My mother often tells me how life now goes much faster than it did when she was growing up. With social media and the Internet, information travels fast. We are constantly supplied with news, trends, pop culture. Kids nowadays know more, sooner. How young was I when I was first exposed to the idea of school shootings? With all this fast-moving media, kids must grow up faster, or be left behind. I feel like the mental aspect of growing has become more complicated, while the basic, physical aspect has become easier.

headline: Make Better Movies Too
commentone: I don't think I have ever liked the movie that won the Oscar.  After all these years of hoping for generally good movies, I have stopped watching them, altogether.  I'm 70.  I don't have the time to waste.
commenttwo:
No, let us not. Neither let us airbrush the Rape of the Sabines for its disturbing message that, to grow Rome into the force that ordered the Mediterranean, rape was a tool of policy. In fact, let us keep the whole history of our race as intact as we can, so that later generations can look at our messy heritage with its contradictions intact, and make their own judgements as long as they, and we today, do not burn the films and literature. Let us even keep intact the writings of Sade, of Genet, the various pornographies of sex, war, consumerism, audiophilia, fast cars, etc.
There is much in this current culture of excess to dislike. I happen to dislike, and to dislike more and more, demi-educated women who believe we need a complete reordering of society to rid us of the great evil of sexual harassment. Since the laws are in place, and the men toppling from their privileged perches, it seems now they want a purge also of the cultural heritage. It is not enough that they refuse to watch Last Tango in Paris, or Manhattan. That is their right. What is not their privilege is to deny me or any others of our right to the full record. And certainly it is not their privilege to censor current art, even if the majority of that art is, in our estimation, bad art. One generation‚Äö√Ñ√¥s Art of the Refused is another generation‚Äö√Ñ√¥s masterpieces. Modigliani‚Äö√Ñ√¥s portraits of his long time lover Jeanne were considered pornographic. Now it is easier to see them a testaments to a long love.

The only ray of hope in this sordid mess is the capacity, in some isolated matters where money isn't the sole driver of policy, for less-than-superrich people to have their opinions heard by the politically powerful.  Both #MeToo and the Parkland kids are examples of this.  I only wish there were more.

headline: Nakesha’s Demons
commentone: I don't understand why she wasn't forced to get help. I know the law is very hazy on this. I speak from experienced. My mother was a schizophrenic from the ages of 19 till the day she died. Her life under the care of the time was hellish, but eventually, things did improve. My mother lived with my family for over 21 years. She enriched the lives of my own children, just by learning about tolerance and the many different faces that love and personality can take. We have an over romanticized notion of "autonomy" and mental illness. It gives us permission to give up and neglect those who need intervention most. (Please don't think I am passing judgement on the individuals here. They clearly cared. More like a system that allows it to happen.) Please get these people the help they need, so they don't die in a gutter alone. I know that could have been my own mother. Instead my own mother died surrounded by love.
commenttwo: So many people tried to help, but our society cannot compel people to get treatment for serious mental illness.  Nakesha Williams had the freedom to not be treated for schizophrenia and the "freedom" to die on the streets.

headline: No Pension? You Can ‘Pensionize’ Your Savings
commentone: Mostly terrible advice here. People get about the same amount of money from Social Security, whether they withdraw early or late. So, why not get it early and steadily instead of waiting until later? You'll get the same amount of money, and you can work some and still get the entire benefit, and, I think, get any penalties on work pay back later (you can earn $17,400 currently before giving up $1 of SS for every $2 you earn). Anyway, beware of anybody saying wait to take SS, that is bad advice, as far as I'm concerned.
commenttwo:
There is software available to "pensionize" retirement savings. See:
www.i-orp.com,
a no fee, no registration, internet retirement optimizer that computes an optimal savings withdrawal plan that maximizes annual disposable income (after taxes, in today's dollars). The included 3-PEAT simulator measures the plan's performance during difficult historical market periods.

headline: Not the Higher Prices, It’s What Might Happen Next
commentone: Wonder how many readers realize that tariffs at one time provided almost all of US tax revenue.  A world of low tariffs is a very new, and largely unproven concept...   Some say the the Civil War was due as much to punitive tarriffs paid by Southern states for imported goods - tarriffs that protected the embryonic industrialization of the North.  A major role of Ft. Sumpter was to enforce the payments of U.S. tariffs on goods imported at Charleston.   Pocketbooks make Politics.
commenttwo: Apologetics don't excuse the bad idea of tariffs.  Saying there is not much steel or aluminum in cars seems a bit of an exaggeration and fails to see how raw material costs compound as they flow through the pipeline to effect other inputs and seed precedents for spiraling like behaviors that are what is a trade war. The author focuses too much on price--and I don't agree with his minimalization of that trend; but, whatever that, tariffs on steel and aluminum are not going to lower prices nor create Rust Belt jobs.  This is just trump trying to govern based on his will and too simple understandings that also appeal to the uneducated base of his support.

headline: Power to the Parents
commentone:
While it is your right--in the U.S.A--to cast your vote at the age of 18, so too is it your DUTY to be informed when doing so. If you don't read, if you don't inform yourself about the issues, if you don't understand at least a little world and U.S history, then you do NOT deserve to vote. If you formulate your opinions exclusively by watching your favorite echo-chamber TV station, you're not informed and thus do NOT deserve to cast a ballot.

Furthermore, if you can't answer a few basic civics questions (# of supreme court judges?, How long is the term of a U.S rep and senator?, Who's third in line to the presidency? Who was our 16th president?) then you should't be allow to vote because you're not fulfilling your DUTY to be an informed citizen!

The problem isn't that we need more votes to be cast for minor children by their parents, rather, it's that, by-and-large, the votes that are being cast are carried-out by of-age, uninformed and intellectually lazy citizens.
commenttwo: These kids are really smart, but smart is not necessarily judicious.  The voting age should continue to be 18, but the age for drinking and buying guns should be at least 21.

headline: Saying a Prayer I Don’t Believe In
commentone: The author's father was a very good man who helped my family in an invaluable way during a time of great hardship.  My family and I have always been so grateful for that assistance.  It turns out that my own father viewed saying Kaddish similarly to the author.  He acknowledged his doubts about the underlying theology, yet he felt it was his great responsibility as a Jewish person, as a son, brother and even son-in-law to, every day, without exception , say kaddish, three times a day, during the requisite period.  He obtained speeding tickets both on the Taconic and Thruway rushing home to Albany from business trips in order to make those evening minyans at Temple Israel!  Thanks to Jay Lefkowitz for this wonderful piece.
commenttwo: You appear to say you are a tad over burdoned!  Belief in a God, will do that!  I have tried many Protestant Faiths and the Catholic Faith, spent time talking to a neighborhood Rabbi, spent a time, a week or so in a Franciscan Monastery, and had my own dedicated private NADA!  Since, I have been very content with myself, what is right and wrong for me, and a brand new experience at the end, to look forward to!

headline: The Challenge of Doctor-Patient Relations in the Internet Age
commentone:
Oh no, people no longer put blind trust in doctors! Increasingly people want to hear recommendations from multiple sources before making decisions - it's a disaster!
Cry me a river.
This healthy empowerment, skepticism, and self-confidence is exactly the behavior we should be fostering in citizens. Search on my fellow patient citizens!
Ask at least two doctors before making a decision when you can. Don't be surprised when you get two diametrically opposing answers. Don't be surprised when you are shamed for questioning their expertise and bruising a fragile ego either. Most importantly, talk to other patients with the same symptoms or diagnosis. They know things doctors never will.
commenttwo: Patients are decision makers & look to their HCPs for guidance. But when that guidance is given w/o the "why," patients rightfully look elsewhere to help them understand what's being recommended and what they should expect w/re to potential side effects and the lived experience of other patients. This is what "engaged" patients do. And hopefully, they have good enough relationships with their HCPs to continue the consultation before they make decisions that they alone have to live with.

Some of these indictments may very well be returned against his family members. Significantly more scandalous and disturbing information will follow into the public realm, and endlessly analyzed by media commentators.

In such a charged, consuming, post-indictment environment, with Trump fully expected to be the "next in line" to be held to account, it is difficult to imagine the American electorate, by then disgusted, fed-up, and angered, not being highly motivated to "throw out of office" those party members who had selected, embraced, enabled, and excused the decidedly unpresidential conduct of their leader. Even if some of Trump's base of support stubbornly holds, Independents will probably vote Democratic by wide margins, while Democrats will be greatly motivated by the prospect of acquiring control of Congress or at least one House.

headline: The Macroeconomics of Trade War
commentone:
So much of Dr. K's analysis on economic things is based on his belief in the presence of FULL EMPLOYMENT in America. This is so totally divorced from the on-the-ground reality of the common people. This economic statistics calculation stands as likely the least accurate of all the typically published representations of the U.S. economy. An 18 hour a week, $9 a hour, virtually no benefits part time job in a retail or restaurant setting is a WHOLE job, counted as one by the economists. For the common person, this is 1/3 of a job. It is in reality.

The sociologists know the truth. Look at their studies of the number of adults living and depending on their parents, the number on disability (faked or real), the part time job market, the underemployed, the crisis in home buying, car buying, and student debt.

Add it all up and we are approaching Depression levels of employment dislocation, with is accompanied by social dislocation and terrible human suffering manifested in many forms.

Economic viability for common people is the biggest and most important challenge on earth.

headline: The Supreme Court’s Power Play Against Labor

Thank you, Ms. Greenhouse, as a knowledgeable Supreme Court "insider", for parting the grand velvet curtains, the pomp and circumstance, and exposing what these robed partisans are really up to: the promotion of raw, unadulterated, power politics. headline: What Motivates Voters More Than Loyalty? Loathing
commentone:
This is completely "dog bites man." An awful truth, which can be confirmed anecdotally multiple times/day.

I have never voted out of hatred. But I have been voting "against" rather than "for" all my life. In fact, for my first few decades I simply stayed home, except for voting three times against Nixon (one was for governor of CA) and once against Goldwater (from fear he would escalate the Vietnam war; boy did I get that one wrong!) These days, living in Maryland which is solid Democratic, I vote Libertarian -- an "a plague on both your houses" message.

So Hillary was widely detested -- didn't need a poll to get that one, either -- and (in hindsight) too dumb to go into those swing districts in PA, Ohio, wherever it cost her the electoral college. Trump just wasn't considered serious.

But going into 2020, there will be far more voters who detest Trump. If the Democrats can stay away from Bernie, Elizabeth Warren, and anybody else who evokes revulsion at themselves personally, maybe we can get back to a sane and reasonable President. Frankly, if we could get that, I wouldn't care much what his/her party label was.
commenttwo:

Republicans had no one close to her accomplishments, abilities, understanding of policies, or grasp of issues. So, Republicans scratched and clawed, kicked and spit, threw mud and their own faults at Clinton.

headline: What We Will Lose When the Union Carbide Building Falls
commentone:
A picture may not always be better than 1,000 words, but in this case it sure is. The picture shows a magnificent building; the article tells us things such as a 52-story building is "human-scaled" but a taller one (as yet undesigned) won't be; the Seagram Building, which imho is made more open and more part of the street by its plaza, is less part of the street than the Union Carbide which "fills its entire site."

In addition to such nonsensical statements, which are at best the value judgments of a very few experts, we get plenty of mush about "more pragmatic compositional effect" and that "romantic" I-beams "recall the intricate ribbing of Gothic cathedrals."

The material about SOM's inner workings is, to me at least, interesting, and I couldn't agree more with the sad commentary on the destruction of Edward Stone's beautiful "folly" on Columbus Circle. But the rest of this piece is arty bullxxxx.
commenttwo: These buildings are now entering that critical 50-75 year range where they are commonly seen as just old and outdated. A lot of Victorian architecture was lost when it reached this age, often to be replaced with buildings like this. If it makes it past 75, it‚Äö√Ñ√¥s historic significance will gradually become more recognized. If it doesn‚Äö√Ñ√¥t, people will wonder why the philistines of the early 21st century denied them their history. It‚Äö√Ñ√¥s just the way it goes.

headline: What You Might Come Across

headline: What to Expect (And Not) at the Oscars
commentone: Why in the world does anyone care about these silly awards? George C. Scott was right; it's a meat parade and a travesty, especially the artificially created "suspense" over announcing who the winners are. It's like little kids sitting and waiting for their awards. And the Oscars has such a lousy record of ignoring great films and performances while awarding total duds that it is more of a laugher than a serious record of film achievement. Pass.
commenttwo:
What I expect is nothing, since that is what the Oscars have so often delivered. They have long been a politicized travesty, an elaborate buddy club, an old-boy-net -- anything but a reflection of artistic excellence. There are countless examples, notably not a single nomination for "The Searchers" and 9 statuettes for the deplorable, unwatchable "Around the World in 80 Days" the same year. And the contrived "suspense"! Laughable. If they want to give our awards, why not just post a list of winners, have a party for them, and go home? Of course, that would eliminate the single biggest night of national free advertising enjoyed by any industry on earth. Here's a smattering of Oscar's long list of failures:

http://www.filmsite.org/noawards3.html

headline: When Elder Abuse Is Self-Inflicted
commentone:
I'd love a discussion on what is available for older folks who have no children or other means of support. Let's look at a situation where you have an older married couple, one dies, and the one left does not have the mental or physical capacity to downsize, sell a home, and also select and move to a retirement home, all on their own.

In this scenario, I can easily imagine how the remaining spouse could end up staying in a home they can no longer maintain (physically and/perhaps monetarily), and eventually, becoming so isolated, weak, lonely, sick, depressed that they become entrenched in a downward spiral of hopelessness.

headline: A Trump Fawners Almanac
commentone: The widely documented dinner with Sessions, Rosenstein, and the third in command at DOJ sends mixed messages, but I found it somewhat reassuring that they seemed to be presenting a united front and, perhaps, signaling (because Rosenstein has publicly approved M's work thus far) that they are not going to interfere with the Mueller investigation. Sessions has a lot of ludicrous, nasty, racist ideas, which I think he truly believes as opposed simply to finding them politically expedient. but did he find lying under oath to be as abhorrent as the rest of us?   He was likely asked to lie under oath about his Russian meetings, and perhaps finds that mortifying.  Best case scenario is that he is now reacting with a personal pledge to stick to the letter of the law from here on out, and protect Mueller.  That is my, probably foolish, hope
commenttwo:
Anyone noticed that the fawn-fests seem to have stopped, or at the very least, are fewer and far between?

of course it could be due to all the recent departures, but it might also explain the president's worse than usual rages since Wednesday.

most men I know get over rages by working out, cursing, or binge-watching dumb movies. of course Donald Trump is not like any other man, and in terms of hobbies, his biggest is himself.

His answer to troubling anger is to threaten tariffs, bring down markets, and have allies pull out their retaliatory game plans prepared during the campaign.

Will somebody please tell the president to organize a "buck up the president" rally so he can start feeling good again?

I'd rather see a smarmy crowd I can turn off then watch markets dive because Donald Trump is out of sorts.

headline: A Whole Lot Is Riding On This New ‘Wrinkle’
commentone: All the commenters griping about Ms. DuVernay‚Äö√Ñ√¥s casting of a young black girl as Meg - a response borne of fear and hate - seem to have missed one of the novel‚Äö√Ñ√¥s central themes: Love saves us all.
commenttwo:
Hopefully this film will preserve the anti-authoritarian message of the novel. Some scary scary stuff happens to the kids in the book (and to their parents). And it's rooted in what the author saw as an evil in society.

As L'Engle's granddaughter told the WSJ: "[T]he book wasn't a simple allegory of communism. Instead, it's about the risk of any country -- including a democracy -- placing too much value on security."

Will that message shine through? That glimmer of L'Engle's gentle Episcopalianism? I hope so.

commentone: As an atheist, I find it repugnant that our national capital, under a Constitution that draws a hard line between government and religion, will waste money honoring this person.  Let him be honored on his own time by people who were in his congregation.  Don't waste my tax dollars sanctifying farcical nonsense.
commenttwo: My thoughts on Billy Graham aside (I have nothing new to add to that conversation), I do appreciate his wife's grave marker. Funny and humble. I like it.

headline: At Heart of Tight Race, Folks Who Picked Trump But Wish They Hadn’t
commentone: While it is obvious that Congress, and all of Washington DC for that matter, is badly broken, I'm forever baffled that voters continuously complain that our elected officials don't work together. Do they not understand that we are electing these same candidates over and over? I think voters express frustration at gridlock without really looking at themselves. I believe that many of these people who are looking for compromise ultimately want their political opponents to surrender. That seems to be the definition of compromise these days. And in Trumpworld, everything is a zero sum outcome, where there are only winners and losers. I still hold out hope that his voters are starting to see that they, and most of the rest of us, are on the losing side of his daily circus act.

headline: Big Banks May Weaken Dodd-Frank Oversight
commentone: I guess I'm glad I'm not rich...  Wait a minute, what is a soul worth these days?  Nothing?  I guess I'm glad I'm not rich.
commenttwo: It might be helpful to remember, as Senator Brown suggests with his "collective amnesia" comment, that after the Glass-Stegal Act, a Depression-era law to prevent the kind of bank abuses seen in the 1920's, was repealed in 1999, it took the banking industry only nine years to collapse the economy.  And while Wall Street was bailed out Main Street was not.  Main Streeters who haven't forgotten should be writing, emailing, and phoning their Congressman to stop this latest attack on the nation's economic health.
