headline: Can There Be Good Porn?
commentone:
I have no problems with good porn. I have serious problems with sick porn. While porn and art are fuzzy in some cases, as Supreme Court Justice, Potter Stewart, has famously said "I know it when I see it," there are indeed differences between good and bad porn.

However, if the author wants to promote social responsibility, perhaps the porn industry should consider promoting safe sex like the use of condom and avoiding violence. How about some storyline when one party said no and the other party complied? But then, with this sort of ideas imbued in the story, is it still porn?
commenttwo:
There ARE pornographers and actresses who possess intelligence. And who are we to judge the I.Q. of certain actors. Google Kay Parker, for example, from the golden age of porn. She was not only incredibly sexy, but added grace and gravitas to her scenes. Georgina Spelvin, the star of the highly regarded The Devil In Miss Jones, was another.

And there are shops devoted to sexual aids that are owned by and largely operated for women, for them to explore their sexuality. I know many accomplished and smart women who frequent them. One shopowner was President of the Coolidge Corner (Brookline, MA) Chamber of Commerce. She would have classes on sexuality, as well as bring in famous actresses and female producers of porn.

The stuff is out there and not to be looked down upon.

This will be a formidable task with an uncertain outcome but hope for a positive change is all they can wish for.  There's little else I'm afraid.

He demands loyalty but has none to give. He changes his positions to suit himself because he does not consider himself to be part of the GOP or any other party. He is just The Donald. headline: Disenchantment for Aide Grew With the Spotlight
commentone:
‚Äö√Ñ√∫Goodbye to Hope Hicks, an object lesson in the quickest way a woman can advance under misogyny: silence, beauty, and unconditional deference to men.‚Äö√Ñ√π - Jia Tolentino

The next paragraph supposes to reveal Hope's other qualities, but except for her reported skill as a liaison to the press these other qualities are still defined in relation to a man. Controlling a man: having an understanding the man's moods, ability lessen his coarser impulses.

Whether it is preventing a man from becoming angry, from doing something stupid, or stopping a mass murdering gunman or terrorist it too often seems a women's role, and worth, is defined by how she acquiesces or controls a man.

"Well behaved women rarely make history" - Laurel Thatcher Ulrich
commenttwo: Now there's truly no hope in/for the White house!

headline: Dorm Living for Professionals
commentone: I am not opposed to communal or co-op living where residents are stakeholders and share in responsibilities and establishing policies. This setup, though, appears to lack any of that. I knew a few people 30 years ago who lived in co-op houses.  One house in particular was huge Victorian home with ten housemates. There was a process of selecting a new tenant when a room became available to assess whether the person was a good fit. I don't see any indication in this piece that these properties have any type of measure to determine compatibility of dorm mates. I'd personally be pretty upset if I was paying over $2,000 a month and getting potentially annoying/weird/unpleasant floor mates with whom I'd need to share a lounge space, kitchen, and bathroom. Is there any type of mediation measure available to the residents?  Any house rules in place?  Someone is bound to pee all over the toilet seat, cook smelly food, leave a mess in the kitchen, have a creepy boyfriend/girlfriend who hogs the couch and TV.  For that price I would want a say in the tenant selection, but it does not sound like that's part of the process.
commenttwo: The monthly rent aside, $130 extra a week for cleaning a single dorm room is beyond outrageous!  I live in a pricey Metro Boston suburb and pay a housecleaner that same amount every other week to clean my four-bedroom, three-bathroom, 2800-sf house. Of course, I pay the person directly -- I'm sure "scarcity" takes a hefty cut before paying the cleaners minimum wage.

headline: Fame Lived and Played Here
commentone: In the late 1950s, my wife's widowed grandmother rented her summer cottage in Chatham to musicians who were appearing at jazz impresario George Wein's famed Boston nightclub Storyville, the Newport Jazz Festival, and Storyville's short-lived offshoot in the nearby town of Harwich. Jazz greats (with and without their families) who stayed in the house we live in now included Josh White, Stan Free, Dave Brubeck, Sarah Vaughn (and her trio), and Wein himself. The Divine Sarah was the last to rent, and my wife remembers as a small child seeing her drummer taking his kit out to his car. There was music sublime in what a friend has dubbed the "Jazz House."

headline: Fervent Defense of Tariffs (Unless Trump Flip-Flops)
commentone:
‚Äö√Ñ√∫Whatever his final decision is, is what will happen,‚Äö√Ñ√π Mr. Ross said on NBC‚Äö√Ñ√¥s ‚Äö√Ñ√∫Meet the Press.‚Äö√Ñ√π ‚Äö√Ñ√∫What he has said he has said. If he says something different, it‚Äö√Ñ√¥ll be something different.‚Äö√Ñ√π

I am so, so, tired of this nonsense.
commenttwo:
Let's face it. He has no idea what he wants here.

By tomorrow, another adviser or a lobbying group will have convinced him to do something completely different. This fiasco is just like the DACA legislation promise ("I'll sign whatever this group puts in front of me" only to be reversed two days later). It is just like the GOP healthcare bill of 2017. He throws a beer party on the back lawn and then calls the legislation "too mean" the following week. And it follows the pattern of promises and then back-pedaling on gun violence legislation.

If Robert Mueller announced more indictments tomorrow, Trump would announce plans to designate cheeseburgers as the national entree.

headline: Fights Worth Having
commentone: The first 3/4s of this column was good. What Stephens dismisses as "social justice warriors" are not a mirror image of the Trumpists. They are not anti-reason they way Trumpists are. I fear the Democrats may blow their chance to turn our country around, away from the current neo-fascist trend, but I don't think Mr. Stephen's portrait of the challenge that liberals face is accurate.
commenttwo:
That Stephens can hail Mona Charen's banal observations about Trump and the GOP as "brave" and "courageous" is a sad indication of just how far gone the Right is in this country. To read Stephens, you'd think Charen had made some devastating critique of Burkean eloquence against her fellow conservatives at CPAC. What utter nonsense. She merely expressed "disappointment" in their hypocrisy. I can't think of a milder, more milquetoast criticism that could be leveled against Trump and the GOP: a political party of truly breathtaking venality and viciousness. The fact that Charen had to be escorted from the CPAC premises for uttering obvious truths, delicately phrased at that, only proves how awful the Trumpistas are.

And the idea that the American left has any equivalent of the Trump movement is a fantasy that Stephens and other conservatives cling to with increasing desperation. Does the left have intolerant and ideologically blinkered members among it? Sure. Does it have *anything* like the full-blown, anti-democratic, openly racist, misogynist, quasi-fascist radicalism that has become de rigueur among the mainstream Trump-supporting GOP? Not even close.
Sorry Stephens and other 'moderate' conservatives of his ilk: Trumpism is a political disease that you especially need to account for and find a way to solve. Liberals have nothing even remotely equivalent to be ashamed of.

headline: First Lady Is a Fit for Genius Visa. Einstein? Iffy.
commentone:
Our priorities are so skewed.
Do we really need a fast track for fashion models ?
Next time you visit your elderly aunt in the nursing home, take a look at who is caring for these most vulnerable citizens.
Next time you eat out at a fancy restaurant, sneak a look behind the door to see who is washing the dishes.
Next time you slog to work in a northern city after a big storm, notice who is manually shoveling the city sidewalks so you don't break your neck.
Query who picked those berries on your breakfast tomorrow morning.
America needs a lot more than just "Einsteins."
commenttwo: Seems to me that what is needed is a good lawyer and a well connected sponsor.  Trump always bragged that he made political contributions to members of both parties so that he could have access and obtain favors.  In this case, I'm confident Trump called in a few chits with a few politicians who made a few strategic phone calls.  And voila!  The system works.

headline: Go Ahead, Millennials, Destroy Us
commentone:
And these children that you spit on
As they try to change their worlds
They're immune to your consultations
They're quite aware of what they're going through
commenttwo: Geez, Tim Kreider.  I'm middle-aged, too, I'm not terrified of the young, and I'm in no rush to be offed.  I'm not rabidly partisan, etc., all the knee-jabbin' cites of bad generational apples.  We need each other, young and middle and old.  It's kinda creepy of you to relinquish ALL of our generation as problematic idiots---although I'm not proud of many members of our generation.  But, please.  You don't speak for all of us.

headline: God, Don’t Save the King
commentone:
"If Trump were king, opponents would be jailed for failing to clap during his speeches. He calls that ageless act of defiance treason. The Constitution calls it something else."

I've heard pundits say at least our institutions seem to be holding up against the full-throttled assault against them by would-be strongman Donald Trump.

Yes, but barely, They demand constant vigilance in a swirl of mind-numbing threats, changes, announcements, attacks, and tweets---practically every one of them fodder for trying to re-educate the American people on our history and our values.

Some may be hard to bring back once the Trumps exit Washington. But I'm less concerned with the when than the how. Ideally, Robert Mueller is allowed to finish his mission of proving that no elected official is above the law.

The carnival act called the White House would make for very bad TV--some plots are insane, others too obvious. Many of the actors are 4th rate.

And so far we've escaped real disaster. Season Two seems surreal, and some of the grownups are leaving--McMaster on his way out, per the latest.

How will this series play if we have a major depression from tariffs or an impulsive war cooked up by "public servants" in way over their heads?

It's one thing to say you're going to shake up Washington--but quite another to blow it up instead
commenttwo: The focus on the British monarchy is misplaced. In the case of the Irish famine, and even the policies leading to the American revolution, the culprit was not the Crown, but Parliament.  Donald Trump, in his historical ignorance, may think he wants to be king, but kings these days have no real power; what he really aspires to (although he may not be able to articulate it) is to be dictator for life, like Putin, Erdogan, Mugabe, etc. On the other hand, since Trump doesn't appear to actually know how to do anything, maybe he really does understand what it means to be king:  a rich figurehead who doesn't have to master any of the nuances of government.

headline: Goodbye, Pay-as-You-Wish
commentone:
When we face cuts to funding for arts and education, we should be dong exactly the opposite. This is not just a problem at the Met. Instead of arguing about how much and how deep, we should ask ourselves how much it would cost to fully fund our arts and educational institutions. It has been stated repeatedly that these programs account for a small fraction of our economy but improve people's lives and the opportunities available to them.

This is also just a bad idea. The museum draws people to the city. Unless their intention is not to raise funds but to limit the number of visitors...dum de dum dum!
commenttwo: This is why a base of people think the coast's and cities are elitist. An institution with a large endowment can't be bothered to provide access to art. Art is supposed to be seen and inspire all types of people from all types of backgrounds.

headline: Hooray for Harvey-less Hollywood!
commentone:
"As one male executive at the heart of the hive complained: ‚Äö√Ñ√∫Men‚Äö√Ñ√¥s heads are on sticks with blood pouring down their faces. Whatever happened to the fun boy-girl game?‚Äö√Ñ√πz'

Fun? Fun for whom?

The answer is self-evident. But I agree with Maureen on perhaps the most salient lines in her essay:

‚Äö√Ñ√∫Men are doing a head fake, saying, ‚Äö√Ñ√≤Yeah, yeah, of course we want to fix it,‚Äö√Ñ√¥ while what they‚Äö√Ñ√¥re really thinking is, ‚Äö√Ñ√≤How do we get out of this looking like we do something without doing anything?"

Hollywood really isn't that different from Washington, now is it? Trying to get credit without giving up the perks, privileges, and pressure from donors and lobbyists seems to be the way powerful white men deal with our country's greatest issues.

Oh, they think it's defense, the stock market, and the economy, stupid, like all their peers.

Not so the other half, who think it's more than time to do something serious about guns, sexual abuse and creepy quid pro quos---real action, not lip service, for a change.
commenttwo:
Hollywood as we knew it never did us much good, imo. Obesity, violence, anti-intellectualism, sexism - they are all products of and connected to what comes out of that system. Our obsession with fame, made insidious via the technological tools that give us far too much information, creates a kind of pathetic, needy culture. We're a big collective of suspended-disbelief bots who stay way too suspended. And I see so many young people who think fame (via likes) is a goal. Not talent, just fame. I really do see it as something wrong within our world, as a negative value that has metastasized.

How many of those women news anchors are also journalists vs how many are talking heads in weird tight dresses? Very confused group. How about we stop expecting skinny arms and face paint while we hear about children being killed in schools? We've got decades of movies and tv stations permanently mixed up in our heads and we let it define own identity and own pursuit of happiness.

headline: How the Tet Offensive Broke America
commentone:
I was in a Marine Corps Platoon Leaders class at Quantico, Va. during the summer of 1967. We were in training to become Marine Corps 2nd Lieutenants leading troops in Vietnam once we graduated from college in June 1968. I had my doubts about the war but I was still surprised that during the entire 10 week class the war itself was hardly discussed. No lectures from officers about stopping Communism or defending South Vietnam. Nothing about fighting for our country. Not even anything about upholding the honor of the Marine Corps.

The lieutenant in charge of our training platoon seemed never to leave his office. Rumor had it that he was against the war so that was why we never saw him. Our day-to-day training was conducted by two drill sergeants, one white and one black, both recently back from Vietnam. They did all the traditional hazing the Marine Corps is known for, although without any real malice or spirit.

They didn't mention the war except a couple of times when they wanted to emphasize the importance of learning what they were teaching us. They explained that if we didn't there was a good chance that when we got over to Nam our platoon would discover that what WE didn't know might get THEM killed. If that happened they might decide to roll a grenade into our tent one night so they could get someone who might know what he was doing. "Fragging,"they called it. I think they were sincerely trying to be helpful. This was almost a year before the Tet Offensive.
commenttwo: Professor Mark Moyar  and General H.R. McMaster have argued at length not too long ago that we could and should have won the war. Counterfactual history, a specialty of military intellectuals.  If only they had been in charge.

headline: Hugs, Smiles And a Pistol At the Ready
commentone:
As a long term member of a regional school committee I found that having an officer on staff, as it were, was a good way to normalize the presence of police within the community. I think that often the police are considered as a "them" rather than one of us. "Us" is far better in terms of officers' abilities to work with citizens (younger and older) and to also keep officers from feeling shut out from their community.

However, there is only so much an officer can do at a school, from the perspective of logistics and distance in large buildings. We expect that such officers as well as teachers are going to offset sometimes big deficiencies in parenting. After all, schools have kids for only about 20% of their waking hours, yet are supposed to be able to address all ills, from abuse and addiction to poor behavioral control and disrespect for teaching - which are often learned at home. Let's keep that in mind as we try to pile yet another task on top of the staff at schools, which were once able to concentrate on - dare I say it - education.

headline: Is It Harder to Grow Up in the 21st Century Than It Was in the Past?
commentone:
Is It Harder to Grow Up in the 21st Century Than It Was in the Past?
Ryan Brooks

I personally believe it is harder to grow up in the 21st century than it was in the past mainly due to social media and the internet. Although I obviously was not alive in previous centuries and therefore cannot compare personal experiences in each time period, I know for a fact that previous generations did not have the IPhones and social media platforms we have today. Many people argue the benefits of social media: being connected to distant friends and family, being caught up in world events, spreading positivity and protest, etc. However, the negative aspects of social media outweigh the positives for most teenagers growing up in the 21st century. Cyberbullying is a huge issue, and I have experienced it personally. In the past, if you we bullied, you would see the bully at school, but then you could retreat to the safety of your own home at the end of the day. Today, you are never safe from bullies thanks to social media. They can harass you through the phone even when you are at home. I‚Äö√Ñ√¥ve had people prank call me, leave harassing text messages, post about me on Instagram and Snapchat, etc. It‚Äö√Ñ√¥s torture. In earlier centuries, the technology for cyber bullying to take place on would not have existed and kids growing up back then would not have to deal with it.
commenttwo: As time has gone on, people have found ways to make life easier. Technology advances in the past century, or so, have made communication faster and more efficient than ever before. Before cell phones there was writing letters that could take weeks to receive, and then came morse code, and Alexander Gram Bell‚Äö√Ñ√¥s first telephone, but just because there are so many inventions to make life easier it doesn‚Äö√Ñ√¥t necessarily mean that life is actually easier. I believe that growing up in the 21st century is harder than it was in the past. Bringing it back to technology; technology allows people to know everything that is going on in the world politically, economically, and socially. Newspapers have become electronic, so people can find out about news minutes after they happen. When something big happens, people like to post it on their facebook or instagram accounts, and even if we do not want anyone finding out about something word spreads fast thanks to texting. People today have no privacy. Technology exposes us all whether we realize it or not. Before technology people could be there own person, and not who the media made them out to be. When you would met someone for the first time, you couldn‚Äö√Ñ√¥t google their name and find out about their life, there were no previous expectations. The pressure people face today is extreme and unlike it has ever been before.  Pressures in school, pressures to be accepted by society both on and off of the media, and pressures to just simply succeed.

headline: It Was Only a Matter of Time: Here Comes an App for Fake Videos
commentone: Thanks a lot for sending tens of thousands of people out looking for the fake Obama video and inspiring the creation of even more of them. Seriously, did you really need to use that particular example? And start your piece with a salacious description of it? Couldn't you have just said "video of a famous person" and left the name out completely and the details to the imagination? New York Times, what journalistic purpose does it serve to take the image of the first lady and defile it that way?
commenttwo:
AI needs to be regulated. If a hacker could take an AI tool released by Google to create Fake App it could also be used by China, Russia, North Korea and Iran for more insidious purposes. It can also be used by businesses in unethical ways to increase their bottom line. This is a lesson that we need to learn well before it is too late. This may be the new reality but needs to be used carefully and for the good and not the evil.
It is already a problem that AI is not transparent and that we do not know why AI makes decisions it does after feeding it with lots of data. AI needs to be develop AI so that it can communicate why it does what does and also to be able to determine what foreign AI is doing. This is something that is difficult to do but if FakeApp can be used to change video without being able to determine that it was done we have given the machine independent processes that we cannot track. We should be scared of this, very scared until we can make AI transparent.

headline: Learning to drive at 62
commentone:
Try getting a license in France at the age of 64. Mine shouted at me right off the bat, belittled me for not downshifting down a hill, asked in a loud voice why he was being forced to conduct the exam, and then tried to trick me into speeding in a 30kph zone (something less that 19mph).

But there is a thread through the process: they don't want you to kill someone. When you get to the written test, when you get to the driving test, all they're interested in is, Are you going to kill someone? They do a good job.
commenttwo: Fine first step. But wait until a day comes when you're feeling slightly deranged. Then you'll be ready to drive in Manhattan.

Erector sets.  Go outside!  Children grow up dumb because their parents are stupid.  Yes, I am speaking to all of YOU.

Absurd comparison. It's fine to discuss how to avoid deaths related to auto accidents, but it's wrong to do so in the context of guns. The purpose of a car is transportation from point A to point B. The purpose of a gun is to kill.

This surly wasn't Leonhardt's intention, but by linking the deaths of Stoneman Douglas students in a tragic 2009 accident to the more recent deaths in a tragic shooting only serves to diminish the unique horror that took place last month and provides some form of cover for the NRA. The shooting wasn't an accident. The gun did exactly what it was designed to do.

headline: Lower the Voting Age to 16
commentone:
I teach high school. Although I understand the author's distinction between cold and hot cognition, I disagree with the author's proposal that 16-year-olds be allowed to vote.

The fact that 16-year-olds, with their eloquent and articulate arguments in favor of gun control, are able to shame legislators who have been bought by the NRA does not mean that they should be given the vote. Other groups of students, even younger, noble, honorable things without anyone suggesting that they be given the vote.

The fact that 16-year-olds, when calm, can be rational and make informed decisions does not mean that they do so. Indeed, they often do not, partly because they have little experience and knowledge of the world. And even those who have much knowledge of the world still have little experience with it. Most have not worked full-time to support themseves, pay taxes, be in a long-term relationship, or do any of the many things that adults have done that 16-year-olds have not.

Mark Twain wrote, "When I was 14, I was amazed at how stupid my old man was. By age 21, I was amazed at how much smarter he had became."

There are other things we can do that will improve American democracy far more than lowering the voting age. Campaign finance reform and an end to gerrymandering, while unrelated to who has the franchise, would greatly improve American democracy. Easier registration and voting have helped, and can help more. And improving education will make better-informed 18-year-olds.
commenttwo: For the same reasons we don‚Äö√Ñ√¥t let 16 year olds serve on juries or hold them culpable to adult standards when they commit a crime, they should not vote.    The reason given here is specious.     Children ride and die in cars, too, yet that is irrelevant.

headline: Make Better Movies Too
commentone: I didn't hear the writer say anything about censorship. I heard her call for movies that show complicated people. The real world has diversity and people cannot be placed in categories such as in the dumbed-down movies Hollywood makes. I loved Black Panther, because it showed Africans as smart, sassy, beautiful people (with great clothes I might add). I loved Three Billboards because it showed a difficult white woman fighting the police, and a sheriff who was sensitive and understanding, and, yes, a racist who  grows in the movie. I will not see dumbed-down movies, and that is my choice, and I'm not taking away that choice from anyone. I do wish, though, that there were more movies for me.
commenttwo:
There is a danger of pressing too hard or seizing control of a spontaneous movement based on one's own taste and vision.

No, I am not a big fan of unimpeded 1st Amendment. I have parted ways with the ACLU decades ago until recently because of that. So, sure, there are movies no one should produce or watch.

However, the danger of seizing control of a spontaneous movement based on one's own vision, no matter how well meaning, can be disastrous in the long run. I have used NCAAP as an example many times ago. A long time ago, it wasn't just a predominately black organization. There was a coalition. Then, depending on who is telling the tale, it has become one. No, there is no restriction for non black to be part of it; however, it is so for all intent and purposes.

Political correctness is dangerous when it becomes a way to shut other people up. Instead of "getting rid of bad movies," just let them fail at the box office. Or tell the world why they are bad. Why, if you really want to attack bad movies, start with all sort of reality shows like The Bachelor and The Bachelorette first

headline: Mr. Trump’s Problem With Democracy
commentone:
"Mr. Trump was surely joking about becoming president for life himself." Stop right there, please, Editorial Board.

Please consider that this thought would never have occurred to Donald Trump on his own. He's as familiar with the Constitution--and the 22nd Amendment prescribing term limits for the presidency--as I am of liquid calculus.

As corrupt as this White House is, and this includes the president, his family, and his staff, let us entertain the "fantasy" that this might be a gambit by the Russians to solder the chain to the ball that they have surely affixed around the American ankle.

The "president" will be 72 in three months and could be with us for quite some time. One would assume that the Republican doormats on Capitol Hill would hold their noses to any proposal to alter the Constitution--particularly in the case of this acid president. However, when wonders at the silence, the absence of outrage, the patriotism gone quiet that once fueled the Republican Party (even if it was a weapon in the culture wars--a smirking dodge), one worries that Mitch McConnell and Paul Ryan and all their ideological gerbils on the right-wing treadmill might just actually try to shove this down our throats, cementing the worst president in our nation's history in office--permanently.

Trump takes orders first from Vladimir Putin and secondly from the evil triumvirate (Mercer-Koch-Shadow Donor Network). He hasn't a clue and that suits the Russians and the American traitors just fine.
commenttwo: Remember when Republicans screamed "communist" and hurled "red" as an epithet? No one mentions these days that the leader of China is a communist, or that Putin mourns the fall of the Soviet Union and longs for his KGB days.  Guess it's just not convenient for Republicans to hate communists any longer, but it sure used to suit them.  I guess that's why they're called "red" states now.

headline: Nakesha’s Demons
commentone: Molested repeatedly. Ending up having two children as a homeless person -- so some men were involved with that. When you life is this hard, I imagine many people would become emotionally and mentally sick, despite intelligence. It's tragic.....but there are causes....and men and women who 'look the other way' and use others are what contributes to this chain of misery. It's heartbreaking, some men and women helped....but there ARE causes.....and well, we must strive to do better at the sources of such misery.
commenttwo:
Thank you Benjamin Weiner for writing a compassionate profile that reminds us that everyone has a story -- every homeless person we walk by was once someone's treasured daughter, son, friend, student. When we define someone as "other" we can believe it couldn't happen to us, or our family member, or friend, but this story reminds us not to turn away. No one is "other."

When I first was out of college I worked in homeless shelters for four years. Working in social services puts a person at the heart of human frailty -- we are all vulnerable, all fallible, and so many of us are one tragic loss, or illness, or a few paychecks away from the whole illusion of "security" crumbling.

I had grown up in comfortable, wealthy suburbs. The clear impression I was left with after those burnout years at the shelters was that the variety of homeless people I met were so very much like the variety of people in my home town. There were unlucky people, optimistic types, charmers, mentally ill people, substance abusers, angels, and mean folks in my home town. Same with the shelters -- only difference was the people in the shelters no longer, or never had, a safety net. Their families weren't rich to begin with. They ran out of friends to stay with. They lost their jobs. Some lost their children. Every winter, some lost their lives. But they weren't that different. They really weren't any different from me.

headline: Power to the Parents
commentone:
I have another idea. Rather than introduce a new way to pose young interests against old interests, what if we really tried to achieve what was best for the nation, both its present and its future?

What if we implored candidates to seek the truth? That would mean we speak openly to all the issues, bringing both present tensions and future consequences to the discussion, but only when we have incontrovertible data about causation rather than our political leanings about potential effects?

What if we spoke openly about children born to single parents? What if we discussed the data on divorce and returned it to being an outcome to be shunned? What if we discussed infidelity? How about we stopped talking about the myriad subjects we might teach in schools and held public schools accountable on basic skills of non-partisan quantitative and verbal reasoning? What if we stopped trying to repeal the 2nd Amendment and starting addressing the truly unusual effects of its currently limitless protection of firearm ownership? What if we said you can have abortions without treating aborted fetuses like detritus in lab experiments? What if we spoke openly to seniors about the impact their property taxes have both on the education of their town's children and their property values?

What if we stopped trying to divide the world into opposing groups of Black and White, gay and straight, male and female? What if, instead, we asked whether policy was objectively beneficial to the nation?
commenttwo:
Here's another delightful ploy by a conservative religious pundit to justify God's command that we be fruitful and multiply. Like the famous child tax credits, it ensures that having more children will turn into a political advantage, particularly for the more rural, conservative, anti-abortion, anti-contraception, anti-sex education crowd.

I'd rather that people who are popping out babies didn't have more control over a political system than I do, especially if it's people who tend to be more conservative. We're currently circling the drain as a result of conservatives being energized by an ignoramus. We don't need their kids following in their footsteps.

Since I'm also an old guy with Medicare and getting some income from Social Security, I'd just as soon seniors had a significant voice in how older people are treated. Youngsters resulting from the famously fecund Republicans are going to form their attitudes at their parents' knee, and old people, sick people and the unemployed will be told tales of Moochers and Takers and how they Sap Society.

Children are to be taken care of by adults, not sent out into the world to make the rules that apply to the incomprehensibly ancient 60-year-olds, or, gee wiz, even older!

If the country is aging, then we don't needs this "Demented voting" system to ensure older people don't have their needs addressed. But if all Republicans got half a vote, that would solve a lot of our problems.

headline: President Trump’s Contradictory, and Sometimes False, Comments About Gun Policy to Lawmakers
commentone: Absolutely astounding story - or is it? Here you have Trump willing to shift his views (if it were a Democrat the Times would say he is  'pivoting') and try to get something done in a bi-partisan way on gun control. In the two years your beloved Pres. Obama was in the White House and had control of BOTH legislative bodies, just what did he accomplish on gun control! Nothing, that's what. And now we got someone willing to buck the NRA, his own party and even his base to answer in some way the awful events in Florida. If Trump announced tomorrow that he cured cancer, the Times and Progressives would invent 'unnamed sources say' conspiracies about Trump's not doing it fast enough. Do you ever listen to yourselves? Would you rather Trump just stick to these earlier positions and get absolutely nothing done about gun control? I think you do, and then you'd have more to criticize him about. Keep it up and not only will Dems not win back the House in 2018, but they'll lose the national election two years later.

headline: Putin Says He Has ‘Invincible’ Nuclear Missile
commentone:
The world saw what a couple of small A-bombs (10 to 20 kilotons of TNT) could do when we dropped them on Hiroshima and Nagasaki in 1945. Today's weapons produce far larger explosions in the 10-100 megaton range. The fireball radius alone for such bombs is of the order of 1 - 2 kilometers (0.5 to 1 mile).

Anyone who imagines that much of society would remain in any operational condition after a nuclear exchange between Russia and the US which could involve hits on many sites spread across both countries is delusional. For decades the doctrine of Mutually Assured Destruction ("MAD") has prevented nuclear exchanges from occurring. Both sides know that each would suffer grievous harm, whether it was the initator or the retaliator.

So what is new? New ways of delivering an H-Bomb? Unless one side can so overwhelm the other that no retaliation would happen, that side would be stupid, no, INSANE, to actualy start an exchange. One can ask what the point of "winning" such an exchange might be. To have a seriously damaged homeland with many millions of casualtes, versus a totally defeated opponent? What does that Pyrrhic victory benefit the "victor"?

As for me, at the age of over 70, if we ever got to the point of an actual exchange, I woud be happy to get incinerated in an early explosion, because to me the prospect of living with the consequences of such an exchange are just too unpalatable.
commenttwo:
The deranged actor on the world stage known as Putin‚Äö√Ñ√Æ

Makes it all the more imperative that spineless congressional Republicans finally cut their loses and dispatch the blight known as Trump.

headline: Saying a Prayer I Don’t Believe In
commentone:
I am so sorry for your loss, and both my parents are gone. My former best friends and stable source of love and support. I lost a brother-in-law to Alzheimer's so I know about the horror of watching a person disappear in front of you.

I am Catholic and my personal belief is that it is not God's will or His fault for allowing such suffering in this world. I believe all of this comes from the physical world we live in, our very vulnerable bodies that are susceptible to disease or physical harm, our own free will, and the evil imparted upon many of us due to the free will of others. I do believe that prayers get answered by God, maybe not all of them, and that He is always with me, and within me, during good times, bad times, and tragedies.

The Kaddish sounds beautiful and it sounds like you are getting some spiritual uplift from it despite your grief and loss. It sound like it makes you re-connect with community despite the isolation of your pain.
commenttwo: Belief follows practice, it does not precede it.  You don't become an athlete, a dancer, a musician, or a doctor without practice.  The same is true for a  believing Jew.

headline: The Escalation of Love
commentone: I've read many of these comments and I ask myself, were these loving people hiding underneath the cruel people they were when allegedly sane? My grandmother was beyond difficult during most of her lifetime, and tirelessly cruel to her only child, my mother. But by the time she reached her 90s, she had mellowed with senility into a sweet old lady. Able to show her love for us in the first time in her life. I'm afraid this change of heart was lost on my mother who was simply glad to have this destructive woman out of her life once she finally died.
commenttwo:
Thank you for this tender story. I travel every two months to see my 73 year old mom in a memory care facility in Florida. I hope that with time, my memories of the person she was replace the person she is. The visits are intense, but we have fallen into a rhythm of eating at a local deli where she enjoys Matzo ball soup. I do not know if she recognizes me but she smiles in response to my smiles and I feel connected. My visits likely provide me with much more comfort than they do her.
Thank you again.

headline: Trump’s Call to Arm Teachers Resonates at Schools That Do
commentone: This is a very worthwhile article, a real situation not a hypothetical. This approach makes sense IF we begin to remove all weapons that can chamber more that 3 rounds from our country. Start with stopping the sale of high capacity riffles, move to national registration of all firearms and background checks for all buyers, add a license law - as done for hunters - that requires passing a safety test and paying an annual license fee to be a gun owner, add in a buy back of all high capacity rifles and handguns. This will take years but meantime, if the budget and management parameters of Sidney City Schools can be replicated across the country, the Sydney model is not the worst idea I have ever heard. It could be put in place nationally with strict controls. Honest discussion of this solution to some aspects of child protection may  provide common ground between the very sensible people of our country and also neutralize the extremists on both sides of the argument from creating a chaos from which no action will emerge that makes our children safer and our country a better place to live in. My first knee jerk reaction to this report was 'crazy' but this is a sensible and thought out approach which quiet leaders have executed carefully while most of the rest of us just complain.
commenttwo: Such a distraction that prevents real change. Blabbing on an on about teachers having guns. Guess you don't really have to do anything but the NRA's bidding then until you tire folks out. Just vote the Republicans out--they are completely corrupt. Guns and heightened alert are antithetical to teaching and learning. Scared people are reacting, not learning. Teachers can't see their students as potential killers or victims that they failed to save and honestly make the academic and emotional investment required to help students share their ideas and best work with others. We need many fewer guns in our gun-sick, violent country. We need our school and public spaces to be havens of safety, universal background checks, no open carry unless you're a military or police officer. Statistically, all over the world, places with fewer guns have fewer murders.

headline: When Elder Abuse Is Self-Inflicted
commentone:
This is a nuanced issue. After my dad died at the age of 91 my 89 year old mother insisted on living alone in their house despite the fact that she lacked the ability to shop for food or go for physician visits and was totally socially isolated. She could go weeks at a time without seeing another human being. I fought bitterly with my mother to move to an assisted living facility and even agreed to pay for it, but my mom refused.

My sister agreed with our mom‚Äö√Ñ√¥s decisions, so my mom gave her sole power of attorney over her legal, financial and medical affairs. It was heartbreaking for me to visit my mom. The house was filthy, spoiled food rotted in the refrigerator and bills were left unpaid. After a few years it was revealed that my sister was stealing our mom‚Äö√Ñ√¥s money and the courts made my mom a ward of the state at public expense.

Things improved dramatically for my mom thereafter. But was my sister guilty of elder abuse or was my mom guilty of self-inflicted abuse, empowering my sister as her agent? Maybe it was my mom‚Äö√Ñ√¥s right to make choices for herself no matter how horrible, but in the end society picked up the tab. And maybe people should be allowed to inflict terrible consequences on themselves, but should they be allowed to inflict consequences on society?
commenttwo: Stay away, all of you!!. People do have a right of self-determination, and this kind of intervention is just plain wrong. I have advanced directives that are very specific for when my time comes, as I cannot trust my spouse to disallow a hospital admission. My adult children are in charge when the time arrives, and they clearly understand my hands-off wishes. The best advise is to draw up advanced directives, and to fill out a form that was printed in the NYTimes a short time ago. Otherwise, you may die in a strange place with tubes coming out of places in your body that you didn't know existed.

headline: Will Hope Hicks Find Her Voice?
commentone:
Both Hope Hicks and Ivanka Trump are largely being given a pass, by Filipovic and most everyone else, because they are young, and beautiful, and women.

Ms. Filipovic tries to caveat her way down a very fine line, but I don't think it succeeds. She presents a plausible scenario for Hicks' thought process and motivations--but it's still a fundamental condescension, and unfairness, to absolve her in any way.

Hicks and Trump might view themselves as simply taking advantage of "exciting career oppotunit[ies]," but they're aiding and abetting a president who is literally making not just the United States but the world a more dangerous place. The White House is not an extension of Trump Inc., and if they've done anything illegal or unconstitutional in their efforts to climb up this vile career ladder, they should be prosecuted to the fullest extent of the law. Hicks doesn't even have the excuse of blood.

I won't be surprised if in the not-too-distant future Hicks, in full makeup, is on some magazine cover, with a piece inside touting her intelligence, her beauty, her victimhood, and some kind of ersatz "strength." But, who knows--maybe she's already spilled everything to Mueller and will help bring down her boss. One can dream.

headline: Your Kid’s Phone Is Not Like a Cigarette
commentone:
Epidemiologically, we do need to un-confound selection bias, to consider the counterfactual. But it is perfunctory not to consider the generation of people unnecessary exposed to tobacco and dying because we wanted to 'wait' for the evidence. Not to be disingenuous, doctors promoted smoking just as teachers may heighten online learning. I am glad the alarm bell on children mobile use has sounded, it is dubious to wait for glacial cohort studies to corroborate the benefits of controlling a 10 year old's addiction to Youtube and preventing pernicious effects of cyber-bullying.

Mobiles are more woven into our daily routines than tobacco ever was. Even my 72 year old mom and dad have smartphones. But smoking was intricately woven into any social gatherings. But now, restaurants,pubs,sporting events,and movies are not tarnished with nicotine stains and tobacco smoke.

The scope of the anti-smoking campaign was broad, one of the key victories is curbing tobacco in public space. So a multi-pronged approach can in fact target distinct aspects of broad public health issues. Due to the urgency of the cellphone addiction crisis, it would be pusillanimous not to borrow the lessons learned.

School policy- no phones.
Local health campaigns-to promote decrease cellphone use in public space. Let kids be kids.
Public health-help kids with mood disorder,addiction to phones.
Library-disable Youtube in kids space.
Education-parents, teachers, kids of the issues.
More research!

headline: A Whole Lot Is Riding On This New ‘Wrinkle’
commentone: I was a little brown girl, growing up, east of Los Angeles. I was usually the smartest kid in my grade, loved math and science, read tons of books, and wore glasses. Finding and reading "A Wrinkle in Time" was an incredible experience for me. There were girls like me! I wasn't alone in the world! I turn 65 this year. My 28 year-old daughter is bi-racial: Latina and African American. I gave her the book to read as soon as possible. Like me, she has read it many times. We are looking forward to seeing the movie together and celebrating the richness and diversity of ourselves and the movie (which includes Ava DuVernay, the actors, and all associated people). Rather than picking everything apart, enjoy the movie and the message.
commenttwo:
I am not that upset by the casting-outside of Oprah (yuck). Directors always put their own take on things. But what's good for the goose is good for the gander.

You can't logically complain about "cultural appropriation" when a black female director has changed the race of several characters solely to feel better about herself and perhaps appeal to a different audience. That's literally the definition of cultural appropriation. =)

If this is to be prevented, then like preventing the Obama Admin for intervening in Syria it must be done before the move is made. The NYT urged that intervention too, and it was headed off in large part by the British House of Commons rebelling, offering example for a larger rebellion against our own elites of both parties.

We must speak up now, before it is too late. Once the place has gone Honduras, it will sink like Honduras and El Salvador and so many more into a US dominated criminal vortex.
commenttwo: If Venezuela can be saved, it must also be saved from the US and the emigres from the old abuses in Venezuela. A US takeover or a return of their version of Batista is not saving them.

"Bold liberalism" vs "tradition" is how the NYT phrases this.

That isn't the Democratic tradition. It is DINO. It is Republican-Lite. It is the Clinton tradition of triangulating with the radical right to govern right of center.

I want a Democrat. A real Democrat. Last time I had to support someone who wasn't even a formal Democrat because the Democrats of the DNC had abandoned everyone except their donors, and gone Republican.

It isn't "ideological purity." It is representing the Democratic base, and its actual real interests.

What we see instead is pandering to donors at high end events, from which voters are excluded, no different than Romney was recorded doing when he made his 47% comments.

headline: Dorm Living for Professionals
commentone:
For all those commentors saying "oh what a good idea for early retirees/older/etc"

Speaking as an early retiree, I would rather jump off the roof of the building than have to live in it in enforced sociability with others who end up there because they 'can afford it"

Not going back to college and dorm life -- uh uh not ever

If I want to leave the dinner dishes to the next day, I can

If I want to skip running the robot vacuum, I can

If I want to fold the laundry tomorrow, I can wait

And the idea of "organized" resident activities...... yuck! Bad as Nurse Cratchet saying "now we all have to play bingo"

No way not ever

I'll stick to my 3 bdrm, 2 bath house with the 2 1/2 car garage on a 1/2 acre that has 2 sq miles of cherry orchards behind the back yard and is only 3 minutes 45 secs from 40 miles of white sugar sand beach and 500 ft high sand dunes --- oh yeah a mortgage that is 1/3rd of what these fools are paying for a room smaller than my dressing room!

This is not 'happy happy' and 'super-spiffy' as the article portrays it. It is pathetic that mid-30s adults are in little teeny bedrooms with shared baths and unable to get on with building a life and a future (yeah buying a house) Obviously getting married and living in a single room would pretty much end in divorce in months - so they stay alone

No place is that great - living in SRO deprivation (while pretending it is great) is pathetic
commenttwo: From the 20's to the 60's  residential hotels, or men's and women's residences ( non-student dormitories) served working people who were living away from home  or older professionals who did not want to clean and/or cook for themselves.  Breakfast was included, you could pack your own bag lunch  or have one made for you, and dinner when you returned at the end of the day all at a reasonable rates.  The assumption was that  women required chaperonage and men were incompetant to take care of themselves.  How is this any different, other than the age of the residents?  I have long  thought that a similar congregate living place, for single parents with kids would be great and supportive way to live, oh , no now someone is going to go out and make money off that idea, too.

headline: God, Don’t Save the King
commentone:

commenttwo:
Couldn't get into "Victoria"--too soap-operatic, too twee--but I enjoy "The Crown", mainly for the quality of the performances, and at once every season there's a poison pill that forces you to re-think what you've seen. In the first season it was Graham Sutherland's thorny encounters with Winston Churchill, in which he discovered Churchill's secret melancholy, and saw the Churchills do all they could to conceal it.
In the second it was the near-Ealing comedy of of "Marionettes", in which nice but slightly dotty editor Alec Guinness criticizes the monarchy and endures a storm of public obloquy. He persists, supported by lovely Glynis Johns, and faces the wrath of Queen Valerie Hobson, and in the end is proven completely right.
(Actually John Heffernan, lovely Gemma Whalen and Claire Foy.)

headline: How Liberals Can Reclaim Nationalism
commentone:
Liberalism and nationalism are contradictory terms one cannot be both.

commenttwo: i have noticed in my travels that the countries most comfortable with collectivism, socialism (think strong social safety net, universal health care), are the more homogeneous ones.  New Zealand, Western Europe and Much of Asia have populations defined by common identity and language.  The more alike a population feels the more they think collectively.  Americans will do that but mostly in their own small group, their town or church. Canada being a notable exception, perhaps due to their French/English dual heritage.  The paradox for liberalism then is to reconcile our two cherished values diversity and collectivism.  Perhaps we should look to Canada for ideas and inspiration.  Somewhere between the melting pot and the salad bowl is the soup pot.  The flavors mix but still retain their original flavors.

headline: How the Tet Offensive Broke America
commentone: Troop anti-war sentiment predates Tet. I knew many who served in Vietnam and none of them trusted or respected the military they served. I received many letters describing drunk cadre, illogical missions, pure idiocy. Their goal was to do their jobs and stay alive, get back to the world they said. None of them thought the war was winnable pre-Tet or after Tet.
commenttwo: Most of the deaths of those of us murdered by our admittedly failed policy were yet to come. Broke us? Hardly. Draft notices were in the mail.

headline: I Saw a Genocide in Slow Motion
commentone: Partners Relief & Development (www.partners.ngo) has been delivering monthly food aid to Rohingya in an internment camp in Rakhine State since 2012 and were interviewed by Mr. Kristoff in his 2014 video. When I was there a while ago, one village elder told me with tears, "It would have been better if you'd brought us poison so we could drink it and die. They (the military) are killing us anyway." So yes: this is genocide in slow motion and we too have been witnesses to that for years.
commenttwo: Thank you, Mr.  Kristof.  Be safe.  We need you another 30 years.

headline: Letting  Teenagers  Live
commentone:
When I was a kid, if you got a car, it was dad's old station wagon or a used VW bug. Nowadays, cars are more powerful, faster, smoother and the manufacturers make them very easy to buy.

Also, when I was a kid, Driver Training was mandatory in ninth or tenth grade (I forget) and it was a real course, with equipment to demonstrate the distance traveled between seeing a reason to stop and coming to a stop, or the many tricks your eyes can play on you. Driver Training is pretty much gone these days. We make them learn academic things that are useful, but we don't teach them the one thing that could save their lives.
commenttwo: Note that Mr. Leonardt has only used the term car "crash" as opposed to car "accident".  These are two different things. Crash is the neutral term experts use because if a driver is reckless or careless the result cannot necessarily be concluded as accidental. Correct language is essential to useful discussion.

headline: Plan for Tariffs Creates Divide In Trump Base
commentone:
"But putting America first may not put all American workers ahead."

Good grief. First of all, why are you repeating the Trump slogan, "putting America first," without questioning whether that is actually the intent behind Trump's actions, and/or whether the results of his actions actually would "put America first"? Secondly, why qualify your sentence with "MAY NOT put all American workers ahead"? Ya think? Of course, it won't put all American workers ahead, and in fact most analysts have stated that it could have devastating effects on the U.S. and world economy.

Finally, why this pretentious attempt to be "fair" with this reporting by suggesting there are "winners and losers." Folks, there are nothing but losers here. Think both short-term and long-term. Think about the future of our country. Think about where all of this is headed. And remember that the only "winners" are the Republican corporate elite who are driving this agenda.
commenttwo: There is a reason why Trump won Michigan, Ohio, Wisconsin, and Pennsylvania -- so called "blue-collar" workers (also referred to as "less educated" workers -- a problematic label given that only one-third of Americans have college degrees) have been hurting for a very long time. Their incomes have been frozen for many years or have declined and good (higher paying) jobs are scare, which is one reason why labor workforce participation is low.  Free trade (like tariffs and protectionism) has winners and losers -- at this point in our global economy the winners have been those at the top (and those who provide services to them) who benefit from global markets and the ability to source products from the lowest cost providers (which usually are not in the U.S.), while the losers have been those at the bottom (true, they can buy goods at lower prices but that is not worth a lot when they don't have good paying jobs).  The other major economic players in the world economy -- China, Germany, and Japan -- are far more focused on protecting their workers and businesses through direct governmental action than the U.S.  Perhaps tariffs and a more activist role by our government is an answer to helping those most in need.

headline: Power to the Parents
commentone: I like it.  We already have virtual representation of large swaths of people.  Areas where there are high numbers of non-citizen immigrants are allowed to count those non-citizens toward apportionment.  This means that the votes of the actual voters where there are high numbers of immigrants are weighted more heavily than areas where there are fewer non-citizens.  It is a clear corruption of the concept of one person one vote, but the courts have upheld it and the Democrats have acted like it is some kind of sacred cow.  So why not give greater weight to the voters within families with more children?  At least their children are citizens.
commenttwo:
Given the number of cadavers who have long been rumored to vote in places such as Cook County, Illinois, surely this proposal isn't that much of a philosophical stretch, albeit a stiff challenge to ever implement.
Conservatives would likely cry, "over my dead body," as the suggestion certainly flies in the face of their efforts to reduce, rather than increase the roster of eligible voters, diminishing the likelihood of it become reality.

One could, on a more serious note, hang a hat on the notion that not allowing sixteen year olds to vote amounts to taxation without representation, as many of them work and pay taxes, but can't cast a ballot.

Far more irresponsible than mid-teens who, it should be noted, are much better informed than earlier generations thanks to social media, are those adults who, having the right to vote, routinely fail to exercise it at all. Perhaps a system, like Australia's, where non-voters are penalized, would be a step in the right direction, and could account for significant increases in voter participation.

headline: Silicon Valley Disruption In an Australian School
commentone: Ugh, another tech head who made money in the private sector that thinks she has a new idea about teaching. I am professor. Trust me, this stuff will not work. I have enough problems with my students not knowing when the United States' Civil War started and ended, please, please, please,  NO "BLUE SKY THINKING ROOMS"  who makes this stuff up??   The idea that if one is successful in one area of life and makes money that it automatically confers expertise in all areas on that person is very common and just plain nuts.  This happens a lot in academia as well. Someone becomes justifiably famous for their work in one area, next thing you know they are on TV opining on things far afield from their expertise as if they know something about what they are talking about. Same for the tech head in this story. Stay with and in your field of expertise out of the schools, please for the good of all of us.
commenttwo:
It really isn't necessary to go to Australia, be funded by a tech executive, or cost $10,000 a year. Here, in the Blue Ridge Mountains of Virginia, the Albemarle County Public Schools are doing all of this, and more, in 25 public, diverse schools.

The problem with what's presented here is that this really isn't disrupting education at all. There have always been great, very open, very child-centered schools for the very few. What is unusual - what needs to be done - is disrupting the old-style school for every child. Interestingly, the 130 students in this school matches the population of one of our multiage classrooms (K-5). But our challenge has been, and our global challenge must be, to have rich, open, child-centered learning spaces for every student.

Ira Socol
Executive Director of Technologies and Innovation
Albemarle County Public Schools
Charlottesville VA

headline: The Challenge of Doctor-Patient Relations in the Internet Age
commentone: If I had stayed away from the internet and merely heeded my doctors' advice, I may very well have died from my stage 3 anal cancer. When I listed my various complaints to the doctors, they told me to stop eating gluten or eat more fiber. Finally, after searching my symptoms on the internet, I knew they were serious. I insisted on a coloscopy and was diagnosed.
commenttwo:
In my experience the doctor only offered a standard protocol, with no explanation of why, risks, etc. Had I not looked online at reliable resources to get more info about the steps in this protocol, I would‚Äö√Ñ√¥ve been left blindly following the ‚Äö√Ñ√∫usual‚Äö√Ñ√π treatment‚Äö√Ñ√Æwhich would‚Äö√Ñ√¥ve been far more intrusive and contrary to my personal values relative to such serious healthcare treatments. Doctors seem to me wired to treat, treat, treat, rather than explain or be the caring assistant a patient needs when deciding according to what that patient wants from life and from the medical industry. Bottom line: Doctors don‚Äö√Ñ√¥t have time to care, they are in fact conditioned not to care very much in order to administer treatment.
People need to consider deeply what their medical-treatment values are and where reliable sources are to be found IN ADVANCE. It‚Äö√Ñ√¥s the only way to keep one‚Äö√Ñ√¥s wits when faced with serious health decisions. Just as I do not buy a house or a car based only on info from the seller, I don‚Äö√Ñ√¥t accept medical care based only on the info from a doctor. Doctors need to wise up and recognize that many people are very good at discriminating between good sources of info and poor ones. This assumption that patients are idiots needs to stop. There are far more factors involved in medical decisions than most doctors seem to comprehend.

headline: What We Will Lose When the Union Carbide Building Falls
commentone: If you want to engage in looking at architectural splendor just go outside at night and look up.  It's free to all and can be seen from any vantage point by all who dwell on planet earth.
commenttwo:
The Seagram's Building has been in every art history book in recent memory--but I suppose more because it was a prototype for so many other mid-twentieth century buildings than because it was visibly unique.
But if there's one thing I've learned from living in this country, its that no building anywhere is safe from the wrecking ball. If someone could tear down Yankee Stadium and the Boston Gardens, then you have to believe that above all else.
At the same time though, even the skyline of London is unrecognizable from its appearance in the early 1980s when I spent time there, so I suppose its universal--the disappearance of all things familiar.
Let's hope, though, that there is some record in our common human memory and culture for the really historic buildings of by-gone and soon-to-be bygone eras.

headline: When Elder Abuse Is Self-Inflicted
commentone:
For 10 years, my mom's been self-neglecting. She recently fell & was to weak to get up. Luckily?, she had charged her phone for a change and could call. Luckily?, she agreed to see her doc. Luckily, my husband was with me and could help move her. Luckily?, the doc saw her even though it had been a year. The doc was clear that if my mom did not comply this time, she'd no longer see her. My mom's pulse was so low that they could not get a BP. Luckily?, after lots of cursing, my mom went to the hospital when the doc firmly said she had 2 choices, to go to ER or go home to finish dying. Luckily?, my mom did rally to do PT. The ? lingers for me as I go to Florida to help my mom transition home. I took advice and approach "with little circular approaches until she sees it as her idea". I get that we all want our independence I really, really do.
She's moved from a snappy "no need for you to come to a grunted "whatever". I've scant hope & firm determination because two lines were crossed - no water for the dog (tho the food bag was open and no, drinking out of the toilet was not an option because‚Äö√Ñ¬∂ it was full). The second line is that my mom still thinks she is fine to drive even though she can't walk more than a short bit before getting dizzy. I can not stand the idea of her being on the road as it would be clear danger to everyone around her. Wish me luck/send me prayers - and please encourage those in positions to change our world in ways to make this all ANY easier to do so.
commenttwo: I'm surprised this article with so many contacts in Illinois didn't make more comment re: self-neglect under state law.  Illinois specifically passed legislation a few years back, defining hoarding as self-neglect (i.e. justification for intervention).  My mother is an extreme hoarder whose behavior put my father's heath and safety in jeopardy, but when my sister and I went to APS to report her, we were told that they were overwhelmed and had no real services to provide.  I like Texas' approach here re: mandatory reporting required of EVERYONE.  Since my father's passing, my mother changed the locks on her house to keep me out and she clings to my brothers, who take turns either ignoring her or actively enabling her hoarding.  This article implies that there are people at the ready to intervene (if only they weren't conflicted about issues of self-determination), but that's not my experience.  This article is right that there is significant reluctance among families about reporting conditions, not always because they fear unpleasant/unhelpful disruption (sometimes it's just embarrassment).  I reported my mother to everyone I could think of (the town, social workers caring for my dad, her doctor, APS), and apart from gasps and shocked reaction when they saw photos, it accomplished nothing.  Problem acknowledged, no intervention offered.  I do believe that family members should feel pressure to report, whether or not intervention is possible.  It's the right thing to do.

headline: Xi’s Power Grab in China Rattles Europe and Its Hope for an Ally in the Trump Era
commentone:
"You squeezed them, you hammered them to the point of desperation. And in their desperation, they turned to a man they didn't fully understand."

That line appears in the The Dark Knight, released in 2008. It seems ever-more applicable to the world today as each day passes.

headline: ‘President for Life’? Trump’s Remarks About Xi Find Fans in China
commentone: Supporting foreign dictators is one thing. We can debate the pros and cons of that ad nauseam. On the other hand, joking or not, implying that authoritarianism is a good idea in this country is a non starter. Americans are a fiercely independent bunch. A segment on the right right now, the bulk of Trump's base, is drawn to personality and group think. But everyone else, the vast majority, from libertarians to centrists to social democrats loathe the idea of authoritarianism.  It‚Äö√Ñ√¥s in our social DNA. We did not "throw off the yoke" of British dictates and rise to defeat every dictator who dared to challenge us since just to let Donald Trump declare himself president for life. Joking or not, should he try I am convinced America will rise to the challenge and prevail once again.
commenttwo:
This "joke" is why we should be working to improve our democracy not limit it.

Some ideas:
- Eliminate the Electoral College. If we were a pure popular vote democracy we would not be dealing with this dictator wanna be.
- Eliminate gerrymandering. We need independent commissions to draw neutral electoral maps based on complete census data.
- Eliminate private money in politics. This amounts to nothing less than legal bribery.
- Move elections to Sunday's. More people off work equals greater opportunity to vote.
- Implement automatic voter registration for every citizen over 18 who has a valid social security number.
- Encourage voting with a public service announcement campaign leading up to election days.

I'm sure we could do more but this would be a great start, don't you think?

headline: A Big Hollywood Night in a #MeToo Moment
commentone:
Identity politics has swept the Oscars.

It has gotten to the point where I can no longer trust a film review of a movie directed by a women or minority and/or on a sensitive issue. Is the movie praised because of its merits or because of the reviewers' terror of appearing unwoke?

Before the awards the Times carried a preview of the Oscars with columnists Ross Douthat, Fank Bruni and movie producer Lynda Obst. Their take on "The Shape of Water."

Douthat: "My assumption has been [that the Academy] is looking for a movie that speaks to the Trumpian moment, ..., and now seem to be leaning toward 'The Shape of Water' because it‚Äö√Ñ√¥s about racial and sexual minorities uniting to defeat the real monster of white male suburban patriarchy ‚Äö√Ñ√Æ and thus a perfect political movie, from a certain perspective, at least, for the times."

Bruni: "Don‚Äö√Ñ√¥t get me started on 'The Shape of Water,' whose swampy charms elude me to a point where I can‚Äö√Ñ√¥t ponder the politics of it. It felt strained, silly, and has ruined hard-boiled eggs for me forevermore."

Obst: "Well, thanks, Ross, for explaining 'Shape of Water,' because really I had no clue why people were going batty for it. I didn‚Äö√Ñ√¥t realize it was woke! Benny Goodman, who knew? It seemed so ridiculous to me as I fall in love with people and language."
commenttwo: Who won the $18,000 jet ski?

headline: At Heart of Tight Race, Folks Who Picked Trump But Wish They Hadn’t
commentone:
It's not gerrymandering or voter suppression or Russia interference in our elections that is bringing American democracy to its knees. It's the delusional and myopic thinking of the majority of Americans that is the root cause. We have people who used to call themselves Democrats but who leave the party because of its "liberal social policies" (i.e., support a woman's right to choose) and then vote for Trump because they delusionally think Trump can work miracles and reverse four decades of steel industry decline--just like that, because he says, "I alone can fix it." and they believe him--delusionally. They apparently didn't listen to all the other things he said, didn't take him seriously or literally or whatever when he berated a Gold Star family, said, 'when you're famous they just let you do it'. Nope, none of the 10,000 offensive things Trump did or said during the campaign or before pierced their consciousness except his promise to bring back steel jobs. Wow, talk about confusion of understanding the responsibilities of a citizen in a democracy. Democracy isn't going to work if voters are so easily conned and only hear what they want to hear and only believe what they want to believe.
My prediction is that there's not enough black women in the district to swing the district to a Democrat. (95% of Black women voted for Democrat Doug Jones in Alabama while only 34% of white women did.)
commenttwo: Act 2 for Alabama: Senator Jones win in the actual state of Alabama and the poisonous Trump administration have raised hopes in this Alabama part of Pennsylvania.

headline: Can There Be Good Porn?
commentone: This is really ridiculous. Porn has a purpose, it's to arouse the people who watch it. It's no more unrealistic than the hundreds of romantic movies that come out of Hollywood that promote dysfunctional emotional expectations about relationships. For example, let's just consider "The Shape of Water." What real man can compare to such mythical romanticism? How can real sex compare to the idealized sex of porn? It's not suppose to and we'll just have to live with the unreal expectations it generates, which are unlikely to cause as much dysfunction as the romantic ones we bring to our relationships from mainstream movies.
commenttwo:
Pretty words and nicely framed arguments but the ugly of porn comes through when the author writes :
"just as some women like seeing bleach blondes on their knees". This is the problem with porn. It involves the subjugation and stereotyping of the particular. If the very filming of porn, with all of the "behind the scenes" and stagecraft visible to the performers, leads to "aftercare" perhaps the author might consider the effect of mimicry, of reproducing in life what is seen on the small box, on the lives and psyches of young viewers. Who offers them "aftercare"?

headline: Can Venezuela Be Saved?
commentone:
I'm old enough to remember when the U.S. boasted that no country had ever freely elected a Communist to public office, and then Chile went and did it.

The CIA encouraged the wealthy class in Chile to go on a "capital strike," to deliberately withhold goods from the market, to lay people off for no reason, in general do everything to increase what Reagan some eight years later called "the misery index." This was documented in Congressional hearings.

Then Pinochet and the Chilean military intervened, cutting off the option of free elections for the next couple of decades, but I'm wondering if what we are seeing here is what might have happened in Chile without the military coup.

After all, the Venezuelan economy is still largely in private hands. Is it that the private sector owners of supermarkets can't find food to put on the shelves or are they holding it back? Have the farms stopped producing? Whether the food shortages are deliberate or a by-product of government policies, the results look the same on the ground.

I agree that Maduro is an idiotic hothead, way out of his depth, but Chavez did some good things for the non-elites of Venezuela at the beginning, and forgave the people who temporarily overthrew his government in 2002 instead of having them lined up against a wall and shot, as most dictators would have done.

Would the Times (and maybe the CIA) be this interested in Venezuela is it didn't have oil?
commenttwo: This is a country where the leaders of the opposition fight among themselves for power, where their message to the mass of Venezuelans is viewed with distrust and cynicism, where memory of the corruption, dishonesty, and indifference of the prior regimes of AD, Copei, URD, and other political parties remains strong.  All that Harvard education means nothing to the inhabitants of Guiria or Maturin or Tinaco.  Unlike Vietnam, where hundred of thousands willingly died to reunite their country, Venezuelans have chosen a different route: abandon it.  There is no united core that will compromise with each and die if necessary to free themselves of the Maduro regime.  There is no credible alternative to Maduro, which is why he still survives.  Maduro will eventually be overthrown and like P J, will leave with his millions safely parked overseas.  And Venezuelans will prepare for the next regime.......

headline: Chaos Theory In Oval Office Is Taking a Toll
commentone:
As a nation, the United States is in grave danger. Not from political partisanship (as bad as that is!) but from utter, complete incompetence.

We see our government in almost total meltdown. Congress is dominated by partisan hacks who protect Emperor Donald the Dumb's court of incompetent fools. There were those in the White House who signed on with the hope of enriching themselves. Now they see that the Mueller investigation is closing in, destroying their careers and costing them huge amounts in legal fees. They are deserting like rats leaving a sinking ship. There is no continuity.

Things have gotten so bad, it is rumored that ultra-Right crazy John Bolton may be tapped as National Security Advisor when H.R. McMaster is the latest to be tossed under the bus.

Bolton is truly deranged. With him in the White House, an international war is inevitable. Hold on, Americans, we are in for even more chaos and disaster.
commenttwo:
Bottom line: Trump won because 63 million Americans like bullies, because 63 million Americans were stupid or naive enough to believe that Trump could bully his way through foreign and domestic policy, because 63 million Americans wanted a bull in a China shop (sorry for the pun) approach to governing because for four decades, government had not helped them so what did it matter who was president? To these 63 million people, Trump was going to either fix it or destroy it or fix it by destroying it.

Millions of Trump voters lost their high-paying, pension-providing jobs so Trump's tariffs are good news. What they refuse to acknowledge, just as they refused to contemplate the consequences of voting for an unethical and immoral 'successful' businessman and reality-TV star for president, is that tariffs won't bring back those lost high-paying jobs, steel and aluminum plants in the U.S. will not reopen. The executives of steel and aluminum manufacturers aren't going to re-start a shuttered plant in such an unstable and tumultuous public policy environment, because unlike Trump, they won't seek funding from Russia to perpetrate unprofitable ventures, and as this story proves, they know they can't depend on the Trump administration for stable policy from minute to minute, much less from year to year or decade to decade.

Trump's announcement was for his base. Nothing else. He's talking only to his base now. Everyone else needs to learn to tune him out.

commenttwo: The gentrification of the old S.R.O. concept works well in a city like San Francisco, where rents are high.  Over 85 years I've tried most types of living arrangements, including S.R.O. and boarding room (dinner served family style!) but, my modern $855 per month two bedroom, one-bath, full kitchen, 950 sq ft senior coop apartment (exclusive of electric and phone) in a suburb of Minneapolis, MN, which also includes a laundry across the hall and one heated underground garage stall suits me just fine these days.

Hold Trump accountable for his dishonesty, greed and his manipulative behavior.  He used you.  We need to hold him and every politician who looked the other way accountable.
