headline: How Did Europe Freeze As North Pole Warmed Up?
commentone: Currently: Paris 48¬¨‚àûF, Fairbanks AK 2¬¨‚àû F
commenttwo:
Professional meteorologists, and even climate scientists, may not be the best people to ask these questions of. Their professional standards for "we know that" are far, far higher than any normal human's, and there are of course details which are unclear.

It might be better to query a hydraulic engineer - where a simple answer is likely - "Can you have a big disturbance in one part of any system with no walls - that does NOT have an effect on adjacent parts? No, of course not. Yes, everything is connected."

One thing we know is that the jet streams are now behaving outside our normal expectations. Sometimes they form deep loops, pushing air much further north, and south, than usual. Yep, that can push the polar vortex off base. That then pushes other air to move.

A useful description from an ecologist, who studies weather: https://littlebloginthebigwoods.blogspot.com/2017/02/jet-streams.html

This will and has led to ethnic cleansing to purify the precious bodily fluid of the mother or fatherland.  The Western World had advanced past empire, medieval fiefdoms, holy emperors until it slipped on a banana republic peel and feel back into a dark history.   Look at what is happening in the U. S.; quit giving us your tired, homeless yearning to be free, unless they are brain surgeons and take back your refuse. Our leader will not cooperate with other nations or his own legislature, he is only concerned with unilateral royal waves the the scepter in the name of ‚Äö√Ñ√∫America First‚Äö√Ñ√π but in the service of himself. I also agree liberals should not try to promote a ‚Äö√Ñ√∫better kind of nationalism‚Äö√Ñ√π based on a celebration of our many sources of diversity which is not even possible without addressing the realities of white supremacy. Nationalism, like capitalism, promotes competitiveness resulting in winners and losers and both have been at the core of what most consider being an American. However, neither are now the most useful basis for America to work together with other nations, not only to increase own domestic well-being, but also to prevent a world-wide calamity from inadequate international efforts to reduce climate change.

headline: How the Left Wins the Culture War
commentone:
It's very disappointing that you denigrate people who are only trying to do
something good for this country, maybe bring us in line with other places where it's not so easy to get an assault rifle or any kind of gun and go out to kill fellow citizens. There have been so many lies, so much nastiness on the NRA-supporting side, people who deny Sandy Hook and the other tragedies despite the evidence.
Now you're trying to paint these good people who're demonstrating for change with the same brush. Shame!
commenttwo:
Just what is legitimate in society and in politics? That is the question Mr. Brooks raises. It is a fair question.

It is legitimate for parents to protect their children. No parent should bury a child killed by a school shooter, a gang banger or another child playing with a gun. Every parent should rage against the gunmen who kill children. Every parent should rage against the people who gave those gunmen access to assault rifles and the gun culture that encouraged those gunmen. Every parent should rage against a political party that refuses to consider gun control legislation.

Mr. Brooks, it's entirely legitimate for parents to vote their rage. It's not just the elite parents who are enraged. It's all parents who wants to see their children grow up. No parent wants her child to become the next shooting victim.

As you watch conservatives become pariahs remember that the love of children is a greater than love of guns.

Maybe we ought to mind our own national messes and stay out of conflicts we don't intend to win. Leave the "annililate" to others, and help with the "rehabilitate." That young marine had half of it right.

headline: Hugs, Smiles And a Pistol At the Ready
commentone: I recall back in in 1997 visiting my oldest child's junior high for the first time during the school day and encountering a uniformed city police officer  monitoring the kids filing into the school.  I don't know if they called them "resource officers" back then, to me he was just a regular city cop.  I am sure these officers are a valuable asset to our kids and teachers, but I couldn't avoid a profound sense of sadness that the perceived safety in our schools had diminished to the need for armed police on the premises.

headline: Late-Career Change: Play It Safe, or Ride It Out?
commentone: At 57 years of age I sold my house, moved in with my boyfriend and quit my job. I also took my mother to Romania to find documentation on our ancestors, set up my own company, did some consulting, acted in a play, took courses in acting, voice and solar energy, I also went to a bunch of conferences and generally had a ball.  I gave up a the tether that was my mortgage, I gave up some income and some appreciation on my house, AND I gave up working in a strategy job for a company that exposed itself to excessive risk in mature industries resulting in lots of downsizing. I'm starting a new gig working in solar energy for a non-profit in April.  There were ups and downs over the last two years but they were of my own making.  There is no point in living a miserable life. An awesome life is available to many, but not all of us. Seize the day. I have no regrets.

headline: Nakesha’s Demons
commentone: A very compelling article that deserves to be top/center on the website.  The topic is sad and feels intractable: mental illness and homelessness.  At the same time, I am so struck by the beauty and love of the people -- strangers and friends (and strangers who became friends) -- that tried to help.  I find their love and humanity uplifting and affirming.  Thank you to all of them.
commenttwo:
Nakesha‚Äö√Ñ√¥s story moved me. My brother has paranoid schizophrenia, and he has been homeless sporadically over the years, bouncing around among family members and taking off unexpectedly, sometimes ending up in jail for low-level ‚Äö√Ñ√∫crimes‚Äö√Ñ√π like trespass. It is devastating for all those affected.

It took years for him to accept his diagnosis and medication as part of his treatment. Without his involuntary short-term admission to an inpatient mental health center, I‚Äö√Ñ√¥m not sure it ever would have happened. After a decade of tragedy and what often seemed like futile efforts, he is no longer homeless. Thanks to sound public policy decisions in Minnesota, Matthew is on medication, has an apartment, and through Assertive Community Treatment (ACT) teams funded by the state, he has multiple weekly home visits from nurses and social workers. They help him navigate many of the challenges he faces. They monitor his medication and schedule doctor and therapy appointments proactively. Notably, when he has rough periods‚Äö√Ñ√Æan inevitable feature of mental illness‚Äö√Ñ√Æthey are able to address it before it becomes a full-blown crisis. The worry, stress, and sense of utter helplessness we used to feel has given way to gratefulness for this program and the people who do its work.

These challenges seem intractable, and for a long time I thought they were. They‚Äö√Ñ√¥re not. What they require is a commitment to more compassionate, thoughtful public policies that treat homeless people as whole people.

headline: The Challenge of Doctor-Patient Relations in the Internet Age
commentone: Most doctors see you for 5 minutes and there is zero chance of getting all your questions answered.
commenttwo:
$17 billion has been spent on drug trials for Parkinson's, for example, and every one of failure. Three times that much as been spent on trials for Alzheimer's and every one a failure.

There are people who have been living with Parkinson's for many years who say their progression has been slowed or stabilized and some who say their symptoms have diminished. Some say they feel better now than they did before they were diagnosed and there are even some who say they are completely symptom-free.

Some of those people achieve those results with the prescription drug and a nondrug regimen, some achieved it through a nondrug regimen solely, but not one single person with Parkinson's achieved it with a drug regimen solely.

Essentially, this Dr. saying that we should trust doctors because they know better. Too bad they're not taught anything about nutrition and medical school. 99% of doctors only know about drugs.

In other words, prescribed Parkinson's drugs provide some relief for some symptoms for some people for a few hours at a time. If you were to follow this doctors advice and only do what your doctor says you would be closing yourself off from any possibility of improvement.

For illnesses like Parkinson's, doctors have very little to offer, but the Internet, Parkinson forums were laypeople trade their experience and research, actually provides opportunities to live a normal life.

headline: Why It’s So Hard to Invest With a Social Conscience
commentone:
There are two kinds of people interested in socially responsible investment. Those who are satisfied to make a personal statement and those who want their actions to change the world. This addresses the problems from the perspective of that first group. Are your investments in line with your worldview?

It doesn't really address the central problem for the second group, that their choice of investments has almost no impact on the world either individually or collectively. In truth socially responsible investing is mostly a marketing technique with different brands for different people. If you want to change the world, you have to look at the management of the fund and how the proceeds are used. There are funds that are associated with social change groups. They not only provide the opportunity to have investments that are compatible with your personal beliefs, but the proceeds get used to fund work that makes the whole world a better place.

headline: How the Left Wins the Culture War
commentone: I'm not sure why Brooks is describing what might reasonably be thought of as a substantial event--people deciding they think something about something, or deciding they think something about something strongly enough to start expressing it--as if it were a kind of hazy trick of branding or a regrettable silencing of other options. It's not that "certain ideas...are being cast in the realm morally illegitimate and socially unacceptable;" it's that people don't find certain gun rights (not "ideas about gun rights," just the scope of the rights themselves) morally legitimate or socially acceptable. Nothing is being "cast" as anything in any "realm." When we find murder morally illegitimate or socially unacceptable, we aren't casting certain ideas about murder as morally illegitimate or socially unacceptable; we are just saying murder's not allowed here. If you hold certain pro-murder tastes, I guess you do. But not all your tastes get to be laws. Or, Brook's point is that all laws (progun, antigun, promurder, antimurder) are just cultural tastes...in which case this is just what a budding moral majority of taste looks like.
commenttwo:
You're finally getting it, Mr. Brooks. There is no way to have civil discourse or compromise with bigotry and ignorance. Surely you remember the 1960s when integration and striking down Jim Crow had to be shoved down the throats of what is left of the Confederacy. Federal troops had to escort kids to elementary schools and colleges.
This generation will remember Sandy Hook and Parkland. My generation remembers Chaney, Schwerner, Goodman and the murder of MLK. This generation will remember Trump and the NRA, mine remembers Nixon and Vietnam.

headline: I Saw a Genocide in Slow Motion
commentone:
"Congratulations to Aung San Suu Kyi on being released in Burma. She should be president ... She's truly a great woman ..." -- Nicholas Kristof, November 13, 2010

"... Aung San Suu Kyi ... is now the effective leader of Myanmar‚Äö√Ñ√¥s government and has emerged as ... complicit in [genocide]." -- Nicholas Kristof, March 2, 2018

One's assessment of others can change rather rapidly. ...
Aung San Suu Kyi doesn't care for the Rohingya, nor do the majority of Burmese. Though she doesn't like what's transpiring, her political situation is such that she feels incapable of speaking out in a despised minority's defense. She's in a difficult situation. But at this point, it's evident that she values being president more than the lives of the Rohingya; otherwise, she would have renounced the army's actions and, if all else failed, resigned. The Rohingya aren't entirely faultless angels, but that's beside the point: They're being collectively punished for the actions of a minority of their members.

Some in the Tatmadaw surely feel they're taking necessarily harsh measures to snuff out Islamic terrorism, but this is mostly an excuse to do what they've long wanted. Today, Muslims around the world are protesting the treatment of the Rohingya. The army has made the terrorism situation worse by engendering desperation and giving jihadists easy propaganda with which to recruit. Radicalism is spreading in Bangladesh; this will only aid its growth.

headline: Big Banks May Weaken Dodd-Frank Oversight
commentone: The point is that capital requirements aren't so onerous if banks are minding their core businesses and sticking to what they're good at.  The big guys think they're size insulates them from those same best practices that keep the midsized banks safe from the mistakes every lend eventually makes in evaluating risk.  Hence the capital cushion that needs to be there to carry the institution through the rough weather that always comes.  This is also why Glass Steagall should be restored. It forced specialists to stay specialized.  Mortgage lenders do mortgages; investment banks play a very high stakes game and if they treat mortgages that way you get subprime loans painted to look like triple A assets.  Because mortgages are boring bulk products and originating them is factory work.  Just that yields on subprime real estate loans got to be too attractive.  Made 'em look like something a venture capitalist should play with.
commenttwo: There's a world of difference between custodial services which are short in duration per transaction, and mortgage backed securities, whose durations are exponentially longer being in essence driven by pools of mortgages tied by coupon rate to securities.  The former can be easily monitored and managed.  The latter depends on scrupulous valuations of portfolio worth which can only be done by sampling and inspection of the pools in question.  Used to perform this for Citi when that company was purchasing mortgage servicing and we were performing the loan quality assurance necessary to value a servicing contract.  This should be done as a matter of course in the setting the value of securities based on credit quality.  That this didn't happen in the '08 period is how the collapse was triggered. Basically by fraudulent sale of securities that were deliberately overvalued and priced as quality paper when it was anything but.

headline: Hi Hi Good Morning Hi I Love You It’s Me
commentone: As a person whose Euro-American ancestors, going back at least 4 generations, all lived in this country, I am able to restrict my WhatsApp interactions to the students I am teaching in an online class in Central Asia and with my son, daughter-in-law in South America. WhatsApp has been wonderful in both contexts. On one occasion, I walked a student through the set up for her statistical anaysis, while lying on my back in bed at 4 am. Teaching internationally is a wonderfully enriching experience and WhatsApp makes it all the more enriching & possible. Now that I have a grandchild, WhatsApp makes it so easy to connect. I think with sorrow, how my parents in 1968 could only get news of their granddaughter through surface mail or international phone calls to the tune of $4/minute. I wouldn't trade it for the world. But, I'm not from an inter-dependent culture.

I don't believe either of his two predecessors, although being more serious men, had that background either.  Therein lies one of the secrets of Putin's rise, despite the weakness of his country. The best option for now is simply to wait out the rest of President Putin's time as the Russian leader; he can't last forever, and there doesn't appear to be any system in place to replace him with someone as capable.  We can then deal with his successor, who will hopefully be someone of a newer generation, without the regrets of the lost Soviet empire.

headline: The Escalation of Love
commentone:
My dad was a huge fan of the Kansas City Royals. When his dementia became really bad, the team was a their absolute nadir, losing in the most humiliating ways. I always told people the one bright spot of his illness was that if he saw baseball on TV, he thought it was the Royals winning the World Series. He was their only happy fan at that time.

This is a beautiful piece of writing. Our relationships with our parents are so intense and tangled. I'm glad to read of the glimmers of peace and resolution.
commenttwo: 30 years of "therapy".  That tells us how much good it does.  It is a life-long sinecure for the "therapist", but only a waste of time and money for the patient.

headline: The Macroeconomics of Trade War
commentone:
Trump has demonstrated he is an anarchist. Dismantling government agencies is one thing but wreaking havoc on the world economy is quite another. Acting upon the ridiculous sound bites amplified by Fox News that resonated with some very ignorant members of his base has become the basis of his new world disorder.
I continue to pray to Mueller every night...
commenttwo:
Trump in his infinite stupidity, has just announced that if Europe places import tariffs on our goods, he will place tariffs on their cars. Europe has done nothing yet, and Trump is threatening massive retaliation. So what's going to happen when trade sanctions are actually made in retaliation? That maniac is on the verge of starting a real trade war. The kind that results in global recessions.

I operate a small cottage industry manufacturing concern. Last year, my income was cut in half because of Trump. About half of sales go overseas. Last year, those dropped by at least 75%. As of Feb. sales have rebounded strongly and most all of those were for export. My European and Asian customers started buying again. If he starts a trade war, that business will certainly dry up.

I have parts made for me out of aluminum. Those have been rising in cost anyway. Understand this. The 10% tariff is much higher when the product hits the customer. Here is how it works.

Let's say my fabricator's material costs rise 10%. He will then raise his prices by 20% because he can't eat the cost of tying up more money in inventory. All fabricators use a multiplier based on raw costs. When I buy the part, I have to add in my multiplier for the same reasons. If there were a retailer in the chain, they would do the same.

The tariffs are then highly inflationary which will trigger higher interest rates.
We will end up with both inflation and a global recession. MAGA!

headline: What We Will Lose When the Union Carbide Building Falls
commentone: Of course, the customers will pay, in their fees, for this vanity project.
commenttwo: Buildings have a life; a beginning and an end.  Very few things are constructed to last "forever" - whatever definition you put on that word.  In construction terms, an overpriced project is often called a "monument" - a project that spends considerably more resources than it provides benefits, usually with someone's name on it.  The name may be an individual, or it may be a corporation.  Monuments are usually built by those who have egos to match - either the owner or the architect, sometimes both.  Even if they fulfill a need for a short time, they very rarely justify their existence compared to the optional uses for those resources.

headline: When Elder Abuse Is Self-Inflicted
commentone: A "friend had restocked" the alcohol and you considered the man to be no longer your problem?  Seriously?  Why did you not bring up the "friend" on charges of elder abuse?  Because surely pushing a recovering addict to drink again is abuse!  You signed his death warrant, when you could have taken a different path.
commenttwo:
It gets murky. With my elderly parents (one now deceased, the other living at home with help from dedicated family members), I had to wrap my brain around the fact that they *willingly* traded their safety and health for "independence." In this case, it was independence to cancel doctor appointments, skip medications, share a can of soup over multiple meals, etc. Poor but conscious decisions. No money issues were driving any of this. Depression? Likely, but you don't talk about that to members of the Greatest Generation.

Now that he's gone, Alzheimer's is in the mix for my mom at 89. She's frail with many chronic health issues and losing her sight, but continues to resist any efforts to help. She's not capable of making her own decisions (maybe never was) doesn't bathe regularly and wears the same clothes unless someone convinces her to clean up. She wants only, desperately, to stay in her home, avoid the doctor's office and any "pills" or dangerous vaccinations they try to foist on her. Her main activities are eating and sleeping. She has no meaningful social connections, no interest in reading, puzzles or games so it seems that her life now is like being in a nursing home: schedules imposed, meals prepared (better tasting, for sure), meds dosed, with someone trying to add structure and interest to her days, all of which she resists. She's safe at home with her own stuff and family to help but is this really better? It's the life she chooses...

headline: How Liberals Can Reclaim Nationalism
commentone:
Correction of typos in previous post.
This article missed a real opportunity to craft a modern American liberal nationalism in the tradition of Theodore Roosevelt‚Äö√Ñ√¥s New Nationalism speech. It first attempts to belittle nationalism by conflating the concepts of ‚Äö√Ñ√∫nation‚Äö√Ñ√π and ‚Äö√Ñ√∫state‚Äö√Ñ√π. While the modern-day state is arguably a recent phenomenon, nationhood is almost as old as humanity itself. States are legal entities that have sovereignty over territory. Nations, on the other hand, are peoples with a common heritage, usually ethnic in nature. The history of most Eurasian nations is rooted in ethnic-based nationalism and so it will be a driving force of their domestic and foreign policies for the foreseeable future.

In contrast, the United States was founded not on an ethnic or denominational basis, but on the concept that all were created equal and were endowed with basic human rights. While we have struggled, sometimes bloodily, to fully realize this vision, we should never forget how revolutionary the concept was during the monarchical, absolutist nationalism of the 18th and 19th centuries. We fashioned a nationalism that was committed to achieving this American Dream for all our citizens regardless of origin or religion in the hope that other nations would see the benefits of such a society and adopt those ideals in their own unique way. The author rightly touts these ideals without realizing how unique, indeed exceptional, they are.
commenttwo:
This article missed a real opportunity to craft a modern American liberal nationalism in the tradition of Theodore Roosevelt‚Äö√Ñ√¥s New Nationalism speech. It first attempts to belittle nationalism by conflating the concepts of ‚Äö√Ñ√∫nation‚Äö√Ñ√π and ‚Äö√Ñ√∫state‚Äö√Ñ√π. While the modern-day state is arguably a recent phenomenon, nationhood is almost as old as humanity itself. that have sovereignty over territory. Nations, on the other hand, are peoples with a common heritage, usually ethnic in nature. There are states that are not nations and nations that are not states. The African states created after the end of colonialism are the best example of the former and the world is full of examples of the latter, such as the Kurds.

In contrast, the United States was founded not on an ethnic or denominational basis, but on the concept that all were created equal and were endowed with basic human rights. While we have struggled, sometimes bloodily, to fully realize this vision, we should never forget how revolutionary the concept was during the monarchical, absolutist nationalism of the 18th and 19th centuries. We fashioned a nationalism that was committed to achieving this American Dream for all our citizens regardless of origin or religion in the hope that other nations would see the benefits of such a society and adopt those ideals in their own unique way. The author rightly touts these ideals without realizing how unique, indeed exceptional, they are.

headline: How the Left Wins the Culture War
commentone: Good Lord-that last paragraph sounds like a threat.  Most Americans want sensible gun reform- nothing elitist about it.
commenttwo:
Interesting, David, that you pick smoking and segregation as the two comparisons for unregulated gun possession; it is apt for more than one reason. Both smoking and segregation belong in history's dustbin,and tellingly conservatives defended both smoking and segregation from progressive attempts to reign them in, as they do with gun control now.

Progressives, I believe are tired of compromising with red state folks and getting nothing in return. Banning just assault weapons is a compromise, as are universal background checks and waiting periods. No one is suggesting banning or confiscating guns. No one is suggesting even the restrictions most other countries employ. What more level of understanding or compromise should progressives offer to political opponents who offer neither?

Obamacare was a compromise rather than universal health coverage. Cap and trade was a compromise rather than imposing tough environmental regulations. Yet, once conservatives extracted those concessions, they opposed the compromise. Enough!

Conservatives are the ones who for years have declared a "culture war," despite the fact that they control Congress and legislatures only because they have manipulated the process with money and gerrymandering.

Why wouldn't progressive try to defeat (in your words, "exile") 20% of the country (don't kid yourself into believing the new GOP represents anywhere near a lasting 40%) of the population, when no other path has been presented?

headline: No Pension? You Can ‘Pensionize’ Your Savings
commentone:
All of the "experts" advising people to delay Social Security benefits seem to leave out a couple considerations.

First are taxes. It's quite likely a retiree's tax bracket will increase significantly at age 70 after factoring in the R.M.D.s. So benefits that may be taxed at 12% at age 62 could quite likely be taxed at 24% or more at age 70.

And while this article mentions the political risks to SS in passing, it's quite possible that benefits will be cut by a third or so in 2034, the projected date for the exhaustion of the SS trust fund.

And, of course, there's probably a 15-20% chance that a 62 year-old man won't make it to age 70.

I'm far from convinced that it makes sense to delay taking benefits.

headline: Romance, Rough Sex or Rape?
commentone:
Each generation sees movies or reads contemporary fiction through its own lens.
In past times, women were attracted to motion pictures, the plots, characters and stars that many of today's women would find annoying, even offensive. Each generation believes it has "grown up," and today it seems expected that we necessarily mock or revile popular successes from the past. With emphasis on sexual misconduct and its many variations, much criticism is in the eye and mind of the beholder -- because while some might wish it were not so, human beings, their tastes, interests and desires differ.
Created characters interest us for many reasons. When watching Valentino's masculinity today, we must make the effort to see him and his women as they were, as audiences who flocked to his pictures were.
We may squirm, mock or condemn the "bodice ripper" moments, but is it possible some women find such behavior of interest? They shouldn't?
There's still something in "to each her or his own." Where fictional portrayals of sexuality, race, relationships go, we may have come a long way, but the past is always prologue. Would we have the car before the wheel? Could we enjoy more if we were less critically picky? In my many years of movie going and reading, I'm still drawn to works of Lubitch, Chaplin,
Sturges, Fred and Ginger, Gene Kelly, my old friend Frank Capra -- and those of their generations. Fun is where you find it.
Doug Giebel, Big Sandy, Montana
commenttwo:
A P.S. to my earlier note.

One day when director Frank Capra was asked which movies he didn't like, he generously replied that he appreciated all motion pictures because he knew what it took to make one. Whether or not his answer was entirely genuine, it contained a pointed kernel of truth. Lest we forget.
Doug Giebel, Big Sandy, Montana

headline: The Clothes Don’t Make  This Group of First Ladies
commentone:
Sounds as if the curator has mixed goals.

If you want to talk about "style of influence," then I suppose she should focus on wardrobe and other ephemera from the women's personal lives.

If you want to talk about "how these women have really shaped history" then why have clothing or snuff boxes or whatever at all? Focus on the issues or ideas that these women advanced, and place them in their historical context, demonstrating why (or why not) they were important. And perhaps how their influence has also advanced over time.

A good rule of thumb for these kinds of interpretive displays is whether or not you would treat their husbands or others of historical influence by showing their wardrobe or their ideas. I think the curator missed her mark on this one.

headline: Can There Be Good Porn?
commentone:
Not surprisingly (if you've read Stoya's excellent blog) this is a thoroughly adult, relentlessly sensible analysis. It hadn't previously occurred to me that content piracy undermines efforts to produce contextually nuanced "good porn," but it makes perfect sense now.

But what to do about it? Most middle-school parents won't even acknowledge that their kids might be curious about porn, so they're certainly never going to watch a Stoya video and discuss it as a family -- even though it probably would produce a hugely beneficial amount of air-clearing (not to mention embarrassment.) So the kids are left to satisfy their curiosity on their own, and what they find to satisfy it is inevitably the Internet's lowest common denominator.

headline: Make Better Movies Too
commentone:
This idea that films must only reflect moviegoers' day-to-day lives and focus on sexual injustice or justice-restored would stifle at least most of the films of Stanwyck, both Hepburns, Davis, Arthur, Loy, Rowlands, Page, Moreau, Masina, and Loren (not an inclusive list, just some of my favorites).

As a woman, I love watching these actors, whose larger-than-life personas and portrayals sometimes ascend to the level of mythic. Just encountering their life forces is empowering.

I shudder to think of any of them having to rein in their magnetism to smaller, (overtly or covertly) polemical stories to maintain the bounds of some predetermined, socially-improving lesson story. "Lady Bird" is fine, but "La Strada" is memorable.
commenttwo: Ms. West is expressing a view and recounting the experiences that formed that view--she's not calling for the installation of a fascist regime, or the burning of movies or books. The tone is polemical, but not particularly nasty.  One purpose of a polemic is to be provocative--to goad people, but also to create the possibility for shifts (large or small) in how they conceptualize their world. (And yes, it can work both ways). Ideally, those changes come about through impassioned discussion or debate. I truly hope that the defensive, dismissive and sarcastic tone of some of the comments here signals a first step toward such a discussion, rather than the last word.

headline: Taxpayers, You’ve Been Scammed
commentone:
PK probably did not have enough room to observe all the distortions from the new law but here are a few others:

The new corporate tax rate delivers $27 billion windfall to Warren Buffett‚Äö√Ñ√¥s holding company. Now Warren is a nice guy but he is not going to raise wages or build a railroad or build a factory‚Äö√Ñ√Æthat is not what Warren does. Warren buys railroads or buys factories. No trickle down here. The same old railroad and factories keep chugging at the same wages. Warren is an extreme example of course but many companies will not build a new factory or whatever with their own windfall, they will just buy one. The income from the brought asset will trickle in to the new owners.

Now about those stock buybacks and those raised dividends. With a buyback, your stock investment goes up not because the company is making more money but because there is less stock out there. So investors sell juiced stock and that profit is taxed at capital gain rate which is a rate less than your paycheck rate. Higher dividends? Taxed at the capital gain rate. And! No pesky payroll taxes on dividends or stock sales. You see where this tax cut is trickling to: me and Warren.

And one more. We now have a whole new tax loophole structure. So expensive tax advisors will see a lot of trickle down to our tax advisors. But those new loophole discoveries will increase the income from capital gains which are not subject to SS, Medicare, Medicaid taxes. And on and on.
Brave new tax world indeed.

headline: The Challenge of Doctor-Patient Relations in the Internet Age
commentone: I have a general rule that I never take any drug or undergo any test or procedure without doing my own research. My doctor knows this and respects it and welcomes my research. There's a LOT of research out there on how overmedicated, overtested, and overtreated people are in this country. And how people headed into surgeries overstate the benefits they anticipate gaining and are unaware of the potential complications. In general the medical profession is inclined toward prescriptions as remedies rather than foods, exercise, meditation, and other lifestyle fixes. If you want those to be part of your consideration, and use prescriptions as the last resort instead of the first thing to try, you're on your own. But luckily, there's a lot of great info out there. In addition to books by well-qualified doctors with an interest in proactive, lifestyle approaches, all the major medical centers have good web pages, as does the CDC (at least before Trump, when we still believed in science in this country), and all the professional associations of different medical specialties. Plus there's Pub Med and People's Pharmacy. And you can ask pharmacists about drug warnings, too. They usually know more than doctors about that. I am not a physician, but I am an academic who teaches and conducts research. You never want to have only one source of information. Ever.

headline: Nakesha’s Demons
commentone: being black and a woman, she had two strikes against to begin with.
commenttwo: I have several mental illnesses, bipolar disorder, psychotic depression, confusion, loss of memory. When I went into the hospital for gallbladder surgery, I came to terms with the fact that I couldn't take care of my beloved parrot of 28 years, and let my friend Marci have him. They fell in love. When I knew my disability check would put me in government-sponsored housing, which is not safe, I arranged for private help to pay the rent and keep me in a beautiful studio overlooking the mountains. I have put boundaries on my life that keep me free, yet for many, they would be their own prison. If you can't face these realities, if your world does not allow you to face these realities, you become homeless. Schizophrenia is worse than anything I have, but she had moments of clarity. She could have chosen another life. She didn't. We have to respect that, and I'm sure she was annoyed that everyone she met did not, but instead tried to get her in a situation they understood. Nakesha deserves to be understood for who she was. And if she died on the street, it was not a tragedy. It was the end of the life she chose to live.

headline: Romance, Rough Sex or Rape?
commentone:
First movie i ever saw as a child in the 60s was 'The Unsinkable Molly Brown'. My grandmother took me, and we talked about and marvelled at this amazing strong woman who was unsinkable physically and emotionally. To this day i think of the character (Debbie Reynolds portrayed) standing up in the lifeboat, shouting "I'm unsinkable!" When her fellow passengers were scared and giving up. I still remember my grandmother and I shouting the phrase out later on, imitating her strength and optimism. In reality Maggie Brown was an activist, feminist and philanthropist who was indeed a strong woman. The role model stays with me as does the memory of imitating her with my grandmother ... a gift of a memory.
Movies have that power, and they both reflect life and create trends, nurture values and ideals, all at the same time. Hoping Hollywood evolves away from sexualizing stereotypes of women and men. We need more strong, hopeful and positive images based on strength of character.
commenttwo: So happy that people are speaking up and questioning "Hollywood" norms.

Lisa,

This resonated with me on so many levels. My grandmother battled Alzheimer's Disease for 12 long years and lived with us for 10 of those years. After the brutality of this darkness had ravaged her mind and body, she finally found peace and succumbed to its power on my 18th birthday on July 3, 1993. And - like you, I've wrestled my own demons in my relationship with mother. Although she doesn't have Alzheimer's like grandmother did (she's very much cogent and physically healthy), it's been a journey fraught with much pain and anger for both of us in our mother-daughter dynamic. Your beautiful and poignant piece was something I needed to read. Thank you for being brave enough to share your story. I see you and am holding your hand.

headline: The Macroeconomics of Trade War
commentone:
The notion that a tariff is going to increase jobs and makes steel a thriving industry is not necessarily so.

The domestic producer has several choices.

With the tariff, the domestic producer can raise his prices but still charge a little less than the import. Then he can expand his market share because of his price advantage, creating more jobs. That is the scenario behind the tariff.

Or, he can raise his price to meet the foreign price, now higher by reason of tariff, and pocket the new profit. No change in market share, no new jobs, but more money in management‚Äö√Ñ√¥s off-shore tax haven.

Which will he do? Expand his business or expand his off-shore bank account?

headline: Trump Embraces a Trade War, Which Could Undermine Growth
commentone:
"President Trump is finally following through on the type of trade crackdowns that terrify Republican leaders in Congress"
I realize that I am grasping at straws here but maybe there is something hopeful in the quote above. After all, if Mitch McConnell and his gang of liars & thieves (ie the Republican leaders in Congress) hate the idea of tariffs, maybe tariffs aren't such a bad idea after all. Just sayin'.
commenttwo:
I understand the reason for tariffs is to stimulate the associated US companies to expand and fill the resulting demand. Several thoughts.
1. Given the approved tax breaks, it seems more likely that companies will improve their stock buyback positions, improve efficiencies in existing facilities and use automation rather than hire semi and un skilled labor to work in heavy industry. No big jobs impact here.
2. Where is the labor of the size equal to China and the rest of the world willing to work in blue collar jobs? The unemployment rate at 4.1%. Is the potential work force near existing plants?
3. How long will it take for companies to positively affect the economy? I say about 2 to five years, minimum.
4. Will companies be willing to train the unskilled?
5. Existing plants will need expansion; time frame 2 to 4 years, minimum.
6. The Bush stab at this was a flop; eventually rolled back. What's different?
7. How will strategic reserves be maintained in a possible decade long decline while we ramp up?
8. Has anyone compared fair trade vs. tariffs for jobs creation over the last 25 years?
9. Exactly how many jobs will be created, at what earning level, in what areas, and what will be the total estimated private investment needed to fill these gaps?
10. Acquiring capital equipment, proper labor, raw materials, transportation, benefit structures, contract agreements and more are really out of the league of a real estate developer 6 times bankrupt, right?

headline: Trump: King of Chaos
commentone:
Yes, Charles. Trump is a hopeless case. A fly trapped in a jar bumping into its walls.

We can leave him there. No need to try to project what the next ricochet will bring.

Instead, let‚Äö√Ñ√¥s focus upon the bumbling boobs in Congress and just what prompts them to bounce off the walls, accomplishing nothing. Are they stupid? Maybe, Are they bought and paid for? Probably. And by whom, and for what??

There are the real questions for exploration!
commenttwo:
What on earth should anybody expect when we allow one person to have as much power as we let the U.S. president have? All this power in the hands of one man is the height of absurdity and yet nobody ever really considers it. We need to reform the office of the president.

Here's my solution: Create civil society panels and corporate panels in each state. These two entities come to as many agreements as possible. Elected presidential representatives for that state take their state's agreed upon interests to a wider presidential representative body in Washington where issues are discussed with the other presidential representatives from other states as well as with federal department heads. The wider body convenes and votes on an issue. We then have the "presidents" decision.

Or we can keep on having fakes like Trump as our president who will start a trade war because he saw something on Fox news that morning that turned the Egg Mcmuffin over in his belly too abruptly. I'm done living with such a silly system that would allow one person to rule us like a king. Enough.

headline: Your Kid’s Phone Is Not Like a Cigarette
commentone:
‚Äö√Ñ√∫But experts are split over the question of whether internet addiction is a legitimate stand-alone disorder.‚Äö√Ñ√π

The addiction issue hardly covers the problem. The serious problem with manipulation of minds comes down to propaganda. And social media are in the business of selling the opportunity for spreading propaganda. As it turns out, spreading propaganda for commercial purposes, like stimulating demand for Coke, uses exactly the same principles of click-addiction and fad-formation as spreading propaganda for any purpose.

The basic cure for this problem is regulation. And that will involve a lot of thorny questions about censorship and freedom of speech. In America today we are incapable of approaching these matters, and will remain in thrall to social media‚Äö√Ñ√¥s profit producing manipulation for a long time to come.
commenttwo:
It is interesting to me that there is an entire discipline built around the design of slot machines to breed addiction. The sounds that accompany the action. The maddeningly paced click click of cherries lining up but tantalizingly just too few to jackpot. And other tricks and gotchas.

Twitter, Facebook, games, etc and the phones themselves that display the apps are likewise crafted to lure in the user and keep them there. The design of apps and devices to breed addiction is a science. Likes, sweeps, beeps, clicks, emojis, ring tones, colors...

It is well to realize that breaking the habit of spending too much time on devices puts you up against clever and ingenious opponents thinking 24/7 about casting a spell.

More than that, the entire engagement is crafted to weaken the critical faculties and lobotomize us in a robot mentality.

It isn‚Äö√Ñ√¥t just you that struggles to overcome your demons. You have to outsmart a legion of demons not of your making.

headline: 5G Cell Service Is Coming. Critics Fear the Stations Will Look Like ‘a Medusa.’
commentone:
Addressing a few folks' comments as well as an area not made clear by the original article:

1. "5G" is more than one thing. It's safe to think of it as "faster" and probably even "better" but the radio spectrum that will support it hasn't been decided yet. See:

https://www.gsma.com/spectrum/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/GSMA-5G-Spectru...

The low-frequency spectrum will behave just like current cellular radio, reaching quite a distance from cell towers and even penetrating into buildings. It's the highest-frequency parts of the spectrum that will have little range (and, by the way, little reach into buildings).

2. Yes, "5G" cellular will use *ELECTROMAGNETIC* radiation (just as all modern over-the-air services from Bluetooth, Wi-Fi, AM and FM broadcast radio, to current cell phones do) but no, there's still no evidence to support the claim that this sort of radiation is harmful at the power levels we're discussing.

3. Yes, the equipment could be housed within hollow poles; good idea! Write to the FCC and other regulatory bodies and demand this.

4. And finally, to "catlover" in Steamboat Springs: You don't think we urban folks are already subsidizing the almost-entirely-Republican rural areas enough? We already pay for your highways, your unused Amtrak service, your airports, your unused farmland, and so on. Your elected Republican officials claim to *HATE IT* when the government subsidizes services; maybe you should be complaining to them?

Were any of these people with "buyer's remorse" about Trump even awake during the 2016 campaign? Everything Trump said was idiotic, incorrect, pandering, later contradicted, or purely buffoonish.

headline: Letting  Teenagers  Live
commentone:
The problem with comparing car accidents with an AR-15 intentional slaughter is obvious.

Car accidents kill many Americans every year, the total even exceeding the total deaths in Vietnam, but this has nothing to do with the need to ban certain guns.
commenttwo:
The author is wrong about the strong deadly opposition to reducing child traffic deaths.

They are simply doing so by opposing taxes, regulation and public capital.

Many kids need cars because there is no viable alternative. There is no public transit at the times needed. There are no sidewalks or lanes for runners, bikers, skateboarders. Without driving a car, a family member must drive them, or a fellow child.

The article leads off with the children depending on another child driving a car. What was the alternative? Was there a bus or subway? Was biking together an option? Or walking?

Much of urban design today was to eliminate many classes of people by requiring a car to live in it. Requiring a car eliminates the poor, disabled, often very young and old.

The requirement children live in a sea of guns is much like them being required to interact constantly with deadly cars.

Most people argue that living in danger is liberty, and the solution for both is more of both. To protect kids from cars, they need a car, just as there need to be more guns everywhere.

And just as bigger guns bring more safety, so do bigger cars. When a small car is hit by a big car, the problem is the car was too small, just as cops killed by guns meant cops needed bigger guns.

But eliminating the requirement for cars requires paying too many workers with taxes and fees, and paying workers kills jobs, just as banning guns means more gun deaths.

headline: Make Better Movies Too
commentone: Did it ever occur to you that young men also "had to take notes" about what made our gender handsome, acceptable, and attractive, those of us who didn't have what Hollywood deemed as good looks or pedigree? Yes, you are correct about what women suffered through, but so did men who didn't meet the WASP ideal like a Cary Grant, for instance. But we did have movies like Rob Reiner's Stand By Me who made boys with weight problems, speech impediments, and lower middle class backgrounds figures of identity and compassion. They gave men like me hope that I wasn't just born to be a loser. My point: Hollywood has a lot to answer for.
commenttwo:
"We are not done talking about why so many men feel entitled to space, power and other people‚Äö√Ñ√¥s bodies " says the article. My take: we see a crude model of humanity in our closest primate cousins. Chimpanzees show exactly the same ferocious misogyny as we do. They have no problems with murder. They have brutal wars with other chimp tribes, just as we do. They don't bother to protect their women. Thus, as I see things, we humans simply have not evolved. Female chimps do not look for protection or even fondness from the males.

But wait---we are equally genetically close to Bonobos. Bonobos are--compared to humans and chimps--gentler, they care for others, and theirs is a matriarchal culture. That suggests that perhaps we could do better.

Meanwhile, human women like me have gone feral. It's a good life, by the way.

headline: Nakesha’s Demons
commentone:
The worst thing one can do is enable bare survival. That road to hell, 'n all. To assuage your pain at reading this story by saying any variant of "she lived as she wanted to" or "she maintained her freedom and dignity" is to be as delusional as Nakesha was in the grip of her illness.

Pharmacological drugs have their terrible drawbacks, but what they do very well is give a person a benchmark for "normal." Unfortunately, in severe illness, the person often refuses to recognize the slide back to delusion if becoming non-compliant with meds.

We've had some very high-profile stories of very ill people who seemed very "normal" after a successful course of treatment and who then felt so well they stopped taking their meds, and tragedy ensued.

You cannot possibly truly believe that a stinking woman with swollen, bleeding feet was happy and dignified in her "freedom."

What we really need are residential secure treatment facilities that are permanent homes for the most seriously mentally ill, that are made beautiful and welcoming, and where those with artistic gifts can be encouraged to flourish, as much as possible, but are not allowed to destroy themselves.
commenttwo:
We need a little sensible legislative understanding of the public health costs of letting profoundly mentally ill people live in public spaces which are not really free.

How much will Nakesha's children cost the system over their lifetimes? How many homeless women give birth every year? How many intermittently homeless women give birth every year?

I was struck by the happy Facebook photo of Nakesha's father and his other children and/or grandchildren. Perhaps if more thought had gone into engendering Nakesha, and proper care of her afterwards, she would not have had such a brutally truncated life. The prime villains here are not our various bureaucracies, but the two people so unprepared for the birth of a child in the first place.

headline: Readers React: What Is the Healthiest Way to Feed a Baby?
commentone: Human babies need help learning how to eat. They learn about their relationship with food by watching their parents. They need to eat with and see their parents or caregivers eating a wide variety of healthy foods with enthusiasm & a positive attitude.  This is how babies learn to adopt healthy eating habits. Childhood obesity often starts with a distorted relationship with food. Baby-led feeding works in theory, but only if the parents have some confidence and knowledge of what to offer a baby & how. Some well meaning new parents may use food to get their babies to sleep more and this can morph into a habit that's hard to break. I have raised 2 children who are normal weight adults. They ate enthusiastically as kids. And so did their father and I. I am a registered dietitian and worked in a WIC program. I also counseled outpatients - many for weight loss, including children and teens. A few conclusions: Eat with your kids and mirror healthy eating habits. Make family mealtime a priority (and fun), especially with younger children. This is so important!  Be positive about food and don't use one food as a bribe for another one.  Parents can only control what a child is given to eat at a meal. A young toddler needs a child size fork and spoon - patiently show her how to use it every time and leave her be. Forget the "clean plate club." Don't use food as a reward or substitute for love & attention. Childhood obesity is a serious lifelong health risk. Let's prioritize prevention.

headline: Saying a Prayer I Don’t Believe In
commentone:
Mr. Lefkowitz,

I appreciate your honesty. Still, it's a sad state of affairs. As a species, we are so inclined to believe what we think would be nice to believe (which, usually, is the reason NOT to believe something).

You indicate, correctly, that we seek out religion for "community" (no serious person really believes there is a supernatural being up in the sky, caring particularly about how humans act). But you then go on to identify that community as the "tribe" and, further, "my tribe." That's the problem. Religion brings people together in the context of exclusion, division, yes, "tribalism;" i.e., my "truths" are correct (even "sacred"!) and yours therefore must be wrong. This is the real meaning - like it or not - of "my" tribe versus "your" tribe.

All this can be said "nicely" for a more positive spin, but it has the same divisive effect. "Moderates" in religion enable and provide cover for those religionists who stick to the actual words of ancient, primitive books and practices, and commit evil acts on that basis.

We can have community without superstition and fairy tales. We can have love, compassion, and respect for humanity, nature, and the world in the clear light of day, freed of the irrationality that persists from our pre-scientific era. Ultimately, we cannot have such love, compassion, respect, or a true path toward ethical behavior, if we try to base those things on mythology and our penchant for a wish-fulfilling, self-imposed authoritarianism.

After the Bush tax cuts failed to stimulate the economy some states still believed tax cuts would still make everything better. As of this year at least 3 states, Kansas, Oklahoma and North Carolina have had tanking economies because they have tried this experiment. In each instance the entitled know-it-all proponents or this type of economy hold the experiment didn't work because they didn't take away all "entitlements" because that would make it work better.

An experiment tests a hypothesis. The data produced during the experiment must be examined in order to reach a conclusion. The experiment must be able to produce consistent results to have value to the scientific community. Scientists use these conclusions to spawn new research. If the data shows a methodology to be flawed it will be instructive in the sense that it would require a new hypothesis or it will be discarded as failed. Politicians need to recognize the data and revise their conclusions with regard to tax cuts.

headline: The Supreme Court’s Power Play Against Labor
commentone: This is all part of the scenario promoted in the Powell Memorandum, written by former Supreme Court Justice Lewis Powell in 1971, a couple months before he was nominated to the Supreme Court.  The memorandum was sent to Eugene Snyder Jr., then head of the American Chamber of Commerce and did not become public until after he was confirmed.  It was leaked to syndicated columnist Jack Anderson.  Powell considered the American economic system to be under attack from socialist and communists.   It was a call to arms to corporations to start developing organizations that could defend business.  Anyway, it's all there and it has been brilliantly executed, one has to admit.
commenttwo: The opposing question should be why labor laws require a union to represent all workers, members or not? If you agree to allow a worker to opt out of union membership, why not allow unions to not represent them? If union membership were truly voluntary, workers who found value in membership, I.e. collective bargaining, would gladly pay the agency fee. Workers who did not want to join in the collective bargaining could fend for themselves in dealing with management. Even for members, any union activities beyond collective bargaining should be supported by voluntary separate donations.

headline: Trade War, What Is It Good For? Absolutely Nothing
commentone: The trade deficit is exactly equal to the amount of money the U.S. takes in from other economies.  As Trump raises the budget deficit to over a trillion dollars with his tax cuts for the rich the trade deficit will follow.
commenttwo:
"Free markets are efficient"

Its been ingrained into us. But there are three problems with that statement. The first is that there is no mention of time. Free markets may tend toward efficient, but they are neither fast, nor kind. It takes time for a market economy to shift investment, retool, retrain and relocate. Change is very disruptive.

The second is the word 'Free.' Tax policy, government regulation (and no, regulation is not always bad) outlook, purity of consumer choice and stability all combine to distort the effect of free. Medical care is not dictated by the free market as the life or death choice tends to seriously skew elasticity.

The third problem us that markets tend to be driven by players maximizing their own benefits. A free market tends NOT to maximize total benefit. Econ 101 illustrations like the 'Tragety of the Commons" and the group interest rate excercise, show the fallacy of believing markets maximize the group good.

So in the case of Steel, we have just removed some freedom from the market. In the long term an efficient market would pull investment from less attractive sources. Wages and jobs would in crease in the steel industry. Workers would migrate to the jobs, aquiring the training as needed. Investors, who were discouraged by the previous ROI proposition would build efficient factories to compete at the now skewed price point.

SERIOUSLY?

headline: A Whole Lot Is Riding On This New ‘Wrinkle’
commentone:
I loved this book so much as a young girl - I must have read it 50 times. Then as an adult I bought and gave away at least a dozen copies :-) I was a big reader and this was the only book I found where the girl was the hero. She saved her dad and her brother and the world from evil - she was truly awesome! The fact that her parents were scientists was great because that meant that girls could be smart. And Calvin liked her, so even smart girls with glasses could have someone like them. This was truly a life saver for me.

The casting for this sounds wonderful! If I felt so good after reading it, I can only imagine what a young girl who isn't white might feel and it's about time :-)

Can't wait to see it - I've got it all memorized, so I think I won't read it again in advance, I think I'll let some of it be a "surprise" when I see it. And it absolutely has more of a young teenage audience - I'm in my late 50s and I will be there when it opens and I bet there's lots more like me, some of whom might have kids of their own to bring. Yay! My favorite coming to life on screen with a great cast, I can hardly wait :-)
commenttwo: FOrgive me but after seeing Selma, and the manner in which Ms Duvernay butchered history in the name of propagandizing, I fear AWIT, one of the great literary experiences of my childhood, will suffer a similar fate.  Duvernay had no qualms recreating LBJ as a neo-racist, falsely claiming that he essentially sided with the racist politicians in the south to undermine MLK and the civil rights movement.  Am I supposed to believe that she will craft a film based on L'Engle's vision, rather than simple replace the film's central message with one more in tune with her race centric viewpoint?  I hope I'm wrong, but will not be surprised if it ends up like all so many other Hollywood adaptations..see "the cat in the hat.'

headline: An ‘Annie Hall’ Reboot for the Ages
commentone: Wonderful project....congratulations all around!
commenttwo:
This story reminded me a bit of the lovely 2007 documentary Young@Heart, about a group of seniors (average age: 80) who sing in a chorus... performing material by The Ramones, The Clash, James Brown, Coldplay, Allen Toussaint, Talking Heads and other unexpected artists. These elders, many of whom join the group just to fill time, really come alive from having a creative outlet, and from having expectations placed upon them at a time in life when the rest of society pretty much disregards what they have to offer.

It's especially fitting that the filmmakers and cast of My Annie Hall forged relationships with each other that will continue past the completion of this project. Because wasn't the original Annie Hall all about relationships?

For their next "senior project" I hope Ms. Sachs and Mr. Starr consider writing some original material -- perhaps based on their experiences getting to know Ms. Chernick and Mr. Miller.

headline: Bunny Williams, Doyenne of Cozy Chic, Lists Her Upper East Side Home
commentone:
As prewar luxury buildings go, this is one of the best in Manhattan. Ms Williams and her husband have created a lovely home, one they'll likely miss and I wish them well in their next abode.

That said, it is wearying to read of yet another multi-million dollar home in a city which of late builds mostly luxury buildings at the expense of extant homes and neighborhoods. It becomes challenging to find excitement about expensive real estate when it's become ubiquitous. Rare are stories of middle class homes; I would love to see interesting design in classic buildings occupied by denizens of modest income. Many large apartments are found in courtyard apartment houses from the Bronx to Brooklyn (and even Staten Island).

Design on a small budget takes great creativity, found amongst NYT's intelligent and informed readers who are not wealthy. But for the classic design in a rare Park Avenue courtyard building and these particular sellers, this article would blend into all the rest.

He doesn't understand ANY of the basic rules of management:
1) Don't mess with peoples' pay--he stiffs people all the time.
2) Loyalty is like gravity--if it goes it has to come back down. Trump demands loyalty. I think he REALLY expects people to risk going to jail, or even to go to jail for him, to give their life for him, but he'll throw them under the bus in a New York Minute.

headline: Democrats Face Primary Shove From New Left
commentone: The term "ideological purity" is a smear term used by the establishment corporate wing of the party to trash and undermine anyone who dares to challenge them.  As soon as the writers of this column use that term, they reveal themselves to be partisans pushing the establishment agenda, rather than neutral reporters.
commenttwo: I think that as Democrats we need to be practical on a case by case basis but with one over-arching goal: electing Democrats in every election until, at least, the balance of power is restored. Ideological "purity" is a lovely idea, but at this point in  our politics, it is not a practical one. We must run on the urgent broad issues stated positively, not just as the party of anti-Trump (most people get that already). It means building up political capital to unpack conservative courts, restore serious environmental stewardship, apply appropriate (neither excessive or too loose) regulation. It means minimizing chaos and leading by the best of our American values. It means minimizing infighting and maximizing the over-arching message: one America for all Americans, rich to poor, all classes, races, etc. Take care of the breakout of sub-groups later, when we have the power and political capital to do so. It means, in the primary, voting for the candidate who best expresses your beliefs AND who can win a general election; and ultimately, it means every registered Democrat voting in every general election for every Democratic candidate. We can't exercise power from weakness; we have to win first.

headline: Hooray for Harvey-less Hollywood!
commentone:
Nothing is over in Hollywood as long as the sexist, misogynist is in the WH and there are still men and women who will vote for him.

In 2016 the US had the chance to elect a totally qualified, capable woman to the presidency and instead settled for a dumb, hateful, racist man, know nothing old white man who ran his businesses into bankruptcy and lies with every breath that he takes.
Frankly I'm not worried about the "good old days" being over in Hollywood when the "good old days" are alive and well in the WH and no one cares.
commenttwo:
Women may have taken charge of the conversation of the industry, but there's another untapped opportunity for changing the Hollywood culture -- changing the (shallow, co-branded) conversation of the red carpet.

Awards shows, despite how they're presented, are business events. There have been stretches of time when the mode of attire for award shows was less formal, and women didn't so readily pour themselves into uncomfy gowns and suffer in shoes designed to destroy human feet. I don't really watch awards shows, but I would welcome a return to those more casual times, when women showed their personalities in clothes they might actually wear in "real life."

Check out Diane Keaton accepting her Oscar for Annie Hall.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oQKuNHhX8Js&t=4s
She looks fantastic (well, she always does). She could walk down a street in that outfit with no worry that something will fall off or she'll turn her ankle. Her clothes are fun, they're full of personality and she's still sexy as hell. (It's hard to remember, but a few women have accepted an Oscar in pants.)

This may be an unpopular view, but I think that to really seize this moment, women should drop some formality and glamor (for the record, I'm female) and rock a funkier, more individualistic look. Again, this is a business event where people are celebrated for their talents and professionalism. The talk should be about that, not about who looked best in a dress.

headline: How Did Europe Freeze As North Pole Warmed Up?
commentone:
During the late and unlamented Little Ice Age Europe was colder than it is now during the Spring and Autumn. Europe is getting at taste of what the world will become if the global warming alarmists take the helm.

We are due for another period of glacial advance and freezing our collective fannies. Perhaps global warming is not as bad as some of the Alarmists make it out to be.
commenttwo: This is how Europe is supposed to be.  Naples is the same latitude as New York.  Venice is as far north as Montreal.  London's as far up as Labrador.  The only thing that normally prevents them from being cold and snowy is the nonstop buffetting of southwest winds off the Atlantic, which itself is unusually warm because of the Gulf Stream.  Any small modification in ocean tempertures or prevailing winds, and it would be expected that the bottom would fall out of European winter temperatures.  If you want my opinion, they should be getting blizzards, just like us.  They've been living in a kind of greenhouse bubble all this time.

headline: Keeper of the Flame
commentone:
Hand up if you started reading this before doing the puzzle. Me too.

Seriously? "Warning: There be spoilers ahead" at the END‚Äö√Ñ√Æwhere you link to the actual answer key ("duh," to quote Joe DiPietro)‚Äö√Ñ√Æbut not in the first paragraphs where FIFTEEN ANSWERS IN ALL CAPS grab the eye before the mind can grasp what it's seen?!

I'd heard Ms. Maddow mention the puzzle, but with Donald Trump's scientific breakthrough in bending the time-space continuum I couldn't remember how many days ago, so I logged in and searched "Rachel Maddow puzzle." Rather than the Times linking the actual puzzle, this came up so I started to read expecting something along the lines of Constructor Notes.

"While the answers are free to everyone, the Crossword puzzles require a subscription" as your penultimate sentence implies readers who chew all the way through your piece not only without solving, but without yet having access to, the puzzle.

If you intend this sort of thing to be neither aperitif nor punch in the gut but digestif‚Äö√Ñ√Æor indeed, in lieu of the meal‚Äö√Ñ√Æthe cold fish is served before the meat, of course.

As to the possessive for the classic piece from Carmina Burana, it's its, not it's. But your errant apostrophe is a sad trombone coda to the arrant catastrophe of dashing my enjoyment of this special puzzle. "O Fortuna" indeed: "nunc per ludum/dorsum nudum/fero tui sceleris."

If you have ever been to the movies in your life, you are probably aware that sequence ain't just Charo's wardrobe.
commenttwo: Was watching Rachel's show last night when she announced that the NY Times was running her puzzle today.  Couldn't wait to do it, but OMG this was one of the hardest puzzles I have worked on in years.  I usually can finish the Friday & Sat puzzles, may have to google one or two answers, sometimes just to confirm that I have the right answer, but today's puzzle just stumped me from the beginning.  And Will Shortz made some clues EASIER!!!  Can't imagine.  Good work Rachel & Joe.

headline: Make Better Movies Too
commentone:
I recently caught some of my favorite 80s teen movies & found many of them unwatchable. It was so obvious! How did I ever think this was ok? Sadly, my generation (X) thought the representations were funny & just "normal."

I must've watched "16 Candles" &"Pretty in Pink" several dozen times. Molly Ringwald was the ugly duckling that just wanted the handsome rich guys to notice her. Only then would she be complete. There were mixed messages- she was individual, creative, smart & chastised for it. Stalked by the "Geek", who, if he couldn't have sex with her, could lie about it to the other geeks by asking for her underwear and showing it to them. And she let him - IF it meant she'd have a chance with Jake Ryan. Her pretty, daft sister was showered with attention for getting married while Sam's 16th Birthday was forgotten. When she spoke up about it, her sister called her selfish.

In "Pretty in Pink", Ringwald played Andie, another creative, smart, individual from the wrong side of the tracks but had a loving father, a cool boss, & an adoring best friend, Duckie. In their world she was everything, but until she was accepted by Blaine, the handsome, rich jerk, she was unlovable.
I wanted to be Molly. She wasn't the pretty, dumb, easy) blonde stereotype in heels. But I also wanted the unattainable, hot rich guy to notice me. My self-worth depended on it. Thankfully my 14 yr old niece has grown up with strong females on screen, even if the boys are still stuck in the past.
commenttwo: Good idea, lets choose Oscar winners solely on politics and the race and sexual orientation of its actors, directors, and subject matter. No need to even consider any other factors.  Clearly the Smurfs and Disney movies, along with romantic comedies are dangerous and must be thrown out, along with anything that might involve actual entertainment or anything that might make the viewer feel good. Let's get rid of the action hero movies too, I mean don't they make the average person feel like a loser?  What a fabulous idea, it could lead  to the end of movie ticket sales and Hollywood itself. Now that might be a good thing actually, then we wouldn't have to watch these ridiculous hypocritical people with their absurd politics preen over themselves every year.

commentone: In this era of crass commercialism and seemingly endless bluster in sport, it is comforting to know that one of the true milestones of athletic achievement rests with a man who trained and raced strictly for the challenge of pushing himself to the limits of his potential, the joy of competing and for the honor of representing his country. headline: Romance, Rough Sex or Rape?
commentone: IN MODERN SOCIETIES with egalitarian ideals, we tend to apply our standards of proper conduct to other times and places.  The movies cited may have occurred in the relatively recent past when women were expected to submit without protest.  Going farther back, in feudal times, the male nobility who owned the land and the serfs, had free access to women.  It was known as the "droit du Seigneur," or the right of the lord (i.e., nobleman).  For example, when serfs or peasants married, the lord of the manor was expected to exercise his right to initiate the wife in her marital duties.  Barbaric by our standards, no doubt.  But in a classist society, such differences in power were the way things worked.  Such powers extended to the owners of slaves in the US and elsewhere, where the owner had access to the females when, where and how he  pleased.  Brutal and animalistic along with being an abuse of power, that was how things worked.  By our current standards, the structure of the society was illegitimate, as were many of the children produced by such forced encounters.  So it is logical that successful men, even in more democratic societies, believed they had a right to exercise their power as males over females.  Again, repugnant and abusive, yes.  But historical fact nonetheless.  Movie plots showing men abusing their power with women reflect the mores of the times in which they are set. I recall a 1977 movie with John Denver and George Burns.  John was very loving with his wife.
commenttwo:
Regarding Lady Bird: it was the most boring and cliche ridden movie I've seen in a lifetime of movie going, and I'm no spring chicken.

Regarding Gone With the Wind, the Sheik, and bodice rippers (not to mention 100 years of soap operas, Twilight and every vampire movie): their main audience is woman, and while I won't say "that's want they want", I still have always been bewildered at their attraction to these type of genres. I presume that ‚Äö√Ñ√∫The Shape of Water" fits into this category (haven't seen it) as I can't imagine many men being interested in a love story between a woman and a fish.

Regarding The Graduate: anyone who would consider Benjamin a stalker is an idiot, pure and simple, though I realize all opinions are regarded as equal on today's college campuses.

Rather than reading the prayer at a fourth grade level, try intellectual rigor and spiritual honesty. You seem like an intelligent person. What is Kaddish really about? What do the words, driving motivations and intimations and hints lead you to? Apply the same quest to the other prayers that you say you don't believe- whatever that means. The Kotzker Rebbe said, "I cannot pray to a G-d who I can understand nor believe in a religion that I can explain." Your professed loyalty to a tradition whose content you reject doesn't look like loyalty or strength. It looks pathetic and like hypocrisy. Aseh L'cha Rav U'kneh L'cha Chaver- seek a teacher and confide in a friend. You are like someone holding precious treasure with a blindfold on. Sorry for the brutal honesty, but you need to shout here for a whisper to be heard. Chag Purim Sameach.

You can find "community" all around you anywhere you are. Your dedication to words and concepts of ancient myths is frightening to me and shuts you off from your own sacred ability to think creatively. God is likely a notion at best and you appear to be embracing only a very narrow portion of that notion. A tribe is only a tribe.

headline: Scintillating, and Serene, São Paulo
commentone:
I notice you gloss over the issue of crime, which is of serious concern in Sao Paulo as it is in Rio.
I recently returned from a business trip to Sao Paulo, during which I had lunch with some clients in a high-end restaurant. The women in our group slung their pocketbooks across the back of their chairs. The waiter came over and nonchalantly zip-tied the pocketbooks to the chairs. When we were ready to leave the waiter snipped the zip ties with a pair of scissors he had in a holster on his belt. I was told that it was common for thieves to wander into restaurants, grab purses and take off. I was also warned about the risks of wandering the city alone at night. Something to keep in mind if you intend to visit.
commenttwo:
Hate to be negative but lets provide a balanced portrait of Sao Paulo.
The traffic is horrendous. A four hour trip (normally less than an hour) to or from the airport is common.
Crime, besides the pickpockets you mentioned, is a serious issue. Purse snatchings, muggings, and gun stickups are also on the rise.
The city is massive and thus not walkable. You'll need a taxi to get to the pockets of fun that you mentioned.
On a recent business trip to Sao Paulo I was fortunate to have colleagues to show me around, otherwise touring the city would have been a challenge.
