headline: Silicon Valley Disruption In an Australian School
commentone:
I‚Äö√Ñ√¥ve spent a bit of time around schools with working with director Vicki Abeles on 2 documentaries about education ‚Äö√Ñ√∫Race to Nowhere‚Äö√Ñ√π and ‚Äö√Ñ√∫Beyond Measure‚Äö√Ñ√π . This in no way qualifies me as an expert on education, but I have in the process interviewed top thought leaders in the field of education and spent lots of time in many schools both private and public that are trying to innovate in the education space in various ways. Some efforts have worked, others not.

‚Äö√Ñ√∫Things Take Time‚Äö√Ñ√π. Schools are not apps, they are living, breathing, institutions run by people. These people have some shared goals, personal goals, financial goals and all of that affects bringing change to education. It takes dedication, perseverance and a very long view to bend the trajectory in education culture and make it stick. Many people involved in trying to bring about this change in education exemplified in this article don‚Äö√Ñ√¥t necessarily have the long view needed to make it happen.

A school may start the journey under a principal or superintendent who is very supportive of the the work being done to alter school but 2 or 3 years in, they get a better job offer, move out of the position of leadership. New leadership comes into the school/system and in putting their stamp on the institution tosses out the previous initiative and starts off in another direction.

I recommend waiting 7 years before writing an article about a new start up that is going to disrupt education and see if and how they survive.

headline: Silicon Valley Toured the Heartland and Fell in Love
commentone:
The bay area is ridiculous, when an 800 square foot house is a million bucks, a plain little ranch house, it has gone nuts. And I really hope that other places do bring their own version of silicon valley, maybe one different, with different ideas and so forth.

However,that doesn't mean mainstreet USA is going to become the next silicon valley, this has been tried before, Utah tried it back in the days of modems (Provo, for example), there was talk of the 'silicon prairie' in Iowa, and it didn't happen.A place like Detroit, that hit the skids with the auto industry,still offers diversity, and it is an urban environment and not far from technical universities and the like. To grow tech companies you need an environment where tech workers will want to live, and they are going to want things a lot of places just can't offer: When they have families, good education systems that aren't starved for resources or where education and science are seen as threats. They want to live in places where most of the people don't assume the world is about being white and Christian with certain values (and yes, I can understand when people say that about silicon valley, places like the people's republic of berkeley), they want to live in a place where someone who is gay, or someone who has kids but isn't married, or isn't Christian or white, can feel accepted. Places flourish because of many factors, and 'flyover country' doesn't always offer these kind of things.
commenttwo: South Bend Indiana? Where Notre Dame football is god? This is an example of a place that isn't going to attract many people, having been there it is the kind of place that handily supports Donald Trump despite having a major university there (Notre Dame might have big sports programs, but it is also a very, very good school) and need I say it is a hotbed of support for Mike Pence? Tech people are not exactly people supporting science that takes a back seat to religion, they aren't into schools stripped of funding to give vouchers to private religious schools and most of them won't feel comfortable in a place where the gun culture is dominent or where people are all loving and accepting as long as you live by their rules, and places like South Bend are not exactly known as being harbingers of live and let live.

headline: Trade War, What Is It Good For? Absolutely Nothing
commentone:
In one sense, good for Paul. If there‚Äö√Ñ√¥s anything that will avoid a trade war, it‚Äö√Ñ√¥s the faith that builds in our trading partners that what Trump is after IS a trade war ‚Äö√Ñ√¨ when what he‚Äö√Ñ√¥s really after are bilateral trade agreements that are GENERALLY fair to American workers; and Paul‚Äö√Ñ√¥s attention to the horrors of a trade war likely will aid in securing that objective. One way or another, Trump should get what he‚Äö√Ñ√¥s after.

The concern that is building globally over Trump‚Äö√Ñ√¥s recent tariff announcements likely will cause a line to form outside the Oval Office of furriners seeking ways to make those tariffs less painful for THEM. The solution is easy: let‚Äö√Ñ√¥s talk about the ENTIRETY of our bilateral trading framework with each of those partners, and adjust agreements to be more balanced with respect to the interests of U.S. workers.

Obama didn‚Äö√Ñ√¥t even try brinkmanship, and what resulted was a TPP that sought to inveigle partners into becoming more like us culturally and place us more centrally in the position of global arbiter of political correctness ‚Äö√Ñ√¨ at the expense of American jobs and general prosperity. Our intended involvement with TPP was a popular means among elites of accomplishing that purpose by many administrations, and over decades ‚Äö√Ñ√¨ cede the leverage we have over our internal markets, in which the entire WORLD wishes to participate, to answer Rex Harrison‚Äö√Ñ√¥s eternal plaint: ‚Äö√Ñ√∫Why can‚Äö√Ñ√¥t the entire world be more like ‚Äö√Ñ¬∂ ME?‚Äö√Ñ√π And to heck with American middle-class jobs.
commenttwo:
I agree with a lot of what Prof. Krugman says, particularly his emphasis that Trump's ham-fisted, bulldozer driven by a 7 year-old approach to dealing with trade issues is dangerous and counter-productive. However, when he asserts that "the case for worrying about trade deficits, like the case for running budget deficits, has largely evaporated now that unemployment is back to 4 percent." Economic prosperity is obviously not measured just by the single statistic of how many citizens are employed. A worker at a fast food chain and one at a unionized factory making multiple times more per hour both count as 1 person employed. Because of decades of administrations, Republican and Democrat, proving mostly feckless in addressing rampant unfair trade practices engaged in by nations running ever growing trade imbalances with us--with China being the worst offender--millions of good, well-paid jobs available to non-college educated workers disappeared. The backlash in 2016 against the obliviousness to this by politicians and economic pundits is a key reason we now have one of the worst presidents ever in the Oval Office.

Yes, Trump acted like a bull in a china shop (puns intended) with his bellicose blather about trade wars being good. But that doesn't mean that massive unfair trade conduct by nations like China don't constitute a present and future danger to the American economy.

headline: Virtual Coins, Real Resources
commentone: This article seems to fundamentally confuse economic activities that produce only virtual outputs with economic activities that don't generate much employment. headline: When Elder Abuse Is Self-Inflicted
commentone:
After reading many of these, I felt the need to share this story:
Some years ago, I worked for an active, intelligent man in his 80s. Unfortunately, his beloved wife died, and he was hospitalized for depression that was treated quite successfully, with electroshock. When he came home, his children fixed him up with a housekeeper, also quite elderly, a lovely, cheerful woman. It wasn't long before they married.
Not all old age is misery. But when it is bad, it is horrible.
commenttwo: Some say people "choose" to hoard and live in life threatening squalor.  Is it really a choice? Or is it more likely a combination of mental and physical illness so significant and overwhelming that even beginning to provide help is more than most professionals, let alone family, can muster? With resources becoming more limited as budgets are cut, this sad situation will increase.  How we treat our elderly, how we prioritize their needs, indeed, how we view aging and ageism, is a question the rest of us will have to answer. I am afraid the answer will not be a compassionate or concerned one.

headline: It Was Only a Matter of Time: Here Comes an App for Fake Videos
commentone:
I recently watched the 1977 movie "Capricorn One" again. It tells the fictional story of a manned mission to Mars that was faked. Before that, in the realm of radio, there was "The War of the Worlds" panic. Of course, it has been possible to create doctored photographs for almost as long it has been possible to make photographs. Meanwhile, there is a similar reality-altering phenomenon that has tainted literary accounts going back to the earliest forms of writing.

Clearly, the potential for manipulating reality has been with us for a long time. It is somewhat comforting to realize that we have managed to come this far despite all the manipulation that has occurred, or could have occurred. Of course, it is hard to know to what extent history has been forever altered by the manipulations that have occurred, to say nothing of the untold individual lives that may have been touched, for good or for ill, by such manipulations.

One possible benefit of this technology is that it may actually tend to dull the blackmailer's tools. When embarrassing photos and videos can be so easily faked, don't they lose some of their power to embarrass? After all, they may well be fake.

More than ever, we need to be teaching people critical thinking skills. Thinking people, more than ever, need to be seeking out reliable sources of information.
commenttwo:
Personal technology is all about making people stupider and lazier.

Social media is all about making civilized people into tribal animals.

AI combines both of these wonderful technologies.

It's a win-win situation...for the creators and users of these systems. It's a lose-lose situation for everyone else.

headline: Make Better Movies Too
commentone: Yes, change art. Represent diverse views. Don't glorify abuse. Then can we start talking about the real elephant in the room? And the message these ads convey is you are inadequate, you should hate yourself. The solution? Buy our product. Didn't work? That's your fault. Buy more. Women in ads are commonly represented as sexy, often scantily clad, and placed next to a razor, a car, a tube of toothpaste, or myriad other products. In any single ad, this is innocuous. When ad after ad repeat the same limited role for women, what message is conveyed? Advertising is pervasive in America. There is hardly a space you can direct your eyes that isn't covered with some appeal to buy something. Shouldn't this be part of our conversation?
commenttwo:
Silly column.

Hollywood has been conservative. Hollywood has been liberal. But Hollywood has always been in the motion picture business to make money. That's why Hollywood makes the movies it makes. If you don't like the bad movie, stay home...and don't stream it at home. I'll join you. But most Americans will not follow our lead.

I'm not saying that Italian movies or TV is, in general, better. In fact, you can watch Italian porno movies on Italian TV so there's no need to go to the movies. However, I have seen many interviews with Italian actors, most of whom work in crime series and/or movies. Most seem genuinely concerned about the state of democracy in their country. Most say they try to portray flawed people who really do care about their country. I get the feeling that most Hollywood actors, regardless of their politics, including what they say in public, really only care about a paycheck.

I almost never see an American movie unless Bill Murray, Michael Keaton, Frances McDormand or Laura Linney is in it. This year I saw three Oscar-dominated movies:

"Ladybird" Decent; good acting, however, an excessively soft, fluffy landing at the end.0

"Three Billboard..." Hard hitting; not perfect, but great acting by all. Your topic. Closure doesn't actually exist. But it's a great American myth that we have to hang our hats on.

"The Square" Great insight into how personal technology is ruining our lives.

The French "Places, Faces" is fantastic ("Villages, Visages").

headline: When Elder Abuse Is Self-Inflicted
commentone: Then there's the case of April Parks detailed in the October 9, 2017 issue of The New Yorker. This hideous woman would get the courts to make her guardian of older people who had money. These were highly functioning people living their lives. Parks took over all their finances, got them into homes, drugged them, and robbed their bank accounts. She sold their homes, and took their beloved pets. Family members tried to intervene but the courts supported Parks. The question of collusion with the judge was not made clear, but looked very suspicious. Family members were finally, after great hardship, able to free their loved ones, and, as of the writing, April Parks was in prison. The name of the article is The Takeover, and you can find it online. It is frightening. I, for one, am not in support of government interference into people's lives. If the man wants to drink and live in squalor, so be it. There is no indication that he abused his dogs. If so, that's another matter. But dogs love their owners and don't care about the condition of the house. The whole issue of guardianship is, in my opinion, on shaky ground, and I do not trust folks who are set up to be guardians. If someone does not want help, and they are not hurting others, leave them alone!

headline: A Red Older Than Its Year
commentone:
Got to open two Lisinis in five days. One was my first of this month‚Äö√Ñ√¥s assignment. One was the last, at Wine School NYC‚Äö√Ñ√¥s Sunday night classroom, upper west side gem, Mezzogiorno (spicy saffron tagliolini with crab, yum!). In between, the Torre and (2016) Potazzine gave some perspective. The T and P seem more like each other than the L. Both seem mannered and self-aware, with a well-defined mix of candied fruit (cherry, berry), proper bitterness to balance, plus something darker (chocolate, leather), too. Together, they pointed out what the L had that they did not.

It, the L, was in comparison untamed and from the heart. It was the most vibrant of the three. Paired with some more complex foods (charred broccoli with shallot, lime and pine nuts; eggplant croquettes with tomato sauce and goat cheese) its flavors came in a wild barrage, like little mouth explosions! Cuddled up with what struck me as all these RdMs‚Äö√Ñ√¥ most ideal pairing, lighter meat and tomatoes (meatballs parmesan; wild boar ragout; maybe Ferguson‚Äö√Ñ√¥s red sauce with mushroom and ground beef, too?), the L purred like a kitten.

Ali called it ‚Äö√Ñ√∫a savory, fruity mystery.‚Äö√Ñ√π Intriguing how, with a simple grilled steak, Martin was struck by the L‚Äö√Ñ√¥s ‚Äö√Ñ√∫elegant simplicity and polarity‚Äö√Ñ√π (savory fruity?) Seems quite the chameleon, adapting well to what it‚Äö√Ñ√¥s served with.
commenttwo:
This is a collaboration with Dan and a report from our foursome‚Äö√Ñ√¥s Tuscan dinner with Lisini and ‚Äö√Ñ√≤16 Potazzine. They were the epitome of vibrancy. Dan described Lisini as ‚Äö√Ñ√∫fascinating and wild, like the falling, glowing embers of a burst of fireworks.‚Äö√Ñ√π We didn‚Äö√Ñ√¥t smell oak, and I only tasted a hint in Lisini and Torre. Slightly hazy, natural, they were refreshing and sincere, and 14% ABV didn‚Äö√Ñ√¥t weigh them.

The youngest, astringent and untamed Potazzine had ethanol nose, with a short, tart finish. Dan sniffed out blackberry.

Lisini stood out in comparison as more balanced and complex than P, savory and fruity (sour cherry) and a warm, medium finish.

The wines were versatile with food: ‚Äö√Ñ‚Ñ¢Margherita pizza; ‚Äö√Ñ¬®eggplant croquettes in red sauce and goat cheese (a startling taste highlight of the evening for Dan); grilled, smokey escarole; wild boar in tomato ragout; and spiced poached pear. These pairings brought out ‚Äö√Ñ√∫sweetness and deliciousness‚Äö√Ñ√π in the wines and reciprocity from food. They were juicy, energetic, and ABV a warming and head-spinning experience.

To my dismay, neither Montalcino worked with seafood. Dan was frustrated by our ordering decisions based on food. Indeed he had the eminent good sense to order food carefully based on wine, and was rewarded with ‚Äö√Ñ√∫a deeply satisfying meld of food & wine.‚Äö√Ñ√π Despite our sensory-driven choices, we were all rewarded with a deeply satisfying meld of great company, wonderful meal, and vibrant, if somewhat disjointed, wine pairings.

headline: A Whole Lot Is Riding On This New ‘Wrinkle’
commentone: This made me cry with joy.
commenttwo:
I adore Wrinkle in Time. I also have no problem with black actors playing characters who in the book were white.

What I have a problem with is that increasingly for the far left (for shorthand, call them SJW), what matters is not art but propaganda. The chief aim is not to create a seamless & purposeful work of art, with plot, character, strong acting & directing etc, but instead to signal the same simplistic virtue-SJW-message: Diversity is Good. Women are Good. And so on.

If you criticise the movie- for instance, the abysmal Star Wars - you are smeared & threatened & mocked & bullied. You are stupid or racist or sexist.

This is in fact the easiest way to tell it's not art & is instead quasi religious---you cannot criticize it & are blasphemed/excommunicated if you do.

In this case, the previews look terrible. The acting looks stiff, the costumes ridiculous. The soul looks sucked out & instead it looks like posturing for a morality play where the entire point (as implied here) is that Diversity is Good. Ironic that Wrinkle in Time's themes are that Groupthink is morally wrong, God is in the universe (it's a religious piece of work), & one must be fiercely different & individual above all--all themes running against SJW.

I hope I'm wrong about the artistry of it,but the more advance propaganda I see browbeating us with the 'message' ahead of time, the more I'm worried I'm right.

headline: Do Subway Signals Get Short Shrift in Emergency Plan?
commentone:
One hates to be paranoid or complain unnecessarily. But the question must be asked: do any of the people who make decisions for this system ever actually ride the subways? Ever?

Because the signal system is the single biggest driver of the delays.

The NYT last summer reported that the L--where they actually fixed the blasted things--has a 91 percent on-time rate. Only two other lines are better than 70 percent!
commenttwo: the amount of delays, breakdowns, weekends and weeknites with NO service or service that needs early, is ridiculous. I live in a location that allows me to take the M, L, or J with a short walk or bus ride, or the 7 /E if I wish for a longer bus ride. Honestly, I try not to bother with any train other than the L, because it's the fastest in getting me to where I need to be, even if I'm not living in lower Greenpoint anymore. The times that I've taken these other trains, it's been a disaster. Last weekend, it took over an hour to travel to 86th and Lex using he E to get to the 6. With construction on the M tracks, getting to the lower east side via shuttle and the J takes an hour during RUSH HOUR. I'm dreading the L shutdown, which is proposed to add extra busses to an already congested traffic corridor on Grand street. I'm dreading the fact that the M trains, which for some reason are allowed to run every 10 minutes, and stop running at 8.45 in the evening, will not be able to pick up the overflow without a massive service improvement. I'm tired of feeling like I waste my $121 every month when the trains service is combined with the mediocre bus service ( lets not get start d on THAT one. Ugh).

headline: Enlightened Sort

commenttwo:
I had a much easier time with this Saturday puzzle than I did with Friday's. Maybe just a wavelength thing. REM, RUR, and SAYSAYSAY were early gimmes. Took a bit too long to remember Ron SANTO. Came down to the unknown 16A, where I did an alphabet run to see if anything besides R would slot in there, but ARABS had to be right.

Caitlin, I hadn't thought about "Far Out Space Nuts" in decades, but when the theme song kicked in, it came back instantly...just how my brain is wired.

British singer Johnny Wakelin scored a Top 20 hit in the US in 1975 with the novelty/tribute song "Black Superman - Muhammad ALI." He followed up in 1976 with "In ZAIRE," a musical retelling of the famous ALI/Forman fight. This one was a flop in the US, but a big hit in the UK.

"Black Superman - Muhammad ALI":

headline: Expanding Affordable Housing,  Despite the $1 Billion Price Tag
commentone:
It's hard for deBlasio to make a case for anything involving money, after Rechnitz accused him in court of taking a massive payoff.

It might be easy to ignore Rechnitz's accusation, except for the endless "pay to play" accusations that have been made against deBlasio by others.

Like Trump, anything deBlasio does, ends up being "about him"; and having the Governor of your state hate you, doesn't help either.
commenttwo:
The article mentions "transparency," but it's hardly a model of that concept itself. That is, whether it's poorly written of assuming expertise most readers lack, it's akin to a flashlight with weak batteries.

I'm (tentatively) willing to say that the Mayor's heart is in the right place - both by his lights and mine. HOWEVER, "affordable" has come to resemble "extra large" in terms of imprecision.

It's not just that however many $3700 apartments (it's worth asking how large they are!) wind up empty because they're over-priced. When "affordable" means that new tech-y or creative individuals arriving in NY have options IF AND ONLY IF their parents underwrite a hefty % of rent, we're back in the land of "if you don't move your offices and people to NJ, we'll slash your tax bill for 20 years." Anybody with a little common sense knows that this robs Peter to pay Paul. Maybe, it explains the state of the subways, say, because the City essentially begs annually in Albany at a time when the 2 men in charge are having a food fight.

Hard to believe that Bill seems to have written off the "working poor" almost to the same extent as Mike did during his terms as Mayor, but that's the way it looks to me. Universal pre-K and other fine programs are like treading water in the Atlantic if a single mother with one kid, say, needs $75K income to enter a housing lottery time and again.

Until/unless wealthy & often non-resident NY'ers pay more, it sounds to me like this is UNaffordable!

headline: Fights Worth Having
commentone:
Hear, hear. As a traditional liberal myself, I'm becoming more and more alarmed at the insanity gathering strength at what used to be my party's fringe. They aren't the least bit interested in a good-faith debate to figure out what the truth is, and their preferred mode of "argument" is to tell me to shut up and match my views to theirs because I am somehow socially unacceptable if I don't. I have the strength of character to not crumple in the face of that kind of emotional blackmail, but I know there are a lot of other people who don't, and who fall in line despite misgivings because they've been conned into thinking that they're obligated to do so. I've seen people who should have known better fall for this nonsense, and I've been trying to warn my fellows in the center-left that we need to take a stand before it's too late.

Racism and sexism will not be defeated via the abolition of free speech. Feelings do not take precedence over facts. Just because you feel bad doesn't mean you've been wronged. Normally you'd expect these fallacies in teens, but I'm seeing them in people who are well past 30 and should be more than mature enough to see this madness for what it is. And lest you be tempted to say it's just a few morons on social media, I can tell you it's not. These are people I encounter in real life. The problem is real. When it comes time to cast my primary ballot, I'll be looking for a candidate who is willing to call them out.

headline: God, Don’t Save the King
commentone: I don't consider our democracy middle-aged. In light of all of recorded history, it's still in its infancy--or perhaps it's a toddler trying to get steady on her feet.
commenttwo:
A favorite scene of 'The Crown' among friends, regardless of whether they are democrats, republicans, or apolitical for that matter, is Queen Elizabeth dancing the foxtrot with the rebel leader of Accra, Ghana.

A call from MD came in two summers last, where some Americans are descended from The first governor of Virginia, Richard Bennett (trying to figure out who is Irish, and who is British on this family tree, elegantly drafted by my French mother is beyond my mental capacity).

'Come on now', asked the caller from Baltimore, I am much brighter than you, but you have a way of sensing what is in the cards. Who will it be, Hillary, or Trump? Not the bravest, Chinese zodiac rabbits are affable, but not necessarily pillars of fortitude, I wedged. It is going to be a tight race, I ventured, walking on ice and there is a chance that Trump could win. Well! It was fireworks galore and the phone lost its batteries.

The day before the Election, a strong premonition that the crown was going to the simpleton. It was sunny weather on Election Day here in this green Valley, and a feeling of hope that perhaps we were stupid but not crazy.

Later that evening, watching 'The Crown' where Churchill is in denial over the coal miners' fog, nearly 4000 polluted in the Capitol City, I forgot all about our Changing-of-The Guards and when tuning in at 10:30, our Nation was flushing rust with slap.

An American Tragedy in the making.

headline: Is It Harder to Grow Up in the 21st Century Than It Was in the Past?
commentone: We grew up thinking that there was a finite number of years left on the earth because of exhausted resources and global warming. We grew up accustomed to the feeling of being left out because we are constantly aware of our friends activities. We grew up in a world where the offensive rhetoric of politicians and other supposed role models is almost expected. We grew up being accustomed to the news of shootings of children who seem eerily similar to us. We grew up where facts, something that is indisputably the case, are disputed. We grew up knowing that if not us, many of our friends would be sexually assaulted. And the worst part is, we grew up thinking that the world just was this way. There is complex web of unsolved social issues and utterly pessimistic views of the world that has created a thick cloud over our generation. With every new social movement from climate change, to religious equality, to racial equality, to women‚Äö√Ñ√¥s rights, to sexual assault awareness, to gun reform, comes the recognition of this completely flawed and helpless world. So when people label us the generation of the iphone, the igen, or even the snowflake generation, they seem to be ignoring all of the awful events that occur so regularly in today‚Äö√Ñ√¥s world. Maybe they didn‚Äö√Ñ√¥t grow up with this list of horrible realities on constant replay. Maybe we will be the generation that makes actual change.

headline: Not the Higher Prices, It’s What Might Happen Next

commenttwo: Except for historians, few are aware that for centuries ‚Äö√Ñ√∫free trade‚Äö√Ñ√π meant NO protective tariffs (i.e., taxes on incoming foreign goods going to domestic manufacturers of same, thereby securing jobs for local labor), BUT plenty of revenue tariffs (i.e., taxes going to government - for the same goods - to provide public services such as education, public health, and infrastructure). In 1913 U.S., basic rates for all tariffs were shifted from 40% to 25% as part of the Underwood Tariff Act and simultaneously a federal income tax re-imposed decades after the one imposed during the Civil War had expired http://www.taxhistory.org/thp/readings.nsf/ArtWeb/C82515A4B6B7A24C85257D... A quid pro quo. All these sources of revenues ‚Äö√Ñ√¨ revenue tariffs, income taxes, etc. ‚Äö√Ñ√¨ to side-step capturing (socially created) wealth in land value (from the land monopolist) that comes with the growth and advancement of the population. This land monopolist is the one George called the robber that takes (from labor) all that is left (of his hard-work income). So here we are today ‚Äö√Ñ√¨ blabbering around the edges of this old debate without going to the heart of it. headline: Power to the Parents
commentone:
The biases, overt and covert, in this column are astounding. Any presumption that Ross supports democracy is laid to rest in this column. Why bother to even vote in Ross' world? The whole idea is to figure out a way to make the folks who disagree with him... not count at all.

I am chronologically in the realm of voters that he would like to disenfranchise. I am only grumpy when I read columns like this, or watch the sordid variations on non-government on display in Washington. In my regular life, I read, take classes, learn new skills, travel and continue to work. Your presumption of a decrepit, self centered and selfish senior is a hallucination that you should consider treating. That describes no one in my circle of friends, family or acquaintances. But even if staying current were not my priority, I am still entitled to be represented.

But disenfranchising the aged and childless is only superficially your premise. What you are actually proposing to to challenge the concept of "all (wo)men are created equal" regardless of age, infirmity, parenthood, color, creed or any other classification. What you cannot abide is the notion of majority rule, unless you are the majority. I expect to exercise my franchise to vote and to maintain active citizenship until my last breath, in a fervent hope that the exceptionally stupid "ideas" intended to undermine our system of government are tossed on the dustbin of history.
commenttwo: Even as a teenager in the 70's, I would have disagreed with the proposal of letting sixteen year olds vote because even then I thought they were idiots and I should know, I was one of them - but, one of the defining qualities of today's culture is that it has regressed to the level of a sixteen year old, with parents seeking to emulate the behavior, tastes and sophistication of their progeny rather than the way it's been for the previous 250,000 years. So, given everyone has settled at the the same level of ignorance, there is absolutely no reason why the voting age should not also be reduced.

headline: Saying a Prayer I Don’t Believe In
commentone:
I lost my mother in January and I am very offended by all of these rude and disrespectful comments. Today is Purim, a festival holiday where Jews thwarted an evil plot against potential Holocaust against them in ancient Persia.

I am especially offended by the smug superiority of the athiests who try to shove their rejection of the Almighty down our throats. If you don't believe in God that's your business. But have the decency to leave the rest of us alone. I'm just hoping my mother is with God in that better place.
commenttwo:
"Does God really will that the world endure the cruelty and suffering we see so often? And, on a more personal level, did God will that my father, an intellectual who suffered from dementia, would lose the ability to communicate and have the mental faculties of a 5-year-old during his last 18 months on earth?"

To ask these questions is to answer them. Either you're "worshipping" a being of unspeakable cruelty, or you realize that such a concept makes no sense whatsoever. I was only exposed to the Old Testament growing up, but there was more than enough in there to drive me far away from organized religion:
- An all-knowing all-seeing god who creates an anatomically correct Adam, but doesn't create an Eve until Adam brings it up. Plot flaw anyone?
- A god who throws his first 2 human creations out of Eden for the unpardonable sin of curiosity (this is man the tool-maker we're speaking about. We have brains.)
- A god who incites a man to kill his own son just to test his loyalty

headline: When Elder Abuse Is Self-Inflicted
commentone:
I think the American ethos of independence is poison to the aging brain.

I'm a first generation American. I have 10 aunts and uncles, all born and bred in a poor rural village in Eastern Europe. All are in their 80s right now. They have all aged gracefully, retiring to care for their grandchildren, staying active well into old age, then easily passing on responsibilities to their kids bit by bit. Eventually they move in with their kids. No sweat. No nursing homes. The parents don't question the norm of caring for their grandchildren. The kids don't question the norm of caring for their parents. It is hard to go off the rails in a truly interdependent family unit.

My husband's side of the family is a bunch of independent wealthy New Englanders. What a mess they are in old age. They retire to golf communities, leaving their kids to juggle two jobs and child care. As they have aged, they have become isolated and crabby, at odds with their kids, fighting over safety and finances. The kids are juggling jobs, their own children, worrying from afar, responding to preventable crises that their parents are always causing. Family relationships go from bad to worse.

American brains aren't wired for interdependence. No institutional solution is going to fix that.
commenttwo: These aging people are shortening their own lives through self-neglect, and at the same time, we taxpayers are fretting about how we are going to afford their Social Security and Medicare benefits. Something is broken here. What kind of life is that?  Some amount of these benefits have to be dedicated to redefining what these decades of retirement should look like. Sending someone a check to buy alcohol and rot alone in his house with his dogs is absurd and inhumane.

headline: Women’s Champions, in Every Way
commentone:
I'm a lifelong Democrat and a fan of equality, but this stuff is getting a bit much. Sports stars are paid based on essentially viewership, not success. Baseball players make more than bullriders, because more people watch baseball. Soccer players in Europe make a lot more than soccer players in the U.S., because more people in Europe watch soccer. It's pretty simple. Female soccer players shouldn't be paid the same as male soccer players. More people watch men's soccer. It's that simple.

The only way you can say this makes sense is if you were to say that WNBA players should be paid the same as NBA players, which is an absolutely ridiculous suggestion.

headline: Your Kid’s Phone Is Not Like a Cigarette
commentone:
Addictions start at home. Watching my dad smoke till he died too young didn‚Äö√Ñ√¥t stop me trying it myself. I quit early. Thank Siva.
My kids never smoked because I quite long before they were born.
My dad was a prolific reader all his life. And he was always kind and thoughtful to us all. Those qualities l learned from him too.
Seeing fat kids with their fat parents all glued to their iPhones not speaking to each other at a restaurant is all too common now. It must start at home.
commenttwo:
I am not sure how the new message is different from our old messages.

We were told not to give our kids excessive screen time - they could not be on TV for hours, playing video games for hours, using the phone for hours. Limit total time in front of ANY screen, and have them do other things that develop other parts of their brains and body.

The challenge comes when you give your child a phone to carry, and limiting that is harder. The social push to give the device at younger and younger ages is hard to resist. But parents are allowed to giveth and taketh away. Kids not doing things they need to do because they are on social media should have to hand over their phones when they get to class or come in the front door.

We can start simply and carry books and crayons and small toys to keep the smaller ones entertained rather than just handing over the phone. There is a lot of self discipline parents must exert to take the time to be present and not allow any electronic device become a babysitter. Inattentive parents breed inattentive kids.

headline: ‘The Assassination of Gianni Versace’ Episode 6: A Nothing Man
commentone: This is not only an examination of a pathetic, self hating serial killer but also a window on a troubling and dark era of the AIDS epidemic, homophobia, loneliness and delusion. Is it always entertaining? Not always. Are difficult stories that are part of gay history not to told? Easy to sweep gays and gay history under the rug.   What else is new?
commenttwo: The acting in all the episodes so far has been exemplary. The production values superb, and all the technical aspects come together to produce what I think of as fine film/television making. And here I am at the 6th episode and I simply cannot find a good reason for this limited series existence. Cunanan remains a pathological demon who destroyed lives and is so monstrous that any attempt to humanize him fails. He is too featured a player for series to be about the hurt he caused or the lives lost.  Now that i've invested this much time I will see it through to the end, I guess, but I would love to know what purpose the creators had in mind when they chose to tell this story. I can't help feeling that now deep into the telling, it is a story that didn't cry out to be told.

headline: A Red Older Than Its Year
commentone:
We all felt these were very good wines at a bargain price for a baby Montalcino. It was hard to pick a favorite and the food match was even harder.
The Lisini had aromas of soft oak, fresh leather, cherries and earth. On the palate some spice and rosemary showed. When served with an Italian faro with pulled chicken and gremolata, it also showed well and seemed to fit in with it.
The Potazzine showed beautifully on its own. Although somewhat tannic it displayed dark chocolate and ripe fruit. When served with a rice pea succotash and cured chicken thigh, it seemed to lighten up the dish and ‚Äö√Ñ√∫cut‚Äö√Ñ√π some of the fat off the chicken. All in all, it was an excellent food wine and our favorite on its own.
The La Tore shoed an even acidity and was very well balanced and round. We were surprised how little the tannins revealed themselves, while I picked up a slight amber hue on the color. It was served with a Steak Florentine and sauce with a quail egg. For many reasons this was our favorite wine and food combination. George Erdle ‚Äö√Ñ√¨ Harper‚Äö√Ñ√¥s Fine Dining ‚Äö√Ñ√¨ Charlotte, NC

commentone:
I would like to challenge Nikki Tinnerello's thought process concerning their published comment under the article "How Do You Think Technology Affects Dating?".

At first look, I can agree with you Nikki, and what you think of dating apps like Tinder. However, with this being said, what are your opinions on clubs? Or even just simple bars? I don't suppose many people go to the club to find the man or women they plan on marrying and having children with. Do you?

Although having a face to face interaction in public is a plus opposed to finding someone online, I don't believe there has ever been any intention for romance after two drunken people stumble into each other, unable to have any real conversation due to their slurred words mixed with the painfully loud music.

Online hookups, although shallow at times, might as well be the preferred option over what I have just described. If you're sure to be careful online and know who you're talking to, online experiences could also be a lot safer than finding yourself alone at a bar with an older man/woman hovering over your drink when you aren't looking, or finding out a week after a one time experience with someone you met that night that you have contracted an STI or sexual disease.

headline: Astronaut and Spider
commentone: It's empty. It's all empty out here, there's no sound but my thoughts and I can't escape my thoughts unless... No, there's no way, I can't. And leave her alone? And leave behind thousands others waiting for my return for another step for mankind? I'll stay here, I have to hold on but...it's getting harder. I've begun to see things, things I don't want to. Things uglier than, things worse than....these things are just the manifestation of my thoughts, my paranoia...I think, God I hope. And no matter how fast I run I can't outrun my mind unless I render it unable to move...myself unable to move but I CAN'T, I'm telling you I can't and-God what is that sound? I can't stop my head from whipping around in every direction and I hear it again. Scraping...oh God awful scraping I can't breathe, it'll find me...I'll find me and lose myself again. The shadows in every corner they're moving, I swear they're moving I need help, I NEED HELP. I hear it, I heard it, "nobody's around to help". A saccharine whisper, the bitter cold reminder, but I already knew. I already know I'm alone, it's only me on this mission after all...just my thoughts after all. "And what if you're not alone...what if we're all waiting to end you? What if everything you know is false? What if you die out here all alo-" STOP it God please stop it I can't stop thinking and I didn't notice when but my face became wet and the monster drew closer, cold metal appendage in my hands, now through my chest. I'm sorry.
commenttwo:
‚Äö√Ñ√∫Havel, I can‚Äö√Ñ√¥t sympathize with you, or tell you that it will be better tomorrow. But what I can say is that you are still alive, and yes of course it hurts, but wouldn‚Äö√Ñ√¥t she want you to stay safe now?‚Äö√Ñ√π
Tholum had both a way with words and slight telepathy to which he used to soothe my mind into a state of understanding.
‚Äö√Ñ√∫If she was in your shoes right now and you were gone, wouldn‚Äö√Ñ√¥t you want her to stay alive for you? Wouldn‚Äö√Ñ√¥t her life be the center of the universe at that point? So just think about that.‚Äö√Ñ√π
Everything stopped for a moment. What could he mean by that, to stay alive for her‚Äö√Ñ¬∂ Maybe, maybe this was true. She would have tried to stop me from touching that space station, but instead, she sent me off with a hug and a kiss. Gods, this will lumber over my shoulders for a while, but I just need to take what Tholum said into consideration. How many light years has it taken for her message to reach me, and to still hold he smile in my damp glove? For love is love, and for the sake of my lily, I swear I will make this life of travel worth your love.
‚Äö√Ñ√∫Yeah. You know what Tholum, drinks are on me, Thank you.‚Äö√Ñ√π
I never thought my best friend would be a giant spider monster, but he made this shuttle more of a home than my own planet. Pvt Havel Smithman, signing out.

headline: Can Venezuela Be Saved?
commentone: I can absolutely accuse Chavez of making promises to the poor and then delivering to the rich. There are billions from Venezuela's massive oil revenues during the Chavez era that are simply missing. Billions of contracts were awarded to Chavez-connected businessmen who over-promised, under-delivered, and took their new-found wealth to Miami. Chavez stripped an entire professional class from the country's institutions and places of business and hand-delivered them to his band of wealthy socialist cronies. Now in 2018 they will bear the fruits of 20 years of crony socialism. It appears the author took the reported statistics (and the sources at of Chavez's popularity) at face value.
commenttwo:
Chavez arose on the backs of an ignorant populace. Like Spain during colonial times, successive leaders neglected the real education of the people. Thus they weren't able to detect deceit where it appeared clearly in Chavez, an ignorant demagogue with political savvy. This is still the case. Mouthing the word "socialism" does not mean you understand what it really means, but the illusions and hopes it creates are very enticing -- until the reality surges up and smacks you in the face. Venezuelans have not really known socialism, though many (the majority??) think they have.

The Venezuelan wars of independence from Spain led by Bolivar, Cristobal Mendoza, and many others, were not supported by "the people." Ordinary people in Venezuela preferred submission to the King than freedom and self-government. Only when the Revolution had triumphed did "the people" see the inevitable change and embraced it. And then they turned against their very liberators: Bolivar died penniless, nearly alone, reviled, and consumptive somewhere in Colombia.

Educated Venezuelans like L‚àö‚â•pez sit in jail, and Yale educated economist Henrique Salas R‚àö‚àÇmer, who lost the 1998 election to Chavez by a very small margin, sits exiled in the U. S. Unfortunately, enlightenment is a slow process. Until then, dethroning the dictatorship of Maduro forcefully may be the only path to an awakening. By the way, Maduro was a bus driver.

headline: Enlightened Sort
commentone: The top two-thirds flew (for a Saturday), filling in like a Tuesday or Wednesday; it felt surreal, actually.  But the bottom third fought me in typical Saturday fashion.   I didn't know SAYSAYSAY or that fact about ARISTOTLE.  And -- good lesson here -- I had SUITS and kept trying things to precede it, "work", "blue", "gray", etc.  That is, I kept viewing this business attire as being worn by a man.  Shame on me in this day and time!  When LAOTZU finally popped into my head, the southwest fell, and the final two letters of ITSAWRAP gave me ASAP and PARA and finally the puzzle fell. That tussle in the south gave this puzzle a lovely exclamation mark.
commenttwo:
I was disappointed that STEPPENWOLF didn't fit into 6D! Now I have their "Monster" as an earworm.

ARHAT filled in from the crosses; otherwise I'm not sure how long it would have taken me to remember it. This was one of those puzzles where I didn't have a whole lot on the first pass through the Acrosses, but the first pass through the Downs really filled in a lot.

I'm watching a lot of Weather Channel today. Hope everyone on the east coast, and especially in New England, stays safe and dry. I'm glad I don't live in Boston any more!

headline: Fights Worth Having
commentone:
‚Äö√Ñ√∫One side believes in the power of reason, the possibility of persuasion, and the values of the Enlightenment. It champions social solidarity for the sake of empowering the individual, rather than creating a society of conformists. It doesn‚Äö√Ñ√¥t see compromise as a dirty word. Its belief in the benefits of civility and diversity does not override its commitment to free speech and independent thought.

As for the other side, it thinks it knows what‚Äö√Ñ√¥s True. It considers compromise knavish. It views debate ‚Äö√Ñ√Æ beyond its own tightly set parameters ‚Äö√Ñ√Æ as either pointless or dangerous. And while it sees itself as the antithesis of Trumpism, it is, in its raging intolerance and smug self-satisfaction, Trumpism‚Äö√Ñ√¥s mirror image.‚Äö√Ñ√π

You see these as two competing narratives. I see them as the same narrative viewed from two different perspectives. The first represents liberal view of what should be. The latter represents the liberal view of what current conservative view is, and what liberal should not be. These two views are compatible and don‚Äö√Ñ√¥t represent a rift between liberal thinkers.

headline: God, Don’t Save the King
commentone:
I enjoy watching the BBC‚Äö√Ñ√¥s coverage of the Prime Minister‚Äö√Ñ√¥s Q and A sessions with Parliament. The PM is required to answer questions posed by both her party and opponents, and while some of the interplay is undoubtedly staged, a lot is impromptu and at times dramatic, confrontational and humorous.

I mention this because the PM and her interlocutors have to be literate, informed, and articulate. The government must defend its policies against withering criticism and demands for clarification of mistakes and poorly managed programs. Plus, there is booing, shouting and interruptions.

We should require our Presidents and their Cabinets to face the Congress in a similar interplay, say once a month and more during crises. Can anyone envision Trump or Pruitt or Mnuchin defending themselves in public?

Of course, this is a pipe dream. We give our elected officials a free pass from criticism and questioning. And it would require from Members of Congress a modicum of familiarity with serious policy issues, instead of the inane and empty posturing that is the rule and not the exception of their relationship with those who elected them.

headline: Goodbye, Pay-as-You-Wish
commentone:
There is a certain delight in visiting a cultural icon that a great city makes available freely to all.

That is part of what makes a city great.

On a practical level, the need to stop at a kiosk and pay an admission fee feels more like visiting a sports arena or county fair. If it isn‚Äö√Ñ√¥t necessary to limit the number of people flowing thru the museum, they would be wiser to promote passes purchased before arriving at the museum. Those would still have to be shown at the point of entry.

headline: Graduate
commentone:
When I first saw this image it reminded me of a discussion my class had. The graphs and binary code made me think that the article would have been about students prioritizing the STEM fields while the arts take a back seat. I interpreted that the grey background as another hint that students were coming out of college with knowledge in the STEM fields but were unable express themselves and were just blank.

After reading the article I learned that the picture represents something completely irrelevant to my first impression. The article instead takes an approach against learning assessments while being in favor of critical thinking. I feel like assessment can be used as a way to ensure the students learn these critical skills. At the end of the day most students are just looking to get good grades in classes. I feel this way about most of my classes, except physics. When I enter that class I genuinely feel like I am there to learn the content. Since tests are weighted for 60% of your grade you are required to learn the material or you will not succeed. In the current system there is flaws when it comes to assessments. David Eubanks said ‚Äö√Ñ√∫‚Äö√Ñ√∫I think assessment practices are ripe for re-examining,‚Äö√Ñ√π. I feel like this is the correct way to approach the issue, adjust the exams rather than get rid of them. These exams should test what the student should know going into the workforce and not go by some rubric created by people who don‚Äö√Ñ√¥t even work in that field.
commenttwo: In the photo I analyzed the pie chart and all the regions of the graphs. I feel that this picture is representing the fact how society and the working world has just become about test scores, grades and what college you graduated from. As if we are just results on a pie chart. When we apply for jobs we just become a score on a piece of paper. I feel that today‚Äö√Ñ√¥s job world has just become where you graduated from, what kind of degree do you have and so on. Job providers look at our credentials and compare us to others to. I think that their is more to a person than what is on a piece of paper. Not only should your qualifications be focused on but also the way you communicate with others your attitude etc. We should not be so focused on the college that this person graduated from, compared to this person. It may not have been an Ivy league school, but I‚Äö√Ñ√¥m sure they had just as good of an education. As the application process to applying to colleges grows ever more stressful and competitive we need to remind ourselves that the school of our dreams isn‚Äö√Ñ√¥t everything. It‚Äö√Ñ√¥s our work ethic.

headline: How Did Europe Freeze As North Pole Warmed Up?
commentone:
Ciao,
Report from Sant Elena, Venice...snow and ice now gone, sky still opaque white, no sun visible; fog, mist, vapor, or whatever it is, still envelopes all, like flying through a cloud in an airplane...and it is a bit warmer.
commenttwo: As the earth's atmosphere warms the differential between the colder polar regions and the warmer latitudes is weakened... unfortunately this differential is the engine that pumps the jet streams and ocean currents (think the Gulf stream for instance). This is why the colder polar air masses can stray north and the lower/warmer latitudes air masses are able to reach the poles. As the ocean currents weaken the inevitable warming of the ocean spells even more irreversible troubles. Pretty complicated I know.... sigh.... but hey, it's all about who is going to nuke who first, right?  Jeez.

headline: How Liberals Can Reclaim Nationalism
commentone: I've had this disturbing feeling in my liberal bones recently that because trump has refused to do anything about past,present and future meddling in our elections,the corrupt GOP and trump will "postpone"the mid terms for fear that they can't be legit.Just saying‚Äö√Ñ¬∂..
commenttwo:
My despondence over the current dire situation only increased upon reading your quotes from Obama. How far we have fallen, and how astonishingly fast.

Liberals, as you refer to those who think in a progressive manner, should redefine nationalism along the lines you describe - away from the exclusionary, divide-and-conquer approach being used to gain power around the world, to one of inclusion of all those who share a belief in fairness, respect for and support of science, true democracy, and a productive balance between growth and sustainability, both in economic and societal terms, and tolerance for and proper placement of religions in society. We have lost, with the cynical help of powerful forces, our sense of common interest and common purpose. Those who are disadvantaged in our society must be helped to recognize their common plight despite differences of race, religion, or cultural background. All who embrace long-standing values as expressed in our founding documents should and must somehow come together to defend those values against those who work tirelessly to destroy them. But we've traveled so far down the wrong road we will require brilliant and courageous leadership to help us once again see the light. Obama was one such leader, yet we failed miserably to live up to his high ideals. It may well, and likely will, require an existential threat to bring us together, one that we can only hope to survive.

headline: How the Left Wins the Culture War
commentone:
Really,
". . . make Donald Trump look like Adlai Stevenson"? And who would that be David? Relax, progressives are not the "other" end of some mythical political spectrum you have in your head. Progressives are pro-social, not anti-social. Progressives are not looking for someone to demonize and distract us, while they rob the bank. Progressives try to activate the best part of human nature, not the worst, an extraordinarily challenging task, given our evolutionary hard-wiring. Why are you so perplexed? Methinks your worldview, and your beliefs about human nature, are crumbling in the face of the instability of an emerging world that does not fit your "theory of world", and the surprising "who'd a thunk it", and varied, responses of individuals and communities of people who do not fit your view of human nature.
commenttwo: Why do I always regret the time I spent reading a Brooks column? Planned Parenthood, MoveOn, and women's March a "usual hyper-polarizing left-wing group?"  Oh please.  You've just polarized polarization.  Brooks is a fool and I will not waste another with him anymore.

headline: How the Tet Offensive Broke America
commentone: The youth culture that sprung up with the baby boomers and their new love of the Beatles, the Stones and psychedelic music along with M L King's pacifism and the civil rights mov't brought down the monolithic father knows best image propaganda that a communist take over in Vietnam would bring down the free world.  The domino theory and Munich like appeasement was used by politicians afraid of being seen as weak on communism.  The pointlessness of the war made such one time true believers like Daniel Ellsberg to leak the Pentagon Papers.  The Tet Offensive was perfect psychological warfare for the VC, especially with Westmoreland of the military industrial complex saying the US had won a huge victory.  Diem's assassination and dizzying corruption of South Vietnam's regime certainly didn't enhance the motivation of the American GI.  America's war was once again a rich man's war and a poor man's fight.  Life was good on US campuses with the counter culture for affluent college kids.   The war was a loser because it pushed all the wrong buttons.  Walter Cronkite's sympathetic influential voice to middle America pronounced this war made no sense.   Then there were the Nixon/Kissinger horrors.

headline: Is It Harder to Grow Up in the 21st Century Than It Was in the Past?
commentone: As a 15 year old I completely agree with the fact that it is harder growing up now than is was, say 50 years ago. David Brooks covered a lot of topics that worry me such as,"We‚Äö√Ñ√¥re the school shooting generation,‚Äö√Ñ√π one Harvard student told me. Another said: ‚Äö√Ñ√∫Wall Street tanked the country and no one got punished. The same with government.‚Äö√Ñ√π These are college students making these comments, they are realizing that the world is a mean corrupted place that their parents in a way have created. One thing I David Brooks failed to mention that I feel is an extreme problem is social media. Social media has brought many people to fame and ruined many more. You say one racist, antisemitic, or hateful comment on social media and you're done; bye scholarship, bye friends, bye social life. Growing up now has a lot more risk than it did in the past.
commenttwo:
I don‚Äö√Ñ√¥t think this is a question of which generation has it worse. Each generation has its own problems, its own struggles. We‚Äö√Ñ√¥re the ‚Äö√Ñ√∫school shooting generation‚Äö√Ñ√π, we‚Äö√Ñ√¥re the #MeToo movement, we‚Äö√Ñ√¥re Black Lives Matter. We join forces to fight for or against something through rallys and social media, but not in everyday life. This is where we become separated. That is the down fall of this generation. One student said, ‚Äö√Ñ√∫We‚Äö√Ñ√¥re more connected but we‚Äö√Ñ√¥re more apart,‚Äö√Ñ√π and this is so immensely true.

I believe the issue of the era is the people of this generation. This generation is fake. We have fake friends who say fake things about their fake opinions. It ends up hurting us. One day we will be ‚Äö√Ñ√∫spreading the word to end the word‚Äö√Ñ√π and the next using ‚Äö√Ñ√∫the word‚Äö√Ñ√π. We cancel ourselves out. We start many great movements and the reason they don‚Äö√Ñ√¥t go far is because we don‚Äö√Ñ√¥t let them. We either take things too far or not far enough.

One student said, ‚Äö√Ñ√∫You come to realize the U.S. is this incredibly imperfect place.‚Äö√Ñ√π Never in my life have I been told that the U.S. was perfect. Turn on the news and you find that out real quick. We are ‚Äö√Ñ√∫A Generation Emerging From the Wreckage‚Äö√Ñ√π which we made. If we would be nicer to one another, if we would report problems as we see them, and stop making fake threats so that the real ones are considered more seriously, we would be safer. We would have more of a voice. We would be the supports keeping the wall from crashing down.

headline: Is ‘Black Panther’ a ‘Defining Moment’ for the United States — and Particularly for Black America?
commentone: To say that a superhero movie is a defining moment in the history of an ethnic community is outrageous. While I may not be able to speak on behalf of black people, since I am white, I still find it silly that this is the standard required for a "civil rights breakthrough". On another note, I do not understand why we need a civil rights breakthrough if blacks are already held to the same legal standard as everyone else, and have the same rights as anyone else. While racism is still practiced by every group (whites aren't the only people who can be racist, and "reverse racism" is just racism) it has nothing to do with public policy, but rather the attitude of certain members of our populace. People should be more educated about the statements they make, and calling a superhero movie an example of a major civil rights breakthrough on the level of Martin Luther King Jr.'s movement or the election of Barack Obama is not an example of a well researched and intelligent statement.
commenttwo:
I went to see Black Panther opening night and was not disappointed. The theater I usually go to is never crowded opening night, no matter the movie. This time it was packed, which didn‚Äö√Ñ√¥t surprise me at all considering the hype this movie has had for so long. As I stated in the last Black Panther article, Marvel does it again and hits this one out of the park.

Although this movie will go down in history as an amazing marvel movie, I don‚Äö√Ñ√¥t think that this is a defining moment in U.S. history. There have been plenty of other black central movies and other black superheroes. Yes this is the first standalone black superhero movie I do not think that it will change the United States in ways people think. For example, Black Panther was created in 1966 by Stan Lee and Jack Kirby. This was a time of segregation and a lot of racism, and for two white comic book writers to go and create a black superhero in this time is very memorable so you would think that it was a big impact. But it wasn‚Äö√Ñ√¥t in the way they thought it would be, more black superheroes were created, that‚Äö√Ñ√¥s all. That‚Äö√Ñ√¥s the same for the Black Panther movie, although there is no segregation and not nearly as much racism going on now. I think that this will just encourage Marvel to create more black superhero standalone movies.

headline: It Was Only a Matter of Time: Here Comes an App for Fake Videos
commentone: Fantastic piece.  I am amazed and worried about what this technology can create and do.  In fact just this weekend I stumbled upon a snapchat feature similar to this that scared me.  The very final filter option currently scans your camera roll for faces of friends to merge/layer overtop of your own.  I don't recall giving snapchat the option to do cull and view my photos in that way and some of the layers or filters were really well done.  On par with the images of your Chris Pratt or Jimmy Kimmel fusions posted here.  This image technology is quietly being adopted and rolled out.
commenttwo:
We're entering a time where people will be required to trust more, just when trust seems to be the very thing that is eroding, and everyone's buying guns.

It is so odd. I buy the notion that religious belief is on its way out, but now that video is no longer incontrovertible evidence, the question about belief is more secular: Do you believe the good that you see or the evil?

Trusting is something you can actively do to make the world a better place. The lack of trust can nip good in the very bud. But how do we strike a balance between letting evil run roughshod and assuming the best from people first?

Although I've been away from my religious faith for a long time, I remember this, and I hope you can see the profundity of it: "Love beareth all things, believeth all things, hopeth all things, endureth all things." To embody that love is better than a gun, but you need faith for it, maybe not religious faith, but faith nonetheless.

headline: Make Better Movies Too
commentone:
As the sage, Gil Scott-Heron once wrote, ‚Äö√Ñ√∫The revolution will not be televised.‚Äö√Ñ√π Hoping that Tinseltown will save us is not enough. One season of fairer competition for Oscar honors does not redress a century of abuse and repression.

The election of Barack Obama did not solve our race problem in politics. It helped give us Donald Trump, who longs to bring back Jim Crow. While it plays out on TV and Twitter, the revolution will not be televised.

#MeToo hurts, but it is the pain of ripping off the bandaid because the wound is infected. Harvey is dethroned, but not gone. Injustice is the operating system layer. There is more pain to share. The revolution will not be televised.

Pain, oppression, and violence are built in. We have to change the underlying rules as well as those on the surface. The revolution will not be televised, or tweeted, or liked.

We have work to do. ‚Äö√Ñ√∫The revolution will be live"

headline: Nakesha’s Demons
commentone: In many cities, teams roam, visiting mentally ill people who refuse life in shelters. We can't force people to take medicine, but we can make their chosen life on the streets better, and we absolutely can make shelters a more attractive alternative. All my adult life I have known people who needed sheltering who refused shelters: Many are unsafe, and theft is rampant. A bed and blanket--the least we can do--and we pat ourselves on the back and consider the problem fixed. Most people living on the street are mentally ill, but they aren't stupid. I am happy for Nakesha and those who knew her that this beautiful and sad portrait of her showed her talent, intellect, and curiosity.
commenttwo: People may be incapacipated by mental illness regardless of age.  How many years do you leave someone homeless?  How many years do you leave someone unable to help themselves?  We rescue animals on the street.  This is not how human beings are meant to be left without intervention to eventually suffer and die.  When a person can no longer judge their own best interests health care professionals and the law must protect their best interests whether an infant or adult.

headline: Not the Higher Prices, It’s What Might Happen Next

commenttwo: Dumping of steel has been a rallying cry of protectionists for years.  Trump, with his usual unthoughtful look before he leaps approach, has thrown international trade into a furor. headline: Oil Was Central in Decision to Shrink Protected Utah Site, Emails Show
commentone:
Mr. Hatch - what lesson are you trying to teach Utah's kids by turning America the Beautiful's public lands into super-fund site monuments so when they grow up, they will never enjoy them as they are now - all on behalf of oil-coal company profits?

"And over there, children, where the mound of toxic, contaminated and radioactive debris and polluted effluent runs, there used to be the Grand Staircase-Escalante. An entire step in that Grand Staircase has been removed and flattened - as they did in West Virginia flattening mountain tops - to remove coal that has blackened the sky and given all of you breathing problems. Come along, kids. There are many more super-fund sites to see."

It seems like trump, Hatch, Zinke, Pruitt et al want to drill baby drill and create super-fund sites in the most beautiful and treasured areas of our nation FIRST. Why aren't these locations available as a last resort when all other wells are used up? Do we really need more drilling EVERYWHERE? By the time these magnificent places would be up for destruction, hopefully we will have moved on to saner energy production that is clean, renewable and non-destructive.

The mental flatulence of these warmongers against the environment - we all need to survive - want to implement the trifecta of global warming pollution - fossil fuel extraction and burning, deforestation, and methane gas production from grazing cattle.

They want to kill our planet NOW making the entire globe a giga-super-fund site.

headline: Plan for Tariffs Creates Divide In Trump Base
commentone:
When you raise prices on such a vital product as steel and aluminum as seems likely with both steel produced here and abroad, the ripples spread out everywhere. As some here have said interest rates and commodity prices rise everywhere. This includes everything the government buys such as military goods and the price of infrastructure repair. The cost of financing our debt will also rise. So who will pay this extra cost? taxpayers of course and those dependent on government services who will see those services evaporate. Unexpected consequences will appear everywhere including on those getting a temporary wind fall.

If you want to change how we do business with those who seem to be dumping cheap products into our economy, we must look carefully at the things they buy from us and negotiate the balance of trade. A tariff is a very heavy handed tool to use indiscriminately and in the hands of a fool like our president it can be devastating.
commenttwo: Consumers have benefitted greatly from cheap foreign goods.  Walmart became a juggernaut with Chinese made products.  Trade protection has been muted by companies that do major sales overseas like Boeing.  Steel is essential to many expensive finished products and for ubiquitous cheap items such as cans.  Steel is a commodity that is taken deadly seriously and many of the USs trading partners will not sit idly by while the US raises tariffs.  Free trade was great for the British empire and for the US after WW2 but now the US is no longer the producer that it was.  Predatory trade practices by China and S Korea have helped domestic sales in the US.  China has taken a preeminent position in trade in the great off shoring debacle in the late 80s. What once was seen as a way for capital to win over labor now is an issue that Trump wants to revisit with tariffs.  Now Trump has tried, with marginal success, to tap into a sea of discontent and xenophobia for the loss of US jobs that probably won't return.  Especially with the technological revolution that has taken place by industrial producers.  Consumers will see rising prices which free traders call a tax imposed because of tariffs.

headline: Poland and Israel in Tense Talks Over Holocaust Law
commentone:

I also had a Jewish neighbor, who as a teenage girl was caught with 2 other girls and put in front of a firing squad. The officer in charge sent the troops for a smoke and told the girls that he had daughters their age. He let the girls flee.
Life and truth are not simple.

headline: Roger Bannister, First Athlete to Break the 4-Minute Mile, Is Dead at 88
commentone: I was 14 when Bannister ran his sub 4 minute miles. What I remember most was a moment when I saw a televised version of one (likely the one in Vancouver with Landry) in a Hackensack, NJ, TV store. The strange thing that stuck in my mind was a sports commentator on the TV criticizing Bannister for his post run collapse into the arms of waiting supporters. He said that by running to the point of collapse he was giving a poor example to youth. His silly comment regustered with me the dumbest comment about a sports event I had heard in my young life. Now at 78, my ears have yet to hear a more foolish comment. Bannister was a great competitor.

headline: Romance, Rough Sex or Rape?
commentone:
Women buy and read Bodice Ripper books in droves Frank. They also bought and flocked to "50 Shades". Better talk to them about if it's hot or not to get consent or if it's the rough stuff they really want deep down. The signals and mores and 'signals' fall on them too (which you don't mention).
They seem to not be a able to make up their minds at deep down the base of it all.
And for those that say "fantasies are fantasies" I say "No they ain't. they're what you're really thinking."
commenttwo:
I believe movies can have a big impact on how young people learn what is "normal" and desirable in relations between a man and a woman. I know from discussions wth several of my friends that a lot of women of my generation bought into the idea that if you were the right kind of woman a man would change for you. The movie "Pillowtalk" was all about that concept. Rock Hudson, a terrible womanizer, is "domesticated" when he meets the right woman, played by Doris Day. By the end of the movie he is shown all in a twitter over the birth of their child. That was a very dangerous message which implicitly challenged us to be good enough women to tame a playboy and implicitly put the blame on us he continued in his bad boy ways. (I wonder if Melania ever watched "Pillow Talk"........)
The other destructive message I clearly remember is that it is normal for men to have cold feet about marriage so if it feels like your fianc‚àö¬© to is pulling back, don't worry. All guys are like that and things will be OK.
These kinds of messages can have a big impact on what young people think is acceptable behavior. Sure, they may not have that effect on older people but by then it is often too late for to avoid acting on those misleading messages. The truth is that if you want a serious relationship stay away from a guy who is a player and if your fianc‚àö¬© is getting cold feet take it seriously. Very seriously. That may not make for great movies but it is good advice.

Rather in my mind God is a creative, loving and divine force whose strength lies within us and is available to us at any time - whether we are in need of comfort or experiencing great joy that we are grateful for.

headline: Taxpayers, You’ve Been Scammed
commentone: It's OK with me to pay higher taxes, and I don't mind drinking dirtier water and breathing more polluted air. Those are small prices to pay for making America great again.
commenttwo:
The tax cut benefits the wealthy and corporations. So what? ¬¨‚Ä†What's it costing me?

Well let's see.

To put so much of the total tax cut into the hands of the wealthiest and corporations Republicans reduced your share. Your tax cut is roughly half what it could have been if the tax cut had been spread fairly among all taxpayers.

It gets worse. Inflation follows tax cuts like these. Expect rising prices - like an additional sales tax on everything you buy.

It gets worse. Tax cuts mean cuts to federal dollars to cities and counties. ¬¨‚Ä†Local property taxes will rise. ¬¨‚Ä†Rents increase as landlords face higher property taxes.

It gets worse. The Republicans also tinkered with the Affordable Care Act Expect your premiums to rise.

It gets worse. Cuts for corporations are permanent so long-term government spending must be reduced. Republicans specifically mention Social Security and Medicare. Expect to see higher co-pays, reduced benefits, and higher Medicare premiums and payroll taxes.

It gets worse. Republicans built your tax cut in the front end. ¬¨‚Ä†Enjoy it now. After a couple of years they're taking it all back and then some.

commenttwo:
The key is the disillusionment of Trump supporters, especially over the one achievement - tax cuts.
The tax cut benefits the wealthy and corporations. So what? ¬¨‚Ä†What's it costing me? I'm getting my share!

Well let's see.

To put so much of the total tax cut into the hands of the wealthiest and corporations Republicans reduced your share. Your tax cut is roughly half what it could have been if the tax cut had been spread fairly among all taxpayers.

It gets worse. Inflation follows tax cuts like these. Expect rising prices - like an additional sales tax on everything you buy.

It gets worse. Tax cuts mean cuts to federal dollars to cities and counties. ¬¨‚Ä†Local property taxes will rise. ¬¨‚Ä†Rents increase as landlords face higher property taxes. Expect similar increase in state sales taxes. Fed share of your state budget likely exceeds 25%.

Corporate tax cuts are going to shareholders and top executives: Workers‚Äö√Ñ√¥ bonuses and salaries $1, ¬¨‚Ä†$30 for stock buybacks, handing money to company owners and CEOs and not invested in plants and equipment, the was supposed to benefit you and general prosperity.

Republicans hopes for your Prosperity depend upon things happening that have never happened before under conditions like today's: trickle down, robust economy at the tail end of a bull market, the Fed,¬¨‚Ä†keeping inflation rigorously under control which it is not even proposing to do, government bringing in higher real ‚Äö√Ñ√∫revenues‚Äö√Ñ√π after a tax cut without real productivity incentives.

headline: What Motivates Voters More Than Loyalty? Loathing
commentone:
This hyper-partisan schism may have had its roots in the 2000 Presidential election decided by the Supreme Court. But it has been exacerbated twenty times over by the Trump regime's actions and, without any doubt, the demagogic, witless, corrupt, sneering, divisive occupant of the White House.

The best way to describe negative partisanship is that it represents an assault on the senses. When a man who fondles women, stiffs contractors, gets a mulligan from "Christian" pastors for adultery, and is blatantly corrupt is President of the United States, many Americans understandably become anxious, confused, and feel that their nation has been cast adrift. Many can no longer reliably trust what our government is doing, what we read on the Internet, and who are friends actually are.

One final point: Edsall's column emphasizes that Democrats are just as angry and distrustful of Republicans as Republicans are of Democrats. I get that, but it is the Republicans who hold the reins of power currently, from which most of the current political stench is rising.
commenttwo: This appears to be a part of the obsession of the press to be "balanced." But this analysis ignores the role of the well funded Right to demonize Clinton that has been decades in the making. There is no Democrat party counterpart to balance the whipped up hatred of Hillary that is still ongoing. However, revulsion of Trump needed no left wing conspiracy or dark money funding to emerge after he announced his run. This was a spontaneous reaction to a grotesque, ignorant, and laughably unqualified carnival barker. So, stop insulting us with this moral equivalence nonsense. There's a difference between manufactured rage and authentic disgust.
