headline: What to Expect (And Not) at the Oscars
commentone: I rarely see a great movie anymore. Of the nominees, I have seen Get Out, Three Billboards, The Shape of Water, and Dunkirk. I disliked Dunkirk so much, I had to force myself to see it through to the end. Get Out was quite entertaining, but not Best Picture material. Three Billboards had its moments, but was disappointing. As for The Shape of Water, I felt it did not compare with Pan's Labyrinth and I even enjoyed Crimson Peak more. As for last year, I could not even watch the entire trailer for LaLa Land and was thrilled that Moonlight won. I have never watched the Oscars, have no intention of ever doing so, and am thoroughly sick of actors, many of whom are not even high school graduates, pushing their socio-political agendas. After subscribing to Netflix and Amazon Prime video, I have a better idea of how many truly awful pictures are made each year, either from poor judgment or for a tax write-off. The public has made it clear they prefer low-brow entertainment like the Fast and Furious franchise. Perhaps the Oscars are outmoded and should go the way of Miss America as phenomena that no one really cares about anymore.

headline: When Elder Abuse Is Self-Inflicted
commentone: The older adults in general, sigh. They are so difficult. I should know, I am one. In retirement I am left to live out my days with them after spending all my adult life and childhood with kids. I think most are depressed, essentially lacking in joy and want to make others as unhappy as they are. Honestly, getting older people to have fun is like pushing a car with it's brakes on. In my experience, they just cannot let go that they don't know it all, are not all that, and might should compromise and get along. Bombastic blow hards, they drink to self-medicate their way out of sour moods and to sedate the knowledge that they are just plain old sour pusses. A vicious circle; sour mood, alcohol, sour mood. Repeat.  When confronted with their bad behavior, and it is bad to be a wet blanket on someone else's day, they think a simple apology is acceptable. Nope. Old people! Work on your social skills. Self-edit what comes out of your mouth. Think anything you want but for goodness sake, give the rest of us a break from your bad moods. Put on a smile when you put on your make-up or shave and face the world bravely with joy. What have you got to lose? Everything.
commenttwo:
So why is there so much disconnection and isolation even in wealthy urban communities with all those fancy independent living, tax credit and "affordable senior housing"? The latter aren't so affordable and 5% of them that do have borderline social activity that would actually engage most people-eg friendly conversation in a main lobby area with organized variety of activities, conversational venues, transport avl, are the most costly and have waiting lists sometimes so long that they are closed. These maybe 860-1300 a month so may not be even viable for the less wealthy. And these are the best option for those without the big bucks to go into those communities that really truely have plenty of social venue-these avg around nearly 4k a month.

We can improve the social efficiency cost/benefit ratio though considerably. Places should be Psychologically social venue conducive. For example when there is a lobby area that connect to conversation starter areas that is the pass through to the apartments, this is far better than some separate community area. Conversation starters would be book/video borrow spot, make cup of tea/coffee -take a biscuit spot, latest newspaper and magazine area, pool table, screen with programs typically of interest turn on with viewing area, calendar, suggestion bulletin area, small fitness area, outdoor garden waiting for transport /bird feeding, maybe tiny planting/growing area, chicken caring area, fence dog play area, gift shop --

headline: Xi’s Power Grab in China Rattles Europe and Its Hope for an Ally in the Trump Era
commentone:
China is communist, and will remain one for sometime. Several decades ago, both China and the former USSR, were much occupied exporting their communist ideology to many parts of the world. Often, creating chaos and unrest.
Today, it is interesting to see where both China and the former Soviet Union are. They both remain Communist. Their presence on the world stage, come in a different form, and not much has changed as far as their ambitions are concerned.
China's pride arises from the country's vast land mass and the huge human population (two of the three factors of production, the third being capital). This is what has helped China to gradually identify itself as a world production center. An opportunity which the US and the West extended to China. While still remaining Communist, China has embraced capitalist economics, helping the country to amass much wealth. China is using its soft power diplomacy to go around investing in infrastructure and other projects around the world. That is a strategy they believe could help them make inroads to establish influence. The developments in the South China Sea is of concern. China's heavy investments in the country's military adds to questions as to what the country is up to?
Ideally, China should be seen acting as a partner with other world powers. However, in this short period, one does not see that, and it is unclear what their real motive is? Was it too soon, or was it an unplanned rush to allow China into the world community?

headline: Your Kid’s Phone Is Not Like a Cigarette
commentone:
The biggest problem is parents who constantly look at their smartphones while their children run around like lunatics in doctor's offices and supermarkets. Parents never knowing what children are up to on the playground because they have their heads bent down against their phone screens.
Kids asking what mommy is looking at and can I see?
Parents are the examples of addiction for their small children and then on top of that, as children grow older they refuse to regulate how and where their older children use smartphones.
Culture is learned and many parents are doing a terrible job of it.

Older drivers, however, reduce their accident rate sooner than teens - meaning they drive better sooner with less experience.  I am in favor of graduated licenses and also letting children drive a lot when they get their permits and their licenses.  Experience behind the wheel is what reduces accidents not necessarily age.

Kids can join the military at 18 but can‚Äö√Ñ√¥t get a legal drink until 21. But our states are all too willing to punish kids who commit crimes to life on registries or in maximum security prisons. Our way of looking at and dealing with minors makes no sense. If they‚Äö√Ñ√¥re kids for one purpose, they should be kids for all. No, 16 year olds should not have the right to vote. They also should not go to prison or be allowed to marry or raise children without oversight or suffer lifelong consequences for what they do as minors.  Eighteen should be the age of legality for everything.

headline: Nakesha’s Demons

I stopped and talked to her everyday I saw her and gave her a pb+j sandwich, an apple, water and some cookies. She was immensely appreciative but spurned all offers of help.  I often wonder what happened to her and think what a waste of life.

headline: Saying a Prayer I Don’t Believe In
commentone: I think the prayer is really a of submission to the superior knowledge and power of God.  Especially at a time of loss, we are likely to become mad at the inevitability of death or disability.  The prayer asks us to accept that things like death are a necessary part of the creation process that also brings us all the good things in life.  God set in motion a process of creation that includes both rules (e.g. the laws of physics) and randomness (the particles of the universe bump into each other in random ways).  The rules allow the physical world to exist, the randomness allows for the evolution of the universe towards the remarkable diversity and beauty that the universe contains.  We cannot have the beauty without "collisions" that also cause change (including death).  Many prayers ask us to submit to the inherent tension between the wonder of life and the changes in ourselves and other creatures that lead us to death.  When we can praise God at a time of loss or impending loss, we are bringing ourselves to an acceptance of that inherent conflict and opening ourselves to be able to have joy in the wonderful things in life.  At times of stress, I say the Christian prayer to myself: "Praise God from whom all blessings flow; praise God all creatures here below..."  To me, it helps free me from stress and sorrow by praising the God who provides life's blessings.

Reading this column about the fate of Jeff Sessions and other appointees of Donald Trump, it is difficult to keep one‚Äö√Ñ√¥s mind on the cautionary tale by Gail Collins about corruption, nepotism and the demands of a narcissistic boss.

There is a tendency to wonder if Donald Trump knows what ‚Äö√Ñ√≤sycophancy‚Äö√Ñ√¥ means and then to dwell on the astronomical odds against his being able to spell the word.

We recall the elated Attorney General sitting in a row of other cabinet members at the State of the Union address, turning to look at them to see if they enjoyed the Trump applause lines as much as he did.

It is hard to imagine that this naughty little elf may stand between Donald Trump and a presidential impeachment.

Websites overflow with how we fail: we are not the richest in per capita income; we don't live the longest; our live birth rate is extremely disappointing; our public high school students are not the smartest; our health care system is not the most inclusive; we are not the most civil... Yet we are still the leader of the free world because as Mr. Wegin implies, who else is willing or has the money to do the actual work of leadership?  If only we, ourselves, had a leader.

The executive branch of the federal government will continue swirl around in this maelstrom of disruption because the chief executive is totally bereft of the values and skills to lead.

headline: How Liberals Can Reclaim Nationalism

We grow stronger as a nation by welcoming and encouraging others to join us and live in this way.  Of course our history has shown us falling well short of our professed ideals, as we are a work in progress; but this basic truth of honoring, above all else, what it means to be human, is a liberal value that American ideals stands for.

headline: In West Virginia, the Politicians Fail, and the Teachers Rise
commentone: The twenty-first century will be won by economies supported by the best, smartest, most flexible, most dynamic work force. There is no way the global labor market can be successfully divided down into competing individuals because individuals inevitably are competing within a huge number of factors that are not generally socialized. To individually prepare in the labor market she must begin at age one day. With the accumulation of advantages not socialized, we create differentiation that gets attributed to so many of the wrong reasons‚Äö√Ñ√Ærace and ethnicity, for example. But further, we fail to measure, or even recognize the individual talent and energy lost to disadvantage. When the educational system just produces variance, even employers and their investors have no way than to recognize the successful business activity that could have been produced, had greater effort gone into work force development. Free mandatory public education was one of the best advantages in producing the American exceptionalism into the twentieth century. Education is a cultural and social resource with the greatest leverage toward economic productivity. It is a national social good. We must never forget. We should  be flocking to West Virginia to support our kids who need as much as we can give.

headline: Is It Harder to Grow Up in the 21st Century Than It Was in the Past?
commentone: Mr. Brooks' understanding of our generation does, sadly, ring true to me. Reason being, as stated by other students, "We're the school shooting generation," and "The utopia of our parents is the dystopia of our age." Now, I have my faith placed in the smaller institutions such as the Dreamers. I do hope for a brighter future, however, I feel as though it may have slipped further out of our reach than in past times. We have to deal with multiple school shootings and an uptake in suicides, as well as depression and anxiety. Schools have gotten harder than they were back then. I feel like growing up in the past might have been as hard as it is today. It may seem like it was harder, with your parents and grandparents telling stories about Howard it was for them, but you don't have everyone's opinion. I have talked to my parents and siblings frequently about their childhood. They believe now it is harder to grow up today than it was back then. I believe the reason being that we may not have to worry more about kidnappings, however we do have to worry about school shootings, rape, suicide and what you can do to prevent it. It is harder to deal with, especially since it could happen at any given point in time.
commenttwo:
I feel like it is hard to grow up in both time periods. In the past they didn't really have a lot of technology so they don't know as much as we do. For us today it is so much faster to know what is going on for example, we can just look at our phones in the morning and see what happened the night before in the past they couldn't do that cause they didn't have the right technology. Its also hard for both because we both have/had problems with violence. We have fights all the time because kids our age thing its cool and a way to get back at someone and in the past it was kinda like that too but in the past there was violence with/between countries.
My mom says the same thing, there is a lot more violence now then there was before and the technology has changed dramatically. When I ask her about how things were in the past she says the same thing every time, "Your generation is so much more advanced. You guys are going to do great things but at the same time it could also be bad. You guys have to watch the way to treat one another and how you guys work together. My generation was hard, I don't want you growing up like me."

headline: It Was Only a Matter of Time: Here Comes an App for Fake Videos

The idea of educating the American public to become more discriminating is a pipe dream of a few surviving Enlightenment innocents.  The solution is admittedly radical:  a comprehensive effort to flood the Internet with fake video.  In a year that might teach skepticism.  Excess and disgust as an emetic for the poison.
commenttwo: Orwell could write a great dystopia based on this technology. Soon all digital records will be suspect, all digital memories will be infinitely malleable. Hold on tight to your paper, folks.

headline: Late-Career Change: Play It Safe, or Ride It Out?
commentone: The "golden handcuffs" is a major consideration, as is being in your mid 50s and trying a change. I retired as a state worker and have a meager pension (it cut my earnings in half), so my full time job is tightening the belt while my husband still works. Always working at least 40 hours a week since I was 18 I'm burnt out but look to see what sort of work there is available, but there is none for a woman my age and with health problems. The poster may be miserable, but unless they're in an industry that is easy to get hired, I'd stay put.

headline: Learning to drive at 62
commenttwo: Roger:  As they say "timing is everything" and this column is perfect for giving all of us who are nearly exhausted with this administration that if we did not have a chance to read some lighter fare we would all likely go berserk and head for the nearest bridge not to drive over but to leap from.  If the majority in this country do not soon get a long reprieve from the everyday onslaught on the conscience and values that really hold this country together we might as well fold up our tents, and streets to drive on, because no one will give a tinkers dam about anything in this country anymore.

headline: Letting  Teenagers  Live
commentone: Your important article will unfortunately be ignored. It is part of a subject far too big for most to wrap their head around. it is about how we organize the society and what we truly value. I grew up in an inner city. ( We did not have "drive") We used public transit or walked everywhere. There were no guns present. I do not know a single kid who died, other than a natural cause, among my high school of nearly 3000. There were no "devices" other than the transistor radio and the portable turntable ( record player.) I know people are thinking how archaic it all sounds. But, maybe we should think just a little harder about how we have come to this place. That way, people will pay the appropriate attention to the last few sentences of your essay. You have distilled it all down for us.
commenttwo: Teaching high school for 30 years and I live a mile from one of the largest university campuses in the world. Texting, texting, texting. While driving, walking, eating, listening to music on headphones, at red lights, at green lights, bicycling, in theaters, at in church, and always always always, in class. But it is the first one that has me so concerned and most relevant to this piece. We put the devices in their hands, and they combine young developing brains with that prime attention-grabber and then give them keys to vehicles. No surprise what the result is.

commentone: Of course, if Judge Curiel later rules against a case concerning the White House, he'll go right back to being a "Mexican", aka a "bad hombre".  Political correctness, right wing division, has its own strict parameters.
commenttwo:
About the presidency, my comment is designed largely for those in the U.S. born between 1920 and 1938 or said another way, those in their 80's and 90's We lived through the depression of the 30's, World War II, the Korean War, The Boomers and flower children, the Vietnam War, Watergate, 9/11 and the second gulf war. Can you ever recall any President in your lifetime who denigrated previous presidents more than the present one has? Can you reconcile the many lies, egotistical tweets, his ill advised appointments to many posts in his administration (the number of firings and resignations over the past few months tells a story) that we have not seen before ? Have you ever seen this much nepotism and conflicts of interest before? Obsessed with loyalty he himself is disloyal to his own appointments. Do you think he has hostility towards Blacks, Mexicans and Muslims?
He calls a meeting of congressional people to talk about gun control but excluded the Democratic Senator from the state, which of course is strange. But here is the kicker: At those meetings when others are talking the president sits with arms folded across his chest. Psychologists translated years ago that it means one is not paying attention to what others have to say. He had a similar gathering on immigration, making a lot of noise, and arms folded, nothing came of it.
Can you ever recall a president since 1932 who has done more damage to the office than all others combined - and in just 13 months?

headline: Mr. Trump’s Destructive Trade War
commentone:

The people I work with also are always trying hard, and giving their best. The students too, most of them try very hard, partly because of the environment we set as a school but also because they also want to give their best.

And then we have our President. A child, an ignorant, inflamed, deluded egomaniac. Surrounds himself with people who depend on his patronage, nepotism, and whim.

It is very hard to take hard effort seriously when our country at the highest level is clearly not. Republicans? Hello? Are you listening? Do you care? Do you think life is a big game or TV show?

A buffoon is leading us. Please stop this.

They've got that now and, like most addicts, they're not going to want to give it up easily.

headline: Nakesha’s Demons
commentone: This piece is a prime example of the outstanding talent at The NY Times.   I have a few uncles who also suffered from mental illness starting in their 20's.  Fortunately, neither suffered any extended homelessness and I had little appreciation for the daily challenges of the mentally ill who end up homeless.  I will look at the homeless men and women I see with a new set of eyes, wondering about their story.  They had been invisible to me and many others-- that may be the biggest tragedy.  Thanks to this moving story, I hope to get out of my comfort zone and engage someone if only to ask them how they are doing.
commenttwo: This tragic story is the end product of many forces. Two of them are  the closing of mental hospitals and  impediments to involuntary hospitalizations; the latter was justified by invoking the so-called ‚Äö√Ñ√∫rights‚Äö√Ñ√π of the mentally ill. The actual result is that vulnerable people like Nakesha are left without the protection that a civilized humane society should provide. The help that these generous caring people worked hard to give her were not enough without the state‚Äö√Ñ√¥s power to hospitalize her against her will so that she could be treated while being kept safe.

headline: Power to the Parents
commentone: How about just dealing with the electoral college system? A relic and travesty of the cruel and demeaning "3/5ths decision."Actually both ideas have little chance of ever happening prior to the next civil war/revolution. We have learned very little in 240 years.
commenttwo:
No. No, no, no, no, no! Those of us who have chosen to remain childfree are already seen as having no value in our society. Douthat, given his predilections, probably thinks our votes should be counted as if they came from 3/5 of a person.

And in Demeny voting, what recourse is available for the child if the child, the "domestic dissident," knows that the parent will not vote in accordance with his or her wishes? I can guarantee that my father -- a rabid racist and supporter of George Wallace -- would never have voted as I would have.

What's next on your wish list Mr. Douthat? Corporations being given proxy votes for their employees, who will also seen as 3/5 of a person?

Here are a few better ideas: leave the voting age as is and make voting mandatory. Automatic registration the moment a person turns 18. Election Day (at least every two years) should be a national holiday. At the very least we should be able to vote by mail, over a period of at least a week.

Putin and Trump are terrible bluffers.

commentone:
When I was growing up there seemed to be no end to movies or TV shows where women were grabbed. Not just for sex or kissing, but simply grabbed to get their attention or prevent them from doing something. I always winced as I would be furious at someone who laid hands on me like that.

Somehow (male) directors saw this as acceptable dramatic behavior. Did boys see this and grow up to think that girls and women can be touched and grabbed at will?
commenttwo: We can talk for ages about how movies portray sexual relationships between men and women, but we have to acknowledge that a lot of women clearly have fantasies about sexually aggressive men. 50 Shades of Grey sold over 5 million copies, almost all of which were purchased by women. Does that mean that women actually want to be in that kind of relationship? Absolutely not. But clearly there is something in that plotline that many women find compelling.

headline: Saying a Prayer I Don’t Believe In
commentone: A lovely article, and it honors your father. For one who believes in God, the answer to unimaginable horror is always, "God thinks free will is worth it." Doesn't matter whether it's an earthquake or the Holocaust. Free will--independent, thinking beings, who can make choices--is dependent on a reliable universe, in which the laws of physics work. And that means nightmarish awfulness, but also transcendent joy.
commenttwo:
I would suspect that the vast majority of comments would be from Jewish people. Growing up Catholic and not being Jewish I found your article superbly informative, certainly fascinating and one that if read by many non-Jewish people would help greatly, leading to better understanding among those whose beliefs are rooted in other religions - Catholic, Protestant, Buddhism, Muslim etc.
I have a very dear friend who converted to Judaism and will send it to her even though she may get the Times, I wouldn't want her to miss this article.
Growing up Catholic in the 30's and 40's I said enough prayers to last a life time and once estimated I had 4 billion years of indulgences stashed away, but as an old person I wonder about God's will. I wonder if because the earth
is a small planet among not one but many universes, whether or not God might have made the earth as a "test market" to determine whether us humans of many varieties, cultures and beliefs can get along with each other. God must be pretty dissatisfied with the results so far.

headline: The Challenge of Doctor-Patient Relations in the Internet Age
commentone:

"Published randomised controlled trials (RCTs) have shown some evidence of efficacy. However, no systematic study on all antidepressants in GADs has been conducted recently."
http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/14651858.CD012942/full

It seems everyone, practitioners and patients, are relegated to outdated data.
During the time since the last major study, GSK was fined 3 billion dollars by the FDA for withholding data related to paroxetine (Paxil).
commenttwo:
Asclepion (Asklepieion) of Pergamum was the world's most famous ancient medical center. The physician Galen was from there.

That medical center had a large library and produced many new medical texts.

Part of the cure for patients was to listen to physicians read aloud from medical books each day.

headline: The Escalation of Love
commentone: I am glad that you are experiencing positive closure with your mother. Sadly, I did not with my mother.  Her dementia merely exacerbated what had always been a depressed, narcissistic and negative personality. I did the right thing by her in her care, was there every step of the way, and made sure she felt loved when she died, but I still feel the lifetime of hurt she inflicted.
commenttwo: Sometimes a thought occurred to me as I cared for my mother during her last years - maybe Alzheimers is not all about the patient but instead is meant as an opportunity for the caregiver?  Solod's article resonated on several levels, not the least of which was that caregiving was an opportunity to finally forgive and express love, unconditionally, to someone who had hurt us deeply, was less than perfect, but was nevertheless an extricable part of us.  To bring things full circle.  I had another similar experience to Solod.  After not being able to talk for a couple of years, my mother was in her final decline and developed yet another aspiration pneumonia.  As the nurse cleared her airway I said "Whew, I'll bet that feels better."  She looked at me and sighed in return, "Yes, it does" she replied clearly.  I stood amazed and shocked.  It meant that I had been wrong for years when I assumed she was mentally "asleep."  If I had it to do over again I would have read to her - Dickens and poetry probably, her favorites.

headline: The Trump-Russia Story Gets Even Weirder
commentone:

This just broke on The Guardian:
"Ex-Trump adviser sold $31m in shares days before president announced steel tariffs:Carl Icahn sold $31.3m of shares in a company dependent on steel imports days before the commerce department mooted stiff tariffs on imports"

Wouldn't it be nice to be one of this man's pals? Icahn's haul, in a single day, is $31,000,000 And Sam Walton just confessed that his tax return thanks to this wonderful new "tax" bill is $29,000,000,000. Yes. Billion with a "B." Most of us would be in prison for the scams and stunts our 1% play.

Every trail leads back to either dirty money dealing or Russia or both for a reason. This inept, criminal fool thought he'd take this country for a ride and make a fast buck. He did. It will be to our lasting shame --and this one is going down in the history books in bold print--that we ever allowed anyone so patently and grotesquely unfit for the office anywhere near it.

Anastasia Vashukevich may or may not have anything to do with it, but everything is on the table when the country's on the floor. The loonier it sounds the more apt it is to be true of this White House.

headline: Big Banks May Weaken Dodd-Frank Oversight
commentone: Although apparently forgotten, CITIGROUP, which is leading this lobbying effort, has been rescued from insolvency at least 3 times since the 1970s: 1st, after the Latin America Debt crisis in the late 70s and early 80s, again after the junk bond collapse and the recession of 1990-91; and of course famously, when it "danced until the music stopped" in 2007-09. So they now want to start the music again, expecting that the tax payers and social security and Medicare recipients will pay any bills that the party creates.  Write your congressperson people.

headline: Can There Be Good Porn?
commentone:
The word "porn" -- or "pornography" covers so very much more than a single, simple term can possibly describe. The same with the terms "heterosexuality" or "homosexuality" - or any other kind of sexuality, for that matter.
By lumping all together in a small pile, with one rather descriptive title, distortion is made to each of the myriad of forms. Depending upon one's upbringing, religious ideas, sexual orientation, or whatever, some of it may be considered just fine, while other types of it be viewed with a definite "ewe".
My personal idea of what makes either ideal, or useful, or interesting, or satisfying porn would be a far cry from my next door neighbor -- or on down the street. Yes, I enjoy a certain type of porn -- a type which, to me, is harmless, but stimulating and enjoyable. After all, I am a man of considerable years, and personal relationships have, long ago, vanished due to my age. I'm sure it would not appeal to others -- however, it is harmless to me, and certainly to anyone else, as I do not share it.
For anyone to suggest that this might be taken away from me because it may offend another, is not only leading to an unnecessary prohibition, but a disservice to me. The same if I would deny anyone else their own type of porn, or means of sexual satisfaction, if that were it.
The conversation, as laid out here, is interesting, and one which we all should be able to have, as it affects in one way or another, each and every one of us.

This is not about purging people from a big tent but it is about respect for the Progressive and Liberal wings of the Tent that commonly get ignored, taken for granted and left out in the cold- both within Party leadership and our national Media.

The term "Kick the Hippie" is what so-called "centrist" Democrats (read Republican Lites like Hillary & Bill Clinton) do once in office. Mr Obama did as well- he outright lied to voters at a meeting held at Soldier Field in Chicago about some things- and toyed with the Grand Betrayal (Grand Bargain) where Third Way and DLC types wanted the US to renege on Social Security, Medicare and other paid benefits. You can easily mark one when they refer to Social Security as an entitlement- it is an earned benefit paid for with a lifetime of premiums in the forms of a special payroll tax. Going to a public school is an entitlement, but drawing an Old Age Pension from Social Security is earned.

Note how in most national media every Republican is welcome but only the "business friendly" so-called Centrists are ever given a routine welcome. Notice how Independent Bernie Sanders was commonly savaged despite his policies being no more "left wing" than that of Angela Merkel, David Cameron or any number of other respected leaders.

We want our place at the table, in leadership and expect to not be sold out after we cast our votes. No more DINOs until they learn to work with instead of against Progressives.

headline: Fights Worth Having
commentone:
In a separate opinion today in this paper, Mr. Edsall reflects on what motivates voters to vote. It confirms what many of us suspected long ago. Loathing trumps loyalty when it comes to getting people to the polls and how they vote.
I, for one, squarely blame the Republicans for having started and, over time perfected, the strategy of instilling "loathing of the other" as the principal motivation for winning elections. Starting with Nixon's southern strategy and continuing today, many time amplified, with the non-stop ranting of Fox News's perverting message of "Democrats and Liberals as the enemy", not to mention our president's constant message of his critics as dangerous subversives. Mr. Stephens longs for the days of "Crossfire" and the polite back and forth of political elites respectfully arguing matters of policy. I, too, long for these days, but banking on Republicans to bring us back to those days is a fool's errand. Mona Charen's experience at CPAC proves how futile it is to bank on them. I don't blame the Democrats for learning this lesson. If loathing of the Republicans and Trump is what will bring Democrats to the polls and vote, so be it. One has to win individual battles before winning a war. Once in power again, maybe the adults of the Democratic party can work to improve the national dialogue.
commenttwo:
The Democrats need a good purging to drive the detritus of the Democratic Leadership Council (read the Clintons and their camp followers/hangers on) out of the party. This way they can stop being Republican Lite, which just enables the unending craziness in the one time party of Lincoln.

FYI- Bernie Sanders is not a wide eyed radical. He is where the Democratic Party stood that brought the New Deal, The Fair Deal, The New Frontier and the Great Society to this land. The party that helped create the broad Middle Class in this country, that sent GIs to College and made it broadly available to the masses. Same for home ownership. Same for Social Security which is NOT broke and is not a Ponzi scheme.

The Republicans need to return to their roots as the party of Lincoln, Theodore Roosevelt, Eisenhower and Gerald Ford, and turn their backs on the crazies that have dominated since just after Eisenhower.

headline: Goodbye, Pay-as-You-Wish
commentone: How long before it's $35?  Or $50?  What will the market bear now that public goods are no more? How much will you charge to enter libraries next?  And how long before nothing good or lovely can be even seen or felt by the poor?
commenttwo: What a shame. The movement towards soaking 'out-of-towners' really does leave a bad, unwelcoming, taste in my mouth. I, and countless others, donate quite a bit to our local arts to help keep prices low for everyone. New Yorkers who are visiting included. It would be nice if the courtesy was extended. Not only is the MET not a part of any reciprocity agreement, but they are now going to charge me just because I don't live locally, and not only charge me a token amount, but $25 dollars? Now, I can just stop by for a few hours, but will have to weigh if its worth it or not. Feel out how much I am 'in the mood' to absorb art at the moment, etc. I have to make a value judgement and economic calculation, which feels quite un-artistic. I've been burned by such judgements before (specifically, I spent well over 100 dollars to go the SFMoMa only to have to leave after two hours because, the kid was hungry, the wife and I started feeling more tired for the art than we anticipated, a room was closed off, and the special exhibit that was widely lauded ended up being beyond boring to me. A year later, and I still regret going and it has soured my entire opinion of the place. All so they could soak a 100 dollars from me.  What makes the art thrive is its incorporation into everyday life. Charging admissions puts up a wall where art is something you have to choose to 'do'. This only further the decline in arts acceptance and appreciation.  I guess at least it is a 3 day pass?

headline: Unknown
commentone: Game theory supports the notion that "tit-for-tat" is generally the optimal strategy to use in conflict situations. That would mean imposing tariffs equal to those imposed on us by foreign nations. However, 2 key provisions of tit-for-tat are: 1) Don't be the first to draw blood; 2) If an opponent makes a move of appeasement, rapprochement, or reconciliation--you do the same. Where I fear Trump will fail with all this is in these 2 key points, because his credo is to "hit back 10 times as hard", and to never apologize--two of his character flaws that are inconsistent with game theory, practical wisdom, the lessons of history, and the good, old Golden Rule. Therefore, whatever he does is likely to fail, simply because he'll muck it up, no matter what his motives or intentions.

headline: Whole Foods Gets Primed With the Amazon Treatment
commentone:

If you actually go to a store, and compare it to how it was just 6 months ago, you'll see it's gone downhill in many little, subtle ways. The tables in the cafe are dirty. My family used to shop there every week, and now we've switched to Sprouts.

Amazon turns everything into something that reminds one of a communist, dystopian future. As that's rather what they want.

headline: Angela Merkel is not the ‘leader of the free world’
commentone:
.
While US Presidents can be world-leaders, they are not leaders of the world or free world leaders either, though that is what the media often call them. They are only Presidents of the US.

US Presidents do not run the US either.

When equal to the task, US Presidents run only the Executive Branch of US government. Oftener they are not fully or even parly equal to the task.

The last US President--one of the very few in touch with all going on in the Executive Branch--was Eisenhower. Even after WWII, his mumbling habit, his dislike of campaigning, and dislike of schmoozing effectively hid his superior administrative ability.

US Presidents do not even run the US economy though the media tell us sheep that they do.

Finally, FRB Chairmen do not run the US economy either though the media sometimes tell us that too.

The US economy is a market-, not a planned economy. Even Mao and Stalin did not run their countries' economies. They left that to a committee whose people they could fire if angered. US Presidents cannot fire FRB Chairmen. They can only choose not to renew FRB Chairmen.

Folks, this is having not only national but global consequences. This man is unfit for office. Put aside your conspiracy theories and help us figure out how to get this absolute abomination out of office before it's too late and he does something to immediately hurt thousands, perhaps millions of people. This guy has got to go. And all of his corrupt family.

Stop putting your hate for the other people in this country ahead of your country. We need to fix this dire situation immediately.

DT has always been utterly transparent about who he is.  A  plethora of evidence was there for all to see from the beginning.  What else could one expect from a man eaten up by a lifetime of corruption, insatiable greed, narcissistic  indulgence, obsessions and rage? We are living through an object lesson in the need for scrupulous discernment in examining the lives lived, the character, of those we elect to ensure they are actually fit for the power and import of their office.  Employing the institutional structures available to us to hold them to constitutional and ethical standards once they are in office is critical. But the GOP will never hold DT to account.  So hang on.  It is a long way down to the bottom of this rat hole, even if the Dems take back the House and Senate at mid-term.

headline: Fights Worth Having
commentone:
I'm afraid I fall into Mr. Stephens' "other side" grouping. I lifelong Democrat, I USED to believe that bipartisan compromise was the ideal. After 25 years of cold Republican calculus I have changed my mind. The Republicans have successfully marshalled neo-Nazis, hate groups, racists, anti-abortionists, Christianity-is-the-state-religionists, corporations, NRA-guns-everywherers, etc that have all combined to turn the Executive, the Legislature and, soon, the Judicary into a rubber stamp for their agenda.

Democrats spent 8 years being told "never", "no", "Obama is not a legtimate President"... So we on the left know full well where the Republicans stand. The mass exodus of "moderate" Republicans from the ranks of the governing is proof of the party's absolute abandonment of bipartisanmship.

So, my takeaway from watching the Republicans trash Obama for 8 years, from one year of their absolute control of the government, the appointments of industry insiders or people with zero experience to run every agency charged with regulation (that is, those regulations that are left...), the refusal to investigate & take action against enemies of the United States who undertook to subvert our democracy is that "moderate" Democrats waste their time attempting to compropmise because there is zero Republican interest in doing so. Democrats who do are being played the fool and are simply patsies. We need solid Progressives who won't knuckle under if democracy is to be saved.
commenttwo:
Cry me a river, Mona Charen. Where was & is the concern for single mothers trying to live on slave wages in inflated economies. Her advice would probably be to take a second & third job or "get an education."
We've heard quite enough hand wringing from conservatives like herself, wailing about the pay discrepancy vis-a-vis the sexes among corporate execs, along with the attacks on the liberal do-gooders wanting people to be fed, clothed & housed, especially for their labors.
She couldn't carry water for Elizabeth Warren.

headline: First Lady Is a Fit for Genius Visa. Einstein? Iffy.
commentone:
This is insane. Leaving Melania herself out of the equation, are we really saying that what this country needs is more women willing to pose naked over clearly brilliant scientists and astrophysicists? Apparently so.

How incredibly sad for this once great country, which has turned into one big schlockfest. I guess the schlock and entertainment are all that America is about these days. Oops, I mean 'Murica.
commenttwo: The real issue with Melania Trump's visa is not whether she met criteria for "merit" as a model but whether she worked without authorization prior to having government permission. If she did then that would have been a major strike against her and certainly cause for deportation. In addition whoever hired her should have been prosecuted for employing someone not eligible to work in the United States. As we debate the future of young people brought to the United States by their parents we should remember they are being maligned by someone whose wife may have worked illegally and should be deported, whose in-laws received green cards on the basis of their daighter's illegally-obtained citizenship, and who himself may be guilty of violating immigration law. When people grumble about the immigration system being broken they should remember it is people precisely like Donald Trump who have broken it for profit and cronyism, not infants carried into the country like so much luggage. We would not consider some undocumented worker's suitcase to be a piece of "illegal luggage" and children with no say, perhaps totally unaware of what transpired, have a more legitimate claim than someone who entered as an adult, worked without papers, then made false statements to receive a visa and ultimately citizenship.

headline: Go Ahead, Millennials, Destroy Us
commentone:
AMEN, AMEN, AMEN!
I‚Äö√Ñ√¥m a 64 year old male boomer and every time I see an old ugly white male pontificating on TV I want to throw up. I just hope when the young take over they let me help them.
commenttwo: First, I've never owned a gun. Have never felt the need. I understand, however, that some people do feel the need to own a gun. There are, I suppose, plenty of people who will express that it is a right to do so--and that they need to do so. Very well. At this point of my argument, there are two kinds of people--someone who will never shoot anyone (me) and those who own guns, who possess a 100% more chance of shooting someone than I do. It dosen't make any difference what kind of gun it is. The chances are still between 0% and 100%. No gun, no shoot. No shoot, no kill. Now, place a gun in a safe deposit box. Forever. It will never kill anyone by itself because it can't. Because it's not possible. Now, place a gun in the hands of a human. The chances increase 100% because it is entirely possible. Try the same trick with a knife. Knife. Deposit box. Same result as the gun in a deposit box. Try this with any weapon. Same result. Deposit box, no kill. Add human hands, 100% possibility. Because humans kill. Humans are killers. We have a long history. As much as I--or we-- would like to believe otherwise. Weapons don't kill people. People kill people. This is logic. This is human. It's who we are. It's what we've done. That's why I don't own a gun.

headline: God, Don’t Save the King
commentone:
Still, if we hadn't listened to those slaveholding Virginians Washington, Jefferson, Madison, and others, and just stayed with the British instead of revolting, we would be Canada today. We might have, some slight relationship to the British Royals, but we would also have the British style of government, and would certainly have ended slavery far sooner, without our Civil War.
If we had a monarchy, one without political power as in England, we would have a Parliament, not this stupid bought and sold Congress. We would probably have national health care and be linked to the other English speaking nations in friendship.
Nothing about Britain's royal stupidity dictates that they have to destroy democracy, in fact, the opposite seems to be happening.
I get your point, of course, but I could see an Obama royal line that I could be really happy with.
Trump and his family are more the Pharaoh type of royalty, stupid and needful of massive contractions with their names on them, than the British.
Hugh Massengill, Eugene Oregon

Really truly disgusting.

You know what, I am a working artist and I make a LOT less money than you, Ai Wei Wei. And I am‚Äö√Ñ√¨ and always have been‚Äö√Ñ√¨more than happy to pay the $25 suggested admission fee at the Met. headline: Hooray for Harvey-less Hollywood!
commentone: The NDA's ( non disclosure agreements) will just get tougher and more explicit language, covering more "acts", and the behavior will continue. The Harvey Pig Routine will give rise to a more sophisticated and subtle form of coercion...it's called acting...
commenttwo: When I was growing up in the 50s and 60s, it was a given that men were entitled.  We were taught this nonsense as children, along with racism, by our parents, movies, TV, books, school, church, our parents' friends -- everywhere we looked, this ignorance was what we saw, heard, felt, and, as victims, suffered.  We were taught this when our minds had no ability to evaluate what we were hearing, and though we grew up and made up our own minds, what gets into a young mind never really changes, though we learn to use our intellect to overcome it because we can see it now for what it is.  The rat-pack culture is fading because it is not constantly reinforced by the culture we have now.  It's a beautiful thing.  But I can't help thinking that there are parts of it that haven't been that great for men, either.  Pressure to "be a man," to let the women and children be saved first.  So good riddance to that culture, for the good of all of us.  This is evolution at work and I am too busy celebrating to get caught up in blaming (psychopaths excepted).

headline: How Liberals Can Reclaim Nationalism
commentone:
I believe collectively citizens can express and embody collective political idealism. While this ability can be diminished when they feel threatened and is easily manipulated for political gain- it can be genuine and constructively channeled.

The best way this can be achieved and sustained is by their direct participation in democratic process- whether protests, elections, movements, initiatives, etc. Unfortunately too many shy away, rationalize or avoid such levels of commitment- even to the point that they can't be inconvenienced to even vote. And it is this state of malaise and indifference that is seized upon by autocrats such as Trump to attain and consolidate power.

More importantly this collective idealism, should not require charismatic leaders- but rather a sense of individual and communal empowerment. In the end this should be one of the chief aims of political education. But unfortunately we are still far off the mark- and instead we find our society gravitating towards totalitarianism, fear and dis-empowerment in a sea of ignorance.
commenttwo: people across the left spectrum look at bible-thumping red-blooded American patriotism  as ridiculous and unhelpful.  Not wrongly.  Unfortunately looking through the other side of the lens, conservatives across that spectrum feel similarly about, say, the "U.S. out of North America" wing of the left.  And in a way, not wrongly.  To back up this argument would take up more space than available here.  The center-left liberal shares the further left beliefs with some discomfort, vague confusion, and convenience.  The hard woke left calls out the privileged center liberal as part of the problem.  The hard left asks the right questions but its offered answers are profoundly unhelpful or worse.  They offer no real way forward in the real world we live in.  Injustice and worse have been part of human history since the get go.  There have been good and even great attributes to the checkered history of this country.  But Americans should not walk in hunched shame, and frankly that is what the woke left wants white Americans to do.  There's no way forward there.  Let's embrace the complexity and reach for better without whitewashing any truth or fear of a tough climb.

headline: How the Left Wins the Culture War
commentone:
No offense but gun owners have brought this on themselves. They refuse to allow any reasonable compromise on guns and as a result mass shootings continue to escalate. Every society has a breaking point where you can be part of the solution or be seen as being complicit in murder.

If everyday gun owners would agree that semiautomatic weapons need the same regulations as automatic weapons and that we should have stronger back ground checks to keep guns out of the hands of those who shouldn't have them the public would back off. But if you shut down any meaningful dialogue about how we can fix gun violence eventually there's going to be a backlash. Seriously what message are you sending when you're having wedding ceremonies with assault rifles while parents are burying their children.
commenttwo:
I really don't understand why Progressive/Socialists put so much faith in new laws controlling guns.

Criminals break the laws...that's why they are criminals. Honest people obey the laws and that's why we will not tolerate another stupid gun restriction that only law abiding citizens obey.

Not that hard to figure....don't you think?

headline: How the Tet Offensive Broke America
commentone:
Some of us understood the folly of this war long before the Tet offensive. My first demonstration against the Vietnam War was in 1964. When my brother's birthday came up #2 in the draft lottery, my father--a life-long defense department employee--told him not to go, because "the Vietnamese never did anything against us." He offered to send my brother to Canada and support him there. (Ira found another way out.)

What we are witnessing today--U.S. bases in 700+ countries, endless wars and interventions on behalf of immensely wealthy corporations and their corrupt puppets in Third World countries--is nothing new. It is the inevitable trajectory of empire, and like all empires, it inevitably declines. Our empire reached its peak after WWII, somewhere in the 1950s, and has been going downhill ever since.
commenttwo: Our government lies to us with astounding facility.  When historians finally write the history of U.S. involvement in the Middle East, I'm guessing it will make the ldeceit and chicanery associated with the war in Vietnam look like child's play.

headline: I Saw a Genocide in Slow Motion
commentone:
Why are human beings so misanthropic? Perhaps our hatred and mockery of others is a reflection of our self loathing. And yet why in this endless miasma must the innocent suffer?

Forgetting- turning away is such a tempting ambrosia- to be lulled into an unknowing sleep- except there is the inevitable awakening- and then the sleep that never ends.
commenttwo: Thanks for reporting on this. Medical Teams International (and other organizations) has been working in refugee camps in Bangladesh since September. The people are living in horrible conditions; the UNHCR and aid groups are trying to make a difference. People outside need to understand that these refugees are people escaping horrific violence, and many have suffered unspeakable trauma, as you have pointed out. I do hope we don't look back and regret inaction in the face of genocide (as with Rwanda in 1994).

headline: Intrigue in the House of Trump
commentone:
Your discussion of the Hillary Clinton/Health Care debacle raises the question, yet again, of what America wants from its unpaid, throwback notion of what a First Lady's role should be. Carping about Hillary in that role was a Republican blood sport for years, and Democrats are now doing their best not to throw mud at Melania, who has--unlike the other Trump self-branders--chosen to slink under the radar and, to all evidence, see her role as First Lady as one long photo op to showcase her expensive clothes. So much for the anti-cyberbullying campaign.

Maybe in the wake of the Trump presidency and the MeToo Movement, we can at long last come to terms with what role(s) a wife of a president, or a spouse of a president, is expected to fulfill.

On another note, don't overlook the fact that Don, Jr. and Eric--although not unpaid advisors with jobs in the White House--are still very much in the loop. They tweet support of their father, they roam the world promoting branding and franchising opportunities for the Trump trademark and they are as much in the mix as the Gang of Two, Javanka. Remember that Trump said he would never speak to his sons after he fake handed over his business to them.

And since, with the Trumps, we're in the realm of trash TV and talking head pop psychology, and I remember so well my history lessons on the dysfunction of palace intrigue in the European courts, I do wonder what the Real Sons think of Jared becoming the Crown Prince?
commenttwo: Of the Trumps, by the Trumps, for the Trumps....

headline: Learning to drive at 62
commentone: This article alone is worth this month's NYT subscription fee.  Roger Cohen lived more by the age of 17 than I have in my entire life.
commenttwo:
I smiled while I read your column. I have kids your age.
My mother insisted I learn to drive and began to teach me at age 12. Not a problem because we lived in a very rural area where most kids first learned to drive tractors.
I have always felt sorry for those who didn't learn to drive as a child. They seemed to make driving harder than it is. But now I understand--young people feel sorry for us who didn't learn about computers until we were in our fifties.
Good luck!

headline: Letting  Teenagers  Live
commentone:
Everywhere I go I see drivers with one hand on the wheel and the other holding a cell phone to their ear, and some of them look like adults in their 40s or so.

A few years ago my wife and I were walking across the street when we were hit by a woman in her early 20s who was texting while driving. We had the light but she just zooped around the corner, not even looking to see that we were in the crosswalk. We were very, very lucky--broken arms but no head injuries, spinal cord injuries, etc.

Teenage drivers are certainly more dangerous than older ones. However we still must find a way to stop people from using their cell phones while driving.

headline: Lower the Voting Age to 16
commentone: i disagree. Young people don't have the mental maturity to vote.  The age should rise to the age of 21. Not only voting, but buying cigarettes, alcohol(which is currently the case), joining the armed forces, buying guns, taking out loans, signing contracts, geting married,  etc.  The Supreme Court used current medical science studies that says most individuals' brains don't mature until the age of 25, when they made the decision(s) to strike down the death penalty and life without parole for those under 18. headline: Make Better Movies Too
commentone:
I love movies. Not all movies, but exceptional movies. I am proud of the USA for producing movies as one of our great, meaningful exports. All over the world I can find a decent America movie to view and share with the local population instead of burying myself in a foxhole as American bombs fall alongside.

In the past few years, however, I admit I am going to movies less and less. Partly because I can see them on Netflix, but mostly because I hate the new seats, the greater expense, the forever ads before the forever previews, and the stupid, vapid, Transformer Blow em ups, the Furious Series with Van Diesel, and etc.

I notice in South America that Hollywood sends them all their Class B horror and shoot-em-up films.

And the sex and continuous violence here begs the question...why is America violent and every citizen needs to carry a gun? Sex is displayed everyplace. And yet, women are shocked that men don't know how to act and treat them? Movies all too often send the wrong message.

But...thankfully, there are enough out there that are outstanding and bring me back to saying, "I love movies". One of my very favorites..."Animal House". Fun and funny, shrieking with outrageousness, something to ward off the evils of a Republican presidency. We need more comedies and fun things rather than all that kiliing and slaughter, because that's what happens all too frequently in this real country called America.

headline: Not the Higher Prices, It’s What Might Happen Next
commentone:
"The real risk isn‚Äö√Ñ√¥t that steel and aluminum are a bit more expensive, though that is likely to be the case. It‚Äö√Ñ√¥s that an entire system of global trade, which the United States helped build, might be undermined."

I think this is exactly what Trump's has in mind, and he has not been shy over the years in stating his case.

In the aftermath of the Second World War, the US constructed a trade system that was primarily designed to promote democracy, economic advancement, and stability among nations that were then economic and political basket cases. It worked. Europe and Asia recovered, and Latin America is now democratic an becoming more prosperous each year (with some obvious exceptions). But the US paid a heavy price in structuring asymmetrical trade deals that, in large part, were not really trade deals but economic stability mechanisms for other countries, and which benefited other nations far more than they benefited us.

We could afford to negotiate disadvantageous deals such as these forty years ago because we were by far the richest nation on earth. Now we aren't, in large part because of what can only be considered largesse on our part.

It's time we started looking out for our own interests on trade, and that is Trump's point.
commenttwo: So if I am a manufacturer of cooling systems (like Carrier) and I have facilities in US, Mexico, and Philippines with available fabrication capacity, since my costs just went up significantly, it is beneficial to shift production and employment to my non-US facilities. Thanks Trump for the clarification!

headline: Romance, Rough Sex or Rape?
commentone:
Everything is culturally relative. Edgar Allen Poe married a 13-year-old girl and wrote famous poems about her. Today, he would be jailed just for approaching her ‚Äö√Ñ√Æ and her parents would probably be jailed as well ‚Äö√Ñ√Æ while she was put in the hands of the child protection authorities ‚Äö√Ñ√Æ if they gave him consent to marry her.

In one African culture, the father of a bride makes love to her on the night before her wedding, so she has some sexual experience to bring to her marriage and doesn't enter it as a virgin. She would feel hurt and rejected if her father did not make love to her. Try running that one by Child Protective Services or the editorial board of a feminist magazine. Should we get on our high horse and call such people "primitive."

Are our culture's values so much more progressive and humane than those of others? Women are now combatants in our army, meaning they are encouraged to kill our "enemies" in places like Iraq. What ever happened to the "gentle sex" being the voice of moderation and peace.

Women write and read most contemporary romantic novels, many of which involve exactly the type of rough, semi-forced sex Mr. Bruni chastises here. Let's be careful of double standards, hypocrisy and abandoning due process ‚Äö√Ñ√Æ of letting today's moralism become tomorrows oppression.

If someone physically or verbally abuses another, beats or rapes him or her, that's a crime and should be treated as such. Otherwise, let consenting adults consent.

headline: Saying a Prayer I Don’t Believe In
commentone: An extremely interesting discussion, and moving on several levels. But if what Mr Lefkowitz says is true, the period of mourning for his poor father expired almost a year ago.
commenttwo:
My dear friend Marion was a militant atheist. When she died of cancer (availing herself of the Death With Dignity act), the three of us whom she had chosen to be around her were Jewish. We waited until we were sure she was no longer with us, and then we said Kaddish. I am sure Marion would kick me in the slats for it, if she could.

I do not believe in God, but the prayer gives me comfort. Perhaps it is the poetry of it, perhaps the connection with the Orthodox home of my childhood. When my wife was in the ICU at Stanford, years ago, and I didn't know if she'd survive, I'd wake up at 3:00 am and say the 23rd Psalm over and over, until I fell asleep again. In those moments, in desperation, I believed. It doesn't matter. I am a very small, short-lived creature in an immeasurably vast universe, and don't require myself to be logical or consistent or have answers--just to do my best to be kind to others and "tikkun olam" -- to pursue justice.

headline: Trump’s Call to Arm Teachers Resonates at Schools That Do
commentone:
It's just a matter of time before a teacher shoots and kills a kid, or maybe several kids. It sounds like it is most likely to happen in Florida, which is apparently run by the NRA, first.

What people don't get is that, aside from the "caught in the cross fire" argument, which is certainly valid, bullets travel. They go through walls, go into parking lots, they ricochet around. Even if they his their intended target, they can go right through it and hit someone else. That's how the NAZI's kill multiple victims in concentration camps with one bullet ‚Äö√Ñ√Æ lining them up and shooting through several at a time.

The more bullets that are fired, the more likely it is that one will hit someone.

Even if a teacher grabs a gun and goes into a hallway to find a shooter, how would he or she know what to do? How do you identify the shooter, and know you're shooting the right person? It might not be as obvious as it seems, given the chaos that attends such incidents.

So, this is like the stupidest idea since‚Äö√Ñ¬∂I don't know when.
commenttwo:
Good. There's no reason for students to be sitting ducks. It's the school district's job to do ensure the safety of kids, and sticking your head in the sand isn't really a good strategy.

Laws don't protect you from bad things, laws exist to punish those who do bad things after they do them. The only thing that can prevent someone unbalanced from victimizing you is you. If you're not willing to take responsibility for your own safety then that's your problem, not society's.

headline: What Motivates Voters More Than Loyalty? Loathing
commentone:
The most optimistic piece I've read in a while.

May all the voters who find Trump loathsome will actually show up.

Of course, loathing also motivates Trump's supporters.

Well, at least we might get a respectable turnout, no matter who wins.
commenttwo:
When I started out in 1976 as a lowly photographer at Mayor Kevin H. White's Boston city hall I was immediately schooled in two principles: One: Help your friends and hurt your enemies. The second: No matter how lowly your position there is political 'juice' attached.

The second came into sharp relief when a city councilor took me to lunch in order to pry out of me information about a member of our photo crew who had successfully gotten the former boss fired for blatant discrimination. How blatant? The boss was a close friend of White. Why should a powerful elected official care about the doings of a guy who was relegated to the night shift and kept out of sight?

The answer is found by paraphrasing Clausewitz: Politics is warfare by other means.

headline: When Elder Abuse Is Self-Inflicted
commentone: The reason my 90 year old mother doesn‚Äö√Ñ√¥t want to live in any sort of assisted living is because the other residents are like her ‚Äö√Ñ√Æ very unpleasant to be around.  Throughout her life she lived in any number of situations that required sharing space, compromise, humor and adaptability. And she expected herself and others to do their fair share to make it work. Now she thinks she has no obligation to do those things. Her idea of aging in place is that someone else is supposed to do everything she can‚Äö√Ñ√¥t do, exactly the way she wants it done. And when she makes horrible decisions that bring on mini-disasters or vastly increase the burden on others, that's independence. Reasonable self-care is part of the social contract. Old people need to hold up their end of the bargain.

headline: Angela Merkel is not the ‘leader of the free world’
commentone:
The global liberal order rests on the foundation of U.S. military power. U.S. military strength is built on the foundation of large budget deficits, which will eventually become unsustainable.

The failure of the unipolar Pax Americana world order is therefore as certain as it is unfortunate. The only question will be the failure mode.

The best option will be for our like-minded allies such as Germany and other European states to increase military spending and shoulder their fair share of maintaining the global order. The worst option will be to continue with current unsustainable approach which will at some point lead to a more sudden, chaotic collapse of the global order.

Germany is currently running a budget surplus. They can afford to increase military spending, but just don‚Äö√Ñ√¥t want to do it. Moreover, a majority of the German populace does not even support German military intervention in case a NATO ally, especially in the Baltics, is attacked.

The only reasonable conclusion is that NATO, a bulwark of the global liberal order, is dying. This not because of President Trump, but rather because of Europeans themselves don‚Äö√Ñ√¥t perceive any external threats that warrant its continuation.

headline: Democrats Face Primary Shove From New Left
commentone: What it means to be a Democrat?  You must hate Trump, lack any and all common sense about the fundamental issues of our time.  Support open borders, higher taxes, and continue to prop up the Russia collusion story even though the facts show that the Democrats are responsible.  Scream racism every time someone looks at you sideways.  Always think and react emotionally instead of using fact and logic.  Also, lie about anything if it serves your purpose.
commenttwo:
I arrived at college as a small-town Republican from a family deeply involved in local politics. Soon after, I had the exceptional pleasure of studying under an erudite and engaging professor who described the elegant path of reforms and the near impossible effort to attain them that defined the Democratic Party. He was a true New Deal Democrat that could quote every major political treatise from Thucydides to James Wilson. I was challenged enough to revise my view of politics because his view was intelligent, not intuitive (identity) or emotional (divisive). And there was a goal, a purpose greater than the success of the politicians running for seats. It was to challenge the limits of a constitution and a government that was exclusively designed to support the singular and archaic value of private property above all.
And it worked when the voting public understood what the party represented.
Perhaps I am not as versed in the contemporary strategy of the present political landscape as other readers, but trying to follow all the positions and platforms gives me a headache. I don't hear a message. I don't have much to hold on to that gives me hope these candidates will work in the best interest of a country that is still a work in progress. I know whom and what they dislike, but that's all.
The party needs to find a focus, preferably economic, because that is ultimately what engages the most reliable response from the voters. We need a focus, not a fracas.

headline: Dorm Living for Professionals
commentone:
I visited and traveled thru SF often in my life, and the changes observed there thru the past two decades are disheartening. At one point, a visitor like myself could visit, tour, see a possibility of living in one of the many unique and clean neighborhoods, and enjoy it.
No more.
That SF is gone forever, along with the character the city used to have, a working character full of clean homes and gritty people and shipyards, foundries, longshoremen, sailors, tradesmen, all of it, gone, driven away by supertankers full of techadvertising finance money. What's next we're going to 'celebrate,' another massive city block upscale four star flopgooglehouse that doesn't allow pets, not even goldfish? No, I won't be visiting SF at all again, won't celebrate it, I refuse, what I knew is completely gone, and you'll all never get that, so I'll keep my heart where my home is, thank you.
At least a person can live here, make a cup of tea, and walk and pet the dogs without fear of getting evicted by a techmillionaire child.
commenttwo: I feel a generation apart from some of the other commenters. Sure San Francisco has a housing problem but there are so many plus sides to tgis concept. Having recently left college I have been without a community and have come to realize that interacting with people forces me to meet freinds. Shared kitchen spaces and bathrooms might be inconvient at first, but ultimately they can lead to closer connections as its hard to wear a facade once you have to do some your most private activities in a shared space. This is what leads to openness and stronger communities. I also believe there are some pretty strong sustainability advances and arguments that can be made in favor of such dorm style living.

headline: First Lady Is a Fit for Genius Visa. Einstein? Iffy.
commentone: Clearly Mrs. Trump is very good at something, and I'm churlish enough to speculate that only a few of her handlers, and now her current husband, know what it is.
commenttwo: This reflects the view of immigration lawyers I know who were surprised by the original story. The consensus seems to be that Trump's girlfriend may have given Melania access to a more experienced lawyer, but that it's not a stretch for a model who has been on the cover of Sports Illustrated to get an EB-1 visa, and that the description of these visas as rare "genius" visas is wrong. Much as we dislike Trump, getting facts right is more important now than ever, and it's possible to point out the hypocrisy of Trump's position without exaggerating the truth. Thanks for this piece.

headline: How Liberals Can Reclaim Nationalism
commentone: Yes we are a salad bowl made up of many ingredients and the bowl is what holds everything.  Our power (read flavors) is the mixing and the symbiosis of the ingredients. If we exclude ingredients we loose the strength and beauty.
commenttwo:
Mounk‚Äö√Ñ√¥s challenge to liberals to reclaim nationalism was stirring. It infers that this restoration will come from a contest with conservatives. Liberal-conservative or Democrat-Republican, seeking our better angels by overcoming tribal divisions is not promising.

Gordon in her book about the KKK explained its 1920s success was due to six deeply held American tenets such as nativism, evangelicalism, and populism. These beliefs have remained strong as evidenced in the red hysteria in the 1920s, the un-American hearings in the 1950s, the war support in the 1960s and up today with bumper stickers of ‚Äö√Ñ√∫these colors don‚Äö√Ñ√¥t run.‚Äö√Ñ√π

Based upon past, a liberal-conservative contest for being more American has been disheartening. There remains effective politicians who have tapped into America‚Äö√Ñ√¥s core values and triumphed‚Äö√Ñ√ÆNixon, Reagan, Trump.

There was a liberal who tried to achieve the results that Mounk believes possible. Former Senator and presidential candidate George McGovern. McGovern said, ‚Äö√Ñ√∫The highest patriotism is not a blind acceptance of official policy, but a love of one‚Äö√Ñ√¥s country deep enough to call her to a higher plain.‚Äö√Ñ√π

Nixon crushed McGovern 520 electoral votes to 17. Since then, liberalism became a pejorative, still in use. The Democratic Party abandoned their philosophy and moved towards the Republican positions.

It is with our laws and our court system and its promise that all Americans will have their civil rights protected‚Äö√Ñ√Æthis is our foremost commonality.

We don't care if evangelicals practice their religion, we don't want them to shove it in our face in schools, public buildings, etc.  We don't care if conservative adults who are wired to be gay remain celebate, marry gays or straights, or give conversion therapy a shot; we think gays who want to live openly as gays and marry other gays should have that right and full legal protections.  We don't want to force you to watch movies or listen to music which you find objectionable.  You don't have to read the NYT.  Most of us have nothing against your owning and hunting with shotguns and small-magazine long rifles.  We won't take these from you. headline: Letting  Teenagers  Live
commentone: In the day to day battle of life, when death touches us we are surprised by our mortality and especially surprised by the death of those who are younger. Death changes things. It reevaluates life. It may adopt new thoughts of anger and despair. It offers a new incite into the value of life. If we ignore it, death will enter and consume us, make us mean and spiteful. Death is lonely. Death is sad. Death comes when we pretend that our lives are safe and protected. They aren't. One doesn't know death until it's an experience of your life. I don't recommend it. What happened at Stoneman Douglas High is tragic, and shares many many other senseless deaths. We can and should do better. We owe that to our children.

headline: Nakesha’s Demons
commentone:
A well written and sad story about a life wasted on the city streets.

I‚Äö√Ñ√¥ve often thought about what it would be like to live over a sewer grate or under a bridge. One‚Äö√Ñ√¥s whole existence centered around the next meal, fending off the next storm, frightened of the next police encounter.

People reduced to living like animals. A horror show.
commenttwo:
This powerful story is a parallel biography of my sister Marti, who was murdered on the streets 8 years ago. Like Nakesha, she was bright, generous, and creative. Marti was a nurse and frequent volunteer. She survived a challenging childhood and at 23, was diagnosed with paranoid schizophrenia.
I was in her life until her mid 40s, when she became so paranoid, she would not allow contact with me, her close ally. Her last 10 years were much like Nakesha's - except her death was more brutal.
Mr Weiser, thank you for this powerfully written, respectful and intimate portrait. We can't change what we don't understand.
To all of the compassionate 'strangers' who feed, converse, and support our lost loved ones - I extend my deepest gratitude.
We can‚Äö√Ñ√¥t expect someone with paranoid schizophrenia to have insight into their illness and seek treatment. Involuntarily commitment, which I've had experience doing, is a tiny band-aid on a deep wound. Homeless outreach typically requires interaction with a social worker or talk of treatment. My sister, like Nakesha, did not ‚Äö√Ñ√≤think‚Äö√Ñ√¥ she needed help. We don't expect people with debilitating cerebral palsy to get themselves to treatment. Why do we expect insight and treatment compliance from people with paranoid schizophrenia? More resources, ideas and research are needed to find solutions. Allowing very mentally ill persons to live dangerously on the streets or housing them in prisons is more than heartbreaking. It's criminal.

That need for change ‚Äö√Ñ√Æ advocated on this page and by others ‚Äö√Ñ√Æ was re-emphasized last week when SITLA announced it planned to lease parcels of land in the Book Cliffs for oil exploration and drilling."
