headline: Roger Bannister, First Athlete to Break the 4-Minute Mile, Is Dead at 88
commentone: A beautifully wrought obituary that reads as though it were some time in the making.  Grateful for the very telling details, like 'took an early afternoon train to Oxford,' and 'had lunch with old friends' before the race, and then the dramatic reading of the final time over the PA system. It all combines to great effect here that captures not merely the achievement but the surprise nature of it.  Startled - pleasantly so - that such clear video exists.
commenttwo:
When I was 5 years old, Sir Roger broke the 4-min mile. I know I saw videos a little later. He was such an inspiration. In the Fifties there were school libraries and they had fiction based on the Track and Field sports. I read them avidly and to me thery were like Science Fiction, Ray Bradbury and them. But sports were more accessible aqnd I began my own routines.

That start was more important than anything else I could have done. My academics were instilled altready, but my physical health more than any accomplishment, although I did Letter in Wrestling my Senior year in High School, has established my good vitals and what I need to feel healthy. I can only thank God and examples like Roger.

headline: Romance, Rough Sex or Rape?
commentone:
I am not Susan Fitzwater but her husband. Please be clear about that.

Good piece, Mr. Bruni. Thank you.

And I find the subject deeply perplexing. Disturbing, almost. The lines of Edna St. Vincent Millay rang through my mind. Nonstop. Bear with me.

The poet is addressing Endymion, the beautiful youth abducted by a moon goddess and lulled into an eternal, enchanted sleep. Referring to that goddess, she writes:

"Whom earthen you, by deathless lips adored,
Wild-eyed and stammering to the grasses thrust
And deep into her crystal body poured
The hot and sorrowful sweetness of the dust.
Whereof she wanders, being all unfit
For mortal love that might not die of it."

My goodness! Frank enough.

Never--NEVER will I try and play Rudolf Valentino. Never--NEVER have I tried to play Rhett Butler to someone's quailing Scarlett O'Hara. And big, brawny Rocky-- forcing himself upon a timorous Adrian? Not this child!

I do not care for scenes of simulated sex period. That's another story. But whether on the silver screen or in real life--there's a handy little two-word phrase every man ought to have down pat.

Consensual sex.

Please pay particular attention, guys, to the first word.

That way--no grief. No tears. No bitter (and lasting) recriminations. No trauma. No psychic wounds that last a lifetime. And. . .um. .. .

. . . .no legal issues.

Thanks again, Mr. Bruni.
commenttwo:
"‚Äö√Ñ√∫Coal Miner‚Äö√Ñ√¥s Daughter,‚Äö√Ñ√π 1980. On her wedding night, Loretta Lynn, just a teenager, cries ‚Äö√Ñ√∫no, no, no, no‚Äö√Ñ√π as her older husband wrestles her into submission. The next morning, when he tells her to get used to it and she says that she won‚Äö√Ñ√¥t, he slaps her. It‚Äö√Ñ√¥s not pretty, but it‚Äö√Ñ√¥s a necessary rite of passage ‚Äö√Ñ√Æ or so the movie seems to maintain."

Wasn't this movie based on her autobiography? I recall reading in the '70s that when she was married at 13, in her repressive Appalachian upbringing, she was pregnant for the second time at 15 before she knew that sex had anything to do with that! Should her actual experiences circa 1945 now be Bowdlerized to conform the concerns of late 2017, early 2018? The movie was about her life, and she was married at 13 back then, not today.

headline: The Challenge of Doctor-Patient Relations in the Internet Age
commentone:
I have a history going back to babyhood of having atypical reactions to many things. I've ended up in the ER a few times because of those reactions. Whenever a physician wants to prescribe something, I question them to make sure that:
(1) There isn't something else that we can try first that doesn't involve medications or surgery.
(2) They're aware of all my existing allergies/sensitivities, reactions and pre-existing conditions; to that end I give them a 1-page document that I update regularly summarizing major elements of my medical history including surgeries, vaccinations, recent tests, current meds, and allergies/sensitivities.
(3) They explain the potential pros and especially cons of the treatment or medication or procedure;
(4) I know what to look out for, what to do, who to call, where to go if something goes wrong.
(5) If there are any questions or doubts, I will take the time to research reputable sources or get a second opinion.

I learned all of this the hard way. I've had doctors prescribe meds I'm allergic to, suggest procedures that were at best optional and at worst unnecessary, and push protocols that were "standard of care" but NOT appropriate given my circumstances. I vetoed major abdominal surgery for my mother despite the insistence of the surgeon because I discovered that surgery was contraindicated for those, like my mother, who have severe dementia.

I don't pretend to have all the knowledge my doctors have. But I do know they're fallible.
commenttwo:
As a physician I have always sat and talked with my patients and tried to give them the information they need and can understand. As the internet came along it became clear that people were sourcing it so I would add to the conversation that when the go to the web they go to the reliable sites and I direct them to those sites. For instance American Kidney Foundation, or the American diabetic society. On return visit we would discuss what they read and sometimes I would learn something new which I would delve deeper into.

The web is only bad when it misinforms....you know just like people.

headline: Trial of Killer’s Widow:  Scared Victim of Abuse Or Cunning Accomplice?
commentone: Who doesn‚Äö√Ñ√¥t lie to the FBI, it seems.  Agents must find it impossible to live with themselves being so perfect.
commenttwo:
If your abusive husband told you he would kill your child in front of you, would you really want to chance it with a guy who was obviously desperate and planning some final act anyway?
Also, think about the mindset of someone who cannot summon the nerve to try and escape a household where violence and injuries are routine (perhaps even to the kids), along with threats of even greater punishment if the abused person says anything about it. Would that person be your choice to rely on for betraying an abuser who might have made one last stop back at the house if his plans were disrupted?

Point is, we can imagine all sorts of thinking on the part of the woman, including motives good or bad or terrified, but why don't we just wait and find out? For those of us with heart conditions, our hearts aren't bleeding for crime to go unpunished; our metaphorical hemorrhaging is for the consequences of of deciding guilt or innocence from newspaper reports. If you were wrongly jailed (it happens), would you want your neighbors deciding how guilty you were even before the trial?

headline: ‘The Assassination of Gianni Versace’ Episode 6: A Nothing Man
commentone:
I think some of you are answering your own questions while perhaps not seeing the point of this series: at the time this happened, there was very little known about Cunanan or exactly what the motive was for his killing spree. If this series feels empty, vain, selfish, narcissistic and void of feeling, it's because that's what the pieces of Cunanan's personality led the world to believe. He was as materialistic -- and as bitterly jealous -- as it possibly gets.

When his delusions of grandeur began to implode to the point that even he could not longer live in denial, it unleashed a monster in him that was beyond reproach. Since so little is known about the man, the series (and originally, Maureen Orth's book) attempts to fill in the back story with what little evidence there is to paint a *probable* timeline of events. The hollow, empty atmosphere of the show is a perfect supposition of what Cunanan truly was in the final years of his life.

Trump wanted to build a wall across the southern border and wanted Mexico to pay for it . Caligula named his horse Consul . Trump named his son in law chief negotiator on the Middle East . Let us hope the same happens to our Country .

headline: Getting a Taste of a Difficult Year
commentone: Mr. Asimov - Your comments about "underappreciated" vintages brought me back to what I considered to be one of my better assessments and purchases in 30+ years of tasting, buying and consuming. The 1991 red Burgundies weren't getting much love coming on the heels of of the highly touted (and rightfully so) 1990s. I attended a tasting of 35 or so wines that were from good producers, most at the village level and some premier cru. I remember thinking, "These wines are so different from 1990, and certainly lean by comparison." But they had excellent acidity and I felt that some time in the bottle would allow them to flesh out a bit. Best of all, they were priced at a 20 - 25 % discount to the 1990s. So I stocked up! And over the next few years, they came together beautifully. As you and commenters on the 2013 Bordeaux emphasize, wines with those profiles are at their best with food. Many a pork roast and beef stew were paired with those 1991 Burgundies, enhanced further by the self satisfaction of having trusted my instincts with a group of wines that weren't flashy up front, but were darn good drinking at the dinner table. The lesson in this seems to be that it's all well and good to follow the tout sheets on the big vintages, but don't be afraid to take a shot with some of the less showy offerings.

headline: God, Don’t Save the King
commentone: Slightly disagree. As some point out in these comments, a parliamentary system is vastly superior to our mess of a Congress, with its "rotten boroughs" in the Senate that would make George Eliot blush if she were an American writing a modern-day "Middlemarch." A parliamentary system would make a Prime Minister Trump very unlikely (even if Berlusconi in Italy was a tad similar). A constitutional monarchy would prevent the dangerous executive-branch excesses we have in the USA. We don't even need to look at Europe; just look north to our next-door neighbor Canada (where a national election campaign takes 6 weeks, another plus!). I'd agree that the "bicycle monarchs" of Northern Europe are better role models than the Windsors are.

The main goal for students is graduating and nothing else, their own personal needs are not as important as their grades. I interpreted in this way because I feel like most of my high school teachers just want me to pass their class, I feel like outside their class they don't care whether I'm doing well or not. The pressure being put on teenagers has drastically increased and it is just insane.
commenttwo: This photo to me represents the hysteria surrounding college. This photo is an example of how college is being viewed. Instead of college being an experience to help you grow and learn, it has turned into a monopoly obsessed with statistics and grades. Students are under extreme pressure, especially in their last years of high school. Almost all colleges have turned into a competition, and students only feel like a grade, and no longer like a person. The image shows no face of the student because it shows how a student is treated today. The only identity of a student lies in their statistics and grades.

commentone: is there anyone in the white house who can be believed on any given day? whatever is said one day is rescinded or changed the next.

commentone: I get what you are saying. But I will not make nice with the swamp people. I will continue to fight them.
commenttwo:
Ugh. The man who is never right about anything is lecturing Progressives. Why on earth would anyone listen to a thing you have to say?
How about the op ed page start cleaning house and give us someone whose opinions we respect? Start with Brooks...and move on to Dowd. She is supposed to be the progressive voice but is no more than someone who strokes her own ego by bashing Clintons or Obama. Thank God for Krugman.

headline: Intrigue in the House of Trump
commentone: The first axiom of a politician, and 45 has been one most of his life, is "If it benefits me, how can it be wrong".  We are currently witnessing this in spades.  Keep your eye on the ball, as the republican overlords and 45, roll back all the policies and laws that have made us the envy of the world.  Oh well....
commenttwo: One has to wonder whether the election of Trump was actually the worst result for the Trump family and for Putin.  Everything had been set up perfectly for hobbling a Clinton presidency with endless investigations, a hostile Congress, alternative news outlets spreading false claims, and legitimate news outlets primed to attack a favorite target.  The Trumps could have continued their shady, mafia-like operations unfettered by legal scrutiny.  Putin arguably could have continued to manipulate public opinion through social media without exposure.  But, as ineffective as a Clinton White House may have been rendered, the basic rules would have prevailed, our institutions would have remained strong, our environment would not be threatened, and our allies would continue to trust us.  In short: when Trump won, everyone lost.

headline: Is It Harder to Grow Up in the 21st Century Than It Was in the Past?
commentone: For the most part, I think that growing up in the 21st century is harder than it was in the past. There are many emerging national problems in today's society, such as the school shootings. Although there are certain aspects of the 21st century that make it an easier time to grow up in, for instance, advanced technology, there are also ever-increasing threats to society. When I have spoken with my parents about their childhood, they agree that it is harder to grow up in the 21st century than it was in the past. They were able to enjoy life more freely without having to worry about the problems of their surroundings.
commenttwo: Being a first generation American, I have always been told by my family that I am lucky to be in a country where I won‚Äö√Ñ√¥t have to deal with poverty. Having had to walk about 5 miles each day to collect drinking water, my family made it their goal to not have their children deal with the same things as them. That being said, while I don‚Äö√Ñ√¥t have to face the harsh reality of poverty, I do have to deal with other things that have been occurring. The 21st century has allowed for things such as rape, kidnapping, police brutality, and more to continue on and take shape in our country. We fear being away from a phone screen that we do not realise how much danger we put ourselves in. Before, children were innocent. They could go out of their houses and not have a care in the world. They didn‚Äö√Ñ√¥t know if the dangers that surrounded them. Now, some kids use these troublesome realities as an excuse to stay home. Technology wise, our generation has the upper-hand. But as many know, technology is like a double-edged sword. It allows from criminals to have easy access to targeting minors. This is one of the main reasons I believe that it is somewhat harder to grow up in the 21st century than in the past.

headline: Is ‘Black Panther’ a ‘Defining Moment’ for the United States — and Particularly for Black America?
commentone: I definitely do believe that Black Panther is a defining moment for Black America. Being a Black American in the US you grow up not really knowing where you come from. All you know is that your ancestors were considered 60 percent of a person and always had to change themselves to be accepted. Black Panther is celebrating what black people have been shamed for for many years, and now in a time where the BLM movement and Black Excellence is so widespread, it gives black people a sense of pride and a sense of belonging, like we are more connected to our roots. Having an all black cast where everyone is powerful, makes brown boys and girls feel like they can be powerful too. Even though other people might just see this as ‚Äö√Ñ√≤another superhero movie,‚Äö√Ñ√¥ I think it has sparked and will spark more conversation among black people, and forever be something we were glad we got to live through and see.
commenttwo: Black Panther was shown to a generation that truly needed it. Today in America we are at a point of such racial violence that people are scared of breathing because of their skin color. The Black Panther was created to give black children someone to look up to, their own Captain America. The movie showed a different side to the black men and women we commonly see on the screens. The men were shown as powerful and wise, not some drug dealing thug on the corner. The women were seen as strong and loyal to their country instead of just somebody's baby mama. It has taken 52 long years for everyone to notice such a hero, in the eyes of many, but now T'Challa gets his place in the sun

headline: Ivanka Trump’s Brand Building
commentone:
'... President Trump tweeted: ‚Äö√Ñ√∫My daughter, Ivanka, just arrived in South Korea. We cannot have a better, or smarter, person representing our country.‚Äö√Ñ√π '
He forgot to add the words 'utterly unqualified' to that statement.

commentone: The world's leaders knows what a moron Trump is, and will wait like the rest of us until normalcy prevails. He was always considered a joke, a sitcom President. Democrats are mistaken in assuming his level of ineptness could be the new normal. Come election time, more people will want to do the right thing. Democrats should make it easier for them and get a new message out. The problem is they're just not savvy enough.

headline: Keeper of the Flame
commentone:
I thought it was a great puzzle and I can only say I wish I had seen Rachel Maddow's show last night so that I could look forward to opening the paper with a little more than my usual Friday excitement. It started VERY slowly for me, but SVETLANA proved to be my foothold and then the rest filled itself in, although I had 'co'HOSTS before TVHOSTS. And I have never heard of SAZERAC. I kept trying to make 'sidecar' work.
I have to take issue with ERM. I think it should be either 'umm' or 'err'.
Otherwise, wonderful job.

headline: Kosovo’s Grand Hotel: Plenty of Pigeons and Cockroaches
commentone: Poor Kosovo. Still, it's a beautiful country as are its people.

headline: Late-Career Change: Play It Safe, or Ride It Out?
commentone: The questioner considering a career change does not reveal his or her gender. If she is a woman, she should be aware of the high unemployment rate for women over 50. Evidently our society feels women over 50 have less to offer. I certainly found this in my own job search after I lost my position due to a reorganization.

headline: Letting  Teenagers  Live
commentone: Americans lean towards following a trend rather than using judgement and reason. It isn't even divisive, as much as it is hypocritical and neurotic.
commenttwo: Thanks for making a very good point...statistics do matter and teen driving deaths could and should be lower. It is part of protecting kids! The same should go for older adults as well (and I'm one of them) testing should be more rigorous across the board.

headline: Lower the Voting Age to 16
commentone: Fooey.

headline: Make Better Movies Too
commentone:
Your idea is courageous, Lindy, but near impossible; efficacious change, without censorship, must be predicated on public opinion. Therein lies the haunt of the devil.
Consider the perverted nature of our culture. Divisive behavior is celebrated in government and in homes. Further, mindless wars, such as Vietnam, Iraq, Afghanistan..., suggest that American divisiveness can only be managed with violence.
This divisive violence enriches Madison Avenue as it fills movie theaters. Unfortunately, this leaves but censorship in the toolkit.
commenttwo: I was struck by one of the films that Ms. West compliments "Call Me By Your Name". She calls it an aching gay romance. Trying to avoid any spoilers, this is a film that is supposed to be about the relationship between a 24 year old American and a 17 year old American - Italian boy. The actor who plays Oliver  the American is 31 and looks it. The actor playing the young man Elio, who has been nominated for best actor, is actually 24 but looks 14. The film is nothing more or less then a soft core pedophilia tale. The film validates, through the character of the young man's father, the relationship even though Oliver has relentlessly manipulates the younger man's feelings. Now lets imagine that this was a film about an older man and a 17 year old woman who the older man gropes to express his desire. Would Ms. West have praised THIS film? Moonlight was a great film about characters who were gay, "Name" is a bad and mendacious film that is given slack just because it is about a same gender relationship.

headline: Mr. Trump’s Destructive Trade War
commentone:
There is another dirty unintended consequence to the proposed policy.

Steel production and aluminum production are two of the dirtiest air-polluting activities on planet earth. I read a headline from two days ago "China's top steelmaking city extends level 2 pollution alert". Aluminum production is equally toxic.

With a weakened EPA (whose current director had dissolved the Environmental Protection Unit in the Attorney General's office when he became Oklahoma's Attorney General), bringing back polluting industries will hurt American children's health. It is not just jobs lost to trade wars, but also health lost to sickness caused by dirty air that we are being threatened with. Make America's Air Dirty Again.

headline: Mr. Trump’s Problem With Democracy
commentone: Trump is dangerous. As usual, he casually tosses out ridiculous comments to test the waters, and then he slowly doubles down, repeating them every chance he gets until it becomes the new normal. He is a master at deception, and many are fooled by his techniques. Soon he‚Äö√Ñ√¥ll be saying, ‚Äö√Ñ√∫People are saying I should be President for life, look, many smart people like the idea...‚Äö√Ñ√π
commenttwo: Trump should be allowed to have his picture taken with Washington in the background.  Washington would surely feel used and disgraced.

commentone:
If you‚Äö√Ñ√¥re surprised by this turnaround, there‚Äö√Ñ√¥s some swamplands down in Florida and a bridge I‚Äö√Ñ√¥d like to sell you.
It was a bit sickening to see the Dems giddy about his supposed support for stricter gun laws. He‚Äö√Ñ√¥s always pulling the rug on us.
commenttwo: Everyone who is surprised raise their hand? Trump just put his foot on the neck of school children across the country. Cowardice and greed. His DNA.

headline: Nakesha’s Demons
commentone: The writer glossed over Nakesha's rape by the fathers of her children. How can impregnating a homeless person be anything but? As a wife and mother who had her children in a supportive environment, but nonetheless knows the toll a pregnancy takes on a woman, this situation with Nakesha warrants an investigation.
commenttwo: Thank you for this article. So touched by the story and the generosity of the people of NYC who cared for her. My brother John was a bright, athletic, promising college student when mental illness struck 30 years ago. He has lived in supported housing arrangements in a town where many of the locals have befriended and accepted him for who he is. He has pushed family away and the feelings of helplessness are devastating for us. But we are forever grateful to the community members and professionals who care for him non judgmentally.  I know Keesha's family must feel the same.

headline: Oil Was Central in Decision to Shrink Protected Utah Site, Emails Show
commentone:
It is easy to blame politicians for the destruction of public lands like this, but the underlying problem is the fossil fuel barons who buy the politicians, consistently showing contempt for those lands, caring nothing about their beauty, the wildlife, their potential to enrich the quality of life for those who want to coexist with nature. I recall a play the "Madwoman of Chaillot" that satirized their dark souls. They want nothing off-limits for them, Paris (in the play), national monuments, the beautiful California coast, the fragile Arctic, the rich fisheries off New England, Amazon rain forests, barrier reefs, and so on.
The fossil fuel industries may make money but they also contribute so much to destabilizing climate change and making the world ugly, polluted, and brutish.
commenttwo: Of course.  If there wasn't anything there, Trump's pals wouldn't care. They remind me of the English overlord of India, who when recalled to London on a charge of extortion and huge theft defended himself by saying that when he saw how much there was to be taken, he was surprised at his modesty.  Except Trump's pals wouldn't be modest in what they steal...leally of course, since they can make the rules.

headline: Plan for Tariffs Creates Divide In Trump Base
commentone:
Trump is closing the import gate long after the horse has bolted. I buy European cars because I have long been conditioned into believing that they are better than American ones. This didn't happen last year, it has been since the 90's.
If he slaps a tariff on imported European cars, I maybe will delay the purchase of a new one....but I probably won't buy an American one instead.
So, remind me again. In a trade war, who wins?

headline: Power to the Parents
commentone:
This is identity politics at its worst. This is conservatives scared of the votes of single mothers and Hispanics going to a party that wants strong public education, a workable health care system, and a healthy environment. This is a dark attempt to give more power to those who would just populate the world in the interest of their religion, while disregarding the rest of us and the earth we share.

It also is a very blatant attempt to push back on the growing movement for gun control. This is an effort to silence the emerging majority that is fed up with the wanton violence and extremist position on guns in our society. These young people will be taking care of all us one day, least we can do is give them a voice and listen to them now.

Such a valid point and so relevent at this time; made extra meaningful because it is written by a male writer (Frank Bruni). And as a man myself, who respects women who repect themselves, I have to express my disappointment that there are still many women who "enable" this sexual abuse behavior . And stupid popular films like Fifty Shades of Grey ; a total chick-flick with 2 sequels , which glorifies female sexual submission.

headline: Saying a Prayer I Don’t Believe In
commentone:
As an atheist I see prayers like this endlessly repeating that "God" is wonderful, great, holy.... a holdover from an earlier era when powerful kings needed to be constantly praised, their ego stroked, to keep away their depredations or to get favors. Its the same in Christianity, Islam (Allah Akbar etc) - don't any believers have a concept of a God that is bored by empty praise and would prefer intelligent observations? No, I guess there too few such kings in the old days.
Or maybe people say these prayers in often unfamiliar languages, be it Hebrew, Latin, Arabic... because of they knew what they were really saying it would sound so silly.
commenttwo:
When Jay points out that there is a gap between our devotion to practice, and the literal meaning of the practice, I think he's making a great point about the force of liturgy and ritual.

However, its sad that Jay doesn't think he can believe the prayer. Because prayer is even more powerful when we do believe the things we say.

More than that, I think the author misses the point of the phrase "in the world which he created according to his will," when he writes:
" Whatever its origins, the text of the prayer leaves me cold. Each day as I say the Kaddish, I struggle with the fact that I am praising a God who, according to Jewish tradition, created the world ‚Äö√Ñ√∫according to His Will.‚Äö√Ñ√π Does God really will that the world endure the cruelty and suffering we see so often?"

He seems to think that the Kaddish indicates that God is happy with the world as it is. That's actually the opposite point of the Kaddish. The immediately following phrase says, "May he establish his kingdom in our lifetime and in our days." The idea of ‚óä√ª‚óä√∫‚óä√µ‚óä√Ø‚óä‚Ñ¢ ‚óä¬©‚óä√ª‚óä√¥‚óä√π "the kingdom of God," is a vision of a transformed world in which things finally are as they should be.
So, if/when our encounter with death or with dehumanizing diseases like Alzheimers (which is particularly harsh for the family members), prompt us to conquer those diseases, or improve the human condition, then we are actually advancing ‚óä√ª‚óä√∫‚óä√µ‚óä√Ø‚óä‚Ñ¢ ‚óä¬©‚óä√ª‚óä√¥‚óä√π the way God wants the world to be.
How does that sound to you?
What do you think?

headline: State Dept. Holds Funds Aimed to Fight Meddling
commentone: In the movie "The Godfather", the family lawyer refuses to accept a letter for Michael saying that if he accepted it, it might be argued that he knew where Michael was hiding out.  Apparently, Mr. Tillerson saw the movie and took the scene to heart; if he accepts the money he might be implicitly acknowledging that the Russians interfered in the election, and The Boss of All Bosses ("Capo Tuti Capo"), aka The Don, Trump, might be implicated.  Life imitates art.

headline: The Challenge of Doctor-Patient Relations in the Internet Age
commentone: As a psychiatrist, i take very seriously my ethical obligation to offer my patients, to the best of my clinical judgement,  the treatments which are most likely to work for them. I welcome my patients' choosing to research my proposed treatments first before starting them. Either they are reassured and thus more likely to believe in the treatment( several studies indicate the more a patient believes a treatment will work,  the more likely it is to work). Or they are better able to articulate particular reservations,  allowing me to speak more directly to their concerns, often leading us to better figure out a treatment plan they are comfortable with. And I would be remiss if I did not admit there are many instances where I have become better informed as a result of my patient's reading.

headline: The Danger of Waiting for a Wave
commentone: In retrospect, we all should have been marching in the streets when Mitch McConnell refused to hold hearings on Obama's Supreme Court Nominee.  I guess the Democratic/Liberal/Progressives that cared were fairly confident that it wouldn't matter because Hillary would win and we'd get our Justice anyway.  The focus now needs to be on Ryan et. al. who continue to fail the American people by not doing their Constitutional job of putting a check on a president who is demonstrably NOT preserving, protecting and defending the Constitution. We (D's) seem so willing to play by the rules (wait for the election!) ; if there is no wave what other choice is there? Do we really just throw our hands up and wait another two years while this administration dismantles the government further? No -  other tactics will be necessary. Hopefully not violent, but a whole heck of a lot of civil disobedience - likely from the very young and the very old. I'll be there.

headline: The Escalation of Love
commentone: How thoroughly agonizing. No one would want this slow and sad end of days for their mom or loved one. I can't imagine it would be anyone's wish to exist in this state for years, let alone the impact on their families. Love makes us do difficult things though at what cost?
commenttwo: What a beautiful piece. Yes, the decline of a parent is awful to watch. As the children we compel ourselves to rise out of the pain and hurt we experienced at this parent's hands, mouth, hard heart and general cruelty. My mother was cruel; she enjoyed hurting us on all levels, reducing us to tears. She suffered from dementia and died in a nursing home. My brothers, sister and I stayed at her bedside determined to have her not die alone. We owed ourselves the chance to love her in death as she never allowed us to love her in life. We did her nails, washed her hands, applied lotion and combed her wild woman hair. We stroked her arms and let her know it was okay to go. The sharing of the experience of her dying and our giving strengthened our sibling bond. We remain thankful to this day for the opportunity presented us to rise above the pain in our hearts and see her off with love and dignity. For me, being able to treat her with love and dignity allowed me to leave all my pain at her bedside. I walked away a free daughter.  I will always be grateful for that gift.

headline: The Macroeconomics of Trade War
commentone:
It would also be interesting to find out the production capacity utilization by the steel and aluminum manufacturers. If they are close to the max, the tariff will likely have a seriously negative effect as the domestic production will not be able to meet the demand. These industries do not likely enjoy a quick and flexible capacity adjustment.

The steelworkers, unions seem to favor this move as I heard on TV from a union leader. I am not exactly sure how and what kind of positive results they may expect from the tariffs. If they think it will raise their wages, I suspect they are sorely mistaken.

There are some concerns, quite possibly valid concerns that China may be dumping steel into the market. That is possible through government subsidies in most instances. What makes anyone think that they will not simply increase the government subsidies even with the tariffs in place and still dump their products at low prices.

Hard to see the logic of the tariffs and trade wars.
commenttwo: I don't think this impulsive new tariff is good economics or good diplomacy. But I do not think it is just an angry fit of spleen dumped on the world by our chaotic president. It strikes me as more of a political strategy aimed at shoring up republican support in the rust belt states for the mid term congressional election   which is only months away. It is a campaign promise kept.

headline: The Rise of  Dictatorship  Incorporated
commentone: Iran, North Korea, Russia, Syria are authoritarian governments not under our control so we don't like them but our similarly authoritarian governments in Egypt, Turkey, Philippines, Saudi Arabia, Poland, Afghanistan etc are fine with us.  So the issue is not dictatorships, it is the great game of international power politics in which as usual most of the people of the world, including in the US that foots a lot of the bill, are the losers.

headline: The Supreme Court’s Power Play Against Labor
commentone:
This is not about free speech, obviously anti-union workers are free to speak out and even try to decertify the union - it is about greedy corporations and their lackeys out to destroy any countervailing power to corporate rule. Now they are going in for the kill of the union movement so they have a much freer hand to exploit their workers, evade taxes, contribute to the social safety net...
We can see the future - even more income inequality with the well to do having more money and power than they know what to do with, many living as lords in gated communities while outside the many struggle with health care, utility bills, housing, retirement income, crime...
But to some extent the unions had it coming - when in power the union bosses top-down rule ignored rank and file, voted big pay to themselves thinking this could go on forever, and many of the members helped elect the very people appointing the judges who will be sticking it to them.
commenttwo: This is all about defunding the Democratic Party by destroying unions. We are seeing a wholesale takeover of our government by a single party conspiring to destroy the opposition.

commenttwo: When I first scanned this headline, I was sure the story was all about the chaos inside The White House!

commentone: But, but, but trump knows all!!!
commenttwo:
Trade war is NOT going to happen, because the US tariffs will NEVER be enacted.

An even bigger scandal will create cover to take attention away from the threatened trade wars. The threat of trade war succeeded in taking attention from anything happening on gun control. commentone: Why give an asinine move credibility by calling it "bold". It's simply another of Trump's ill though out, base mollifying blunder.

headline: Trump Proclaims Tariffs On Steel and Aluminum, And Stocks Sag in Reply
commentone: Another idiotic move by the child-president Clown, who, as it turns out, actually knows very little about business and even less about...well...everything else.
commenttwo:
Hang on. It's going to be a bumpy night.

For starters watch Canada slap 25% tariff on its auto imports from the US.

headline: Trump: King of Chaos
commentone:
Trump's chaos is a manifestation of a level of impulsiveness that seems to be inherent in his disordered personality. Sadly, the impulsiveness, matched with a virtual indifference to whether anything he said was right, made him an effective candidate. People thought he was more authentic and different from more typical people who have risen in political organizations, who are used to making more measured statements and are considerate of the consequences of what they say and do. To be an effective governor, senator or representative, at some point you have to convince people you work with that you are reasonable, even if reasonable can get defined in remarkably different ways. Trump ran a family business that could never fire him. It was a business that mainly traded on his celebrity, but tried to pass it off as business acumen. His bankruptcies and the anguished reminiscences of his ghost writers are testimony to how phony this is.

Trump managed to combine his impulsiveness masquerading as authenticity with just the right amount of paranoia to successfully demonize his opposition in a way that found its political moment.

Trump now lives in a world where words have meaning and is lost. He used to be able to rant, make headlines, promote his brand, be irritating and get ignored beyond the occasional lawsuit.

Sad and dangerous to watch this unfold.

headline: Trump’s Call to Arm Teachers Resonates at Schools That Do
commentone: The Capitol Building, White House, and Supreme Court building all have metal detectors to protect the people to work inside. Maybe that's why most of the legislators, justices, and executives aren't as concerned about gun proliferation as those of us who work in elementary schools or go out dancing. I'm being (a little) facetious. Still, I'd love it if someone would tell me why the second amendment rights end right outside the doors of power, but the rest of us are left vulnerable.

headline: When Elder Abuse Is Self-Inflicted
commentone:
The individual's right to autonomy can be a death sentence for people like the gentleman in this article.
The elderly mother of a friend of mine -- in her 80s and living alone since the death of her husband -- had been sliding into dementia for some time. She had stopped bathing, wouldn't dispose of spoiled food, and refused all outside help. My friend was desperate -- appealing to elder services and to the mother's own physician for help in obtaining the authority to move her mother into assisted living, where she would have care and supervision -- and was thwarted at every turn; told, in fact, that she might have to wait for an accident or emergency to happen. There was a power of attorney and health care proxy in place, but no one would help her to invoke it, saying that the mother's autonomy had to be protected.
In the end an accident did occur, and the mother was deemed incompetent to make her own decisions. The outcome could have been far worse.
Who, exactly, was served by honoring the mother's right to autonomy over her health and safety?

headline: Wily Trump Aide Nurtures Her Access and Influence
commentone:
The people who went before her are under indictment, outed as a violent abuser, toxic nationalists, and Omarosa. Hanging on isn't really much of an accomplishment.

In reality, it's treasonous to support and enable the amount of chaos emanating from the White House. Her detractors and fans have one thing in common, she has lied to them both from her gilded pulpit.

One can only believe they all do it for self-aggrandizement and under delusions created by media outlets that lie.
commenttwo:
`Kellyanne Conway Steps Back ...'

Not far enough. This woman has forgotten how to tell the truth, which makes her a perfect fit for the National Embarrassment. Trump spent hours the other day talking about gun control. When asked about the surprising - and confusing - session, Conway said the session had nothing to do with gun control. The `president' was merely talking about `school safety'. A silly woman whose contempt for the truth will be her legacy.

headline: Your Kid’s Phone Is Not Like a Cigarette
commentone: If you don't want to worry about how your children are using technology, don't buy it for them.  They will have plenty of time to learn about social media when they can afford to buy their own technology.

headline: 5G Cell Service Is Coming. Critics Fear the Stations Will Look Like ‘a Medusa.’
commentone:
5G and it's components an eyesore? BOO HOO! For those of us in rural areas the idea of any reliable cell/internet would be most welcome!
Why cell and internet services are not regulated utilities yet is beyond me.

headline: A Trump Fawners Almanac
commentone: To Trump, the Attorney General was supposed to come fur-wrapped with the turned, tanned skins of his enemies.

headline: A Whole Lot Is Riding On This New ‘Wrinkle’
commentone: I loved this book as a kid and absolutely related to the character of Meg, even though I was an Asian American girl and she was written as white. Like other commenters, I was initially shocked by the bright color palette in the movie's trailer and had to get used to the changes from my mind's original images. But I am really rooting for this film and for Ms. DuVernay and for Disney's overall intention to diversify Hollywood. I just hope they honor the book's intimacy and, frankly, its cerebral quality; because to me, the book is about the journey of a girl to embracing her own brilliance and then using her strengths to find her father.

headline: At Heart of Tight Race, Folks Who Picked Trump But Wish They Hadn’t
commentone:

headline: Classic Letter Puzzle
commentone:
Untune is clued correctly and is a real verb. When a player makes all the strings harmonize, she tunes; when, in the middle of a performance, she does the same thing, she retunes. When she wants to have a different pitch for one or more of the strings for a given piece of music, she detunes. When she purposefully takes the strings off correct tension without regard to pitch, she untunes.

There are a couple of reasons why someone might untune a stringed instrument: if it is to be stored under bad conditions (esp. high heat), if work is being done on the bridge or the tailpiece or strings are being replaced, if the instrument has both fine and coarse tuners and the fine ones are too tense, or to pull an especially mean prank on a neighboring violinist. I've been impressed by the clueing in NYT puzzles that has kept untune, detune, retune correctly distinct.
commenttwo: Yay. The revealer's "three _down_" should serve as a prompt for those who are thinking the themers are the three _across_ answers, to finally sort out today's Witty Ditty.

headline: How Liberals Can Reclaim Nationalism
commentone:
"One of the greatest political challenges of our age requires 'principled resistance' to right wing nationalism"? Hogwash! This is political navel-gazing at its worse. Zen stuck in its own nothingness. A maya tone deaf to the allusions arrayed in imaginations removed from blood and tears. Yes, there is a danger in "blood and soil." But right wing nationalism hides its roots! It flag-wraps xenophobia/racism/misogyny; authoritarianism, the discredited beliefs of white supremacists, neo-Nazis, violent radicals and cultists under a phantasmagoria of glorious nightmares. It proffers a paradise of oppression controlled by a force of righteous, elite fools who get everything wrong. Their false conspiracies about student shootings embolden chaos! Inert to indifference and greed, nationalists use scapegoats to slip the yoke and ally with power and wealth.

This threat, is not the "greatest" we face! It is marginal, compared to the realities at its roots. First, nationalism is a response to non-national conflicts; fierce, modern attacks against citizens by competing groups armed with modern weapons of war. Financed by nations who use these groups as proxies in Syria, Iran, Turkey, Iraq, Sudan. Inside Myanmar, North Korea, Thailand, the Philippines, these armed conflicts ignore state boundaries to target civilians, creating the largest displacement of citizens in modern times, disrupting schooling, employment, opportunity. Nationalism is a symptom--not a solution--that makes this worst!

But his subjective flourishes take on objective meaning, when his thoughts on democracy are offered in public. Presidents are normally grounded in the ideals of democracy, aware of the consequences of ill-spoken words. Especially words that undermine the ideals celebrated in our glorious union. Trump called our system rigged, indulged in make-believe about 3 million phantom voters without hard proof. He means it when he says neo-Nazis and many good Americans have common ground. headline: Nakesha’s Demons
commentone:
Yes, you never know the story of the person next to you. And, what if we carried that awareness with us every moment of each day? What if we chose kindness, as so many of those who encountered Nakesha did? How might our world be changed by that simple choice?

That is what will stay with me from this magnificent story of one life and all those who were touched by it--that I must continue to do that noble work of choosing kindness every waking moment of my life.

There's no question that our own painful memories combined with the pace of most of our lives can make this hard work. Nonetheless, it is really the only work worth doing, and that work is never wasted whatever the outcome.

Thank you Benjamin Weiser for sharing this story of how one life can touch and transform so many others. I wish the newspaper were filled with more stories of people at their best instead of at their worst.

headline: Saying a Prayer I Don’t Believe In
commentone:
Living in Charleston, I often visit colonial headstones. With no natural rock, the local churches have the best examples of New England grave markers because of temperate weather. Amon the carving and manifold cultural forms, winged skulls, infant cradles (inscribed, memento mori!), recognizable cameos whose coats have buttons (status), left handed angels, women cited as relics (her husband died first), secret iconography in flowers and feathers, enclosed by fences with shafted spear points: in medieval times, a fallen knight was protected by a ring of spears, so are the dead protected against evil.

These formulas of inner meaning., repeated because they were felt, took on new meaning. Prayer has context. Repetition contrasts the journey of living; prayer helps mark that distance/direction.

If prayer seems to mock our cruelty, it reminds us of free will. That sin, sickness, even death is not singular, but a common act. Blocked by self-serving desires, our pain and need for blame, prayer points to the gift we have abused. Prayer celebrates divine freedom and condemns the folly of men. God gives the joys and glory of freedom; we immediately disregard a few rules and find collective ways to defile our gifts by self-seeking desires and the allusions of temptations. Prayer says forgive the faults which are our own. Glory to God!

I offer this prayer, its history in a Smithsonian recording from the 1930s, the source of my own epiphany: "Lord, give them better."

headline: Senate Intelligence Panel Says House G.O.P. Leaked a Senator’s Texts
commentone:
Truly bad, misleading lede.

‚Äö√Ñ√∫behind the leak of private text messages between the Senate panel‚Äö√Ñ√¥s top Democrat and a Russian-connected lawyer,‚Äö√Ñ√π

It makes it sound as if Warner, like Trump, was somehow complicit of secret dealings with shady Russians...

In fact, he was making contact with a lawyer who knows Steele, the former British intelligence agent who authored a series of reports on *Trump's* election complicity and Russian connections, in order to set up a meeting with the Senate Intelligence Committee. The outreach was known to the members of the SIC, and OK'd by the Republican chair, so it was neither secret, nor shady, but an integral part of their investigation into *Trump's* Russia dealings.

The fact that the lawyer's firm has represented a Russian oligarch in the past is irrelevant, although in Trump's usual attempt at deflection, in which he projects his own misdeeds and nature onto others, Trump will tweet and shout like crazy over it!

Lying, Crooked, Little, Low Energy Donny Boy will eventually get his comeuppance.

headline: The Challenge of Doctor-Patient Relations in the Internet Age
commentone:
All doctors will love this article, it maintains the status quo that doctors know better. They hate to be challenged. Well, get over it.

I routinely ask my doctor: Why? What else is possible? and so forth. I can now challenge his/her medical opinion and listen to their reasoning. The difference is now I may have some facts to ask my question in the right way. Medicine is not always a simple answer and only a single treatment.

Doctors of today are much more knowledgeable than those that came before but less likely to offer a more simple resolve to a patients issue. Many times I suspect that the solution is governed by institution rules (ie. legal and insurance rules) rather than what is the best medicine.

Case in point. I had a small piece of glass in my foot. Today's doctor a GP said that a surgeon is required to remove the glass from my foot. He was not able just to take 2 minutes and remove the piece. I think my doctor of the 1960s would have done so with ease and safety. I went the route of self doctoring with no issues.

So I believe an informed patient is a good patient. After all, it is their body.

headline: Trade War, What Is It Good For? Absolutely Nothing
commentone:
Trump continually thinks stupid is clever! He has evolved a language of excuses to shed responsibility, words that make him both victim and victor (election/immigration/gun control), a logic that frames every loss as a win (healthcare, trade). His winning formula? Protest, punch, and punish.
Wilbur Ross' aluminum cans pretend tariffs have minuscule effect. He should display Caterpillar's hydraulic mining shovel or a GE diesel turbine, better demonstrations of the costs of Trump's latest ‚Äö√Ñ√∫win.‚Äö√Ñ√π

In fact, every Trump ‚Äö√Ñ√∫win‚Äö√Ñ√π is expensive! Each burdens the public. Healthcare pays for corporate tax cuts which buy back billions in private stock--the public treasury is transferred to private entities. Private costs become public deficits. People are scattered statistics in a tilted balance sheet that shows how easy it is to deregulate by fiat and kill for profit.

Flint still lives with the pallor of poison in its water. The waters of the Dan River (NC) still turn up dead fish from a coal ash spill, as Pruitt removes regulations that protect people living along its streams. Blow out regulations on oil rigs are more lax than before the Gulf spill. Now tariffs: Is raising taxes and raising prices really winning? Republicans once called it socialism, this corruption of free markets which increase profits and costs by handicapping competition. To Trump, this is America winning. We can't afford many more of his victories.

headline: Trump: King of Chaos
commentone:
Fantasy-led government is a reality. Charles deconstructs:

‚Äö√Ñ√∫On the one hand, he [Trump] latches on to outlandish ideas, or simple, emotional aspects of complicated issues, or conspiratorial drivel, and he vests the whole of his emotional energy into proving their veracity, often against overwhelming evidence to the contrary.

President Obama wasn‚Äö√Ñ√¥t born in America. . . There were good people on both sides in Charlottesville. The ‚Äö√Ñ√∫fake news media‚Äö√Ñ√π is the enemy of the American people. The whole Russia investigation is a hoax. He‚Äö√Ñ√¥s doing a good job as president.

On the other hand, . . . his convictions are not fixed at all, but ephemeral and fleeting, changing from moment to moment, . . .

This is when you can see that he is clearly faking it. He wants so desperately to be right that he says whatever his audience--whether that be a small group or a filled arena, whether that be members of Congress or fans at a rally--want to hear and will respond to.

This is how you can get wildly vacillating positions and bold, empty promises in bipartisan meetings.

And one thing that clearly comes across in those meetings is how much he talks rather than listens. It‚Äö√Ñ√¥s all about what he believes, what he would do, how courageous he is, how conciliatory he is, how smart he is about the subject.

That is precisely how you know that none of it is true, and that he is simply stringing together a jumble of words into conflicting ideas. You see a fear of being exposed as an idiot and fraud."
commenttwo:
Charles' gift for writing, its craft and words, its eye and sound, its honesty and mystic, is a gift for all seasons. Writing starts with empty space. The writer takes his or her invisible thoughts and expresses them in letters that sound sound to the eye.

When writing is bad, we turn away. When it's good, we are riveted, unable to turn away. Count me as awaiting his Pulitzer as I read with an admiring gaze (and secret envy! Charles proves there is a God; I wish he would give me just a little of these glorious gifts.). In the meantime, for the craft and composition of thought, he deserves the Pulitzer. This is among the finest, most gifted writing of this era!

Remember in "The Wrath of Khan" when Spock realized that Khan was only thinking two-dimensionally? headline: The Challenge of Doctor-Patient Relations in the Internet Age
commentone:
Diagnosed with diverticulitis [an intestinal infection], the ER doctor told me to eat lots of fiber etc. I researched it when I went home [on reputable sites, e.g., Mayo Clinic etc.] and found that this was the polar opposite of what I should do -- with an active infection you need to baby your GI tract with pablum. The fiber etc. is for preventing future flare ups once you're healthy. Good thing I could and did check online, eh! The uninformed doctors are out there.

That said, I had great respect for my primary care doctor and trusted her judgement, because we had had time to develop a relationship and I had had opportunity to assess her capabilities. I still followed up with my own research and she seemed to respect my active involvement in my health and my desire to have a dialogue. Note that I never marched in with "the internet says you're wrong so I'm not doing it." It was more, "I read X at the Mayo Clinic site, what do you think about this?" and she would usually have a very good answer.

Many people do not have the opportunity to establish trust with a certain doctor. And some doctors are not actually that informed. On the other hand a good doctor, on top of her game, who knows you, and whom you can actually get in to see, may have deep professional insight of a type that can't be gleaned even from the most reputable medical website. As you search for this unicorn, protect yourself by being an intelligent consumer of reputable health information.

headline: Democrats Face Primary Shove From New Left
commentone:
We are simply too big and diverse to have only two major parties. The United States is probably the least homogenous nation on earth and our ethos fosters individuality. So how can two parties possibly represent all our views?
It would seem that each of the two majors, should split into at least two, far left, center left, center right and far right.
A candidate could be much more authentic if she didn't have to support hot button party orthodoxies (say, abortion rights on one side or Second Amendment on the other) while still appealing to centrist voters.
Term limits, an end to gerrymandering and more political parties would allow for representation that actually reflects the views of real voters.

headline: How the Left Wins the Culture War
commentone:

In my lifetime, our culture has turned its back on lynchers, rapists, wife beaters and drunk drivers. Yes, in the 1950s those were the good ol' boy bullies that the sheriff would protect and decent citizens were afraid of.
There will always be people of low moral character with violent and self-centered egos. The best way to defeat them is to expose their uncivilized behavior, call it out and paint their affiliates as guilty by association.
Today those good ol' boys are prancing around in the mantle of "patriotism" and "family values", otherwise known as the Republican Party. But the veneer is washing away and the bully buddies are being exposed for what they are.

Decent people need to move away from the bully class and the Democratic Party needs to give them a safe place to move to.
Responsible gun owners are not the problem, the vast majority of men are not sexual predators, and a large portion of truly religious people actually only want to do good for humankind.
Republicans demonize blacks, hispanics, gays, women who are not compliant, Muslims, welfare recipients and the poor. The Democratic Party does not need to start labeling and demonizing groups and classes of people. Expose the actual perpetrators for the hypocrites they are.

headline: How the Tet Offensive Broke America
commentone:
I was there, a 24 year old infantry platoon leader in the Delta. Not long after TET, I was wounded for the second time and nearly died in a Saigon hospital from the infection that ravaged my entire body after have spent hours in a rice paddy canal neck deep in contaminated water after a horrific enemy ambush.

The VC had quickly rebounded from the drubbing they suffered during TET, they were as lethal, crafty, and determined as ever. From that point forward their numbers would be bolstered by more and more North Vietnamese regulars.

I spent another 25 years serving as an infantry officer.

I am convinced of one undeniable and persistent fact, that the so called lesson of Vietnam was in fact never learned, it was a fiction and a delusion proven without question in the contrived invasion of Iraq in 2003, and our subsequent 16 year war there and in Afghanistan ‚Äö√Ñ√Æ both with no end currently in sight.

headline: Letting  Teenagers  Live
commentone:

headline: Nakesha’s Demons
commentone: This story is proof that it is not possible to force a mentally ill person (with probable schizophrenia) to seek treatment if that person does not wish to be treated, or does not consider herself to be mentally ill. I wish that all those who are saying that we need "better mental health services" (as they do after every school shooting) would read this story.
commenttwo:
What a tragic story. A promising life cut short by mental illness. As I read this, I thought of my cousin's wife. She was beautiful, like Nakesha, and from a prominent family. Her father was a university president.

After giving birth, her personality changed, and she started the deep descent into mental illness, paralleling Nakesha's story. Her husband, my cousin I'm sorry to say, divorced her instead of helping her. He's a psychologist by trade. She slept on the streets, and like Nakesha, had a baby, who was raised by my cousin's daughter, a girl still in college. Unfortunately, I was a student myself, and too far removed geographically.

To this day I wonder what happened to her. Similar stories, similar fates, Nakesha and my cousin's wife. Both beauties, both extremely intelligent. Nakesha's superb talent and immense creativity were unsurpassable, and the world will be lesser for it. Had she received the help and medication she needed, she could have been a household name. How sad.

We really need to step up to the plate in this oh-so-wealthy country, and take care of our mentally ill. Our next candidates in 2018 and in 2020 need to include mental health on their agendas. Thanks to the New York Times writers and researchers who put this story together. And above all, thanks to the many people - friends and strangers - who tried to help this lovely woman.

headline: Romance, Rough Sex or Rape?
commentone:
Mr. Bruni‚Äö√Ñ√¥s comments can of course be expanded to apply to all the arts.

One of a very famous rock quartet‚Äö√Ñ√¥s songs even warns the young woman in question that ‚Äö√Ñ√≤I‚Äö√Ñ√¥d rather see you dead . . . than to be with another man.‚Äö√Ñ√¥

Rap is justly infamous for its manifold threats against hos (or ‚Äö√Ñ√≤hoes‚Äö√Ñ√¥), including random pronouncements of death sentences that derive from nothing more than masculine fits of pique.

As a result of just finishing some time with a search engine, I was shocked to discover that the theme of feminine love aroused by being kidnapped figures in hundreds, perhaps thousands, of movies made around the globe.

Everyone knows the outline of this kind of sexual Stockholm Syndrome, even if they‚Äö√Ñ√¥re unfamiliar with the phrase. Man kidnaps beautiful woman. Beautiful woman risks her life to break out of his trap but fails to escape. Whether through wiles or violence, kidnapper makes woman his lover. She melts, falling deeply in love when confronted with the full force of his ‚Äö√Ñ√≤passion.‚Äö√Ñ√¥

As a special bonus, through the magic of time lapse, the viewer may be treated to a profile of the woman‚Äö√Ñ√¥s baby bump and an accompanying close-up of her blissful smile. If you've been seeking the ultimate male fantasy, there it is.

William Burroughs advised us ‚Äö√Ñ√≤never to forget our glorious simian heritage.‚Äö√Ñ√¥ As long as male-oriented arts remain buoyant, despite the present push to feminize movies, we‚Äö√Ñ√¥ll have reason to remember Burroughs‚Äö√Ñ√¥ advice.

headline: Saying a Prayer I Don’t Believe In
commentone:
Bless You Sir. Keep talking to God and he will answer you. Your doubts will be erased.
As for me, I place all my trust and faith in Jesus Christ. It is unwavering.
commenttwo:
As a liberal Protestant I'm with you all the way in this. A good church, or synagogue, mosque, or temple, in my considered opinion, is a good community.

Protestants recite the Apostles' creed from time to time. I don't "believe" it as a set of propositions that describe reality. I do believe it in the important sense that it reminds me of my membership in a community extending across time of those who take their relationships with each other and the larger world seriously. I do believe in a transcendent or ultimate good, although I doubt I can express or understand it as a set of propositions. It's possible if not probable that those who come later and share my concerns will look on my understanding of God in the same way that I regard the 5th C. ideas expressed in the Apostle's Creed. Do justice, love mercy, and walk humbly with thy God.

headline: The Escalation of Love
commentone: This essay really touched me and reminded me of how my relationship with Mom changed over the years as she declined. It always amazed me when she said she was grateful to me for taking care of her ‚Äö√Ñ√¨ even while she was so angry about all that was happening to her. Ms. Solod‚Äö√Ñ√¥s description of what happened at the end of her last visit with her mother was like when, shortly before Mom died, she reached up to stroke my cheek when I was crying. And like when, toward the end of her life, she‚Äö√Ñ√¥d stroke my hair if I laid my head in her lap. In many ways she became more loving to me as she progressed with her dementia ‚Äö√Ñ√¨ of course, those moments happened in the midst of times when she‚Äö√Ñ√¥d yell or slap my face in anger about having to do something she didn‚Äö√Ñ√¥t want to do (take meds, shower, be required to have someone walk with her so she wouldn‚Äö√Ñ√¥t wander off) or tell me I was ‚Äö√Ñ√∫just dumping her‚Äö√Ñ√π when I had to move her to the secure Alzheimer‚Äö√Ñ√¥s facility. What a roller coaster of emotions, but what an incredibly personal experience to have had with her.
commenttwo:
Dementia has enabled Lisa Solod to project feelings onto her relationship with her mother that otherwise wouldn't exist. Finally she has some measure of control over this brutally destructive force in her life.

As my elderly mother has declined physically, her mind has remained sharp. A vicious, sadistic, resentful narcissist, she continues to damage her grown children every chance she gets. Two of my sisters are martyring themselves in a hopeless quest to finally win her approval before she dies. It would be easier on them if they could, like Solod, scratch her on the head like a cat and interpret random nonabusive interactions as love.

No wonder then there is pressure for  other measures harking back to the 1920s and 1930s: racially discriminatory immigration restrictions and "beggar my neighbor" tariffs.  The world's last experience in the 1930s with a demented leader of a major world power did not end well, when 100 million are estimated to have died in WW2.  We still do not know the bill in harm to humanity and the planet that will be presented as a result of Donald Trump's presidency.  It will probably be large unless he is stopped soon.

headline: The Rise of  Dictatorship  Incorporated
commentone:
Given the US record of creating chaos in the Mideast, the utmost caution in relation to the American military expedition in Syria, which is ongoing, must be exercised.

George W. Bush, with his 2003 invasion of Iraq, and Obama, in an inevitable recoil from the mess left by Bush, inadvertently opened the land corridor that Iran has used to link up with Iraq, Syria, Russia in Syria, and Hezbollah in Syria and Lebanon.

Now the main Western effort must be to keep matters in Syria and Lebanon from exploding into a huge conflict that would bring genocide to the region, including to Israel and Saudi Arabia, and bolster Russia by taking out oil fields in Saudi Arabia, Iraq, and Iran.

Since Putin has so little regard for human life, the oil side of the equation may be his main motivation, a fact unmentioned by Mr. Stephens.

A catastrophic war that shut off the oil flowing from the Gulf region would cause all Europe and much of the rest of the world to bow down to a Russia that is rich in exportable oil and natural gas.

True, the US has vast oil supplies of its own, but the great majority of those supplies are used to quench the overwhelming American thirst for petroleum and its by-products.

In short, Putin may well have intervened in the Mideast with a view to setting up a situation in which millions of people would lose, but from which he could walk away with a vast increase in global power. Certainly, he doesn‚Äö√Ñ√¥t fear the worst, which for him might represent the best.

headline: Trade War, What Is It Good For? Absolutely Nothing
commentone: Trump won in part by promising he would get tough on trade.  He promised the 44% of Americans who voted for him that just having him, a master negotiator, as president, would change America's future.  He, and the "tough" negotiators appointed by him, would jaw-bone foreign adversaries (China, Mexico, Canada, the EU) to give America a better deal.  All previous trade agreements were bad for Trump, and had given away the store.  Obama and Hillary were just more of the same.  But Trump would bring back American manufacturing with a roar.  That, and restricting immigration and keeping out colored and Muslim immigrants, would make America great again.  There is one thing in all this thread of argument and bogus logic: it's pure rubbish.  Trump is a pathological liar, con man, ignoramus, and cheat.  He scammed America.  Not only is he ignorant of every policy area including trade and immigration, he doesn't care that he doesn't know, but believes he knows more than any expert.  That's the definition of the dangerous fool.  America is heading for rough times, but the world also, thanks to America's choice (helped by Putin) in 2016.
commenttwo:
There is some truth in Trump's comment about being "down" with other countries. The countries that run the trade surpluses, especially China, are the ones who should fear a trade war the most as they have more to lose. In order to get concessions - for example to get China and other countries to quit dumping, which is still common - it may be necessary to threaten a trade war. When the other countries are threatened, they will reply in kind, but such counterthreats may be largely empty. But the US has power in these things which it has not been using, or which it has been using in the primary interests of corporate profits rather than those of American workers.

Winning even a war of bluffs will not be simple or easy, and Canada is not the country to even threaten a war with. But there is no reason to let China get away with things like its obvious currency manipulation, as Krugman has said before.

headline: Trump Proclaims Tariffs On Steel and Aluminum, And Stocks Sag in Reply
commentone:
‚Äö√Ñ√∫The United States Constitution gives Congress the power to impose and collect taxes, tariffs, duties, and the like, and to regulate international commerce. While the Constitution gives the President authority to negotiate international agreements, it assigns him no specific power over international commerce and trade. Through legislation, however, Congress may delegate some of its power to the President, such as the power to modify tariffs under certain circumstances. Thus, because the President does not possess express constitutional authority to modify tariffs, he must find authority for tariff-related action in statute.‚Äö√Ñ√π

This from the Congressional Research Service Paper: Presidential Authority over Trade: Imposing Tariffs and Duties.

The seminal question is whether the GOP Congress will continue to abet Trump‚Äö√Ñ√¥s hugely dangerous antics. Hardly a day passes that the fomenter of chaos in chief doesn‚Äö√Ñ√¥t roll out another crisis utterly of his own making.

headline: Trump’s Call to Arm Teachers Resonates at Schools That Do

It sounds like some school districts in rural or semi-rural areas, made a determination that given the unlikelihood of a 4-5 minute police response, that they would arm teachers with specialized training.

Mass shootings always take place in gun-free areas. Just letting the public know that a school is not a gun-free area will deter attacks, just like military might increases the probability of peace.

No one is saying it's the only element of a solutions, just that it is a piece of the solution.

In the recent Florida shooting, the police and the FBI had ample warning of a threat and either were negligent in following up or had insufficient tools to address the fact that there was a young man who gave massive evidence he was a threat and he was not stopped. Maybe there should be rules granting easier involuntary commitments and/or confiscation of weapons from the people who appear threatening. You could pass laws that allowed immediate action, based on reports of friends, family, mental health professionals, law enforcement, followed by due process to prevent civil rights violations.

headline: What to Expect (And Not) at the Oscars
commentone: It seems that there needs to be a special category for biopics as the Oscar awards seem so prejudiced towards them, albeit not in the year of Rocky, 1977. That said, owing to being a parent with a pre-school child, I've only been able to see a few Oscar-worthy films this year. I fell asleep twice watching The Post, but presumed Meryl Streep would be nominated as she was remarkable. The other Oscar film I did see, "Get Out," was a bit of a disappointment, perhaps because I had read and heard so much about it before viewing. Not that I knew the whole plot and ending; I didn't. It disappointed because it was simply a good, at times a very clever film with fine acting, a good script and some interesting (albeit not very subtle!) racial commentary. It concerns me, though, that so many awards are being offered to a film and filmmaker for a work that seems simply good. It's biased, of course, to refuse to watch a film because one has prejudged it as "not Oscar worthy." But it's no less biased that that same film is so valorized, perhaps because it has a black star, co-star, with Jordan Peele at the helm as writer, director, and producer. I've been a Peele fan for years. He's brilliant. But this film of his is not brilliant. It is neither "flawless," nor is it #MeToo. But it is very good. I would hate for "Get Out" to be the "Rocky" of 2018.

headline: Whole Foods Gets Primed With the Amazon Treatment
commentone:
"For the most part, the 470 stores are still the same upscale, expensive healthy food emporiums that they have always been." Actually, no they're not, at last not here in Nashville. In my experience, local/regional items have disappeared. Unfortunate because I like to support the area where I live (and consequently rarely if ever order from Amazon).

There is less organic fruit and produce than before and one item I picked up cost $1.00 more than before. I've given up eating from the food buffet: by the time you wait to go through the checkout line, the food is not hot. Even worse if you want coffee too and have to go through two lines. Their attempt at recycling is half hearted and it used to be good.

Today I did something I've never done before: seeing the very few checkout lanes that were staffed, I turned, replaced the items I had in my basket and left. I had found very little I was looking for anyway and had picked up substitutions. Other stores are picking up their slack...
commenttwo: I would say there was an immediate impact of the Amazon takeover at  our local WF - when the store lost about 30 employees back in November.  Faces that I had come to know over several years - were gone - and replaced by people who just don't seem to care as much.  The pre-Amazon employees seemed happy to work for WF, and that made shopping there a nice expericence.  That is no longer true - and I might as well shop at my local  grocery chain store - and save money in the process.  Given that Amazon is notorious as to how it treats its workers (see several NY Times stories) - I don't expect to see positive changes in the future.

headline: How the Tet Offensive Broke America
commentone:
The tendency of government officials, whether military or civilian, to blame the press or antiwar demonstrators for defeat in the Vietnam war reflects, in part, the all too human habit of blaming others for one's own failures. Additionally, however, Presidents Johnson and Nixon, along with their generals, had to cope with the unenviable reality that they would appear in history books as the first group of American leaders to lose a war. President Johnson, in fact, apparently committed troops initially to avoid that distinction.

America has fought wars for a variety of reasons, some defensible and some not, but Vietnam may have been the first in which a major factor in the decision to intervene centered on a president's need to avoid political disgrace. Even after he agreed to negotiations, Johnson remained determined to achieve a favorable outcome in the conflict. But the soldiers surely sensed that politics, not national security, determined government policy. Hence the loss of morale and the determination to survive at all costs.

Johnson's attempt to preserve his own political power at the expense of other men's lives contributed instead to his own downfall, and justifiably so.
commenttwo: We still want to be an Imperial Power, even though we cannot recognize that for the most part. It pays off in material riches for the top 1% and the Military Industrial Complex. Let's figure it out and get out of Afghanistan and Iraq now.

headline: In West Virginia, the Politicians Fail, and the Teachers Rise
commentone: I just checked. WVA has a Republican governor and one Republican senator. Are these people missing too much school? I think so. Republicans are the enemy of unions. There is a Supreme Court decision coming about unions. It looks very bad for them but they still pull the "R". I think the are missing too much school.
commenttwo:
I have never seen West Virginia in the daylight.

In the fall of 1971, taking my wife and 2-y.o. son to Minneapolis where she was to re-enroll in nursing school while my Army enlistment came to an end, we found ourselves, well past midnight, somewhere between Charleston and Parkersburg and en route to relatives in Cleveland to spend a day before continuing on. The needle of the gas gauge was already below the "E" when we pulled off the interstate into a small, small, small town looking for an open station. A pair of approaching headlights happened to be attached to a police car and I honked my horn and flashed my headlights as the squad car passed by.

The officer was already turning around by the time I came to a stop and pulled up beside me. On hearing our plight he led me to a nearby, closed and dark, gas station. The owner will be here in a few minutes, he told me. Have a safe trip. And so it was.

If the citizens of West Virginia today are the descendants of folks like the policeman and gas station owner who generously helped us on our way, I don't see how they would deny their children the right of a good education provided by teachers doing what they love to do.

We all must eat. We all must have shelter and safety. None of these, except for a fortunate few, find these gifted to us.

West VA, pay your teachers a decent salary, and do whatever it requires to come up with the necessary funds. Even if it means your elected representatives must take pay reductions.
