headline: Intrigue in the House of Trump
commentone:
How many of us still light our evenings with candles made at home by dipping threads into vats of melted tallow? This was the norm during and after the Revolutionary war. These dim sources of light, possibly aided by oil-filled lamps, illuminated the spaces in which the authors of the Declaration of Independence, the Federalist Papers, and the Constitution of the United States.

The prescience of these men (and they all were men, though, as Chernow's biography of Hamilton illustrates, the women of their lives were not without influence) was neither crystal clear nor complete. (The 2nd Amendment clearly did not foresee the death-dealing capability of modern weaponry; the possibility of a Trump-like demagogue so beyond the pale it never entered the realm of imagination.)

The Washingtons and Hamiltons and Adamses and Monroes of that day would, in this --our-- moment of time, be in full-throated and -armored revolt, against Trump and his lick-spittle Republican Party, the villain[s] to be wrested from the throne, just as they did George III and his court.

The break with England of the 18th century was violent an bloody.

The upcoming conflict between Trumplicans and the believers in true democracy may easily surpass the carnage of the the Revolutionary and the Civil Wars, combined.

Disregard the warning above at your own peril.
commenttwo: America will not function properly again until Trump and his entire gang of grifters, impostors, incompetents and fools is removed from power and made an example of.  This will happen, exactly the way it is supposed to, despite the treasonous spinelessness of the GOP.  I wonder if anyone, Trumpists or Trump haters, are fully prepared for what Mueller is going to say.  The jig is nearly up for Trump and his pals.  They are a legal pin-cushion.  Prosecutors don't soft-ball and dither and present "both sides" like pundits do, they prosecute.  And as the only non-partisan we can turn to for the truth, he will be listened to.   Don Jr is up to his eyeballs in the Russia/Wikileaks theft and election meddling, Javanka has a slime trail, and there is no telling how many staffers will be facing charges of lying to the FBI, where there are no "white" lies.   They will be throwing each other overboard as they claw for seats on the lifeboat, all while the ship goes down and the Captain jabber-tweets his almost-comic mixture of Fox baloney and pure, desperate panic.

My second example is how people go out of their way to bully fellow students simply for not getting an amazing score. To summarize, today's society is a cruel world when it comes to our academic achievements. Instead of judging the fish by it's ability to climb a tree, compliment on it's achievements.

headline: Learning to drive at 62
commentone:
I took my high school driver's ed lessons in Houston when the speed limit was 75 on the freeway. For Texans this has generally signified ; " up to 95 is fine".
The driver's ed teacher had me drive a couple of blocks up the street to the Katy freeway-known to this day as " The Beast". He said: " Get on the freeway". I protested that I had never driven a car at all, anywhere ,ever prior to that day. He repeated the order. I'd read the book and understood merging as a concept. Somehow I was able to do it. He instructed me to get up to speed and then to pass " that semi." I drove fast enough to pass it (very fast) watched in my mirror, signaled and pulled in front of it. He began screaming : " I didn't tell you to pull in front of it; just to pass it!" I responded : " Well what's the point of passing it if you are not going to get in front of it ?" He angrily ordered me off the freeway and clearly he was shaken up. I think back on it and am astonished that he felt empowered to take me on such a risky venture. I've driven cross country N to S and E to W, border to border many times since then . It is essential in my part of the world. I've driven in Boston and N Y City , L.A. as well. Still I realize that what happened the first time was foolish and dangerous for anyone in my path that day as well as for him and for me. I practice gratitude about many things.
commenttwo: I continue to marvel at Mr. Cohen's naturalization.  He does not seem to care for America or its plural federalist organization very much at all.  He would be so much happier in his native land with its mass democratic, highly centralized sociast government.

It costs a bit, which is a problem as it should be free for all.

Check out:

Accidentavoidanceworkshops.org
Teensmartdriving.com

headline: Readers React: What Is the Healthiest Way to Feed a Baby?
commentone:
My son didn't sleep throughout the night and took an hour to drink 1 oz. of formula at a time for over a month. His older pediatrician told me to feed him a tablespoon of rice cereal mixed with his formula to help fill him up and to help him to sleep. We did this twice a day and it did help him to be fuller and to sleep better. We went on to try other cereals mixed with the formula that were made thicker and thicker as time went on; and, eventually started him on fruits and then vegetables.

When he was old enough to choose his own foods the surprising thing he did was to select foods that I could eat during my pregnancy and not eat those I could not eat. He never developed a taste for sweets or sugary foods because I could not eat them, and didn't eat pork products either. His taste went to raw vegetables versus cooked and he has maintained good diet habits and slender physical weight until this very day.

I am a firm believer that if you keep good healthy foods in the house, have a decent diet for the entire family, you will all benefit and develop good eating habits. You cannot expect your children to maintain decent weight levels if you yourself don't do anything to maintain them for yourselves.

headline: The Challenge of Doctor-Patient Relations in the Internet Age
commentone:
I have not yet seen a psychiatrist in my life yet - and I am pushing 70. Hope never to see one. Not that there is anything wrong with it.

But I have had this experience with a GP - when I lived in Indonesia.

He was from South Africa and was our company doctor.

I travel a lot and had been nursing a cold for sometime after a recent trip to West Africa.

So, I went to see Willie. He looked me over.

He then read my charts going back 3 years. And then, he re read again.

Willie says he needs to take my blood pressure.

After taking it, he says he thinks I may have a high blood pressure. I had never been told this before in my 50 years.

I asked him why he suspected. He said an earlier doc in my charts had noted a pressure of 154 or something. But no one ever told me.

Willie says off alcohol, off salt and eexercise some for a week and come back.

Go back, same result. Asked what is to be done - he said medications.

Asked what type, he challenged me to educate myself first using web.

A week later, armed with info - we had an excellent discussion and a medication was prescribed.

Willie was mighty proud that I had educated myself.

Fast forward some 20 years. Now, in Mumbai.

Did the same with a doc here and he almost threw me out.

Luckily, I had a choice and went with another doc.

Educating yourself before seeing a doc is as good as letting your fingers do the walking before a travel.

More you know about a place to be visited, more you get out of it.
commenttwo:
None of the dozen psychiatrists who "treated" my partner, who was rapid cycling through depression and chronic fatigue symptoms and mania with psychosis, was able to explain the cause of her malady, or even try to digest the genetic, nutritional, hormonal, immune system, and functional tests we presented -- all of which pointed to dangerous abnormalities. That did not stop any of them from prescribing drugs that would "probably help," but actually caused terrible psychiatric, metabolic, cardiovascular, and nervous problems of their own. The answer to these reactions was either to take more meds to address them or try some other psych med that had already been identified as problematic, which is why it was not used originally.

By carefully tracking symptoms and cycles and matching them to diseases I discovered on the Internet, then dug into in online medical and scientific journals was I able to narrow down the physical causes of this condition and get my partner to specialists who might offer some real answers. Eventually, a test for Lyme disease confirmed one of my hunches. More Internet research identified the herbs and supplements that could remodulate the cytokines and hormones that were completely out of whack without aggravating genetic conditions that caused her to have extremely adverse reactions to psych treatment. She stabilized in two weeks and stayed symptom free after three months.

Psychiatrists were no help at all. They refused to learn what worked and why.

headline: The Macroeconomics of Trade War
commentone:

commenttwo:
For those who're counting (hello, Paul), the trade deficit in 2017 for Goods and Services was actually $566 Billion, which is up 12.1% from 2016 and 28.9% from 2009-1010. The trade deficit in Goods alone, to which Trump refers, WAS $810 Billion last year, up 7.6% and 14.2%, respectively. Courtesy US Census Bureau.

Now, about that underemployment rate, Paul. Politicians and lazy economists love to use the U-3 rate which is hovering around 4%. Honest analysts prefer the U-6 rate which is around 8%. Sticklers also add a fudge factor for the deep structural underemployment that creates a further drag on the US economy.

Trump's tariffs are not going to start a Trade War, because the War has been raging for decades, and we are the losers. Just look at all of the macroeconomic indicators.

In the long run - that long run your economic idol referred to - our current economic policies will cause widespread dislocation that will make the Great Depression look like a vacation in Bali.

The ARVN struggle on the opposite side of the Marine battle in the Citadel is almost entirely unknown. The Marines did not arrive to join the battle inside the Citadel until February 13. headline: Trade War, What Is It Good For? Absolutely Nothing
commentone:
Professor Krugman's lessons for the day are #1 "these tariffs aren't that big a deal" and #2 "America...accounts for nine percent of world exports and 14 percent of world imports".

The Doctor goes on to tell us that these inconsequential tariffs would lead to a trade war that would be a "huge mess" for the US. In this trade war hundreds if not thousands of factories would close and millions of workers would be forced to change jobs, move to new places, and more. Many would suffer irreparable losses.

Which brings us full circle to Lesson #2. The US has been in a global Trade War in which we have been - to use Mr. Krugman's word - HUGE losers. His description of the impending catastrophe of Trump's no-big-deal-tariffs is the description of exactly what has happened to the US manufacturing economy in the last forty years as our foreign trade policies have gutted a vital segment of the national economy.

The vital signs of the US economy - trade deficit, national debt, deficits, NHE, etc...- indicate a very sick economy with a terrible long term prognosis.

You would think a guy with a Clark and a Nobel on his mantle could grasp the serious implications of our macro-economy.
commenttwo:
It's fairly simple to understand.

On the business side, we have allowed the American Globalists to abolish industries and jobs here in the U.S. with the flip retort millions can find something else to do with their time whilst they are provided cheap goods. Now combine that with the political side - we have entered multinational trade agreements we do not enforce due to geo-political priorities. Just think about what that has produced. Big Biz and the best government money can buy treats small business as Wal-Mart treated them - under-price and put them out of business. And today, it is like screaming across the vacuum of space to get a politician to pay attention. Join a Pac if you want their ear, right?

Hello Trump, for we have had enough. Small business employs the majority of Americans and us humans still vote. It appears these lopsided multi-national trade agreements are going to be renegotiated, then enforced.

Listen to us or go find a burger-flipping job yourselves.

headline: What Motivates Voters More Than Loyalty? Loathing
commentone: I hate the idea that Democrats are too supportive of gays, women, minorities, and the poor.  If we have to embrace the punitive, racist, restrictive life of the fifties that most (repub)Licans long for, who will we be representing? We can't reach compromise with the Licans because to do so guts our party of everything we stand for.
commenttwo:
Articles like this perpetuate several false narratives. First, this article doesn't look at the substantive differences underlying the partisan split. Should we give billions of tax cuts to corporations while Americans don't have guaranteed healthcare? Should we favor immigrants based on race, ethnicity, and religion? Is climate change real? These differences really affect the future direction of the country. It's not just some silly tribal feud.

Second, this kind of "why can't all just get along" lament perpetuate a false equivalence - that both parties are equally responsible for the divide. The apparent logic here is: if Democrats say Republicans are close-minded, but Republicans say Democrats are close-minded, then they must be equally right or equally wrong. But you have to look at the context. The white nationalism pervading the Republican Party today has even long-time Republicans like McCain, Graham, Corker, and Schwarzeneggar criticizing the party they have been loyal to for decades. Even Dick Cheney of all people voiced opposition to Trump's xenophobic "Muslim Ban." Even Republicans acknowledge the party has swerved to the fringe.

You have to look at the context and not just look at bunch of poll results in a vacuum. This "you're both right, you're both wrong, let's just get along" lament of partisanship is shoddy political analysis.

headline: What We Will Lose When the Union Carbide Building Falls
commentone:
I think it‚Äö√Ñ√¥s important to remember what America was like after WW II and before the Vietnam War and Watergate. It seemed normal at the time, but looking back I suppose it was unusual to grow up in a country where many people had a sense of both innocence and tremendous power at the same time. Personally, in assessing that time I think one is well-advised to consider concurrently what a heady brew that combined sense of power and innocence was; the extent to which the feeling was justified by the WW II victory and US behavior and prosperity in the aftermath; and the extent to which the feeling was not justified because there was indeed racism and unnecessary poverty in the foundations of that world.

With my amateur‚Äö√Ñ√¥s sensibility about these matters I can‚Äö√Ñ√¥t tell you why on the one hand the MetLife Building and the title music for the film How The West Was Won evoke that era for me; while on the other hand a picture of the Orange County Government Center in Goshen will cause me to opine to my companions ‚Äö√Ñ√∫The Greatest Generation liked ‚Äö√Ñ√≤em ugly; sometimes they‚Äö√Ñ√¥d even affirmatively cover up the detailing on the old Art Deco government buildings while they were building new stuff that looked like that.‚Äö√Ñ√π

Maybe those guys associated Art Deco with the Depression and the prelude to war; if a time machine were available I‚Äö√Ñ√¥d be willing to meet them halfway at the 1939 World‚Äö√Ñ√¥s Fair.
commenttwo:
When I lived in Westchester, I loved to stroll along Park Avenue near Grand Central. That stretch of the street is wonderful collection of the best mid-century ‚Äö√Ñ√∫glass boxes‚Äö√Ñ√π anywhere. I always liked the Chase building, with its massive lobby crowned by a giant, gaudy Chase logo, a bit better than than the Seagram building. These two towers, along with the Lever House, should be protected as a group.

Too often in our country we focus on protecting individual buildings instead of neighborhoods/districts. Then we wonder why European cities are so much more charming! The loss of the Chase/Union Carbide building will damage the integrity of the entire area, Seagram and Lever included. Why not keep them and encourage lower rise development elsewhere to meet demand? I remember when there was a supposed glut of office space in Manhattan.

As an added point, the Chase/Union Carbide building was completely refurbished just six(!) years ago. What a waste!

headline: When Elder Abuse Is Self-Inflicted
commentone:
My oldest brother (the oldest of four siblings) died alone as a hoarder in a small junk, paper and garbage filled apartment.

He was estranged from his two brothers (including me) and his sister. The estrangement was the product of his behaviors toward us and our parents throughout his life. He attempted to kill me and my other brother on separate occasions and also tried to steal our parents assets and property after they died. Our mother had to make sure that he never had any opportunity to be alone with our sister in fear for her safety.

He alienated his coworkers with his lies, such as telling them he was an only child, and his arrogant and condescending attitude toward them.

He never married. There was some speculation that he may have been gay but he never acknowledged his sexuality to any family member.

In short, he was an unpleasant and disagreeable person to deal with and to be around. He developed heart disease, cardiomyopathy, and apparently shut himself away in his mess of an apartment as he waited to die.

His death, alone and not lamented, was the culmination of how he had chosen to live his life and the decisions he made throughout that life.

Was he mentally ill? Perhaps. Was he willing to ask for help? No. Could he have done anything different throughout his life? Yes, but in retrospect, he would never have been able to do so.
commenttwo:
I never knew this was a recognized affliction. I wish this site allowed photos in comments. My mother was one of these people. I convinced the hospital to report her to APS a couple of years before her death, but she left the nursing home to which she was discharged AMA on the third of the next month, with my bi-polar brother who wanted her SS $. When APS showed up to the house, he was there, lied and told APS that he was living there and caring for her, and she refused to let them come in, so APS just closed the case. It took 5 months, 4 dumpsters, and an on-site auction to clean out her house. It was so horrible to see how she had lived - when she was alive she never let me or my sister into the part of the house where she lived, and we both stopped going to her rural property after she started threatening us with a handgun. There was nothing "invisible" about her - her situation was a constant heartache, but she was paying her bills for the most part and had my brother to help her cover, so we were pretty helpless under Texas law.
Those who say this is a matter of neglect, or lack of will to "help," have never dealt with a family member with this mental illness. She refused to allow any change to her living arrangement until bubba took her to an ER and then checked her into a local nursing home for rehab, where they dosed her with multiple sedatives and anti-psychotics until she died a few weeks after the medicare payments ran out.

headline: Can There Be Good Porn?
commentone:
The problem with this theory that I see is that porn is passive or reactive. It is produced as a product to market and therefore, like cars or other items in the marketplace, caters to the customer. Some people like trucks, some like sedans, some like SUVs and the whole world knows what you like when you drive down the street.

Porn is consumed in private and no one need know your preference. You can be Roy Moore demanding judgment on all sinners in public and, home alone, watch sex acts that degrade women (or other men) and, because you participate in the marketplace, someone will make sure you get what you want.

So "good" porn, which I guess would be the depiction of an act of caring and respect, as well as lust, between partners, could be, and is, made, but it isn't all that is made-not even close. The "bad" porn that is produced, physical victimization of one person by another through sex, is a social danger, particularly for young males, because it corrupts what physical intimacy should mean. At the worst it may, for those most impressionable, ruin their chance for a full life. At the least it validates fantasies that should be left under the rock.

So the problem isn't that all porn is created equal. The problem is like the serpent in the garden. "Bad" porn may only be a part of all that is there but its existence overwhelms all else in the porn universe.
commenttwo:
Good argument. I'm not sure the porn industry should really have to defend itself though. As long as you're operating within the boundaries of existent law, there's not really any need to provide an explanation. Politicians are making an issue out of the porn industry in the same way Wisconsin attacks teachers or Trump promotes coal. The conservative argument is actually to leave well enough alone.

If I learned about specifically harmful or abusive practices within the porn industry, I would advocate policy action. Without that information though, I can't really form an opinion. I don't think children are any better or worse off for accessing internet porn. Does a women's lingerie catalog promote healthier ideas about sexuality? Besides, kids have video text now anyway. They're going to figure things out somehow. Otherwise, the human race is in trouble.

Speaking of context though, I once read an interesting research paper outlining black market impacts. You would be absolutely shocked at how bad outcomes are for sex workers where transactional sex is illegal. Individuals in the sex industry fare way better in Las Vegas then anywhere else. Turns out the ethical thing to do is to protect workers in the sex industry rather than push them to the margins. The industry will exist with or without your approval.

headline: Democrats Face Primary Shove From New Left
commentone:
Democrats have chased people out of the party but I think Lipinski is misrepresenting exactly who is the predator and who is the prey. Dianne Feinstein's fall from grace was reactionary to the internal politics of the 2016 elections. Democratic party leadership forced Clinton on an electorate that didn't want her and she lost like everyone knew she would. Clintonian neo-liberalism is dead in the 20-teens. The party simply hasn't figured that out yet. The party no longer represents the demographic seeking their representation. As you can imagine, voters are rather upset.

There are many forces at work contributing to Democratic entropicalism. However, the core dissatisfaction stems from two factors. First, the "machine" is designed to play on a field that no longer exists. Second, the tent is trying to house too many people wearing too many different hats. As result, we have an unresponsive and uncoordinated mishmash of clucking show birds. Republicans suffer from a similar problem but they've seemed to accomplish an agenda anyway.

Now would be a good moment for an end to the two party system. Instead of shoving everybody into one of two tents, different parties should allow representation for different core principles while still forming governing coalitions. Democrats would be wise to reflect there's a reason you don't see duality strictly enforced in politics very often. A softer grip is often the steadier hand.

headline: Disenchantment for Aide Grew With the Spotlight
commentone: Am I missing something here? Hope Hicks is a witness and perhaps a participant in collusion/treason/just plain bad judgment in dealing with a foreign power. She doesn't get to take a pass about whether she wants to telli what she knows. The fact that the Trump family views her as some kind of cipher is immaterial. She may be leaving now to avoid further implication, but it's too late for that. So, I expect, actually demand that she be honest. Her penchant for discretion that charmed the Trump family means nothing to me. Her position requires that she serve the American people, not the Trump family.

headline: Dorm Living for Professionals
commentone:
There was a rental company in upstate New York that did the same thing. I think they called the units "mini-studios" instead of "dorms" though. Certain buildings had private baths or two units sharing a single bath. Other buildings had shared facilities. All the buildings had shared kitchens and lounges with professional cleaning services. The rooms came furnished. The locations were convenient.

The rents were more like $300 though even for a "high end" apartment. Compared to the typical market rate for a one bedroom apartment at the time, these units were a much better bargain than Starcity. 42% of the market average is still a rip off. Something around $300 was more like 15-20% in that time and place. Starcity is charging the maximum price they think the market can afford, not the fair price for services provided. Apparently they underestimated seeing as there's already a waitlist.

The true metric for affordable housing is the ratio of median house price to median household income though. San Francisco still ranks dead last among American cities by this metric. Maybe even globally.

Cisco isn't getting off the hook that easy. They still have a very long way to go.

headline: Fights Worth Having
commentone:
Interesting. At some point in the reading, I was reminded of the PBS documentary "American Creed." This was a balanced, explicitly bipartisan film seeking to re-create a fiction regarding American cultural unity. In other words, the film is propaganda highlighting ideals of the American mythos that may or may not have ever existed. Both Bret Stephens and Mona Charen remind me of this film.

There's a pleading appeal from the conservative right to convince people that their view world is still sound and justified. The tragically funny part about "American Creed" is the role argued by Bret Stephens is actually played by Condoleezza Rice. You can't help but taste a bitter irony when Condoleezza Rice is begging the conservative case for cultural unity and social cohesion.

Look, I respect people of conscience regardless of their politics but we can't ennoble an ideology without conscience. Liberalism, particularly Clintonian liberalism, is imperfect but Trump is a sideshow to the conservative purpose. Wars and tax cuts do not become us.

In my lifetime, the only thing conservativism has delivered is strife and hardship. Trump didn't write the tax bill. He probably didn't even read it. The Obamacare obstructionism predates Trump. Merrick Garland predates Trump. Failure to act on Sandy Hook predates Trump. Hurricane Katrina predates Trump. I could go on endlessly.

Conservatives ceded their conscience long ago. Getting booed at conference makes no difference.

headline: Letting  Teenagers  Live
commentone: Growing up in the late fifties and early sixties, i lost several friends in automobile accidents (one in high school three more in college.) Since then, I have offered sympathy to parents and grandparents as teen fatalities pile up. One factor not mentioned in the editorial is alcohol use. In some communities there is a culture of early age drinking that makes driving almost suicidal not to mention potentially homicidal.
commenttwo:
I remember the New Jersey graduated license program. I can't say the program was very effective though. The only people enforcing the intermediate license restrictions were parents. A police officer was not going to pull you over for looking young. I still don't know anyone that ever received a ticket for violating the provisions of an intermediate license. Punishment was strictly parental. In which case, maybe teenagers aren't the problem.

I think 16 and 18 year olds are equally capable of operating 2,000 lb deadly vehicles if trained properly and kept on a short leash during the learning curve. Age is mostly irrelevant. You're confusing correlation with causation. The problem is too few parents, or instructors acting on their behalf, spend enough time educating young adults on how to drive properly. Actually, too few adults know how to drive properly themselves. Monkey see, monkey do. Bad habits follow bad examples.

I do support the idea of treating gun control as a public health issue though. People die by firearm. The public interest is generally best served by keeping people alive. Hence, we have a public health issue. Simple. I just don't want gun advocates to use data collection as an excuse to delay any action on gun control. I'm being generous in saying I'm willing to allow data to guide policy on gun control in the first place. However, how long has the tobacco industry been suppressing research on cigarettes?

This is my concern.

As E.J. Dionne said on NPR last week: Trump doesn't have any values, only interests.

Trump also is cognitively, psychologically, and socially damaged--and that is a lot of damage for anyone, much less the President of the United States.

Trump is so damaged that he fails to process how he appears to others (it's either "for me" or against "me"), the consequences of HIS often impulsive and self-centered and self-serving decisions, or even why truth matters in his addictive quest for fame and fortune.

Thus, completely lacking in nuance and almost totally devoid of a conscience, the egocentric, simpleminded and narcissistic Trump misses the entire point about ethics, laws, and precedent and views Judge Curiel only in relation to Trump.

And I am pretty sure Trump will not grasp the meaning and implications of Judge Curiel's principled and nuanced statement:
‚Äö√Ñ√∫Courts are vested with the authority to interpret the law; we possess neither the expertise nor the prerogative to make policy judgments. Those decisions are entrusted to our nation‚Äö√Ñ√¥s elected leaders, who can be thrown out of office if the people disagree with them. It is not our job to protect the people from the consequences of their political choices.‚Äö√Ñ√π

In fact, I doubt Trump even cares, and that is our American tragedy to deal with--but, of course, the Republicans willfully will not.

headline: Mr. Trump’s Destructive Trade War
commentone: Just like many of his failed business ventures, Donald plans to leave the U.S. crippled long after he is gone. To say he is ignorant is an understatement. I suppose he is motivated by his insatiable narcissism. To him, the most important thing is to keep stirring the pot and keep his name in the headlines. (No arguing with his success on that front!) Bottom line - it is the Republicans in congress who continue to prop up this reckless, pathetic excuse for a president. Unless they are replaced with a party who cares about governing, the future for our country is very dim indeed.
commenttwo:
If you care about climate change, pollution, depletion of natural resources, the wages of middle class Americans, overconsumption in any form, wealth inequality or any of a host of other issues including poaching of African elephants and rhinoceros, then any policy which limits the current free for all system - wherein the U.S. loses and our trading partners win - must be viewed as a positive.

The arguments on behalf of U.S. gains from the current trade regulations have been debunked in many ways. Al Gore promised more American jobs at higher wages if we would pass NAFTA. Bill Clinton promised Chinese PNTR would lead to an increase in American jobs on American soil. George Bush and Barack Obama both promised huge gains from CAFTA and the South Korea deal. Where South Korea is concerned, we were promised $10 biilion more per year in U.S Exports. This year we finally gained some $5b yet our deficit with South Korea has been double (as high as $28b vs $13b the year we signed the deal). All these promises turned out to be untrue.

The economists predictions of American gains have been a bust. It is time for a change. America and our planet will be better off because of it.

headline: Mr. Trump’s Problem With Democracy
commentone:
That's a bad joke coming from Trump. If we've learned anything over the past year, Trump doesn't so much hold an opinion as work a room. His jokes are more like impromptu opinion polls. I feel like he's testing the waters to see how much he can get away with. If he really was joking, Trump has a sick sense of humor.

However, yes. Everyone finds Trump's admiration for dictators alarming. As touched upon here, you can find strategic alliances with dictatorial powers but that doesn't mean you need to applaud their methodology. The CIA has murdered leaders more democratic than Xi Jinping. If we're operating on a strictly principled basis, the joke is awkward in more ways than one.

The remark is actually like a backwards catch-22. You're crazy to fly but you're sane if you don't want to fly. With presidential power, you're insane if you want to lead. You're pretty much insane to want the office at all. You're clearly admitting your insanity by admitting you want to lead forever. The sane person doesn't even want the job.

Most leaders, even the crazy ones, realize this dynamic at some point after their ascension. You can watch them visibly age on the television monitor. The euphoria of authority eventually gives way to tedium and stressful burden. The people who seem happy in office after decades of turmoil are the truly psychotic ones. That's when you need to watch out.

headline: Nakesha’s Demons
commentone: Thank you so much for this story. I truly believe it could be any one of us, and that is how I consider other human beings experiencing a life like Nakesha's: with humility.
commenttwo: Ms Williams had a mental illness; however, she lived her life as she wanted.  I admire all those who tried to get her housing and medical care.  Clearly Ms. Williams did not want that.  Rather than seeing this as a tragedy, I see it a woman who defined her own life.  It is what we all want.  We who see the homeless as people we need to reform, need to remember Ms. Williams.  Given what she wanted, how could we have made her environment less threatening?  A place where she could stash her belongings, a free and safe place for her to shower.  Many homeless people want housing, many do not.  Listening to those we want to help is the first step.  In Ms. Williams life, there were those who did listen.   Some just saw her as unsightly and a public nuisance.

headline: Not the Higher Prices, It’s What Might Happen Next
commentone:
I humbly disagree. Tariffs will cause inflation. They always do. The question is simply a matter of when and how much.

That beer manufacturer isn't going to raise prices on a half-cent can immediately. However, they'll edge the cost onto wholesalers eventually. The big vendors will fare better. Smaller buyers will take a bigger hit on unit purchase price. The change is then reflected in consumer prices in turn. Once the first store jacks the price on a case of PBR, everyone will follow suit. The bigger retailers will pad their margins and the smaller ones will stay where they were before the tariff.

The car industry will follow the same basic model. If new construction costs more, you can expect rents on office and housing to gradually increase as well.

I'd generally agree with the basic assumption that tariff inflation won't be widespread throughout the economy. However, there is one important caveat. Companies might participate in margin swapping as a result of the price increase. Cars are more expensive as a result of steel. If you have a wide enough portfolio though, you can spread the cost increase on automobiles across multiple product lines. Instead of taking a big hit on cars, you take a smaller hit on care and fill-in-the-blank.

Bottom line though, this will cause inflation.

headline: The Macroeconomics of Trade War
commentone:
What I think Krugman is saying is that if you can import raw materials cheap or free to make imported widgets, then your profits rises UNLESS you reduce the price, but US monopolies rarely do that. Or replacing the quality US widget, you could just import cheap trash with the same label.
Or better yet, if you can arrange for foreign slave labor AND use cheap/free raw materials then the base cost for your widget is insanely low.
US companies then realize outsized profits, hoarding obscene wealth, hidden from taxation.
So indeed "free trade" is great, for a few.
Wall Street then shares this enormous bounty with US consumers and the labor force they fired. Retraining for a better hi tech job. All winners. Right?
Or do they hoard it all and just leave all those domestic workers permanently unemployed. Rejects, invisible, outside the happy labor stats because they long since gave up looking for work. Around 10 million of them.
They hardly get a trickle, slowly dying from opioids and depression.
That's the ugly back side of what is really not "free trade", except for Wall Street and the 1%.

headline: The Rise of  Dictatorship  Incorporated
commentone:
hmmm,.. Mr. Stephens, you probably think we could have won the Iraqi and Vietnam wars if they had just been fought correctly.
Please think through the possible unintended consequences of your military proposals and get back to us. Thanks.
commenttwo:
We did have a leader possessing all those qualities under Obama. You're missing the major blunder of the Iraq War though. We possess the military and diplomatic strength to conduct large scale operations against dictatorial powers as well the national interest to do so. However, we've lost the moral and political authority to aggressively pursue dictators as a result of the George W. Bush administration.

You can't point the finger too hard at anyone after you're caught overthrowing a foreign leader under false pretenses and then botching the essential nation rebuilding project that necessarily followed. Our hands were more or less tied. Contrary to the suggestion made here, the "red line" mistake didn't actually concern Obama's inaction at all. The mistake was uttering the threat out loud knowing he was incapable of taking action.

Granted, Trump is probably the worst possible leader to handle the situation now. I would rather see my high school football coach take the lead on our international policy. However, even a better leader would find the US position in Syria tenuous. We burned our global capital on Iraq. The Obama administration worked very hard to restore some of it. headline: The Supreme Court’s Power Play Against Labor
commentone:
If a politicized right-wing majority wants undermine a 40-year-old precedent ensuring the collective right to bargaining, Labor can always respond with 40-year-old tactics. I read a statistic the other day that roughly one-third of all teachers opted out of statutory union fees when legally allowed the opportunity. That leaves two-thirds of all teachers. Walk out. Leave the burden of labor to the laborers who don't want to pay their fair share.

If you're worried about finances, we'll kick start an initiative to keep heads above water. That's what collective labor is really about. Protecting workers and their families from poverty and abuse. Transferring obscure Taiwanese prisoners to US authorities is much more easily accomplished when done quietly. To me, this suggests honesty first but also desperation.

A social media post helps prevent Vashukevich and Kirillov from getting quietly "disappeared" by Russian interests and/or Taiwanese avoidance. headline: Trump Proclaims Tariffs On Steel and Aluminum, And Stocks Sag in Reply
commentone:
Of course resource availability is a national security concern. That's why we have resource reserves numbskull. That's also why global interdependence promotes peace. You're less likely to fight a war with a country that makes your life easier. However, the tariffs aren't about resource independence or national security. The tariffs are about looking busy and doing nothing. Doing nothing helpful anyway.

You can thank Trump when his administration's policies finally accomplish what even the Great Recession never could: Inflation. What do you think is going to happen to consumer prices when you dump fiscal stimulus on a heated economy while simultaneously starting a trade war with our biggest economic rival? Steel is a homogeneous good for crying out loud. You can't change the global market price. You're only changing the logistics.

This is so far beyond idiocy I don't even have a word for it.
commenttwo: If Donald had paid attention in economics 101, he would have learned that tariffs are a terrible idea. Now he has started a trade war with our allies that will only serve to hurt the US economy in the long run. I guess Republicans are the party of protectionists now, so if you believe in free trade, vote for Democrats. The upcoming recession will have started with this move that was aided and abetted by the Republican congress.

headline: Trump: King of Chaos

Trump is a salesman. We can smell our own. He's a particularly bad salesman though because he relies on his personality rather than a product in order to generate a sale. I can't say I'm surprised given his background. He's never had to make rent on a commission.

A good salesperson is responsive to the client while still remaining within the boundaries of reality. This is the product I think will best suit your needs. If the business can't provide a better product, that's what you say. A good salesperson knows how to say "no" to a customer without lying to them.

Trump obviously never learned this lesson.

headline: When Elder Abuse Is Self-Inflicted
commentone: My 75-year old father had an operation to repair a AAA on Feb. 1. Afterwards we couldn't get him to eat. For 3 weeks. We kept taking him to the doctor once a week - I was hoping they would send him to a rehab center or send somebody to help us get him to eat. On Feb. 21 we took him in again - his heart rate was 150 after standing/walking and blood pressure 80/52 and they still wouldn't hospitalize him. I realized this was going to end up in mere days I figured with a final call to 911. Once I established that he didn't want to die, I explained to him passionately what was going to happen - that his brain wasn't working right now and that he had to eat or he wasn't going to make it to his next appointment, I finally got him to cooperate, but I wish they wouldn't have released him from the hospital when he wasn't eating in the first place.

headline: Can Venezuela Be Saved?
commentone:
Without the Republican Party--this is where the U.S. would be right now. It's the arrogance of the Left--which thinks it knows better than the people--which leads first to paternalism, corruption, nationalization, coercion, force, despotism, then finally...collapse.

Venezuela
Cuba
North Korea
The (former) Soviet Union
China (before capitalist reforms)
Eastern Europe and East Germany--before the wall fell.

These are places no Liberal in this country would ever want to live--but they try mightily to recreate the conditions here.

All of these countries began experiments with the good intentions of their leaders. But when the people saw the failings of those good intentions--they had to be enslaved--and forced to go along.

Think it couldn't happen here? Just look at how the Left is already trying to shut down free speech. Look at how they have nearly completed a take-over of the media. Look at how they have completed a take-over of our education system--both primary and secondary. Look at the burdens they wish upon businesses--in the form of taxation and regulation. We are only a few spaces along the continuum from Venezuela. Give the Democrats total control...and we'll be shoved ever closer. After all...look what happened the last time they had total control--they imposed their quest for utopia on our health care system. Only Republicans keep them at bay.

headline: Dorm Living for Professionals
commentone:
I lived at a Boston YWCA for 2 years in the early 2000s. The residents were all women, ranging from 20s to 80s. It 2 communal bathrooms per floor No cooking facilities besides 2 microwaves, but most people had their own fridges. Lots of older divorcees and students. Lots of shopping and restaurants within walking distance (residents could get neighborhood parking permits, but the neighborhood parking crunch made life with a car extremely inconvenient). Residents watched 4th of July fireworks from the roof deck.

It wasn't a bad way to live. I have a family, car, and home now, but I wouldn't mind living in a rooming house again.

headline: Fights Worth Having
commentone:
All "liberals" or moderates, or progressives, were turfed out of the Republican Party by the 1980s. As Reagan said about the Democrats "I didn't leave the party, the party left me." If Stephens wants to believe that he can claim to be a "conservative," he is not really in touch with where the movement is today. Similarly, the Democratic Party is now one that favours identity politics over economic reform, consigning Sanders, et al, to the outer reaches - Bernie isn't considered a Democrat by many "Democrats." Virtue signalling, e.g., "wasn't 'Black Panther' wonderful," is less "taxing" than universal health care. The new New Deal is not played with a deck of picture cards, i.e., indicating social and economic ranking, but with colour cards.

Throughout history, the "real enemy" has always been those who claim the same mantle but are somewhat different. Catholics and Protestants claim the same Gospel, but to be a Protestant in the reign of the Sun King - or to be a Catholic in Elizabethan England - OMG - and don't forget the Thirty Years War! What was the fate of a Menshevik in Bolshevik Russia, or consider the fate of a Shia in Sunni Islam - and visa-versa?

Purity demands sacrifice - of others.

headline: How Liberals Can Reclaim Nationalism
commentone:
The United States has been unique in that while it has a territory, that territory changed and greatly expanded during our time as a nation.
What hasn't changed are the ideals, and they are what we should re-unite around.

To paraphrase "A Charlie Brown Christmas":
"Isn't there anyone who understands what America is all about?"
"Sure, I can tell you what America is all about"

E pluribus unum
"all men are created equal"
"unalienable rights ... life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness"
"Government of the people, by the people, and for the people"
"With malice toward none, with charity for all"
and most powerfully, the idea of voluntarily coming together to work together on high goals:
"We the people of the United States, in order to form a more perfect Union, establish justice, insure domestic tranquility, provide for the common defense, promote the general welfare, and secure the blessings of liberty to ourselves and our posterity, do ordain and establish this Constitution for the United States of America"

"That's what America is all about, Charlie Brown."

Folks, this is neither liberal or conservative, Republican or Democratic. We need to stop labeling ourselves or others except as Americans, in constant pursuit of the ideas above. We WILL disagree as to what best moves us toward those goals, but we can disagree respectfully and civilly. We will never be perfect, but we should never stop trying to form that "more perfect Union"!

headline: Learning to drive at 62
commentone:
I learned the basics of driving on a farm tractor at age 10. At 12, my older cousins began giving me car drivers lessons on deserted rural back roads. I got my first license at 17, and have driven at least a million miles since.

But when I travel out of country, with the exception of one trip to Jordan ( when I needed to get from Amman to Petra and back before tourists discovered Petra), I surrender driving and stick to trains, busses and taxis. Its kind of relaxing being able to sit back and not worry about all the red tape and other inconveniences of being responsible for a car. I have never really missed not having a car when on one of these foreign travels.

Of course, the places I visit mostly have public transportation infrastructures unmatched in this country.

I would like to give it a shot on the Autobahn, though.
commenttwo:
" ... lots of Trump supporters so busy watching the ‚Äö√Ñ√∫genius‚Äö√Ñ√π on Fox that they seldom venture out."

Or anywhere outside Progressive strongholds.

headline: Nakesha’s Demons
commentone: Wow, just so beautiful, touching, sad, and also up-lifting. Crying sad & happy tears simultaneously. Thank you.
commenttwo:
As with so many others here, I was greatly saddened by this story. It was great, of course, that a number of people tried to help Nakesha, but, what was really sad to me, as a physician, was that she obviously suffered from Schizophrenia, a difficult but very treatable disease like Diabetes say.
It feels to me, even from many well-intentioned comments here, that the term "mental illness" stigmatizes but these are diseases (especially Schizophrenia) that happen to people, seemingly for genetic reasons. In that sense, the sufferer bears less responsibility for their disease than most people with Diabetes or Heart Disease, but, like those other diseases, people with Schizophrenia often resist or do not follow their treatment.
As a society, we have decided some years ago that they should not be confined, and have largely ignored their plight but I think the wealthiest country on earth could certainly do better by them. There are a lot of sad stories like Nickesha's.

headline: Plan for Tariffs Creates Divide In Trump Base
commentone:
If one really believed that increasing these tariffs would result in higher retail prices, then one would also have to believe that lower corporate tax rates would result in lower retail prices. Which obviously, the Times does not. It believes all the tax savings will go to business owners and shareholders, with none passing on to employees or customers.

The fact is, prices for retail items are set by supply, demand, and consumer preference. If costs are raised, producers may or may not be able to raise prices in response. But if they could have raised prices, they would have done so anyway to reap higher profits.

The impact on the price of a can of beer will be minimal, if anything. Perhaps it will encourage more recycling incentives for aluminum cans,.

headline: Putin Says He Has ‘Invincible’ Nuclear Missile
commentone: Kinda of terrifying how many news outlets are reporting a new iteration of existing nuclear weapons as "Invincible" "Terrifying" and "Chilling" It's scary stuff, sure, but Nukes have always been scary. Alot of these headlines are playing right into Putin's hands, making him look tougher than he actually is. Thank you to the NYT for keeping a calmer handle on things.
commenttwo:
When I was about 8 years old, around 1956, I remember an animated short feature I saw on TV. Children were going to sleep in their beds on a calm night. An airplane flew across the sky, dropping a nuclear bomb that detonated. The children were incinerated in their beds, revealing skeletons, which then turned to dust. It scared the willies out of me, and at the time, made me uncertain that I would ever survive to adulthood, as I lived close to "Ground Zero" Manhattan.

The fact that I still remember it in such detail illustrates what effect such scares can have on children. Let's not scare them out of their childhoods.

headline: Saying a Prayer I Don’t Believe In
commentone: Having just returned from a visit to Israel and the West Bank, I find it ironic that many Jews are so pious in praying to God, while the Israeli government treats the indigenous Palestinian population with extraordinary cruelty in imposing brutal occupation policies.  How can these beliefs and practices be reconciled?
commenttwo:
As has been noted, there is more to saying Kaddish than the meaning of the words. The fact that a minyan (quorum of ten) is required to say Kaddish means that one never mourns alone. Also, even though I may not "believe" in the literal meaning of the prayer, I have found the strong rhythm of the Aramaic intonation, the hypnotic alliteration and repetition and the concluding wish for peace very comforting. The original prayer requests peace for us and all Israel but many congregations insert "and for all the inhabitants of the earth."
There is a special Kaddish for the victims of the Holocaust, which interweaves the words of the prayer and the names of the concentration camps and scenes of mass murder.
And in many congregations everyone recites Kaddish for those who have no one to say it for them. So I don't think much explanation or justification is necessary. Whatever your reason for choosing to say Kaddish or not, it's ok.

headline: Taxpayers, You’ve Been Scammed
commentone: Leona Helmsley said it best:  Only the little people pay taxes!
commenttwo: While I agree that the tax cut is bad, I don't think Mr Krugman addresses underlying issues.  I'd like to go beyond the blame game. The feelings of economic insecurity in this country seem pervasive.  I think even many rich people feel similarly.  Wealth is transient and can evaporate quickly.  Many businesses face increased competition around the world. High tech jobs are moving to India and China, not just low tech ones.  The feeling is that we are fighting over a smaller pie because no one knows how to make a bigger one.  Entrenched interests are also a major issue.  Spending on healthcare for example is much more per capita than other countries.  I'm willing to bet that China and Russia get more bang for the buck with their military spending as well. I don't have much faith that US government spending is efficient.   So the vote was more about taking money away from folks who don't appear to be spending it well.  As long as people feel the government isn't doing a good job, they will vote against it. The big flaw in my view of the ACA is that it added a lot of spending without addressing cost significantly.  Again, entrenched interests prevented real reform.  Automation and globalization eliminated a lot of American jobs.  How can we address the real issues?  How do we build common ground?

headline: The Supreme Court’s Power Play Against Labor
commentone:
Because Liberalism is by it's very nature "Pro-Goverment", the headline of this column pits the Supreme Court against unions. But there is another side to this story--and it could have just as easily have been written that way. In fact, it should have been.

How about this for a headline: "Supreme Court Aims to Rein in the Greed and Power of Public Unions".

Public union membership makes up a small percentage of our population--less than 1% in many state and municipalities. Yet, there are very few states or municipalities which are able to fully fund these pension and health care obligations. This means that either promises will be broken--or substantial tax increases will be required to keep them. In some states, such as Illinois and California, those unfunded mandates have risen into the hundreds of billions of dollars--and the likelihood they can ever be covered--barring a massive taxpayer revolt, is doubtful.

Needless to say--something has to give. According to Stein's Law, "If something cannot go on forever, it must stop". Now is the time. The unholy collusion of Liberal politicians and public unions must be broken--for no other reason than to protect the taxpayer against the ridiculously high cost of public employee benefits. We cannot continue to let our federal, state and local governments march toward bankruptcy, in order to cover the promises made to so few.

These massive unfunded mandates need to be reversed.
commenttwo:
This isn't really about First Amendment rights, this is about Conservative zealots, who want to diminish and destroy any collective rights labor has to negotiate better working conditions and benefits.
How an expected 5-4 decision to cripple labor is a "decision for Freedom" is beyond me.
I was a Union member, in my profession for 31 years, and thanks to that same Union I have a pension plan (that I paid into from my first day of work) that is giving my wife and I a comfortable retirement.

Why these Conservative Zealots want to attack and demean these same workers who have built America (and their stock portfolios) is beyond me.

headline: Trump Proclaims Tariffs On Steel and Aluminum, And Stocks Sag in Reply
commentone:
I recall Milton Friedman advancing the theory that foreign nations dumping goods and commodities at low cost into the US market was a good thing, as it was a form of foreign aid to the US economy.

Apparently, from today's Wall Street reaction, it agrees. While it does lower cost in the short run, in the long run it can cause sectors of our economy to shrivel and disappear. At which point, we are at the mercy of foreign suppliers for price and actual supply.

I suppose foreign oil producers could dump crude oil into our market at $10 a barrel, killing off our domestic production. But once it was killed off, what would follow? The experience of 1973's oil embargo provides a harsh lesson.

headline: A Red Older Than Its Year
commentone: Next day, same wines and a meal of Ribeye steak seasoned with salt and pepper and grilled on a Fogo Hardwood charcoal fire ( https://instagram.com/p/BgFEuI2jlgD/ ) My wife claimed the steak was seasoned very nicely. Again the Lisini seemed to enhance ‚Äö√Ñ√∫fruitiness‚Äö√Ñ√π, this time the fruitiness of a juicy steak. I think it was part of the good seasoning. My wife liked both wines but to my surprise she preferred the Caparzo. The wines did seem more similar than the day before but I still preferred Lisini and it‚Äö√Ñ√¥s elegant simplicity and polarity
commenttwo: Last week, inspired by the Lisini, my wife had a great idea: This would be great with liverwurst. Reading ‚Äö√Ñ√∫Wine with Food‚Äö√Ñ√π last week I was running into a recipe of  ‚Äö√Ñ√∫Spiced Chicken Liver Mousse‚Äö√Ñ√π Florence Fabricant recommended as a pairing for Rosso di Montalcino. I made that and the Moskin Marinara with whole wheat rotini. We enjoyed it with La Potazzine. The liver mousse tasted like an excellent liverwurst with exotic spice notes of ginger and cardamom. La Potazzine was less tart, more herbal, oaky, tannic, and very delicious with that liver mousse on buttered full grain bread topped with some smoked maldon salt.  Next day the Torre was a little too cold (57F) at first and had to be decanted to warm up. We had it with the liver mousse on crackers and a variety of char grilled steaks. The liver mousse was even better after a day in the fridge. The wine was refreshing and tart (somewhat like the lisini just better). It turned out to be our favorite. After two weekends, we finally think we understand the soul of sangiovese. It has its own chemistry of attracting opposites: Tart cherry (in a refined fruity way), vibrant and acidic on one side and beautiful tannins on the other. It is sometimes tough for me to tell if they originate from oak or grape skin. That is for me what makes up the dialectic , the polarity, the electricity of sangiovese.

headline: Dorm Living for Professionals
commentone:
I have read the article and all of the comments posted to date. I don't understand all the negativity. I would certainly consider a living arrangement like this.

I think it's important to separate the comments about the housing market in San Francisco with those about adult dorms (a term I first heard decades ago, by the way) generally. San Francisco is crazy, and I don't feel qualified to weigh in on what's going on there.

But I DO live with a roof over my head, so feel perfectly qualified to weigh in on minimalist housing generally.

I can see retirement in the future. I wouldn't mind living in a tiny space if it meant I got to live affordably in the city of my dreams. Even if I WILL have the money, maybe I won't want to spend it all on heating/insuring/cleaning 3,000 square feet and all the attendant crap that seems to fill up your home. You literally could not pay me to live in a McMansion.

If this type of housing isn't for you, shrug and move on. The vitriol I'm reading is bizarre; it makes me wonder why the idea has hit such a nerve with some people. Am I just reading a lot of email from developers who want to make me house-poor?

headline: Expanding Affordable Housing,  Despite the $1 Billion Price Tag
commentone:
New York City like my own community of Arlington VA is using a failed paradigm to address low income housing and homelessness of building a limited number of new expensive apartments that can never meet the housing needs of the many. NYC is spending about $3.4 billion in foregone property taxes, and $1 billion in direct funding to produce about 24,000 units of affordable housing , a per unit cost of $183,000. Most of this cost is absorbed by developers and builders and a low-income housing industrial complex, and relatively little is received by tenants in the form of lower rents.
The much better approach is to give out housing vouchers to needy families and individuals and let them find their own place to rent or share with others. Give each of about 25,000 households homeless each night in NYC a say $4,000 a month voucher to cover the entire rent somewhere. This would cost $1.2 billion or $48,000 per household per year, far less than the $183,000 per household building new units. Then the remaining $3.4 billion now spent on new subsidized units could be given out as an average $500 a month housing voucher (varying depending on income of the household) that would help 550,000 households a month, and help prevent more homeless.
So, most homelessness would be abolished and a half million households get a small subsidy to help pay their rent.
commenttwo: How many of those impoverished New Yorkers in need of affordable housing also rely on government assistance for their entire income? (ie: they are unable to work). For this group NYC should 'think outside the box"! Instead of paying $40,000+ PER YEAR for subsidies, NYC should purchase thousands of housing units that sit vacant in upstate New York's small cities, such as Utica, Amsterdam, Troy, etc. Rather than wasting money building new units on very expensive Manhattan-Brooklyn-Queens real estate, move the people to where the housing already exists at very affordable prices!

headline: Fights Worth Having
commentone:
First, a general ‚Äö√Ñ√∫hear, hear, is in order for Bret Stephens‚Äö√Ñ√¥ reminder that it‚Äö√Ñ√¥s very important for us all to be able to debate with one another within our own party. Argument can sharpen reasoning. It also clarifies values.

headline: How Did Europe Freeze As North Pole Warmed Up?
commentone: How do people not understand this yet?  The poles are encircled by jet stream winds that contain the coldest air at the poles.  Global warming weakens those winds.  This allows the cap of cold air to slip to warmer climates.  This causes A) unseasonably warm air to go to pole causing climate change to be most severe there. B) unseasonably cold air to occur where the cold air cap has slipped to.  In December that was the Eastern US.

headline: How the Left Wins the Culture War
commentone:
Mr. Brooks, I have enjoyed your columns, but this one, respectfully, lacks self-awareness.
Why?
Because you warn the left not to alienate a powerful political force without recognizing that a powerful political force has so overplayed its hand that now there is a liberal backlash. What can be more alienating than watching our children slaughtered by scores and watch as conservatives callously line up to find everything else in the world to blame, but guns? Right wing gun nuts are literally threatening the lives of children who are speaking out against gun violence in the wake of the Parkland killings. Lawmakers stupidly note that it would be ineffective to get rid of just certain types of weapons and that to really do something you'd have to get rid of all these weapons...and then where would you be? I mean, Rubio's comments were so stupidly revealing.
Or how about the dumb tax cut for corporations? So they highlight anomalous stories of companies giving bonuses (scraps) to their workers, but stock buy backs reached $200 billion. but I digress.
So consider me alienated. Consider me outraged. Consider me a person who looks at a gun rights supporter in a similar vane as those who support big tobacco. They are complicit in the killings of Americans. That's not an extreme position. It's fact.

Perhaps, we have been calling David Brooks to get out of his ivory tower and mingle with the common people and he has degenerated in his thinking into one of them. So sad.

"I'll be all around in the dark - I'll be everywhere. Wherever you can look - wherever there's a fight, so hungry people can eat, I'll be there. Wherever there's a cop beatin' up a guy, I'll be there. I'll be in the way guys yell when they're mad. I'll be in the way kids laugh when they're hungry and they know supper's ready, and when the people are eatin' the stuff they raise and livin' in the houses they build - I'll be there, too. "

headline: Is It Harder to Grow Up in the 21st Century Than It Was in the Past?
commentone: As a teenager, I can absolutely say that it's not easy for my generation. These days, we have seemingly all the information we'd ever need at our fingertips, and in some ways, that's made life better for us. We're more aware than past generations - for example, you hardly ever meet someone who doesn't have an opinion about Trump these days, teens and kids included. However, as a result of that, we're also more aware of the injustices of this world, which can be a tricky thing. On the one hand, it can create a fire inside the hearts and minds of young people trying to change the world they live in, like how victims of the Parkland shooting are actively campaigning to pass gun reform laws because the People in Charge simply won't listen to them. On the other hand, though, it can make us pessimistic. Now that we're so aware of the problems we'll have to face as adults, we worry not only about short-term things like applying to college (which is also worlds harder than it used to be), we also worry about the long-term issues we face like a warming planet, which can be bad for our mental health. The good thing is that enough of us still have hope that we can make things better. We attend marches and protest online, we voice our concerns and make people listen if they don't hear us, we work hard even when our parents tell us we're lazy. Life is hard, even in this age of technology and general woke-ness, but we're trying, and I think that's really the most important thing.
commenttwo: Although it was hard to survive in the past, I feel it is hard to grow up in the 21st Century. Today we have social media and technology therefore you can't escape anything. If you get mad and post a mean picture, that picture stays out there even if you "delete" it. Your future depends on the things yo do growing up. Colleges, work places; they all look at your social media.

Black Panther is supposed to be inspirational for young black people? A country whose succession is determined by who is the more effective fighter? headline: Letting  Teenagers  Live
commentone:
O', puleeze, Mr. Leonhard. Have mercy. Don't give ideas to Trump and the gun lobby that is already working overtime to find distractions to the gun problem in the country.
Everything has its time and place. Now is not the time for dragging car crashes into violence by lethal weapons. No one plans car crashes; those are accidents that just happen without any pre-planning. Shooting and killing using guns are almost always pre-planned and pre-meditated. Apples and oranges both are fruits, but they are not one and the same thing.
Back Off, please............ .
commenttwo:
David this article elevates this problem to its proper priority. The teen driver death rate should be given a much higher priority than it is now; James Powell and I have been writing about fatalities and injuries for decades. Safety has improved after the late Senator Pat Moynihan and Ralph Nader called attention to our national problem. They were largely responsible for passive safety features now in every car -- like seatbelts, airbags, and safer brakes and car frame designs.

Senator Moynihan invited James Powell and his co-inventor Gordon Danby of Brookhaven National Lab to the Senate to determine if the US were to develop a Maglev network built mainly along our Interstate Highway System what would it cost and how would this system benefit the US.

They found that the system would move both highway freight trucks, passengers, and passenger autos much cheaper, much faster, and safer than driving.

The Senate Environment and Public Works committee were excited about the prospects and reported an R&D program to prototype the Powell and Danby system. The bill was passed by the Senate but failed in the House because of strong opposition by industry interests.

This was in 1992 and if passed, we would now have an all-weather, 300 mph system that would move freight and passengers for much less and make highways much safer. Failing to pass this legislation and failing to not even finance testing and competing this system, I believe, was a huge mistake.

headline: Mr. Trump’s Destructive Trade War
commentone: You can always count on the editorial board for pro-free trade propaganda. The notion that we could talk other countries into going along with strong tariffs against China is ridiculous. What would have resulted from those discussions likely would have been watered down, meaningless provisions. The E.U. cannot even make common cause against China as Germany has been known to put pressure on other member states when they want to get tough on China. China is an authoritarian, expansionist and mercantilist regime and the US has every right to retaliate against it as well as other countries that dump steel in the US and protect their own markets. The fact is, in order to re-establish the steel industry the US must impose tariffs on other countries that export steel. This is how things have been done for hundreds of years. The type of policies favored by the editorial board are the ones that have decimated our industrial sector in the first place. They have also aided China‚Äö√Ñ√¥s rise and will put the US in a subservient position.
commenttwo:
The US, prior to the 1980s was a world leader in manufacturing. We exported more products than we imported giving us a very good balance on profitability on trade.
In fact, US manufacturing saved the world from a catastrophic World War II by our ability to produce the necessary armaments to win the war. After 1980, somewhat mysteriously, the US started becoming a service economy rather than a manufacturing one, which benefited the workers as well as the corporations. The unregulated global economy caused the change. Unfortunately multinational corporations' hunger for profits caused them to seek cheap labor abroad, damaging the US economy greatly. I've yet to see who deserves the blame for this change. It appears that US multinational corporations pulled the plug on American manufacturing simply to make more profits for themselves and the Wall Street bettors.
As a result, we have large deficits in trade with China and others that keep getting worse, and the globalists ignore that fact as long as they are making more profits for themselves. Tariffs are our last way to balance our trade deficits. If trade wars result, so be it.

headline: Report Said to Assail Ex-F.B.I. Official on Media Disclosures
commentone:
The FBI's pristine credibility and reputation for being a non-partisan law enforcement agency took a huge hit in the summer of 2016 when then-Director James Comey took it upon himself to publicly chide Secretary Clinton for her email issues. If that wan't bad enough, Comey released his infamous letter to Congress in the eleventh hour of a presidential campaign that effectively doomed the Secretary from winning the election.

Since then, the sitting president has shown no gratitude for the favors he received from the Bureau, and has instead called into question the integrity and fairness of the once-highly esteemed agency. The president has belittled Comey and Andrew McCabe, as well as rank and file agents and says the agency is part of a "deep state" designed to undermine his presidency.

The Bureau under J. Edgar Hoover was preoccupied with fighting crime and political enemies of the establishment. Yes, Hoover wielded untold power in Washington and during his reign, presidents left him alone and steered clear of politicizing the Bureau.

The sitting president is more perturbed with McCabe for his wife's political affiliations than anything else. He also seems to want to establish a "deep state" of his own and make the Bureau into his own law enforcement agency that he can put on a leash and have full control of, his own personal KGB.

My greatest sympathy to you. This took me back to 2016, when I too, lost my father to dementia. Although I'm an agnostic/atheist, I too was comforted by by the religious traditions with which I was raised.
commenttwo: Having read many of the comments, I must say that there are a number of beautiful and heartfelt responses.  At the same time, there are so many that simply reject outright any understanding of, or openness to, the concepts of God and religion, often in a derisive way.  I find these kinds of comments very disappointing.  My question to those who deny is simply:  how do you know?  Where have you looked?  I hope you don't really think that the fact that there is no "man in the sky" is proof of something.  That kind of thinking is laughably childish.  If you are serious at all, read what has been said by serious thinkers and writers who have explored the subject in a serious way.  The fact that there is a lot of misery in the world, and in our lives, does not mean that there is not something that holds all of this together.  Have you ever considered the possibility that by looking for that something, you may come to understand these things in a different way, and experience your own life differently?  The answer may not be different than the question.

headline: The Challenge of Doctor-Patient Relations in the Internet Age
commentone:
As a physician, you cannot appease everyone's desire for information and "understanding." Towards the end of my practice years, when internet information was readily accessible, I would often point patients to internet resources such as DailyMed ( https://dailymed.nlm.nih.gov/dailymed/ ), Medline Plus ( https://medlineplus.gov/ ), and Choosing Wisely ( https://medlineplus.gov/ ). Yes, they were imperfect. So was I.

Some patients will not fit well with certain physicians. I did not expect all people to do their own research, and if I thought they were making a poor decision I would explain why. There was no expectation that everyone would listen or would always like the way things were presented--but they did deserve to hear.

Financial and insurance constraints alter conversations. Educational levels are sometimes a factor. Some patients want to hear everything--las unrealistic as patients who wanted me to make every decision. The admonition to "do what I would do for my own family" sometimes felt like a curse. Some patients were more intelligent and more analytical than I was--sometimes a problem when smart people think that is enough.

I did not have to deal with "Dr. Google" as often as current practitioners. It is a blessing and a curse for physicians and patients alike, but we should not go back to the "old days," when much medical information was unaccessible to the public or to physicians not practicing in major medical centers.

The Russians must be pleased at the social and political discord they sowed through the American landscape. The president is at war with his own intelligence agencies and scoffs at the idea of a serious Russian threat to the upcoming mid-terms. Preparing and being vigilant against any perceived foreign threat against America‚Äö√Ñ√¥s democratic institutions and sovereignty only gives credence to the belief of outside tampering with the country‚Äö√Ñ√¥s voting apparatus, something the president is taking great pains to dismiss as fake news. The nation‚Äö√Ñ√¥s intelligence and law enforcement agencies are right to mistrust Russia or any foreign power‚Äö√Ñ√¥s attempts to meddle in America‚Äö√Ñ√¥s election affairs.

It may be that last November‚Äö√Ñ√¥s Democratic victories will be the trickle and merely a harbinger of a blue wave to come this coming November. This is the time for Americans to stand up and emphatically show Russia that US citizens have indeed taken their country back from the Kremlin.

headline: The Supreme Court’s Power Play Against Labor
commentone:
There are few areas where Republican hypocrisy is more evident than in the field of labor relations and collective bargaining.

Republicans claim that it is unfair to require all employees in a unionized shop to pay dues because, their reasoning goes, those dues are sometimes used to support political issues and candidates with which the workers disagree. So, despite the fact that all of the employees benefit from any concessions the union may have won, this is too severe a violation of their rights to be permitted to persist.

They do not, however, have any problem with corporate campaign contributions despite the fact that not all shareholders may agree with their political choices.

But there is one key difference here: When a corporation makes a political contribution it is doing so with money that rightly belongs to the shareholders -- it is their property. But when dues are paid to a union, that money becomes the union's property to do with whatever it will. It no longer belongs to the workers.

Of course, you, I, and all God's chillun' know why Republicans have this sharply differing views of individual political rights: Most union political donations go to Democrats, while most corporate contributions go to Republicans, and they are hiding behind the banner of "political rights" just as southern slaveholders hid behind a claim of "states' rights."
commenttwo: America is unraveling and the winning decisions by conservative members of the Supreme Court are largely to blame. Their naked bias toward corporations and plutocrats shows a flabbergasting contempt for ordinary people. They are truly no fans of democracy, considering how they have worked to undermine ours.
