commentone: This will begin to go bad at some point and it likely won't be the classic mass shooter at the middle of incidents; it will be the father in a custody battle demanding to take his kids, the disgruntled ex-school district employee, and the like. The wannabe shooters will switch to other tactics, like sniping, blowing up the propane tank on the playground, and other tactics available to the maliciously creative. Maybe you could say this is the modern version of 'duck and cover', more to create a false sense of safety than any true security. It takes hundreds, thousands of hours to begin to prepare to be able to respond effectively to crises like these. Soldiers and law enforcement officers get that degree of training, and yet we still have friendly fire incidents and citizens gunned down for no good reason. That's no knock against soldiers and police; it's just the reality of trying to think straight and act appropriately under fire.
commenttwo:
It is probably difficult to find a person more pro-gun than I, but I do not support arming teachers. And why? Because schools are very safe places, and therefore, there is no need to put into a place a policy that contradicts that fact.

Here is what is remarkable, and is perhaps missed by most, because it appears that humans, for survival purposes, have evolved to focus on the negative (danger). Each school day, there are 55 million students in schools, and nearly every single one of those students could get a firearm without much difficulty, but yet, we do not have tens of thousands of shootings in schools each day.

Certainly, one shooting anywhere is one too many, but we need a balanced view.

headline: What Motivates Voters More Than Loyalty? Loathing
commentone:
This is an interesting article but is a prime example of the kind of "false equivalency" that pervades political reporting these days.

Yes, many Democrats are indeed motivated to fever pitch by our loathing of Republicans, most notably Donald Trump and the people who make up his administration. Many if not most of us can articulate precisely why we experience this loathing and the things that Republicans have done to earn it.

Republicans, on the other hand, tend to have their loathing goaded into them by right-wing media and Republican speechifying, "Lock Her Up" being an obvious example.

Another example is their almost universal loathing of Nancy Pelosi. In forums and blogs all over the place, they never hesitate to write totally insulting things about her. But when you ask them what she ever said or did that has made them feel that way, they can never articulate any cause or reason for it, and the best I have ever heard one of them respond is to say that she's a "baby killer."

It is hard not to loathe an administration that coddles neo-Nazis, pollutes our air and water, threatens our social programs and medical care, breaks up law-abiding families by deporting parents, pushes for a gun in every hand, and that brags about it and taunts you for your inability to stop their destruction. It is somewhat trickier to provoke loathing against someone who has never done you any harm, as has become routine in Republican rhetoric.
commenttwo:
I dislike the Democrats for two principal reasons. The first is that they are essentially soft socialists; willing to suppress and control freedom and the private sector to favor those in society who are either criminals or are totally unmotivated care for themselves and their families. The second reason is that the Democratic Party is committed to opening the borders of the United States to every needy and incapacitated person in the world to expand the existing dependent underclass for electoral advantage. This is most easily accomplished by allowing unlimited immigration from Mexico.

Democrats would sell out the values of American society to accommodate the pathologies of the Third World.

headline: When Elder Abuse Is Self-Inflicted
commentone: People's priorities change over time. Living a long life vs. living the life you want to live is not always the same thing. At what point are you your own person if the choices belong to others? Perhaps people should have advanced directives for how they want to live through old age.
commenttwo:
I'm living this frustrating terrifying nightmare.

In Virginia, a loved one can live in the most squalid unsafe living conditions imaginable & nothing can be done unless they are adjudicated as lacking mental capacity. And to get that you are sol since that cannot be shown/proven without social services/law enforcement gaining access to the home.

In my senior family member's case, they live in an upper middle class neighborhood in a house with no heat or AC, not one fully functioning bathroom, mold from water damage due to roof leaks, entire downstairs ceilings collapsed from leaking pipes, failing electrical wiring due to nonrepair, squirrels living in the attic & mice all over. The husband is a hoarder of the highest order & their sole source of heat are space heaters in 2 rooms that run night & day in winter. Buckling bathroom tile caused a fall/broken arm in Dec, requiring surgery. Hip next?

If the health dept went in the home, they'd condemn the place for sure. But the conditions are totally invisible from the outside. And that's the vexing maddening part. Legally, If the officials can't see it, they can't act.

I got all the sympathy in the world from County Social Services along with their truthful summation of existing state law:

"As unsafe as it may be, legally you can't tell someone not judged incompetent how to live."

I just wish someone could tell me how to sleep at night & and not worry endlessly in the day, fearing THAT phone call.

headline: Can There Be Good Porn?
commentone:
I worked in the porn industry in the 1970s for a very well-known sex magazine/newspaper in New York City and spent a lot of time with directors, producers, actors and actresses from the porn film world. I have no intention of glorifying or defending the industry as it had more than its share of shady characters and difficult and damaged people. It was also filled with as much delusional self-regard as Stoya shows us here.

However, purveyors of pornography back then did understand one thing: there is no objective definition of "good" or "bad" porn. "Good" porn is what arouses you. "Bad" porn is what doesn't.

People like to watch other people have sex. It's as simple as that. Lots of people have their kinks; these days it's easy to find your kink represented on the internet and if there wasn't the demand there wouldn't be the supply. Attempting to manipulate porn into current societal values is a losing proposition. You can't regulate people's fantasies.
commenttwo: I suggest that all sex participates in the pornographic heart of the world which is what propagates it ... and does no harm... but seems forever to upset and frighten the puritanically minded...

headline: Can Venezuela Be Saved?
commentone: If you read some previous Times articles on Venezuela, you get a clearer picture of what went wrong.  Maduro, and before him Ch‚àö¬∞vez, handed over the oil production industry to the military and other socialistic agencies of the government.  The result has been a breakdown of oil production, which with the decline in the Oil market, contributed to Venezuela‚Äö√Ñ√¥s economic woes.  As in Cuba, North Korea, etc., a centrally controlled socialist economy soon becomes incompetent, inefficient, and finally dysfunctional.  If you allow socialist idealists, ignorant of such things as supply and demand, run things in pursuit of utopian goals, then you get social and economic failure as well as corruption and hypocrisy.
commenttwo: The Venezuelan economy is an extreme version of the resource curse, also called the Dutch Disease after it was observed as Holland developed it‚Äö√Ñ√¥s natural gas resources in the post WWII period. What happens is that when an extracted resource, like oil in Venezuela‚Äö√Ñ√¥s case, becomes the economic foundation of a country it fosters public subsides, suppresses investment in other productive industries and becomes the funding source for extensive corruption and the development of an entrenched plutocratic elite. This is seen today in Russia, Republic of Congo, Nigeria, Gulf States and many other places. Norway learned from the Dutch experience and shunts its North Sea oil wealth into its sovereign wealth fund, out of reach of corrupt political elites and immunizing its economy from much of the distorting effect. Venezuelan took the opposite path, poisoning it‚Äö√Ñ√¥s economic potential by using oil wealth as an unsustainable public subsidy and political influence tool. It‚Äö√Ñ√¥s recovery will take at least a decade, once it starts, but the starting point will only be reached after the current political crisis burns itself out. The tragedy is that ongoing oil production will continue to fuel the crisis.

headline: No Pension? You Can ‘Pensionize’ Your Savings
commentone: As a retired tax preparer, I get tired of the blanket advice to delay taking Social Security.  It is not so simple.  The break even point for those taking early benefits at age 62 is between age 76 and 77, assuming you spend it all and do not reinvest any.  So first look at your health and family history of longevity.  if you die before that time you lose your bet.  More importantly, and never mentioned, is the fact that you are much more likely to enjoy your spending in early old age than in late old age.  Other than medical expenses, what do most people really spend after eighty?  I would rather enjoy my retirement when young and healthy enough to do so, than worry about running out of money at the age of eighty.  And if you have not learned the unimportance of money by then, I feel sorry for you.
commenttwo: Work longer? Delay taking social security? These are very basic ideas. This article was not helpful. I echo sentiments of others here... what about CD ladders or other options? headline: Roger Bannister, First Athlete to Break the 4-Minute Mile, Is Dead at 88
commentone: I was 7 years old, living in the Philadelphia area, when Roger Bannister beat the 4-minute mile, as my Dad called it.  I can remember sitting at breakfast and Dad reading excerpts of the story from the Philadelphia Inquirer that morning, and the ensuing conversation, mostly from him, about how it wouldn't be long until someone ran the mile in under 3 minutes.  Although I never ran track as a schoolboy (I played basketball, tennis, and football), I always followed the Penn Relays, especially the mile races, in the sports pages, all because of that one event more than 60 years ago.  I still get a chill every time I watch the finish to the mile.  I was struck by the obit's reference to his motivation for running, something that became a partner in his training and his excellence: his fear of bullies, bombs, and bullets striking him.  Like many great athletes, fear does motivate: fear of not performing to expectations, fear of not winning, fear of losing, fear of being embarrassed by one of your mates, even a fear which I often had of not getting schoolwork done because of excessive involvement in the sport, or just whatever fear happens to meet the athlete in the morning.  Bannister was not only an athlete for his time, he was a model athlete for all times, making a serious contribution to sport, medicine, and civic life.

headline: Romance, Rough Sex or Rape?
commentone:
Barbara Stanwyck in 'Baby Face' and 'Double Indemnity'; Peggy Cummins in 'Gun Crazy'; Audrey Totter in 'Tension'; Kathleen Turner in 'Body Heat'; Anne Baxter and Bette Davis in 'All About Eve'... not all of the women in Hollywood movies have been 'timid mice.'

I do get your point, but it's not quite so black and white.

And speaking of black and white, it's difficult to watch many classic older films without encountering stereotyped, shuffling African American porters, bellhops and maids; inscrutable 'Orientals'; mincing, effeminate dog whistled gays...

But then along come post-WW II films like 'Bright Victory' and 'The Defiant Ones.'

Cultural change has been occurring at breakneck pace over the past 50 to 75 years; and as right wing 'evangelicalism' and Fox News make clear, not everyone has come along for the ride. Nobody ever said it was going to be easy, or that progress proceeds in a straight line from A to B.
commenttwo:
F Morris/Montreal: "Again an article telling us--i.e. us men--what are the incorrect (indeed, criminal) formalities for getting to sex. Just fine. But could you--or someone, anyone-- please tell us what is the proper non-rape, consensual approach? Maybe provide a video. For no one seems to know anymore."

* * *

While, during my 62 years, I haven't had nearly the amount of sex that famous, wealthy or very handsome men have, I've certainly had plenty, and not once did I ever have to coerce a woman. Have I missed out on opportunities over the years by not being very aggressive? I'm sure I have. But if a woman wants to play "hard to get" and then thinks I'm a wimp because I didn't try hard enough to "get" her, then that's the kind of woman I wouldn't want to be with anyway.

Other guys may feel differently. But that's how I feel.

headline: The Macroeconomics of Trade War
commentone: Dumbness seems to be a hallmark of trumpism, hold on it is going to be a bumpy ride.
commenttwo: Trump is full of truly terrible. dumb ideas and his desire for a trade war is just one of them. According to the American Iron and Steel Institute, steel production has dropped from a high of 137 million metric tons in 1973 to 87 million metric tons and the number of steelworkers has dropped from a high of 650,000 in 1953 to 142,000, due largely to automation. In the 1980s, it used to take an average of 10.1 man hours to produce a finished ton of steel; now it only takes 1.9 man hours. In 2002, the last time then-president Bush imposed tariffs on imported steel, the resulting price increase cost 200,000 jobs in industries that use steel, such as construction and car making, and many members of the Steelworkers Union -- the very ones Trump is trying to cater to with his stupid tariff idea -- are not involved in the extraction of ore for raw material but are actually employed in construction and the recycling of scrap metal. Of course, not only steelworkers would be affected by a trade war but all sorts of other products that we produce and export abroad would be subject to retaliatory tariffs in our export markets, with disastrous effects on our economy.

commenttwo: Seems like we are returning to the bad old days of "substantive due process", when, in defense of the principle of "freedom of contract", the Court struck down child labor laws, overtime laws, workplace safety laws, and the like.  Now the same process is playing out under the banner of "freedom of speech", as the Court strikes down limits on commercial speech and corporate political spending,and, in this case, uses the free speech rights of non-union workers to enable unlimited free-riding.  Substantive due process almost destroyed the Court's legitimacy during the Depression, and threatens to do so again.  Oh, wait, Bush v Gore already did that.

headline: The Tet Offensive Was Not About Americans
commentone:
Americans are predictable of their dismissal of RVN soldiers. I never experienced that.

What I did have a personal connection with was in the closing days of the war, in 1975, when the ARVN division with which we'd operated in Long Khanh province, 50 miles from then Saigon, around the then district capital Xuan Loc, held off and repeatedly defeated the attacks and advance of multiple NVA divisions armed with tanks and artillery.

The tenacity and fierceness of Capt. Tran Ngoc Hue doesn't surprise me. It does depress me. So much needless suffering by everyone for ideological reasons that are as permanent as gusts in Spring, and then gone.

Millions of Vietnamese dead. For what?

Google, Facebook, Twitter and the other internet companies might be the principal reason for the present scale and scope of this problem.

The most effective advertisers on Facebook or YouTube (i.e., Google) pander to anger, resentment and loathing. Those are the emotions that are the easiest to manipulate.

The companies feel no responsibility to act on behalf of their users or society at large. They are funded by advertising. We are just the product.

Bad actors can now coopt the algorithms and power of these companies. And these companies are now some of the most powerful in the world.

headline: Go Ahead, Millennials, Destroy Us
commentone: The standing joke goes, "If you remember Woodstock, you weren't there." But, I was there, and I do remember. Our generation was then and remains today the most self-absorbed, hedonistic, and self-serving generation in American history. We struggled to relate to our simple-minded, ossified and out-of-touch parents, better known as the most courageous, self-sacrificing, and idealistic generation to rise and sacrifice their lives en masse in opposition to evil since the Civil War. We talked a endlessly about peace and love, organized campus rallies and "love-ins." We toked our reefer, tripped to Jefferson Airplane, and marveled at our chemical-induced "revelations" as the chosen children of a still nameless god. In the end, we loved only ourselves, our six-figure incomes, and our McMansions. Our children don't know or understand us. By our own making, we've become simple-minded, ossified, and out-of-touch. Millennials have inherited our mess and I wish them well as they attempt to save the world.
commenttwo: The standing joke goes, "If you remember Woodstock, you weren't there." But, I was there, and I do remember. Our generation was then and remains today the most self-absorbed, hedonistic, and self-serving generation in American history. We struggled to relate to our simple-minded, ossified and out-of-touch parents, better known as the most engaged, courageous, self-sacrificing, and idealistic generation since the Civil War. We talked a endlessly about peace and love, organized campus rallies and "love-ins." We toked our reefer, tripped to Jefferson Airplane, and marveled at our chemical-induced "revelations" as though we were the chosen children of a still nameless god. In the end, we sold out, not because were repressed, but because we loved ourselves, our six-figure incomes, and our McMansions more than our ideals. Our children don't know or understand us. They rightly judge that we are simple-minded, ossified, and out-of-touch. Millennials have inherited our mess. I salute them as they step into our parents' shoes and do what needs to be done in order to save the world.

headline: N.R.A. Says Trump May Retreat on Gun Control
commentone: Can we reach we really say this flip-flop and his newest tariffs are the actions of a sane man?
commenttwo:
There are many lovers of the outdoors like me who grew up in the woods and on the rivers and lakes hunting and fishing who have never been members of or supported the NRA, but the time has come to do more.

Perhaps we need an RGOA or Responsible Gun Owners of America who support the Second Amendment, but not the right of anyone to own any kind of gun they want.

No respectable hunter or outdoorsman wants or needs military-style weapons.

Nor do we want lunatics, felons, woman-beaters, or anyone under the age of 21 to be able to buy a gun.

We want background checks and gun registration.

We want to mandate safety training as part of new gun ownership.

We want guns to be safe and for areas like schools and churches to be safe from guns other than those in the hands of security officers.

Folks need to get away from using terms like "gun control," and start talking about "gun safety."

Here's my recommendation to members of the NRA.

Instead of renewing that membership to a trade organization dealing in death that is the biggest threat to your responsible ownership of guns, take that $40 or $50 and invest in the three "B"s: Beer, Bait, and a Bag of ice, and take your wife, your kids, or some of your friends out on a river or lake for a day of fishing.

It will do your soul a heap of good and will be a better investment of your money.

For me, I'm offline for awhile for a walk in the woods where I find peace no one will ever know from being a member of the NRA.

headline: Nakesha’s Demons
commentone: More! More! More of this type of reporting, please.
commenttwo: I draw an analogy here between those experiencing homelessness and mental illness, on the one hand, and those dealing with addiction of one kind or another.  Health care professionals are now recognizing that relapse is so frequent in the struggle against addiction as to be in essence a part of the cycle of recovery.  Because that‚Äö√Ñ√¥s the case, many professionals now advocate that housing and other programs for those battling addiction NOT insist on sobriety in order to begin or to continue treatment.  Instead, they suggest that treatment focus on using reasonable means to reduce the harm caused by addiction, over a lengthy period, knowing that relapse will probably occur.  In the same way, perhaps we should focus efforts on folks like Nakesha on providing the best care possible while they continue to live on the street.  Mobile medical teams, portable showers and laundry facilities, street side grills for food prep and cooking, etc., may be the only ‚Äö√Ñ√∫help‚Äö√Ñ√π souls such as Nakesha will accept.  Involuntary commitment is rightly difficult to do, so perhaps this would be one way to help while still honoring the dignity of the Nakeshas of the world.

headline: No Pension? You Can ‘Pensionize’ Your Savings
commentone:
An article about "pensionizing" one's savings should have gone into more detail about annuities beyond saying "many of them are complex and larded with fees". After all, annuities are the traditional way of doing this.

Having recently retired from a freelance career, and having saved a substantial amount of money, I am currently struggling with the choice of buying an annuity versus simply amortizing my savings on my own (or some combination thereof). From the research I've done so far, it appears that, despite whatever costs are built in, the payouts from annuities appear to be pretty good, and, of course, are guaranteed, at least for your life, or for a period certain, with a slightly lower payout. Furthermore, just like with Social Security, the longer you live, the better you make out.

Going the self-amortization route is a gamble in it's own right. It leaves you having to continue investing your money and hoping for the best. With the market at an all-time high right now, the downside risk with equities is significant. And fixed income returns, while trending upward, are still pretty meager. As someone who's kind of wrung out from all the ups and downs in the investment world I've lived through, the case for dispensing with the guesswork and uncertainty, taking my profits, and converting what I have into a guaranteed income stream, is very compelling.

Although these are factors, the bulk of the blame should be laid at the feet of the industry executives who either couldn't or wouldn't see that the WWII / post war boom could not last forever; would not see the need to spend money on modernization, innovation and adapting to market changes (much like the American automotive industry).  Their first solutions were to  move to non-union states seeking lower labor costs and to lobby extensively for laws that would allow them to become off-shore companies - again in search of the least expensive labor.  An important factor is the rise of the new CEO class who have no history of doing a business that makes things; they are financial people who come in, reshuffle the business, get a sharp rise in income ( selling off assets, reducing cost anyway that is possible) take a big compensation and exit  -before the crash.  American greed for the big, quick payoff, rather than the slow gradual accumulation of wealth through years of doing good business is what has killed the American steel and aluminum industries and they do excellent PR jobs of shifting that blame off on to others - it is always the fault of someone else!

headline: Silicon Valley Toured the Heartland and Fell in Love
commentone:
The hills have already been tortured by Mr. Peabody (the coal magnet, not the cartoon dog). Let's not add insult by building hideous condos, McMansions and boutique cafes for the imported city folk who find the area quaint and smell a good investment.

If you love the area, then great. C'mon down! Just assimilate, if you don't mind. Don't move here and start changing things because "back in San Fransisco we used to....".

Bend, OR turned into Little LA when those folks saw opportunity and moved; Colorado got popular with the in-crowd and all my hippy friends were priced out within years. I personally saw it happen in Ojai, CA when the San Franer's moved in. I don't want that to happen here just because real estate prices are good and companies smell a better bottom line. We've seen enough corporate exploitation already.

And then let's talk about the deals your elected officials are willing to cut to lure these folks to your area. How many years will locals be paying for the privilege of winning these businesses? How many local jobs will actually be created. Oh, they'll talk about how peripheral businesses will spring up to support their offices, but most of those high paying office jobs will be filled by outsiders.

Economic development is a good thing if managed well and that's were it all falls down, of course.

headline: Taxpayers, You’ve Been Scammed
commentone:
Since the Reagan Administration, we have seen the greatest redistribution of wealth to the richest Americans in the history of our country.

In the mid-1920s, the top 1 percent of US families controlled 50 percent of American wealth.

By the early 1980s, the top 1 percent of US families controlled only 30 percent of American wealth.

By 2012, the top 1 percent of US families controlled 42 percent of American wealth, but that isn't enough for them.

By 2017, eight rich people, six of them Americans, own as much combined wealth as half the human race,

These one percenters won't be satisfied until, at a minimum, they control at least 50 to 60 percent of American wealth.

That, my friends, is what got Donald J. Trump elected with the help of the Citizens United decision.

He and his greedy families are one of them, and I'm afraid with modern tools of disinformation and propaganda unless the Citizens United opinion is somehow overturned, the rich are just going to get richer and the rest of us 99 percent are only going to get poorer.

commenttwo:
The man is "unhinged."

What fastens us to reality are principles by which we live. They are the "hinges" on which our "door" of conscience and consciousness swings.

This man has no principles. He's nothing more than a collection of impulses and reflexes, like a hiccup, a yawn, or a sneeze.

headline: Charles Wilson, 88, Lauded For Excising Brain Tumors, Sometimes Several in a Day
commentone:
Interesting reading. The skill and drive needed exceeds most 'common' surgeons (and most surgeons are far from common.)

My only question is, why didn't he have the 100 cadavers gathered locally, rather than fly to Gainesville for the weekend?

I am reminded of hearing about a very delicate cardiovascular procedure from it's developer, who commented it took him about 150 cases to begin to feel he was in control and able to assess the individual variation, and be prepared to handle any unexpected circumstances.

Not something that is an easily acquired skill or experience.

None of this can be cheap, and when our government begins to limit treatments and travel to out-of-network surgeons for rare and delicate operations, how will we decide if mom or dad or ourselves can go?

It sounds a bit like Hans Brinker in the Silver Skates.

I haven't read Mr. Gladwell's article, but I wonder in Dr. Wilson's declining years if he felt the satisfaction for doing as he chose to help the living, and how it must have felt to back away from such pioneering work, knowing full well while others were skilled, none as to his degree?

headline: How Liberals Can Reclaim Nationalism
commentone:
Economic globalism, has been used by the wealthy and powerful of the world (definitely a "tribe"), to co-opt and weaken any means of democracy which might challenge the ascendancy of their tribe. The wealthy of all nations, have much more in common with each other (their tribe) than the citizens of their own nations.

Since their exists no global government, "globalism" has been used as an excuse to dismantle *National* economic policies (such as FDR's New Deal) - policies which are necessary to best harness capitalism, and prevent it from destroying itself, politically, and economically. This leaves a power vacuum filled by the wealthy.

Nationalism has been vilified as the sole cause of horrific examples of totalitarian governments. However, Nationalism has often been merely one factor - one tactic - used by totalitarian leaders to consolidate power, once existing governmental and economic systems have been destroyed. Would extremist leaders have been able to seize power in the 1930's without massive economic catastrophe? Doubtful.

Economics and democracy are what we should be focused on. FDR's New Deal, took into account political and economic realities, promoted National economic projects, and instilled National pride - not a bad thing. Promotion of National economic policy should be a given. Other nations have National industrial policy, look to keep wages at a livable level, and try to avoid trade deficits. So should the United States.

headline: How the Tet Offensive Broke America
commentone:
I was in Vietnam Nam from January 1970 to January 1971. I was a REMF. There were a lot of us who were less than enthusiastic about our presence there. One example of how widespread it was - even among those out in the bush - has stuck with me.

At Christmas time in 1970, I was listening to a radio broadcast of the Bob Hope USO show. He was at one of the large U.S. military bases that served the grunts who were doing the dirty work - going out on patrols, engaging the VC. They weren‚Äö√Ñ√¥t privileged desk jockeys or lifers holding safe jobs; mostly, they were draftees.

Back in the States, the Bob Hope show would be run on television, via recording. I had watched it myself in the years before I went there. It portrayed an audience of flag waving, all-American, smiling, ‚Äö√Ñ√∫round eye‚Äö√Ñ√π girl ogling, safe for prime time viewing GI‚Äö√Ñ√¥s having a good time. How massively the sound had been edited became obvious when I heard the ‚Äö√Ñ√∫live‚Äö√Ñ√π version on the radio that year.

What I heard during Hope‚Äö√Ñ√¥s usual schtick of semi-bawdy jokes, appeals to cheap patriotism and self-depracatory one liners was a nearly steady stream of heckling, obscene language and mocking insults directed at him, from the audience. It was clear and unmistakable that the ‚Äö√Ñ√∫troops‚Äö√Ñ√π were no more in favor of the war -at least at that point- than could be found at your average college town back in ‚Äö√Ñ√∫the world‚Äö√Ñ√π.

headline: The Challenge of Doctor-Patient Relations in the Internet Age
commentone:
As a chronic pain patient for the past 18 years, I have seen physicians' medical opinions migrate from prescribing opiates to absolute refusal. Their "judgement" is directly affected by fear of the cost of defending themselves against DEA prosecution. Thanks to the current opioid hysteria, untrained "docs with guns" are now making medical decisions for people with permanently disabling, agonizing physical conditions.
Their reasoning is based not on medical studies but on flawed statistics and CDC recommendations made by addiction specialists who have significant financial interest in filling pricey clinic beds.
There are good reasons not to trust a physician who has a gun held to his/her head by a law enforcement officer who thinks they know more about pain treatment than the doctor.
Of course, restricted pain treatment isn't the only issue affecting patient trust. Know why undertakers nail down the lid on the coffin? So the oncologist can't prescribe one more round of chemo.
commenttwo: I had a bothersome sort of vertigo symptom for a while after a car accident.  A friend sent me a link.  I read the article and realized, maybe there's a treatment for it.  So I made an appointment with a doctor.  The result: I was referred to a specialist, who prescribed some exercises.  The problem went away.  And I have a doctor I can communicate with.

headline: What Motivates Voters More Than Loyalty? Loathing
commentone: I find myself trying as hard as I can not to loathe the republicans.  But it is awfully hard.  I loathe racism, I loathe bigotry and xenophobia.  I recently watched a reporter interview a group of Arizona republicans, on a competitor's web site.  It was an awful display of hatred and resentment.  I come down to what Karl Popper had to say about this type of situation.  I am a tolerant person, living in what I want to be a tolerant society.  The only thing that I can not tolerate is intolerance.  If we tolerate the bigoted and intolerant, make no mistake, they will put an end to those of us they don't like. Decency and tolerance are not suicide pacts.
commenttwo:
On the question of "Do the parties differ?": Obviously, the two major parties differ on individual policies--gun safety, details of tax policy, gender issues, etc. I see these differences.

But on the systemic issues that matter most to me, I see no significant difference. I hate any political party that acts as if the main purpose for which we, the people, created governments is to protect and increase private wealth, and yet establishment Democrats talk as Republicans do, as if tax cuts are a valid end in themselves. The two establishment Democrats currently running for nomination for Wisconsin governor have said tax cuts were a priority--at a time when the commons here are starving.
I hate any political party that refuses even to acknowledge the fact that capitalism has reached a brick wall--for itself and for the planet. I saw the video of Nancy Pelosi disdainfully dismissing a question along those lines with "We're capitalists and that's just the way it is, " just as a Republican would have answered.

No complex emotional or social variables inside the voters made them hate both parties. The source of this hatred is that both major parties are still ignoring the most urgent, existential crises facing us, while acting as if the bottom-line mission of government is to increase private wealth, particularly corporate wealth. They have different ideas about means, but their goal is the same: to serve, defend, and promote private wealth.

headline: A Big Hollywood Night in a #MeToo Moment
commentone:
I thought the 90th Academy Awards show was extremely boring with insipid humor and bizarre moments, i.e., "handing out hot dogs at an adjacent movie theatre" and giving away a jet ski with a weekend in Lake Havasu. Good grief, this attempt at humor was painful, to say the least.

It was refreshing to see no one movie dominate the top awards, and what a great surprise to see Allison Janney and Sam Rockwell finally being recognized for their incredible talent.

Seeing Annabella Sciorra brought tears to my eyes - so happy to see her again and anyone who ever suffered from sexual assault could easily see the pain, the anguish as well as the inner strength she mustered in order to stand before the world after what happened to her. Her resolve to stand and fight and attend the awards as a presenter was a highlight of the night.
commenttwo:
The Oscars are irrelevant. Nowadays they are nothing but marketing for sociopolitical position pieces thinly disguised as entertainment and art.

Truly good entertainment that is creative, fun, entertaining, and still often thought-provoking is to be found in films other than the strange little flicks that get the Oscar nod that show at your local movie theater and on cable/streaming television.

Even though I am on the left, I think the reason the right talks so endlessly about Hollywood and the cultural elite is exemplified here. All we are supposed to pursue art and entertainment for, according to the Hollywood cognoscenti. is to wallow in the agony of every group that feels themselves to be aggrieved.

Many people pursue art for art's sake, not to make a political statement.

headline: A Whole Lot Is Riding On This New ‘Wrinkle’
commentone:
When I was growing up, I loved sci-fi and fantasy: His Dark Materials, Redwall, Harry Potter, classics like Dune and 2001 and Foundation and The Illustrated Man ... among many, many others.

Yet when I read A Wrinkle in Time, it never grabbed me. I couldn't get into it, and had the distinct impression that I didn't care for it. This confused me. By all accounts this book is right up my alley, yet there it was: I disliked it instead.

Now, as an adult, I gave it a second try. Maturity and better taste, I reasoned, would allow me to actually appreciate the book.

To my surprise, I had the same reaction!

I intend to go back and read it for a third time, to see what exactly it is that turns me off to the book. For the moment, I am left simply with a fascinating example that all pieces of art, regardless of their greatness, will be disliked by someone at face value. Why?

In any event, best of luck to the movie and all involved!

headline: Angela Merkel is not the ‘leader of the free world’
commentone:
Socio-political power begins and ends with the military. If you have a strong army, you will rule the world indefinitely.
...
Except for the Mongols.
And Alexander the Great.
And Rome.
And Spain.
And Persia.
And England.
And the USSR.
And North Korea.
And ...

Freedom may not be free (if you really want to ensure the U.S.'s indefinite freedom, kids, join the Navy or the Guard), but to imply as this piece does that the "free world" is propped up entirely on military power is ludicrous and dangerously naive. Every nation and empire that has done so has fallen, eventually. We need leaders who understand that balancing military might with other important foreign and domestic policies (anti-corruption policies, strong economic alliances, equality under the law, etc.) is the appropriate and long-term method of ensuring the free world is both powerful, and free.

headline: Can There Be Good Porn?
commentone:
"Can their be good porn?" I ask myself that every time I see ESPN's "Skin Edition;" stumble into random modern art museum exhibits (I once ran into a sculpture in an esteemed art museum where two goats with giant erect penises were tongue kissing) or the nude statues of the ancient Greeks; and ponder the legality of the "how-to" sex books at your local Barnes and Noble.

When does a naked human body or the act of intercourse transform from beautiful, harmonious and necessary, into perverse, obscene, and distasteful?

When is it art? When is it "just a strip club?" When is it criminally coercive? When is it an easy, perhaps even pleasurable way to make money (read: no more or less coercive than any minimum wage 9 to 5)?

Our society is all over the map on the answer to those questions. Does that mean there isn't an answer? Or is the wide variety of opinions the answer?

After I had children, the questions have become even more potent. The knowledge that, someday in the distant future, my daughters could be Playmates or Victoria Secret models, does that alter the conversation from my end?
...
I appreciate the discussion, Stoya. It's one that seems to get pushed to the back burner far too often, which is sad given how important sex is to... well, life.

I'm at the tail-end of the Boomer gen (sometimes known as "Generation Jones" - we were the younger siblings of the Vietnam troops. I have kids who are in the their late 20s. I don't share your feeling of "suspicion" about them. I remember where I was on 9/11 - I had just dropped my kids off at their schools and was headed to work as a brand new social worker in the urban core.

I know what these kids are about. They care about the right things. And now with internet and global live news and the information they have had all their lives, we are not only outpaced but also out-sophisticated about many things.

I agree, let them do it. I know my two will be at the front lines. And I'm not suspicious of them. I'm suspicious of the people in DC, and since this election I have lost all respect I ever had for them. I'm glad the kids weren't taught to fawn over them.

headline: Goodbye, Pay-as-You-Wish
commentone: A great pleasure has been visiting NYC over the years, in different seasons, charting (or wandering) a half day walk all around Manhattan, ending at the Met, where I have paid a dollar to get in, indulged in a big lunch in the cafeteria, and then a sort of ecstatic float through the galleries. I lived in NYC for a couple of years after college and always found the Met to be a refuge: a truly lovely break from the city, or the bad day I was having, or the weather. Since then my visits from other parts of the country, often rural, have been so enriched by a stop at the Met. The feeling that a great collection, a kind of church for the eye and mind, could be available to the people of the world for a few dollars, made it infinitely more valuable. And it helped make NYC the generous, creative world capital that it can be. For art pilgrims, this is a sad day.
commenttwo:

But seriously - $25 a ticket? My family would not be able to afford that. If most people are not paying then set reasonable fees instead of dumping the entire bill on outsiders.

headline: Learning to drive at 62
commentone: The good side of starting to drive at 60 or older is that you can decline giving rides to neighbors, on account of your "lack of experience".  I am 83, started driving at 60, the year my husband died, and (honestly!) do not feel up to giving rides to my neighbor (same age).  Others, more friendly, used to drive her whenever she asked; unfortunately, one died, the other has on-and-off feet problems that prevent him from driving, and the third one is mostly "otherwise engaged".  Note that the township has a very efficient and inexpensive shuttle service for seniors and the disabled, but obviously that  is not as convenient as taking advantage of a neighbor.

headline: Letting  Teenagers  Live
commentone:
For once, I find myself in at least some agreement with Mr. Leonhardt. We do need better rules to protect teen drivers (and the rest of us too). But the problem isn‚Äö√Ñ√¥t just lack of experience, it‚Äö√Ñ√¥s primarily lack of skill combined with underdeveloped judgment. None of the proposed solutions address the lack of skill.

No state currently requires meaningful skills training and the license exams barely test for skills competence. None require demonstration of loss of control avoidance and recovery, which is one of the leading causes of accidents. Properly and safely operating a motor vehicle requires skills training and practice under controlled conditions. Emergency braking, rapid steering changes, and skid control are necessary skills as most drivers will encounter situations requiring at least a couple of those maneuvers multiple times each year.

When conducted by professionals, skills training also helps to develop better judgment. Yes, there is added expense (and time) associated with skills training but it will make a far greater difference in lives saved than just tougher traffic laws and require less, rather than more, police enforcement to get those results.

headline: Make Better Movies Too
commentone: Agree that there has been a reckoning but the column reminds me much of what my youngest daughter would say (she is the same age as the author).  Given all that, my youngest daughter also knows the world is changing and you cannot go back and change the past.  She learned from the past with stories from her great grandmother who was a suffragette, her grandmother who was a rosie the riveter during WWII, and her mother who was the first in her department to get a science PhD.  Movies often reflect the social mores of the times and today is no different and as they say, the times are changing and contrasting what was with what is and what shall be is an important discussion of how we change the attitudes and the types of representation in the movies.
commenttwo:
Anyone who looks to movies as a guide for how valuable they are as a person, as fun and enriching as movies can be, is a fool.

Lindy West looks to movies as a guide for whether or not she is 'ugly' and what value she has as a person.

I will leave the intelligent reader to do the math here.

headline: Mr. Trump’s Destructive Trade War
commentone: Is it possible that someone in the White House, with the intention of lightening the mood, suggested a thumb war and the president misheard and, well, here we are?

headline: Mr. Trump’s Problem With Democracy
commentone:
"Mr. Trump was surely joking about becoming president for life himself."

What makes you think he was joking? This highlights the blindspot that the NYT and other intelligentsia have about the threat presented by Donald Trump and the plutocrats that have taken over our government. You dismissed Trump as a whackjob - which he is - but he is a well-funded and shrewd one, who realized that Americans are fed up with the status quo, and are ripe for exploitation. If you want to know how to defeat Trump and the plutocracy you need to climb down from your dismissive ivory tower and rub elbows with the common folk to begin to understand their problems before you can prescribe solutions.

Donald Trump is a wanna-be dictator, and if given the slightest chance, he will seize it and our democracy for his own purposes.

headline: N.R.A. Says Trump May Retreat on Gun Control
commentone: It goes to show that the people who follow the Trump cult are not drawn by his stands on issues, which change with the breeze, but by familiarity: He was a television personality.  He can say anything, do anything, but like a cult leader, it's all irrelevant to the followers.  He only needs to stand in front of the crowd and claim to be their salvation.  Anything other than that message is not recorded.  Although he didn't use the same term, Trump marveled at his own phenomenon as a cult leader when he noted "I could stand in the middle of 5th Avenue and shoot somebody and I wouldn't lose voters".  Well, by getting bed with the NRA he has indirectly done something very similar, and it is now evident he was right.
commenttwo:
". . . it may have taken the gun rights group only a little over a day to persuade the president to back away from his apparent embrace of gun control"

This scenario clearly demonstrates Trump's weakness more than the NRA's power and influence.

And here, for just a New York minute, I thought our leaders had turned a page and real, honest to goodness change in gun legislation was going to occur. And yet his supporters still believe everything that he promises. The windsock once again blows empty air into the faces of the American public. Thanks for the continuing heartbreak and disappointment Mr. President.

headline: Nakesha’s Demons
commentone:
The Tragedy of severe mental illness in a bright, creative, talented person.

It takes all those attributes I listed above - in an unstable genetic/environmental situation - to produce the type of delusions Nakesha experienced. That and the inability to test reality - to question what‚Äö√Ñ√¥s coming into her mind - vis a vis factual reality.

So tragic! It reminds me of one of the most interesting people I got to know my Freshman year of college - who either transferred or dropped after that year. She was later known to have become delusional and to be living on the street in New Orleans. Some of her delusions related to religious practices.

What a tragedy in this nation that we lack universal healthcare, including expansive mental health services. How many creative individuals could be functioning in our nation - if only they received the type of long term, intensive services these individuals sorely need and could likely benefit from?

Instead, so many remain homeless. Interact with law enforcement in ways that end them up in jail. Prison has become the only alternative to mental health

My heart breaks.... Especially for people with paranoid delusions it is so, so hard to win their trust or get them treatment

care for all too many persons, plagued by severe mental illness, whose behavior draws attention, concern and even fear from members of the public.
commenttwo: As heartbreaking as this is for Nakesha and for those who knew & loved her, I can't help but believe that their care vastly improved her life.

headline: One Last Creamy, Late-Winter Blast of Taste
commentone:
". . . craggy chunks of cauliflower are as likely to be doused in cheese sauce"

" . . . [leeks] roasted with the cauliflower, turning floppy and very sweet ‚Äö√Ñ√Æ sweeter, even than the cauliflower, which softens and crisps at the corners."

Never been a fan of cauliflower nor leeks because of their flavor, but these two suggestions sound just too good to pass up, especially if the cheese sauce masquerades the taste of the cauliflower and the roasting makes the leeks very sweet, Throwing these two items into a cheesy pasta sounds like a home run.

Once again, thank you Ms. Clark for a tempting and inviting spin on a dish that is usually mundane and/or unappreciated.

headline: Plan for Tariffs Creates Divide In Trump Base
commentone:
Our economy is like a giant Jenga tower and Trump just yanked out a plank at random, with no care for how it fits into the overall structure.

When simple minded people elect a champion, it can nothing other than a simple minded one.

headline: Power to the Parents
commentone: On the other hand, my fellow retired boomers are just a demographic blip (albeit a large one) that will merely be an echo within 20 years when over half of us will have passed away.  The real issue is getting the young to vote, vote informed and vote responsibly.  Most of us are old enough to remember when the voting age was lowered to 18 and 50% voted and has not reached that level since then.  The apathy is real.   Why would lowering the voting age do any better?

headline: Putin Says He Has ‘Invincible’ Nuclear Missile
commentone: Putin isn't the first candidate to exploit and interject fear into an election in hopes of winning. Scarring and terrorizing citizens to ensure they will vote for the candidate goes beyond pathetic and alarming.
commenttwo: Let‚Äö√Ñ√¥s see:  How long will Trump ignore this Russian threat too?

headline: Roger Bannister, First Athlete to Break the 4-Minute Mile, Is Dead at 88
commentone:
"Sports Illustrated called him ‚Äö√Ñ√∫among the most private of public men, inexhaustibly polite, cheerfully distant, open and complex.‚Äö√Ñ√π

I don't believe a more honorable nor graceful characterization of anyone, much less an athlete, has even been written that equals this Sports Illustrated single sentence. The attached picture of Sir Bannister at his home in Oxford truly captures his elegant and cheerful demeanor. A true class act in every sense of the word.

I could not help but laugh out loud at Sir Bannister's recollection of his wife's misunderstanding of his accomplishment of running four miles in one minute. Sounds exactly like something I would have mistakenly stated since I have a propensity of getting my words twisted.

headline: Saying a Prayer I Don’t Believe In
commentone:
As I have said before, most of religion is good stuff that we badly need. If we could just reject the literal interpretation of nonsensical, supernatural dogma, and the cynical use of scripture to subjugate women and persecute others, I could support it wholeheartedly. In fact, that is very close to what Unitarian Universalism is: religion without the hypocrisy, lies and injustice. But alas, the Unitarians cannot replace the deep cultural significance that many hundreds of years of Judaism, Catholicism or Islam have for people.

It is great belonging to a community; one having regular group meetings, potluck dinners, engaged in good works and inciting us to be better people. Prayers and fellowship are comforting, we enjoy the beautiful music, and we have someplace to be supported when loved ones die. Ritual is healing and comforting.

Churches are full of people who are really only there because of paragraph #2. They should be honest enough to call out their own leadership when they see their religion used for negative purposes.
commenttwo:
Very beautiful and touching.

I recall a patient of mine, from many years ago, a young woman whose grandmother was dying. She didn‚Äö√Ñ√¥t believe in God, but found herself praying.

Maybe prayer is more for the person praying,

headline: Senate Intelligence Panel Says House G.O.P. Leaked a Senator’s Texts
commentone: I am happy for the leaks.  The media has largely failed in its pursuit of facts about misbehavior by members of government.   Warner‚Äö√Ñ√¥s contacts were legitimate issues to be revealed.
commenttwo: Nunes is more than a partisan hack.  As I recall, he was part of the transition team.  He seems to be doing everything he can to obstruct any investigation; perhaps he's hiding his own wrongdoings.  This whole thing is such a test of our systems because there are so many people in power who aren't using it for the good.  I have been impressed by the way Warner and Burr are working together and, of course, so much rides on Mueller and his team.  I hope there will be congressional hearings so that the nation will hear the evidence, improving the chances of action by Ryan/McConnell.

headline: Silicon Valley Disruption In an Australian School
commentone:
The students in this school will be learning the single most important skill of perhaps the last fifty years, and certainly of the last twenty -- how to produce advertising. It will be like second-nature to them.

I wonder if Ms. Wu has embarked upon a serious reflection concerning what was beneficial in her own education and what should have been done differently, and why. I'm fairly sure she did not suffer under a hundred-year-old model designed to produce a factory worker out of her. Perhaps she did reflect on her own education, but the article omits her thoughts? Instead, it features a soundbite that appears to reflect a woeful ignorance of history, but is sure to scare a few parents into worrying whether their children will be left behind. Like I said, advertising.

I didn't notice any discussion of new methods for teaching foreign languages. Is that a skill that is still an important part of being a true 21st-century global citizen, or is that so yesterday?

headline: State Dept. Holds Funds Aimed to Fight Meddling
commentone: Give Google the money and demand actionable results and I bet that results will follow.

headline: Taxpayers, You’ve Been Scammed
commentone: Even if there were anything to it,the trickledown effect would only work if you were employed - and workers are a shrinking proportion of our citizenry.
commenttwo: Brillant analogy, thank you!

headline: The Danger of Waiting for a Wave
commentone: I'm pinning my hopes on the 11,000 Americans who turn 18 every single day. Their entry into the voting world comes on top of seeing their peers shot to death in their schools, and their voices being shot down by their elected representatives. They aren't going to sit by and take it, and they aren't sitting home watching Fox "News." Between the women and the kids, we've got this. But just to be sure, VOTE.
commenttwo:
We are very close to the same conditions that wrought 1968, and even 1861. There are large contingents on both the left and the right who feel disenfranchised, and depending on how things go with Trump - if he's allowed to remain in office, or he's removed - it might well trigger violence.

The sad irony is that instead of pointing the finger at the other side, the disenfranchised should be united in opposing the plutocracy that has taken advantage of the working and middle class for decades. But as shrewd and powerful as they are, the plutocracy has us fighting among ourselves while they walk away with the spoils.

In the short term, America must restore its democracy and break up the stranglehold by the Republicans on the levers of government. If that fails, there may be no long term.

headline: The Rise of  Dictatorship  Incorporated
commentone:
The problem Mr. Stephens overlooks is a little closer to home. We have an identical axis of evil right here: Trump, Congressional republicans, and Trump supporters. We have our own problems and need to fix those before trying to fix the world.

Trump is Putin, al-Assad, and Kim Jong Un in the making. The cronyism, dysfunction, corruption, and love of power and money here is the same as any one of those corrupt foreign dictatorships.

We have no credibility to try to enforce Pax Americana. These foreign despots all feel emboldened to become even more heinous because they can see America is so badly in disarray as to be non-functional.

Think closer to home, Mr. Stephens. Instead of looking outward for axes of evil, just hold a mirror up to America.
commenttwo: The title of the column led me to believe that it would be an expos‚àö¬© on the Trump/Kushner kleptocracy, which poses a far greater threat to our nation than Iran or Syria.

headline: The Supreme Court’s Power Play Against Labor
commentone:
"...part of a broader special-interest campaign."
Only now, when it is all coming to fruition, is this special-interest campaign clear; a multi-pronged long game. A major part of it all was killing the unions, which will now soon be accomplished. Once the unions die, as we have seen, employers can do with impunity what they will to labor. They can off-shore, outsource, discriminate, suppress wages, fire without cause, eliminate pensions and benefits, and on and on. Because, as we've all been told, there are too many regulations, and employees are lazy, and the cost of our products will go up, and there are not enough qualified employees, etc., etc. All lies, but lies that were bought by a sleepy, gullible public and corrupt leaders.
commenttwo: I guess when it gets bad enough for the light bulb to come on for the beleaguered working class, the workers will have to reinvent the unions from the ground up.

headline: Trump Proclaims Tariffs On Steel and Aluminum, And Stocks Sag in Reply
commentone:
Let's hope this is another of the stable genius's 'run it up the flagpole' stunts wherein queued forces will now jockey for position and the chance to be last to, 'whisper in his ear,' change the mercurial one's mind and position...as has occurred on more than a few occasions.

If not, wonder who Trump will pick as his patsy when the economy reacts and follows Wall Street down the Crapper.
commenttwo:
The U.S. economy, like it or not, is hopelessly entwined in the international economy, with the myriad facets tangled up like a Gordian Knot. Simply dealing with one aspect - steel and aluminum imports - will only make matters worse domestically. There needs to be a holistic approach to significantly reducing the off-shoring of manufacturing and jobs, without wrecking our domestic economy. Like a cancer that has spread to vital organs, if we aren't extremely careful with how we remove it, the "patient", our economy, can die.

Trump, in his typical ham-handed, simplistic, fashion, is trying to solve it by hacking away with a sword instead of a scalpel. Let's hope he realizes his folly before it's too late.

headline: Unknown
commentone: There are unfair trade practices everywhere.  If we paid fair prices for our coffee, it would be $20 for a small bag.  The unfortunate thing about Trump, and most conservatives, is that their idea of fair is what works best for them.  They cannot see outside of their bubble, mostly a construct of fear and a protectionism against a world they don't really understand or care to engage in with an attitude of understanding and friendship.  For what it's worth, the Chinese have bought up most of our debt.  Does this way into his thinking or is it winners and losers only?
commenttwo: The very best of luck to all who may come into contact with this horrendous storm and to all first responders who will no doubt be involved on so many levels. Hope you remain safe, warm, and out of harms way. Take care.

headline: What Motivates Voters More Than Loyalty? Loathing
commentone:
I used to split my ticket and vote for the person, not the party. At this point, I can't see myself voting for a Republican at any level of government ever again. Republicans seem quite proud of their anti-intellectualism, racism, support for unlimited gun rights and desire to enrich the already wealthy.

Republican's support for Trump shows a level of hypocrisy I didn't think possible. The HUGE increase of our deficit and looking the other way as Russian hacks our elections are just two stunning example but there are scores more. I blame FOX and hate radio for much of the polarization. When you broadcast lies all day, every day, they convince the gullible.

I know Republicans who swear President Obama was born in Kenya and is a practicing Muslim. Proof doesn't matter to them. And oh, how they hated the fact that he is African-American. I cannot and will not ever vote Republican again.
commenttwo: Just read the handful of comments (6 at the time of this writing) to see the evidence of Edsall‚Äö√Ñ√¥s point. All of them are essentially some version of ‚Äö√Ñ√∫it‚Äö√Ñ√¥s not us, it‚Äö√Ñ√¥s them.‚Äö√Ñ√π

headline: When Elder Abuse Is Self-Inflicted
commentone: So, the question is, did the court and the Protective Services agency rescue the man and save him, by taking him out of his filthy home, or did they abridge his rights and kidnap him?  In this particular case, I see we are let off the hook somewhat because we can claim the man was "ranting incoherently." Or was he in fact simply outraged and angry?  The fact is, the man chose to live like he did.  There are many people who choose to live in squalor, drink excessively, and neglect to bathe and care for themselves.  And while a few of them might enjoy assisted living once they try it, most simply want to go back to their old filthy life.
commenttwo:
Aging seems to be like having a target painted on your back that it's OK for other people to interfere in how you choose to conduct your life.

Who has the right to judge cleanliness standards, the choice to take medications, or anything else simply because the individual is older? There is a rush to do so, yet the simple things aren't taken care of unless money is handed over - like paying someone to take the garbage can to the curb once a week.

The same arguments could be made for many other scenarios: judging how parents raise their kids, homelessness, mental illness... This article makes it OK to stereotype old people as needing to be monitored and controlled for their own good when we don't do the same for more urgent issues or for the same problems in other age groups.

headline: Whole Foods Gets Primed With the Amazon Treatment
commentone: The issue at my local Whole Foods is the poor level of service when compared to the service at a local small ( 6 store) chain. The lines are brutally slow at WF and no one seems to know or  care   about anything outside their department. Questions are either shrugged off or one waits for a manager who often takes more than 10 minutes ( a long time during a grocery visit) to mosey on up from some hidden office.    The small chain has higher prices relative to the giant chains but manages it lines with an always present front end person so their is almost never a line ( managers jump on registers during busy times), even the guy sweeping the floor knows where every item in the store is and two managers are always present at the front of the store to answer questions. Amazon needs to study places like Illinois' Sunset Foods  and implement their methods to make Whole Foods worth the mark ups.
commenttwo: I've seen brand names virtually disappear from my local Whole Foods in KY.  All store brands now, and the variety of products offered has become far smaller.  Unless there is something I really want (cooked, carry-out), it's not worth the inconvenience of going there anymore.

headline: Wily Trump Aide Nurtures Her Access and Influence
commentone: Let me explain this. The fact that someone is a "woman" does not make us proud or impressed when they run a "winning" campaign. This woman is a fraud. This woman is willingly selling her soul to the devil. This woman is the perfect match for this president, but she is not a winner. Because of her, and her president, we are all losers.
commenttwo: Considering how often Conway put her foot in her mouth, lied, uttered half truths and innuendo  in public, that could also be a reason,
